column2: LEAD: Re ''Shortage of Social Workers?,'' Dec. 7: If there are difficulties attracting students interested in clinical social work, perhaps schools would do well to re-examine their internal structures and possible hidden agendas.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 16 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: The way things are going, Milovan Djilas may yet get to write a book that does not land him in jail. Considered the most prominent Yugoslavian dissident, Mr. Djilas fell into official disgrace in 1953 and has pretty much stayed there.

LEAD: Diane Frances Van Arsdale, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson J. Van Arsdale of Westbury, L.I., and Steven Neal Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Miller of Bellerose, Queens, were married yesterday at the Baptist Church-in-the-Garden in Garden City, L.I. . The Rev. Patrick Morris, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: High-Tech Turmoil

LEAD: THE county's ''motel children'' should not have to travel miles every day from temporary motel quarters back to their home school districts, State Senator MaryB. Goodhue said in annoucing a bill she said she would introduce next week in the State Legislature.

LEAD: We were disappointed and puzzled by Amy Wallace's article on medical education. Through an infuriating use of partial and out-of-context quotes, the article created the absurd impression that Johns Hopkins disdains the humanities and emphasizes only hard-line biomedical curriculums.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Among the ordeals that faced the young French painter who wanted to climb the official ladder in the 19th century none was either more daunting or more decisive than the historical composition contest that was held every year between 1816 and 1863 at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris. Success in that contest was the indespensible preliminary to all the other competitive stages that led in time to the Rome Prize.

LEAD: IT would be a hard job to halt the tide of auto-focusing, single-lens-reflex (SLR) cameras. Never mind that so-called point-and-shoot cameras do the job of making picture-taking easy for most Sunday snapshot photographers. The language being spoken by SLR camera makers these days is not ''quick and simple'' but ''versatile and complex.
LEAD: The latest events in Lebanon demonstrate how easily terrorists can confound national policy and international diplomacy.
LEAD: ''IT was the biggest family I ever belonged to.'' ''It was a village.'' ''It was a complete community; we had everything a working family could need or want.''

LEAD: It was clear that either Thomas W. Manning or Richard C. Williams, both of whom say violence is justified in shaping America to their vision, fired the shots that killed a New Jersey State Trooper, Philip J. Lamonaco, five years ago. During their two-month murder trial, Mr. Manning said he had done it, but prosecutors insisted that Mr.

LEAD: This semester, the second in which John Bajusz has enrolled in both Cornell's College of Enginering and Johnson Graduate School of Management, he takes seven courses that bring some five hours of classes each weekday. He is also in his fourth season as a starter on the basketball team.

LEAD: The stewards at Aqueduct canceled the racing program yesterday, citing the below-zero wind-chill factor early in the morning. Thursday's racing was also canceled by the weather and Friday's program was called off after one race.

LEAD: THE sniffle season being in full flow, it is small wonder that the winter is turning out to be another festival of medicine in many homes. I myself, like any used car, have been in regular attendance for oil change, odd noises in the transmission, creakiness in gear shift and suggestions for getting more mileage with less fuel intake.
LEAD: The Giants. In a low-scoring, close game.

LEAD: ACCORDING to officials in the Justice Department, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d might soon ask the Supreme Court to overturn its 1966 Miranda decision, which requires the police to inform criminal suspects of their legal rights to silence and to counsel before questioning.

LEAD: INVOKING what one conceives to be his Constitutional rights has become a very popular activity. The tobacco companies do it when they feel that Congress might curtail their advertising, motorcyclists do it when they oppose helmet laws, some individuals do it whenever they don't like something, and now, a

LEAD: NOW that Dwight Gooden has pleaded no contest to two felony charges stemming from a fight with the police in Tampa, Fla., the prosecution's file on the case has been made public. According to the file, one of the officers involved in the scuffle with Gooden yelled ''break his arm'' during the altercation last Dec.
LEAD: Overshadowed by the gyrations of the equity market, Treasury notes and bonds traded listlessly last week with a trend toward lower prices and higher yields.

LEAD: All five members of a family died in a fire Saturday that apparently was touched off by a wood-burning heater used since a snowstorm cut off electricity to their mobile home last week, the authorities said. The victims apparently died in their sleep.

LEAD: Phil Esposito, the general manager with the best coaching record in the National Hockey League, will be behind the Rangers' bench at Madison Square Garden again tonight for a game against the Devils because Tom Webster's train from Toronto will not arrive in time.

LEAD: It will be interesting to see how Coach Lou Carnesecca responds to his team's third Big East loss of the season. For the first time in three seasons, St. John's, which rallied from 17 points behind only to drop a 64-63 decision at Syracuse on Saturday, finds itself in something of a life-or-death situation.
LEAD: The cables that support the Williamsburg Bridge are rapidly corroding and money for a daring operation to replace them is being held up in Congress, state transportation officials said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Ivan R. Powell, a designer and illustrator who taught at the Parsons School of Design, died of cancer Saturday at New York University Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Rarely has a Super Bowl team relied on one man as the Denver Broncos did today. The funny thing was, for a half John Elway seemed to be leading them to an upset of the Giants.
LEAD: A Brooklyn man, angered by a dispute with his wife, shot her and their 14-year-old son before fatally shooting himself, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: When Presidents misbehave, defenders look to history for precedent to demonstrate that all White House occupants cut corners or flout the wishes of Congress for brave or expedient reasons. A favorite illustration is Franklin Roosevelt's 1940 swap of 50 old destroyers for the lease of British bases in the West Indies.

LEAD: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and eight unions still without contracts were expected to resume talks today after a weekend of informal discussions that appeared to offer little hope for an immediate settlement to the strike, now in its second week.
LEAD: A Chinese university student was arrested today and charged with passing ''intelligence'' to an American journalist, according to the New China News Agency.

LEAD: When the Rev. H. V. Savage established his Kitchen for the Poor in 1969, he envisioned the free food center in the heart of Toledo's black district as a temporary measure until economic gains took root from civil rights laws and Government antipoverty programs.

LEAD: The illness that hit the stock market Friday and caused a stunning reversal of luck for many investors is likely to take at least a few days to get out of Wall Street's system, market experts believe.

LEAD: A cabdriver was stabbed and left critically injured by the side of the road here Saturday night, the police reported. They said they were searching for a man and a woman suspected of the assault.

LEAD: Maintaining Super Bowl suspense is also a matter for Japanese fans, several million of whom will stay home tonight to watch the game on delayed tape. Because the broadcast begins 10 hours after the final gun, the trick is to get through the day without learning the result. The Tokyo Broadcasting System could have gone live and, in fact, did provide a live closed-circuit hookup Monday morning, local time, at the Tokyo American Club and the Hilton Hotel, where a seat cost $50, breakfast included.
LEAD: A concept that many earth scientists regard as a key to understanding the dynamics of this planet has been challenged at a conference here on volcanoes.

LEAD: Silas Bissell, arrested here last week as a suspect in a 1970 attempt to bomb the University of Washington, said he would rather be in jail than live the life of a fugitive as he has for 17 years.
LEAD: Two brothers were charged yesterday with what the police called the drug-related killings of two men whose bound and gagged bodies were found in a Brooklyn marsh early Saturday.
LEAD: The Foreign Ministry said today that it had asked several African nations to help find 10 French medical workers kidnapped Friday from a refugee camp in Somalia.

LEAD: Yuri Grigorovich, director of the Bolshoi Ballet, said yesterday that he had invited Natalia Makarova and two prominent American ballet directors to Moscow in addition to Mikhail Baryshnikov. He said he hoped that the four would participate in a round-table discussion on the arts and sciences there next month, but added that no official invitations had yet been sent by the Soviet

LEAD: THE soprano Elisabeth Pehlivanian and the violinist George Pehlivanian - of Armenian descent, Lebanese birth and Long Beach, Calif., residence - presented an unusual and richly rewarding program Saturday night at Weill Recital Hall.

LEAD: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue in New York yesterday Joan Renee Fishman and Michael Elliot Salzman, associates at the New York law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, were married by Rabbi Philip M. Weinberger.

LEAD: An air traffic controller said in an interview published Friday that two supervisors at southern California's main radar center failed to report two incidents in which passenger jets passed within a few miles of each other.

LEAD: L.I.R.R. Fights Rust A handful of trains continue to run on the Long Island Rail Road, keeping the tracks polished and checking safety systems. Page B3. Poverty of Blacks Spreads More blacks are living in poverty, a new study says, and they are becoming increasingly concentrated in the nation's largest cities.
LEAD: A ready measure of Canada's thriving auto industry can be taken from the 270-mile section of Highway 401 that links Oshawa, east of Toronto, with the border at Detroit.

LEAD: When Wynn Handman, the director of the American Place Theater, first called Cynthia Heimel, the author of a humorous book on modern social mores called ''Sex Tips for Girls,'' she didn't know who he was and had never even considered writing for the theater.

LEAD: SHOULD we fight the Battle of the Alamo again? John Wayne did it last in 1960; there were films before that, too. Davy Crockett, Jim Bowie and a handful of Texans met Santa Anna. Comes now ''The Alamo: 13 Days to Glory,'' a three-hour movie on NBC. Don't ignore it, however, just because you know how the battle turns out.

LEAD: Just one week ago, the Knicks were brimming with the confidence borne of 8 victories in 12 games and were buoyed by their surprising defeat of the Celtics. Anything was possible. Even the playoffs. Patrick Ewing was playing the best basketball of his professional career. Bill Cartwright was a commanding complement at power forward, a position he was still learning.

LEAD: The White House is in the market for two people who are conversant with economic policy. Alfred H. Kingon, the Cabinet secretary who is also Chief of Staff Donald T. Regan's No. 1 man on economic issues, is leaving to become ambassador to the European Community in Brussels once the Senate approves him for the post.
LEAD: Two anonymous callers reportedly asserted today that an underground Moslem group had carried out the kidnapping of three American teachers and an Indian professor at a university here Saturday.
LEAD: Last year, virtually all of the 20,000 defendants in criminal cases in Washington, D.C., underwent drug tests voluntarily, according to the head of the program, John A. Carver.
LEAD: The Pentagon office in charge of ''Star Wars'' research is tightening the flow of information to the public, according to Government officials and experts outside the Government.

LEAD: An agreement reached on Friday by what is known as the Paris Club to reschedule $870 million of Philippine debt is expected to help the Government of Corazon C. Aquino in other long-stalled debt negotiations, bankers and Government officials said last week.
LEAD: Fans reacting after Giants scored a touchdown in first half as they watched game at The Ritz in New York (NYT/Angel Franco)

LEAD: N.B.A. Super Day in Boston: Kevin McHale scored 30 points, including 14 in a third-period surge, as the Boston Celtics defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 111-96. With their 55th straight victory at Boston Garden over an Eastern Conference rival since a loss to Milwaukee during the 1985 playoffs, the Celtics reached the halfway mark of the season with a 30-11 record, seven games ahead of the 76ers in the Atlantic Division.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods OrdersDecember Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Merchandise Trade BalanceDecember Farm PricesJanuary
LEAD: International

LEAD: Inch for inch, ''The Age of Sultan Suleyman the Magnificent'' is one of the most spectacular exhibitions ever set before the American public. It is also in some ways one of the most demanding. Not only does it deal with folkways remote from our own, but it also asks us to empathize with a great warrior, statesman and administrator who authorized the execution of his sons and grandsons while overseeing the growth of an empire that stretched from Aden to Algiers, from Cairo to the Crimea, and Baghdad to the outskirts of
LEAD: Gerry Mulligan's Concert Jazz Band, which has existed sporadically since 1960, came together this past weekend for a tantalizing three-night appearance at the Blue Note.

LEAD: In secret councils that go on long into the night, leaders of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints are trying to resolve troubles that have erupted here, near a site hallowed in their beliefs.

LEAD: When an expert partnership sits down to play in a major event the players are likely to have hours, or days, of theoretical discussion in the bank. But accidents can happen when they have had little prior conversation about bidding methods.

LEAD: NEW YORKERS had their first glimpse of a fascinating ballet by George Balanchine on Saturday night when a duet from ''Mozart Violin Concerto'' received its New York premiere as part of ''Festival of Dance Stars 1987,'' a program of pas de deux at Brooklyn College. It was a real discovery.

LEAD: The Justice Department today announced that it would sue to block the merger of the Hughes Tool Company and the Baker International Corporation, two of the world's largest oilfield service companies.

LEAD: ''It is simply not fair in the interest of this country for them to stay there and place themselves in jeopardy. They aren't showing any special courage, but are simply offering themselves to be used as pawns against the interests of this country.'' - Representative

LEAD: The Chinese may have taken long strides toward modernization in recent years, but when it comes to the Super Bowl they're four months behind the times. China Central Television, the country's sole network, has bought the rights to show 10 of the National Football League's 1986 regular-season and playoff games on tape, and only yesterday began broadcasting one roughly every other week, in sequence.

LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. returned to profitability in 1986. The Dallas-based company said it earned $29.1 million, or 71 cents a share, for the year in contrast to a loss of $118.7 million in 1985.
LEAD: Houston has emerged as the leading candidate for host of the 1988 Democratic national convention, even though party leaders prefer New Orleans, according to Democrats close to the process.

LEAD: Last year's Super Bowl coaches, Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears and Raymond Berry of the New England Patriots, saw two different games yesterday when the Giants beat the Denver Broncos, 39-20, in Super Bowl XXI.

LEAD: They were better than good and maybe even great. But they were more than that; they were also what every championship team aspires to be. They were resourceful. For it was not always the blowout it now seems because of the lopsided nature of the score. For more than two quarters, it was close, nail-biting close.

LEAD: There was a time when only your hairdresser knew for sure. Not anymore. If you patronize any of the area's leading hair salons, an army of chemists, computer programmers and shrewd marketers may know more about your hair than you thought there was to know in the first place.

LEAD: To many of the 130 million or so Americans who watched it, the Super Bowl was also the Super Bet. The game is by far the biggest betting event of the year, drawing more than $40 million legally in Nevada, Las Vegas, and hundreds of millions illegally in the 49 other states. ''People who bet $25 on a game during the season will be betting $100 on the Super Bowl, and $100 bettors will be betting $500,'' says Tony, an otherwise anonymous recovering compulsive gambler who helps man the hot line (689-7500) for Gamblers Anonymous in New

LEAD: Phil McConkey, the Giants' wide receiver, appeared briefly on television after the Super Bowl game today, handing a gun to a security officer. According to a spokesman for the police, McConkey was returning a policeman's pistol that had fallen.

LEAD: The Cannon Group, once the hottest little film studio in Hollywood, has fallen on hard times. And Yuram Globus has this to say for himself and his cousin Menahem Golan, who run the company: 'Our only crime is that we love cinema. You don't see us at the Polo Lounge, on the tennis court or at parties.

LEAD: THE original black-and-white enemy footage in ''P.O.W. -Americans in Enemy Hands: World War II, Korea and Vietnam'' strongly resembles and confirms the wild battle scenes in the current movie ''Platoon.'' The voices of nine Americans who were prisoners of war are heard tonight at 8 o'clock on Channel 5.
LEAD: Yang Xiaokai's nightmares have returned. When the 36-year-old Chinese national awakens each morning, he often recalls a haunting dream of imprisonment.

LEAD: Brad Benson, the Giants' offensive left tackle, is in his ninth year with the club, longer than all but two of his teammates. This was his best season individually. He was selected as the National Conference player of the week after his performance against Washington Dec. 7 - an uncommon honor for an offensive lineman - and soon afterward was named to his first Pro

LEAD: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday about a contract for Navistar International to supply diesel engines to Ford Motor misstated its expiration date. The contract, which was to end in 1990, was extended for an unspecified time.

LEAD: The dollar's sharp decline since the start of the year has come as a pleasant surprise to corporate treasurers, who have been accustomed to using the foreign exchange markets to finance international transactions and hedge against volatile movements in currency values. Now, if they are lucky, they can play the market for a profit.

LEAD: * Diamond-Star Motors Corp., Bloomington, Ill., the company formed by a joint venture between Chrysler Corp. and Mitsubishi Corp., said Friday it had chosen Automotive Industries as the supplier of its interior trim parts. Terms were not disclosed.

LEAD: Company-paid medical benefits for more than 5,000 retired and active workers of the Kaiser Steel Corporation have been canceled because the company cannot afford them, according to a letter sent to employees.
LEAD: Mark Bavaro after catching touchdown pass. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition won a parliamentary majority today that will permit it to govern West Germany for another four years.
LEAD: One year after her triumphant campaign for office, President Corazon C. Aquino is fighting to defend her presidency against powerful challenges on both the left and the right.

LEAD: At the moment that Raul Allegre's toe touched the ball and the clock began ticking on Super Bowl XXI, Bruce Jagoda popped the cork on a bottle of champagne. ''It's over now,'' said the 39-year-old financial analyst.
LEAD: Bernhardt J. Hurwood, the author of 64 books on a wide variety of subjects, died of cancer Friday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: At the first sign of a cold she takes to her bed and remains there till it subsides. He, on the other hand, goes to the office no matter how hacking the cough, how throbbing the head. She sprains her ankle but keeps her appointments; he throws his back out and cancels everything. He wants chicken soup and conversation during recuperation; she yearns only for isolation and silence.
LEAD: President Reagan has nominated seven people active in the arts for the National Council on the Arts, the advisory body to the National Endowment for the Arts.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: West Germany has yet to decide if it will extradite to the United States a suspected Lebanese hijacker whose detention may have triggered the latest kidnappings in Beirut.
LEAD: Richard M. Karp, 57, executive vice president and co-creative director of Grey Advertising with Richard R. Kiernan since 1979, has been promoted to chief creative officer.
LEAD: A startling jump in murders here is being blamed on a burgeoning drug traffic that has become more profitable - and more violent -than ever.
LEAD: It has been 13 years since the U.C.L.A. Bruins had their 88-game winning streak, the longest in college basketball history, snapped by Notre Dame.

LEAD: Despite recent student demonstrations in China and the ouster of the party head, Hu Yaobang, both of which raise questions about future Government policy, American business remains optimistic about prospects for the continued growth of trade and investment in China.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Larry Speakes has been the main press voice of the White House since the press secretary, James S. Brady, was wounded in the assassination attempt on President Reagan in March 1981. Come Feb. 2, Mr. Speakes will leave the White House to become a vice president for communications at the investment concern Merrill Lynch &

LEAD: The Department of Defense and the White House's Office of Management and Budget seem at odds over raises for senior officers of the armed forces. Next month, unless Congress disapproves, Cabinet officers, sub-Cabinet officials, members of Congress and Federal judges will receive salary increases of up to 16 percent.

LEAD: As predicted here not one month ago with stunning prescience (I never forget the ones I get right), the hot new verb of the year is ''out-compete.'' In his State of the Union address, the President will hustle to get out front of the caravan of competitiveness (h'ray!) that has become the euphemism for the parade of protectionism (boo!).

LEAD: BASKETBALL COLLEGES: Pittsburgh at Syracuse (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 7 P.M.); Michigan State at Northwestern (ESPN, 9 P.M.) HOCKEY DEVILS VS. RANGERS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M. WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.)
LEAD: THE soprano Osceola Davis and the baritone Jorma Hynninen joined forces yesterday afternoon for a distinctive and unusual program of spirituals at St. Peters Lutheran Church.

LEAD: Mingo-Jones Advertising, a black-owned agency that specializes in minority advertising, has been selected from a field of more than 12 similar shops to be the General Motors Corporation's first such agency.

LEAD: THE Juilliard School has long presented public new-music concerts, primarily as part of its students' education but also as an admission-free offering to the New York audience. The concerts used to be rather randomly programmed, but since Joseph W. Polisi became Juilliard's president, and since Joel Sachs took over the concerts, there has been an annual attempt to focus them into a festival entitled '

LEAD: THE issue of one share, one vote is slowly making its way through the Securities and Exchange Commission and it appears that the agency regulating Wall Street will come up with a compromise before the end of March.
LEAD: After watching years of pain threaten his career before it really began, Phil Simms changed his luck today.

LEAD: More than 180 people, mostly police officers, were injured in a night of violence over the weekend in a year-old dispute over Rupert Murdoch's switch to modern printing equipment at his newspapers here and the resulting dismissal of 5,500 workers.

LEAD: The folks at Logo 7, an Indianapolis shirt-screening concern, had a lot riding on the Super Bowl. As the largest N.F.L. licensee, the company had its workers standing by last night ready to turn out T-shirts, jerseys and other garments proclaiming the winners as league champions just as soon as the outcome was clear.
LEAD: The rug merchants speak Russian, but gladly accept personal checks for dollars that they deposit in New York bank accounts.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 26, 1987: Monday American President Co Kennametal Inc Armstrong World Indus Kentucky Utilities Black & Decker Koppers Co Consol Freightways Lubrizol Corp Foster Wheeler NWA Inc Heck's Inc Stone Container Howell Corp Wells Fargo M & E Tr TUESDAY Ball Corp Interstate Pwr Becor Western Inc Interstate Securs Becton Dickinson & Co Johnson Controls Black Hills Corp NUI Corp Borden Inc Newmont Mining Corp CILCORP Inc Norwest Corp Crompton & Knowles Rollins Inc Eaton

LEAD: ''When I realized my parents were older than other kids', I felt embarrassed and angry, that they weren't like the parents on TV,'' said Rich Simon, a Washington psychotherapist whose parents were in their 40's when he was born. ''Because they died fairly young, I became sort of an orphan at a relatively early age.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It has been 30 years since the Giants last won a National Football League championship, and when they finally did it again today, the fans who followed them here to Super Bowl XXI celebrated in the way that only the long-suffering faithful can.

LEAD: A commuter guide that appeared last Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday with an article on the Long Island Rail Road strike incorrectly described the parking fees at Shea Stadium. The price is $2 before 10 A.M. and $3 afterward. In addition, an article and a picture caption Wednesday about the effects of the strike incorrectly described the parking situation at Shea Stadium.

LEAD: Phil McConkey, left, the Giants' wide receiver, leaping to avoid Bronco defenders after making a catch in the fourth quarter. McConkey flipped over and narrowly missed scoring a touchdown, taking the ball to the 1-yard line.

LEAD: Fund raising for the 1988 Presidential campaign will differ markedly from other recent elections because of the lack of an obvious favorite in either party and the increased number of early primaries, according to political strategists and campaign finance experts.

LEAD: From his office at the Long Island Rail Road's headquarters in Jamaica, Queens, Larry Baggerly surveyed what he said was one of the saddest scenes a railroad man could behold. On the tangle of tracks that pass through the line's central station, threads of silvery trains were parked, their running lights burning but their motors dead.

LEAD: For someone who has been following the Giants only two months, Dr. J. Robert Cade was pulling awfully hard for them to win last night. Cade isn't a New Yorker, has no nephew on the team and made no big bet. It's just that he's been getting special delight from the victory ritual in which Harry Carson sneaks up on Coach Bill Parcells and dumps a cooler of Gatorade on his head.

LEAD: Oil specialists in the United States are deeply concerned that the escalation of the Iran-Iraq war could ultimately cause a significant shift in world oil supplies. Such a shift, by its very abruptness, could cause unsettling movements in price.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission have found no antitrust problem in the request by Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, to purchase additional shares of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, officials of the Federal agencies said. Mr. Trump is already Bally's major shareholder, owning 9.9 percent of
LEAD: The Giants won the Super Bowl today, emphatically.

LEAD: It is no secret that the thrift industry is fragmented into the highly profitable and the highly unprofitable. But the Federal Home Loan Bank Board recently released figures that starkly drive the point home.
LEAD: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said H. Weston Clarke Jr. is retiring as senior vice president of personnel on March 31 and will be succeeded by Harold W. Burlingame.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Drafting Committee for Convention Against Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: MOMENTS before the second half of Super Bowl XXI was about to start, the Denver Broncos were holding a 10-9 lead as the Giants hurried out of their locker-room tunnel. Over the public-address system, Frank Sinatra's voice was booming.

LEAD: IN four decades at what they are sure is Washington Heights's oldest business -Sachs Trimming Store, 4232 Broadway, founded 1911 - Charlotte and Bert Cohen have had to accommodate themselves to a number of changes.

LEAD: More than a week after 154 contributors and staff members of The New Yorker wrote a letter to their newly appointed editor asking him to decline the job, their protest continues to preoccupy literary and journalistic circles.

LEAD: Robinson Vargas Levy is a new health-care specialty agency that has opened at 235 Park Avenue South serving Winthrop Pharmaceuticals as agency of record and doing projects for Pfizer Laboratories and J. B. Roerig, a unit of Pfizer Inc.

LEAD: COASTING. By Jonathan Raban. Illustrated with map. 302 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. IN his new book, ''Coasting,'' the English travel writer and novelist Jonathan Raban does just what his title will suggest if you connect it to the silhouette of a sailboat and the map of the British Isles that also appear on the front of the book's dust jacket.

LEAD: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens yesterday denied that he erred in spending eight hours at a luncheon with a reputed organized-crime figure in 1983, saying he was unaware at the time of the man's criminal ties.

LEAD: Dr. Judith Reichman, an obstetrician and gynecologist in private practice in Beverly Hills, Calif., was married yesterday to Gilbert Cates, a film, theater and television director. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

LEAD: Less than a month after becoming chairman of the J. Walter Thompson Company, Joseph W. O'Donnell has been discharged, apparently because of his involvement in discussions with an investment banker about taking the advertising agency's parent company private through a buyout.
LEAD: The latest Washington bumper sticker reflecting, in a historical vein, the Iran-Nicaragua investigations reads: ''Release the Reagan Tapes.''

LEAD: New York City is poised to make a major decision on the future of the Hudson shoreline by choosing from among three distinct plans for a 25-acre site that extends into the river, behind the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 2.6 percent in December from November, but orders for all of 1986 dropped 16 percent compared to 1985, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.
LEAD: Mayor Koch, eyes watering with emotion and the bitter cold, today touched the wall at Auschwitz against which 20,000 people were shot by the Nazis.

LEAD: The USX Corporation is considering the sale of some, if not all, of the businesses that make up its diversified products group as the initial part of its long-awaited restructuring, Wall Street and industry sources believe.
LEAD: TIME Inc. and The New York Times are both going to accept condom advertising, largely because of the health threat of AIDS.

LEAD: MAKING BELIEVE A large exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center gets you close to the ingredients of spectacle, to the very real objects designed to make your mind accept imaginary settings. ''Art Behind the Scenes,'' in the main second-floor gallery of the library, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street, displays 125 objects made by more than 60 artists for theater, movies and opera.

LEAD: A move to prohibit state officials who are lawyers from representing clients before state agencies will be debated at the 110th annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association, which opens tomorrow in Manhattan.

LEAD: The kidnapping of three American teachers in Beirut led today to expressions of resentment against Americans who have remained in Lebanon despite unequivocal warnings from the State Department that they cannot be protected.

LEAD: QUESTION: Baseball's triple crown for hitters goes to the player who leads his league in batting average, home runs and runs batted in. But there's also an unofficial triple crown for pitchers that goes to the one who leads his league in victories, strikeouts and earned run average. Has any team ever had both triple crown winners in the same season?
LEAD: It was a day to stay home or venture out into an unfamiliar New York.

LEAD: Dennis Conner unveiled a new spinnaker today for Stars & Stripes in a practice run for the America's Cup finals. The 12-Meter flew a giant white spinnaker with three rows of pockets along the upper half of the balloon sail. The use of pockets appears to increase the sail area of the spinnaker and give added lift to the sail.

LEAD: NEW YORK is going to have its first sportsman's show since the late Daily Mirror's Coliseum-based event closed for good more than a decade ago, and it may seem incongruous, given the city's tough gun control regulations, that the new event is slanted strongly toward the hunter.
LEAD: Johnston & Murphy, the Nashville-based shoe manufacturer, is taking its account to AC&R Advertising.
LEAD: In theory, all of Indonesia should work like Abu Hasan.

LEAD: The judge in the manslaughter trial stemming from the making of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' has barred prosecutors from introducing a statement by the film's director, John Landis, that he ''didn't care'' about the location of a helicopter on the movie set moments before the helicopter crashed and killed three people.

LEAD: Members of the St. Nicholas Hellenic Orthodox Church, 155 Cedar St., marching down West Street yesterday on way to Hudson River for Epiphany celebration. On this day, the waters are blessed to commemorate the Baptism of Christ in the River Jordan. At right, the Rev. John Romas blessing Bill Kyrkostas, second from left, and Michael Abitabile after they retrieved the cross used in the ceremony from the river.

LEAD: The only drawback with running from Lawrence Taylor, as the Denver Broncos learned today, was that it led them directly into the path of Carl Banks. The Broncos and the rest of the teams in the National Football League, will now have nearly six months to devise a method of avoiding both in the future.

LEAD: World Trade Bank N.A. has named John F. King chairman and chief executive of the Los Angeles-based merchant and commercial banking organization. LEAD: Rich Karlis's eyes were red from tears. There were no answers in his eyes, only questions about why he had failed on two critical field-goal attempts in the first half of the Super Bowl.
LEAD: Ben-Zion, a poet, writer, painter and sculptor, died after a heart attack Friday in his home in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. He was 90 years old.
LEAD: Jim Calhoun, coach of the University of Connecticut's basketball team, said today that three players have been declared ineligible because of poor academic performance.

LEAD: WALL STREET savants are fond of saying that small investors usually come into a bull market too late, sell too late and generally exhibit poor timing. If this is so, most small investors should have missed the extraordinary rise in the market this year and then been whipsawed by last Friday's roller-coaster market performance.

LEAD: The new American Ambassador to Mexico plans to substantially revamp United States participation in a program with the Mexican Government to combat narcotics production, according to his advisers.

LEAD: A quiet neighbor of South Africa, Botswana is in many ways a model of what the United States would like to see in Africa: a genuine democracy, non-racial, devoted to free enterprise. Its politics earn that prized American adjective, moderate.

LEAD: With the average age of marriage increasing and growing numbers of women postponing childbearing to pursue careers, women age 35 and older gave birth to 224,000 babies in 1984, a 36 percent increase since 1980, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. Yet, contrary to the widespread perception of late childbearing as a recent yuppie phenomenon, older parents were actually more common in earlier decades.

LEAD: The judge presiding over the case involving charges of child molestation at a pre-school chastised the prosecution Friday for surprising a witness, who is a former prosecutor in the case, with a tape recording without first notifying the defense.
LEAD: Four Mets charged in July after an incident at a Houston nightclub are scheduled to appear in court Monday.

LEAD: Nina Beilina's violin recital at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night was - either by design or accident - rarely devoted to the beauty of the instrument or the virtues of virtuosity. Miss Beilina's program was largely somber, often dense with complexity, even grim.

LEAD: Students at Princeton University will pay 5.9 percent more in fees to attend the Ivy League school next year, according to the Board of Trustees. Under the increase, announced after a board meeting Saturday, students will pay an average of $16,918 next year, a $938 increase, Princeton officials said.

LEAD: Barely two years ago, while artists, poets and musicians lent their talents to promote the new cause, Colombians were enthusiastically embracing the idea that a ''peace process'' could end decades of political violence here.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''The door is always open'' to a settlement in the continuing dispute between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese and New York City over foster-care programs, John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday. But he said the archdiocese would not compromise in its opposition to providing family-planning information to youngsters in the program.

LEAD: Buried deep inside a new Air Force complex at the edge of the Rockies here is a steel-encased room that the Pentagon once envisioned as its own version of Mission Control in Houston, a place for the military to command classified flights of the space shuttle.

LEAD: Ewa Demarczyk, who is renowned in her homeland as ''The Black Angel of Polish Song,'' is one of the few international popular singers with the vocal resources, theatrical command and musical discrimination to transcend, at least partially, the language barrier that makes so many European performers inaccessible to American audiences.

LEAD: A little boy's truck is a toy, not a harbinger of a career in the trucking industry. A little girl's doll is not simply a doll but a symbol of the baby she's expected to have some day. Small wonder, therefore, that women are so often devastated when they find themselves infertile. Men may wish just as fervently to be fathers but women have been programmed for parenthood, socially as well as physiologically, almost since birth.

LEAD: The Koch administration, in a move that has come under criticism from civil-liberties groups, is planning to begin asking people arrested on felony charges to undergo drug tests voluntarily before their first court appearance or arraignment.
LEAD: Mayor Harold Washington and former Mayor Jane M. Byrne, his opponent in the Democratic mayoral primary Feb. 24, are running neck-and-neck, according to a new poll.

LEAD: The confirmed death toll in last Thursday's clash between leftist demonstrators and security forces rose to 18 today. At the same time, a leader of a major leftist organization softened its criticism of President Corazon C. Aquino.

LEAD: Wreckage of the Tulip Bowling Alley in Floral Park after structure was destroyed in a series of explosions and fire. Firefighters responding to a report of an odor of natural gas arrived shortly before an explosion blew out front of building. They were able to rescue three residents in an apartment in the rear before other explosions occurred.
LEAD: NEW dance troupes seem to be sprouting up constantly in France nowadays, and inevitably, not all of them can be top-flight. Nor do they all have the same purpose.

LEAD: In March 1983 an American company won an order to sell an advanced medical spectrometer to Eastern Europe but had to wait 910 days for an export license. The Pentagon feared, needlessly, that one computer chip and hard disk drive in the machine might be of military help to the Russians.
LEAD: The real estate would seem to be some of the most desirable in California: a 432-acre island, just 20 miles north of San Francisco, overlooking the San Pablo and San Francisco Bays.

LEAD: Jim Burt with his son, Jim Jr., after the game. (NYT)
LEAD: About 117,000 engineers began a nationwide strike today that could halt repairs to most of Britain's telephone and data services, officials said.
LEAD: HE came out waving the white flag that has become his trademark - not the white flag of surrender but the white flag of incitement.

LEAD: Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo called on India today to enter into immediate negotiations to defuse tensions rising from the massing of troops in each country on their mutual border. He declared that Pakistan had no aggressive intentions toward India.

LEAD: The snow was so heavy Thursday that many protesters had difficulty finding the rally, wandering across the Ellipse until they finally saw, off on the white horizon, a small cluster of placards and banners.

LEAD: The surge in the Dow Jones industrial average since the beginning of the year - not counting Friday's wild gyrations - has been accompanied by a decline in the value of the dollar. There is, many experts believe, a strong link between the two.

LEAD: If he had his way, the Count of Paris, whose full name is Henri Robert Ferdinand Marie Louis-Philippe d'Orleans, the head of the royal House of France and a direct descendant of such luminaries as Louis XIV, would reign in France as a modern constitutional monarch called Henri VI.

LEAD: Dr. Vincent Ellis McKelvey, an earth scientist who spent 46 years with the United States Geological Survey, seven of them as its director, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal paralysis, Friday at his home in St. Cloud, Fla. He was 70 years old.
LEAD: The question is beginning to seem as old as the St. Patrick's Day Parade itself: When will a woman be elected grand marshal?
LEAD: Phil Simms and Brad Benson celebrate a touchdown. (AP)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Paul Azinger, a 27-year-old Floridian who has been threatening to win on the PGA Tour for many months, finally got his first tour victory today, capturing the 52d Phoenix Open. He was able to edge Hal Sutton by a single shot when Sutton, the 1986 Phoenix Open winner, missed a 5-foot putt for par on the last hole.
LEAD: ''Must be 110 degrees in there,'' said Sean Landeta, as he made his way out of the narrow box that was the Giants' locker room today in the Rose Bowl.

LEAD: Aaronson, Bartolone, Pearlman Advertising, which resulted from the Jan. 1 merger of AMS Advertising and Shapiro, Bartolone & Budrow, has been selected by Fremarques Ltd. to handle the United States introduction of The Antiquary, a 12-year-old Scotch whisky from J&W Hardie, a subsidiary of the Guinness Beverage Group.

LEAD: The New York Pops - the assembly of freelance players that Skitch Henderson presents each year at Carnegie Hall - opened its season Friday evening with a first half devoted to music for the stage and a second half devoted to one of the stage's most successful composers, Marvin Hamlisch. The first segment, purely orchestral, came from shows by Offenbach (''Orpheus in the Underworld''), Bizet (''Carmen'') and Weill (''The Threepenny Opera'').

LEAD: The United States and its biggest economic allies are negotiating arrangements for a meeting to discuss the dollar and the ways their economic policies affect it, European and Japanese officials said today.
LEAD: Reggie Williams's 3-point field goal with 28 seconds remaining today highlighted a 13-1 run that gave Georgetown a 74-71 victory over previously unbeaten DePaul.

LEAD: WHEN ''Chariots of Fire'' won a bagful of Oscars five years ago, the scriptwriter, Colin Welland, received his award with the hyperbolic boast that ''The Brits are coming.'' The British film industry may not be living up to that claim, but the subject of that particular movie, British track running, is going from strong to stronger.
LEAD: Robert Van Buren, known as the Hungry Banker, is getting ready to swallow Continental Bancorp Inc. of Philadelphia and expand into Pennsylvania from New Jersey.
LEAD: The ''Your Money'' column in Business Day on Jan. 10, about Individual Retirement Accounts, misstated conditions for their tax deductibility.
LEAD: A front-page article Saturday about a guilty plea by Mark W. Hoffman in two bombing deaths in Utah in 1985 misidentified the prosecutor. He was Robert Stott, not Robert Scott.

LEAD: T. Boone Pickens is not saying much about it, but when the last remnants of his Mesa Petroleum Company are transferred in early February to its successor, Mesa Limited Partners, it will open a door for the Texas oilman to pursue corporate takeovers outside the energy business.
LEAD: A day after this all-white community was crowded with up to 25,000 marchers demanding racial tolerance, ministers here complained today that Cumming had been unfairly characterized as racist.

LEAD: A Presidential election offers a golden opportunity for issue-oriented special interest groups. Such a group can press candidates to take a position on its key issue in the nominating competition and in the general election. If both finalists endorse the group's position - say, more national parks or no compulsory drug testing - favorable publicity results, and something might actually happen in the next Administration.

LEAD: Treasury auctions this week are limited to the regular weekly sale of three-month and six-month bills, but government securities dealers are looking ahead to a heavy supply of notes and bonds next week.

LEAD: Q.How do cats retract their claws? A.Cats retract and extend their claws by using two tendons, one above and one below the claw's center of rotation. The claw is retracted when tension is applied to the extensor tendon above the center of rotation. This moves the claw upward and backward. When tension is applied below the center of rotation through the flexor tendon, the claw is extended.

LEAD: WHEN AT-class computers were introduced in August 1984, each came equipped with a battery-powered clock and calendar. Clock-calendars are a dandy thing for people who hate to type in the time and date each time they create or update a file. Besides, some of us rarely know what time or day it is. Even when the computer's power is switched off, the clock-calendar keeps track of the real time and date.

LEAD: ''A SONG about racism with jazz piano soloing is certainly not your obvious hit,'' the pianist-songwriter-singer Bruce Hornsby said a few days ago. ''I don't think it's commercial at all.'' But that song, ''The Way It Is,'' moved steadily up the pop charts to No. 1 after its release last September, and it has made Bruce Hornsby and the Range one of the leading new bands to emerge in 1986, selling more than 1.7 million copies of their first album, also titled ''The Way It Is'' (RCA).

LEAD: A Taste of Spring Is it too soon to think spring? Not when shad and shad roe have arrived in town. The shad fillets and pairs of shad roe are available at some of the fish markets that command higher prices. (At wholesale, the fish are selling for around $4 a pound, a price that may drop as the season progresses.) Citarella, 2135 Broadway (75th Street) has shad fillets for $6.95 a pound and the roes for $6.95 a pair.

Karl Lagerfeld tried so hard to express the new spirit at Chanel that he ended up making styles better suited to the theater than to real life.

LEAD: Antone Atallah, a former Foreign Minister and a Member of Parliament, died today, his family said. He was 89 years old. Mr. Atallah, born in Jerusalem of a Greek Orthodox family, was Jordan's Foreign Minister in 1964-65 and in 1970.

Codes in many communities require that there be at least three feet between the stove and the nearest flammable materials.

LEAD: WITH the advent of central heating in the mid-19th century, cast iron registers and grilles were used as a way to distribute heat in a home. Installed in walls, ceilings and floors, the grilles enabled hot air, created by the basement furnace, to circulate from room to room. Now these registers and grilles are being revived, largely by those using wood stoves.

LEAD: Shavod Jones, 15 years old, convicted of shooting Officer Steven McDonald in Central Park last July 12, was sentenced yesterday to three and one-third to ten years in prison.

LEAD: A Federal judge rejected a request by the Diamond Shamrock Corporation to block a $300 million stock tender offer by a group headed by T. Boone Pickens Jr., the Texas oilman. Federal District Judge Jerry Buchmeyer said he would not grant a preliminary injunction because the Pickens group had not violated Federal securities laws.

LEAD: THE usual animated pace of Chinatown intensifies to a dizzying pace this weekend as the new year is welcomed with spirited toasts and staggering feasts. Some Chinatown restaurants offer special prix-fixe banquets during the holidays; others feature traditional dishes ripe with symbolism: chicken brings good fortune, egg rolls portend the arrival of spring, egg dumplings signify golden ingots, round meatballs connote family togetherness.

LEAD: ANYONE who enjoyed Pilobolus - once known as Pilobolus Dance Theater - at its very beginnings will always have a soft spot for the company. There are times, however, when the group might reciprocate the feeling and make things less uncomfortable for its audience.

LEAD: Don Cherry and Nana Vasconcelos, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (662-2133). If anyone can use the vast, reverberant space within the cathedral to improve their music, it might be the improvising duo of Don Cherry and Nana Vasconcelos. Mr. Cherry made groundbreaking records in the 1960's as the puckish trumpeter in Ornette Coleman's jazz quartets.

LEAD: ''I WANTED a bowl for the dining-room table,'' Jill R. Fine said, recalling how she and her husband, M. Austin Fine, began their 25-year pursuit of Americana. Most of the couple's collection - 338 ceramics, paintings, pieces of furniture, quilts and weathervanes -is to be auctioned today at 10:15 A.M.

LEAD: Billy Olson, the pole-vaulter whose last-minute withdrawal from tonight's Wanamaker Millrose Games had been blamed on ''despondency'' over his failure to clear the bar in his first two meets this year, was being portrayed yesterday not as an emotional weakling. He was being portrayed as a hero who had been competing and setting world records while silently suffering from a chronic and debilitating sinus infection that has finally forced him to the sideline.

But in promising to shake up the party, the repository of real power, he moved into an area that has frustrated reform-minded leaders in the past.

LEAD: IN many ways ''Mes Petites Amoureuses,'' Jean Eustache's 1974 French film opening today at the Public, looks as if it had been meant to answer anyone who'd been less than enchanted by the director's ''Mother and the Whore,'' one of the more antagonizing films presented at the 1973 New York Film Festival.

LEAD: Horse-players who place their bets with Sam this winter are not patronizing a local bookie, but getting a glimpse at the future of parimutuel wagering. Sam is the acronym for Screen Activated Machines, customer-operated electronic ticket dispensers, nine of which have been installed at Hialeah Park.

LEAD: The President had two scripts for his State of the Union Message Tuesday night - and delivered the wrong one. The speech he delivered in person billowed with stale wind. His written message crackles with energy, spelling out how to rebuild America's competitive pre-eminence.
LEAD: A worldwide AIDS epidemic will become so serious that it will dwarf such earlier medical disasters as the Black Plague, smallpox and typhoid, the nation's top health official said today.

LEAD: A biography of J. D. Salinger was blocked yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan that said the book unfairly used Mr. Salinger's unpublished letters.

LEAD: THE current 50-year retrospective of works on paper by Jack Tworkov at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery, 429 West Broadway, at Prince Street, is an exhibition that reveals itself slowly and gently. But it turns out in the end to have more strength, and more variety, than many a show that tries to knock us out before we even get inside the door.

LEAD: One hardly needs an excuse to celebrate Franz Schubert, but since the composer would have been 190 years old tomorrow, this seems as good a time as any for a party. And that's just what's in store tomorrow at the Symphony Space, which will commemorate the birthday with a 12-hour free concert entitled ''Wall-to-Wall Schubert,'' scheduled to last from 11 in the morning until 11 at night.

LEAD: The trial centering on ''The Bell Jar,'' a 1979 film of Sylvia Plath's novel, ended here today in Federal District Court when both sides agreed to a judgment that Dr. Jane V. Anderson, a 55-year-old psychiatrist, was unintentionally defamed by the movie.

Mr. Baker is still trying to decide whether he would rather be leading that parade in 1988 or watching it from his eighth-floor window.

LEAD: THE Netherlands is now getting special attention by way of two related museum exhibitions. The one at the Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, is a selection of 16th-century drawings, most of which are making their first appearance in the United States, and it comes with a plump catalogue. A joint effort by the library and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, where it first materialized, the show musters about 120 works, including eight by Pieter Bruegel the Elder (about 1525 to 1569).

LEAD: Impellitteri Dies at 86 Vincent R. Impellitteri, Mayor of New York from 1950 to 1953, died in a Bridgeport, Conn., hospital. He was 86 years old. LEAD: Friday A NEW OPERA Over the centuries, the twists and turns of love have been a favorite subject of opera singers. This weekend will be no exception when ''All's Well That Ends Well'' is performed as a two-act opera at the Marymount Manhattan Theater under the auspices of Dell'Arte Inc., an arts organization.

LEAD: IN ''Scene of the Crime,'' Catherine Deneuve plays a small-town bourgeoise mother, separated from her husband and devoted to her son, whose external passivity masks a deep-seated thirst for action, passion and even violence.

LEAD: ''Opera do Malandro'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival under the title ''Malandro.'' Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 27, 1986. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, Broadway and 66th Street.

LEAD: On Jan. 15, arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union resumed in Geneva. That event was greeted with satisfaction in most quarters around the world. The outstanding exception is here in the United States, where a significant body of opinion on the right views arms control as a snare and a delusion.

LEAD: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York proposed yesterday a revamping of the financial system that would eliminate many distinctions among banks, securities firms and insurance companies.

LEAD: A $150 million tax-exempt financing by the Illinois Development Finance Authority on behalf of the Illinois Power Company was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: The United States, tipped off by the Manila Government, foiled a plan Wednesday by Ferdinand E. Marcos to return to the Philippines from Hawaii to rally his supporters in the wake of an apparent coup attempt.

LEAD: For parents who want to get a jump on summer-camp possibilities for youngsters with special needs, the third Special Camp Fair will be held on Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street. Representatives from 100 summer camps will be on hand to provide information about sleep-away and day camps that specialize in programs for children with physical or learning disabilities.

LEAD: The setting was in Maputo, Mozambique. It is summer and the flame trees were in gaudy blossom along the broad, grass-verged avenues where well-to-do Portuguese lived when this was a colonial capital called Lourenco Marques.

LEAD: A report on the Iran-contra affair made public today by the Senate Intelligence Committee portrays Reagan Administration officials as regularly deceiving one another, as well as Congress, about major elements of the operation.
LEAD: The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration today rejected a proposal that widespread resumption of in-flight holding patterns be resumed to ease airline departure delays.

LEAD: Continental and Eastern Airlines said yesterday that they would cut their lowest fares by as much as 40 percent on nearly all domestic flights beginning Sunday. Passengers must buy the tickets when they reserve seats, and no refunds, exchanges or transfers to other people will be allowed.

LEAD: Silas (Trim) Bissell, a captured fugitive who was once a member of the radical Weatherman organization and eluded Federal agents for 17 years, apparently by living as a ''model citizen,'' may be released on bond in the next few days, his lawyer said today.
LEAD: Business leaders here today promised 75 jobs to students graduating from local public high schools this year. Eventually, they intend to guarantee a job for virtually every graduate.
LEAD: Interest rates ended little changed yesterday in a quiet but nervous bond market that continued to take its cue from trends in the currency market and prospects for America's trade balance.

LEAD: The Bowery Savings Bank said yesterday that it was severing its relationship with Chargit Inc., the processor of Mastercard and Visa transactions that filed for protection last month under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code.

LEAD: The Islanders traveled to Washington for tonight's game against the Capitals with neither their best scorer, Mike Bossy, nor half of their goaltending team, Kelly Hrudey. Bossy, who will miss his sixth and seventh consecutive games this weekend because of a strained back, may return next week when the team travels to western Canada for three games.

LEAD: The Mets issued the surest sign of seasonal cheer yesterday when they invited six of their farmhands to spring training, which opens when pitchers and catchers report to St. Petersburg, Fla., Feb. 20.

LEAD: Archbishop Pio Laghi, the Vatican's Ambassador to the United States, has defended his handling of the disciplining of Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle, saying that much of the criticism the episode unleashed stemmed from the Vatican's desire to handle the matter discreetly.
LEAD: Charles J. Haughey, the frayed but durable ''Boss'' of Irish politics who descends on precincts in his bright green helicopter, today began his campaign to become Prime Minister a third time.

The Giants denied Atlanta permission, though the Falcons have been in contact with Parcells's attorney, one report said.

LEAD: Politicians are entitled to a certain quota of cynicism. Senator Bob Dole exceeded his by denouncing Secretary of State George Shultz's meeting with Oliver Tambo, the head of the African National Congress. Mr. Dole, a probable candidate for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, was perhaps less concerned with terrorism, as he claimed, than with currying favor with his party's right wing.

LEAD: Martha Clarke's ''Hunger Artist'' will begin previews next Thursday at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street. LEAD: China has signed its first contract to launch a foreign satellite. The official New China News Agency said the contract had been signed by Wu Keli, vice president of the China Great Wall Industrial Corporation, and Henry A. Schwartz, chairman of the board of Terasat Inc. of Houston. The communications satellite is expected to be launched in 1988.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 378 money market mutual funds decreased $554.6 million, to $233.88 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $294.7 million, to $65.28 billion. Assets of the 195 general purpose funds were down $449.4 million, to $61.96 billion.

LEAD: Those who follow the early-morning telecasts on ESPN of the America's Cup races will have to listen to a new vocabulary of sailing terms while fighting off sleepiness. Here is a glossary of some of the terms likely to be used. Aft: Toward the back of the boat. Beat: To sail upwind. Bow: The front of the boat.

LEAD: There are two schools of thought about the jump raise of partner's major opening. Modern tournament players favor the limit treatment, showing the equivalent of about 11 high-card points and inviting game. This leaves them with a problem with slightly stronger hands and it usually is solved by giving two no-trump or three no-trump a conventional meaning.

LEAD: Skiing Hess Clinches Two Golds: In Crans-Montana, Switzerland, yesterday, Erika Hess of Switzerland clinched her third consecutive gold medal in the combined and record fifth gold over all with a controlled but swift downhill run at the world Alpine championships. LEAD: The Honda Motor Company has bought a supercomputer from Cray Research Inc. for $7 million, the seventh Japanese company to do so. These high-speed computers, capable of extraordinarily complex calculations, have been the focus of trade talks this week between the United States and Japan. Because they are so expensive, even a few sales may help trim Japan's trade surplus with the United States.

LEAD: Trevor Berbick, the former World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, received at most $700,000 of his $2.1 million purse to fight Mike Tyson, with $1 million of the money going to the promoter Don King and his son, Carl, Nevada boxing regulators say. LEAD: OF OUR $173 billion trade deficit in 1986, Japan alone accounted for more than one-third - almost $60 billion, up from just $12 billion in 1980. Of that, more than half was due to automobiles. The arithmetic is compelling. You cannot lower the trade deficit unless you address the automotive component.

LEAD: New York City fire officials said yesterday that no major violations had been found in an examination of fire suppression systems at a huge petroleum-storage facility on Staten Island where renovation work was said to have been facilitated by bribes to fire inspectors.
LEAD: IT took six years and $65,000, but a statue of the late Gov. Ella T. Grasso is to be dedicated at the State Capitol Thursday, on the sixth anniversary of her death.

LEAD: Imposing a 55 miles per hour speed limit on a Grand Prix might seem comical, but the concept has effectively been the policy of the American Contract Bridge League for many years. Players in major national championships have been barred from using scientific bidding ideas just in case they happen to confuse an inexperienced opponent.
LEAD: A Chinese student educated in the United States has been identified by his wife as one of the demonstrators detained in China's crackdown on political dissent.

LEAD: Even before ABC's mini-series ''Amerika'' had begun production, powerful foes were trying to keep it off the air. In 1985, the Kremlin warned ABC's Moscow bureau of possible reprisals if the show ran.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hildreth L. Stong of Tiburon, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Snow Stong to John Shaw Cassidy, the son of Margaret S. Cassidy of South Bend, Ind., and the late John A. Cassidy.

LEAD: An article about abortion Jan. 22 by Dr. Warren M. Hern stated that Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, had introduced a constitutional amendment concerning reproductive rights. Mr. Packwood has not offered such an amendment.

LEAD: THURSDAY'S assemblage of music by the New Music Consort at Weill Recital Hall seemed touched by a variety of influencing hands, yet all these pieces followed the serious steadfastness of purpose that has marked mainstream 20th-century composition.

LEAD: SITTING in his four-room New York City apartment, in the dining room that has long served as his office, Robert Ferguson does not look like a man with the power to create stock market gyrations like the 100-point swing in the Dow Jones industrial average one day late last month. Yet some think he has such power.
LEAD: When R. Max Peterson first joined the Forest Service in 1949, the prevailing image of the service in the mind of the public was largely inseparable from that of its icon, Smokey Bear.

LEAD: For nearly four decades, the Council on Foundations, based in Washington, has been the big umbrella for philanthropic nonprofit organizations, lobbying for some 900 affliated groups and serving as a clearinghouse for information.

LEAD: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke filled three cabinet-level positions last week, promoting each official from within the Westchester government, and issued a ''wish list'' of 76 specific programs that he said he hoped the State Legislature would approve.

LEAD: British gardeners have been mucking about in their soil, more or less continually, since Roman invaders showed how easy it was to clip boxwood shrubs into peculiar-looking blobs. So we American gardeners must be forgiven our awe of this landscape, which is littered with naturalistic parklands, structured knots and mazes, gaudy arabesque parterres and flowery herbaceous borders.

LEAD: IF someone could ask for more trees on East Ninth Street, Joanne Schultz and some friends figured, they could also ask Community Board 3 in Manhattan to support a negotiated peace in Nicaragua. It worked, and in 1985 the Lower East Side, a neighborhood that encompasses the Bowery's skid row, the cutting edge of avant-garde art and a large Puerto Rican and Asian population, became a sister city to Barrio Nueva York, a community of 1,000 in Bluefields,

LEAD: Under the best conditions, logging is a hazardous way to make a living. But these days many Maine logging concerns are taking additional risks by not carrying workers' compensation insurance, which pays for medical care and provides workers a portion of their wages while they recover from injuries received on the job.
LEAD: Residents of a new condominium complex on Baltic Road in Torrington, Conn., could contend with some surprising elements in the warmer months, like shanked five-iron shots.

LEAD: PAGANS AND CHRISTIANS By Robin Lane Fox. Maps. 799 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

LEAD: In an expanded new approach to performing basic research in the United States, the Reagan Administration is sponsoring the development of a set of science and technology centers at universities to spur industrial and technical innovation.
LEAD: ITS facade bears credos vowing enlightenment through education. And inside the University Club, men are fighting to repel invaders.

LEAD: TOM BINNS, a British jewelry designer, makes pins that speak for themselves. ''This is a fashion accessory,'' one says in gold-plated capital letters. The pins will be available in March at the Bartsch boutique, 456A West Broadway, near Houston Street.

LEAD: WHEN the stock market seesaws violently, as it has done lately, individuals often find themselves on the wrong end of the swing. ''Most people react after the fact,'' said Glenn R. Dubin of Dubin & Swieca, a New York money management firm in partnership with E. F. Hutton & Company. ''If they see on the cover of Time magazine that the market is going up, they buy, and when there's a correction, they panic and sell.

LEAD: Those who mired America in the Iran-contra arms affair deceived the public, Congress, each other and themselves. That much is established by the Senate Intelligence Committee's new report. Judging from the roseate White House reaction, the self-deception continues. The President is pleased that the report ''is consistent with'' his claim that the Iran deal was a statesmanlike initiative ''from its inception'' and confirms his unawareness that munitions deal profits were diverted to the

LEAD: The marriage of Nancy Donner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Donner of New York, to Gary B. Martin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Martin of Baltimore, took place last evening at the Tavern on the Green in New York. Rabbi Mark Loeb officiated.

LEAD: WHY ISRAEL? IN SEVEN YEARS of reporting from the Middle East, there is no question I have faced more frequently or contemplated more often than this: Why are so many people fascinated with Israel? Or, to put it another way, why is Israel so often the focus of news?

LEAD: Skiing Swiss Sweep Downhill: Peter Mueller, taking risks on the tricky Nationale course, upset Pirmin Zurbriggen, the defending champion, and led a Swiss sweep of the medals at the world Alpine championships at Crans-Montana yesterday. It was the first major downhill title for Mueller, a 29-year-old veteran of the World Cup circuit.

LEAD: One Flyer flipped an opposing player on his back. Another Flyer sent a player sprawling with one punch. This was only the between-periods highlight film at the Spectrum, and the strategy worked perfectly. On tape, the Flyers towered over everyone.
LEAD: A senior Pentagon official today called suggestions that the world could some day be free of nuclear weapons an absurd folly. President Reagan has often said a nuclear-free world is his goal.

LEAD: THE Rova Saxophone Quartet's favorite sound is a tangled, writhing, pulsating lump of noise - one that might involve repeated phrases, improvised lines, trills, raucous honks or a tightly packed combination of all four. The group writes and plays chamber music laced with improvisation, cross-referencing Stravinsky, Satie, Albert Ayler, Steve Reich and James Brown's horn section.

LEAD: Annmarie Prine and Matthew M. Neumeier, an associate at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, were married yesterday in Novi, Mich.heheevev. Mark ANeNe meier, the brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Cross.

LEAD: I do not think that CBS News has to apologize for itself or to search for itself. Dan Rather - ''the bulldog reporter,'' as you call him -has the right instincts to keep CBS News in the proud tradition of Murrow and Cronkite. Anyone who survived Vietnam, Afghanistan and the 1968 Democratic National
LEAD: THE sun is high enough by 7 to light the wings of flying gulls as they glide over the flats left by the ebbing tide.

LEAD: THE Reagan Administration is sharply divided over proposals to provide health insurance to the elderly for catastrophic illness. On Capitol Hill there is much more agreement. Without waiting for President Reagan to submit a detailed proposal, members of Congress from both parties rushed last week to endorse the expansion of Medicare, the

LEAD: LAST week, Japan announced that it would extend the Voluntary Restraint Agreement limiting Japanese car exports to the United States to 2.3 million units. However, with the backing of the Big Three car makers and the United Auto Workers, the Democratic-controlled Congress is under strong pressure to legislate even tighter curbs.

LEAD: A TRENCH with a concrete roof stretches 3,000 feet into the scrubland around the N-Reactor on the Hanford nuclear reservation in Richland, Wash. In a major accident, water from the Columbia River would be pumped through the core and into the trench. Small amounts of radioactive water are dumped there routinely.

LEAD: The House and the Senate both voted last week to provide an immediate $50 million to feed and shelter the homeless. But the Senate put the House on the spot: It added on an amendment to block a pay raise for top Federal officials, including members of Congress.
LEAD: The Calgary Flames fell behind by two goals but stormed back with four consecutive goals to beat the Devils, 5-3, tonight.

LEAD: Eleven people were slightly injured today when two gondola cars fell from a cable at Mt. Snow Ski Area and others stacked up against a lift tower. The injured included several people who jumped to the ground, a spokesman for the ski area said.

LEAD: BY the end of January I have usually managed to tackle at last some of the chores that I had resolved to clear away for the new year. High on that list of thankless, postponed tasks is a bit of computer maintenance. I am not talking about changing the ribbon on my printer, nor am I referring to such basic upkeep as standardizing the labeling system for my floppies.

LEAD: To the Editor: Charles A. Lemaistre creates a badly distorted picture in ''Nobody is Safe if a Smoker is Around'' (Forum, Jan. 4). His assertion that ''involuntary smoking is a cause of disease, including lung cancer,'' is based on conclusions that are highly questionable in light of the evidence.

LEAD: Paige Hilary Klotz, a third-year law student at New York University, and Richard J. Grossman, an associate at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, were married last evening at La Reserve restaurant in Manhattan. Rabbi Louis Sigel officiated. The bride, a 1982 Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Cornell University, is a daughter of Mr.

LEAD: North Carolina's starting point guard, Kenny Smith, will miss today's game against Notre Dame and may be out of the lineup for two weeks. Smith underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Friday, and according to the team physcian, Dr. Joseph DeWalt, it could be two weeks before the all-America candidate can return to action.
LEAD: ASK anybody what is a Suzuki and you are liable to get one of three answers: (a) I don't know; (b) a small fuzzy dog, or (c) a motorcycle.

LEAD: From August 1985 to July 1986, I taught English at the Changsha Railway Institute, and much of what Mark Salzman described in his article rang true to me (''Of Confucius, 'E.T.' and Happiness Candy,'' Dec. 21). But I wonder exactly what sort of signals Mr. Salzman sent out in China and what sort he brought back to put in his book.

LEAD: In search of a clearer vision of America, Edmund G. Brown Jr. is checking out the view from Japan. The former California Governor, now 48 years old, said in an interview last week that he came to Japan in August to study Zen meditation and complete a book that he attempted to start writing in Los Angeles.
LEAD: OVER the last few years, leaders of the Westchester Town of Mamaroneck have been wrestling with the problem of saturation - the absence of buildable land.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Jordon McCarthy of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Sue McCarthy, to Didier Devynck, the son of Odette Devynck of Lille, France, and the late Antoine Devynck. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: FEW lines have more effectively caught the chill of modernity than the conclusion of Wallace Stevens' poem ''The Snow Man:'' ''For the listener, who listens in the snow, / And, nothing himself, beholds / Nothing that is not there and the nothing that is.'' Plagued by the suspicion that we are nothing and haunted by the dread that nothing remains nothing, many regard our epoch as a post age.

LEAD: Conservative legal scholars, judges and officials who convened here Friday and today to debate constitutional theory and legal philosophy served notice that their push for fundamental legal change would outlive the Reagan Administration and its current troubles.

LEAD: FREEDOM of information - the very words express a noble principle. No more deals agreed to behind closed doors. Let the sun shine on all government business. Citizens have a fundamental right to know how decisions are made.
LEAD: Rudyard Kipling's Classic Stories: A Trio of Well-Loved Tales A Stephen Bosustow Production for Learning Corporation of America. LCA Video. 25 minutes. $14.95

LEAD: J.D. Salinger, who is famous for loathing fame, has won a decisive round in a court fight to keep some of his private letters private. A Federal appeals court in Manhattan last week reversed a lower court ruling and blocked the publication of a book that the court said unfairly used some of Mr. Salinger's unpublished letters.

LEAD: For some time now, the big subjects of European and American art have been very different. Contemporary German and Italian art offer the United States a sustained meditation on history and the complexity of European culture, and a longing for healing and transformation. The United States offers Europe an intense, deeply obsessive involvement with popular culture, commodification and the communications industry.

LEAD: THE cupboard is not bare, but the inventory is certainly down. The herbed cheese is gone, including the nettle, which Mark Burdick was not sure would be popular in Litchfield County but ''got snapped right up,'' he said. Nearby, a new batch of nettle cheese sits, slowly aging. But the cheese can not be rushed.
LEAD: THE MAGICIAN'S GIRL By Doris Grumbach. 200 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $16.95.

LEAD: To the Editor: As the Buildings Department examiner on the crane-installation project at 650 Madison Avenue, I was pleasantly surprised to notice the familiar sight on the front page on Dec. 7 under the headline ''A Skyline Stage for New York Cranes.'' Your article on cranes was interesting, informative and largely correct.
