LEAD: Leslie Patricia Kamen, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology, and Dr. Lawrence Siegel, a fourth-year medical student, both at the University of Pennsylvania, plan to be married in August, the mother of the bride-to-be, Vera Jordan Kamen of New York, has announced.

LEAD: FOR the Fathom Dive Suits Company of Orlando, Fla., President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative seemed just the right opportunity to begin manufacturing rubber wet suits on the island of St. Lucia.

LEAD: IN one of the world's worst-kept official secrets, Pakistan has for years harbored military bases of the guerrilla insurgency in neighboring Afghanistan. To Washington, Pakistan's role is part of an elemental conflict between ''freedom fighters'' and a Communist regime propped up by Moscow.

LEAD: THE game was called Scruples and my friend Irene had brought it with her for our yearly New year's weekend at Mohonk. Irene always brought games. We had lived through the years of Scrabble, graduated to Boggle and gone on Trivial Pursuits with our entourage of six adults and six teen-agers.
LEAD: ''There's nothing really outstanding I do but I do a lot of things really well,'' said Payne Stewart, one of the most consistent golfers on the PGA Tour in recent years.

LEAD: A spokesman for the Civil Liberties Union called it ''a terrible idea'' and the director of the Legal Aid Society's criminal defense division didn't like it either. But city officials are going ahead with a plan to ask suspects arrested on felony charges to undergo drug tests voluntarily.

LEAD: The engagement of Maria Carzis and James Gordon Boyes 4th, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Truman D. Boyes of Plainfield, N.J., has been announced by the mother of the bride-to-be, Efthymia Carzis of North Plainfield, N.J., and Athens. Ms. Carzis, the daughter also of the late Peter G. Carzis, graduated from Syracuse University and is the editor of Fashion International and Fashion Calendar.
LEAD: IDOLS OF PERVERSITY Fantasies of Feminine Evil in Fin-de-Siecle Culture. By Bram Dijkstra. Illustrated. 453 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $37.95.
LEAD: Federal District Court judges in New Jersey are so overburdened with criminal trials that about 50 civil cases have been assigned to Federal judges in Philadelphia.

LEAD: IF at first you don't succeed. . . . A week after he failed to crack the Giant defense in the Super Bowl, John Elway will be getting another chance today. As the quarterback for the American Football Conference squad in the Pro Bowl game in Honolulu, Elway will be facing four Giant defenders who helped stymie him last week.
LEAD: WARSAW, Jan. 31 -
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany kept his parliamentary majority and his job last week, but the real victors in the election were two of the country's small parties.
LEAD: Lisa Jane Stern and Kevin F. Taylor, cum laude graduates of Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., plan to be married March 28.

LEAD: WHY are we so interested all of a sudden in a French writer who has been dead for a quarter of a century? Why should there be, just now, three new books by or about Louis-Ferdinand Celine? I think it's partly because we're fascinated by his craziness. We're more accustomed to craziness than we used to be and there's a peculiar pleasure - the reader's revenge?

LEAD: For two weeks now, a gray sky has hung low over New York City, spitting. Mostly it spits snow, sometimes it spits rain and occasionally it spits something that it would be a kindness to call sleet. The sun shows its face only long enough to prove it's still up there. So slush is piled at the curbings, and trying to walk some streets is like trying to traverse the Wollman Rink without skates.

LEAD: The engagement of Christina Kan to Robert C. Sullivan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sullivan of Chappaqua, N.Y., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Kan of Fairbanks, Alaska, parents of the bride-to-be. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: Whether the Super Bowl lived up to its hype is of little consequence. What matters is that at long last the pro football season is behind us and ''60 Minutes'' can start on time every Sunday evening. CHARLES COHEN Valley Stream, L.I.

LEAD: WHEN free agency was created 11 years ago it marked the genesis of an escalation in salaries that has made baseball players as a group the wealthiest athletes in professional team sports. Now, however, club owners are intent on a salary de-escalation, and have made free-agent spending the most glaring target of their effort.

LEAD: MENTAL-health clinics in northern Westchester report that a growing number of children and adolescents are seeking treatment. But as the need increases, some of the nonprofit clinics that provide services at reduced fees are expressing concern about their financial situation.

LEAD: IS it possible to speak of A. R. Gurney Jr. without adding that he is the theater's acknowledged chronicler of contemporary WASP culture and one of our most prolific and oft-produced playwrights?

LEAD: FEW MILES NORTH OF THE CONGO River, the sun is sinking into the South Atlantic. Standing in miniature silhouettes against the orange glow are the palm trees and American-operated oil wells of the Cabinda coast, in Angola's northernmost province. LEAD: SOLDERING has been used for centuries to join metals and is still one of the simplest and most widely used methods for securing metal joints and seams.
LEAD: FOR two years, six Jews have been hiding from the Nazis in the garret of a factory. Now the dreaded, ominous pounding is heard on the door downstairs.
LEAD: SCRATCH a real estate developer and you are likely to find an exhibitionist.

LEAD: U.S. Warms to Poland A United States official said after three days of talks with Polish leaders that ''we are clearly on a course of improving our relations.'' Page 6. Farewell to People Express Looking back with nostalgia, People Express workers flew their final flights before the company's absorption by Continental Airlines.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your correspondent M. D. Minichiello and others will be pleased to learn that a mechanism does indeed exist in the United States to deal with sterling-denominated V.A.T. refund checks in a simple and inexpensive manner.

LEAD: ''When you add it all up, the economy isn't booming, and it's not busting based on these numbers. It's just muddling along.'' - Edward E. Yardeni, chief economist, Prudential-Bache, on the durable goods report.

LEAD: WHEN Hugh Wolff mounts the podium at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, he will be taking part in something of a family reunion. The 33-year-old conductor will be leading the National Symphony Orchestra, whose members he calls his ''musical mothers and fathers.''

Shultz said he would be willing to meet with the group's leader, Oliver Tambo. That meeting took place last week at the State Department, signaling American willingness to recognize Mr.

LEAD: IN a turbulent world economy still riven by national forces, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d is striving to find a way to make the major industrial nations work together in their common interest - and, not incidentally, in the American interest as well.

LEAD: BECAUSE of the snow last week, 76-year-old Beatrice Taylor's weekly reading lesson with Alice Wiggins, a local public-school teacher and her tutor in a public literacy project here, was postponed.
LEAD: COASTING By Jonathan Raban. 302 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: WHEN Governor Kean and the Legislature created a commission to study state taxes and spending, they agreed to push the reporting date back until next year, a move designed to keep tax issues out of the current legislative election year.

LEAD: Leonard Fein remembers vividly the unplanned circumstances that led him to create an organization he named Mazon, the Hebrew word for food, which is helping feed the hungry in the United States and abroad.

LEAD: A 200-year-old Philadelphia wing chair - its frame riddled with nail holes, its carved front feet looking like hairy paws - became the most expensive piece of furniture ever sold at auction yesterday in a sale at Sotheby's.

LEAD: Leslie N. Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Frank of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married last night to Richard L. Silverstein, a son of Marilyn Finkel of East Rockaway, L.I., and Al Silverstein of New York. Rabbi Stanley Platek performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

LEAD: AT first blush, those familiar with the workings of the state-run rent-control system during and after World War II may think they recognize a familiar beast taking shape in the Cuomo's administration's proposed reform of the rent-regulation systems.

LEAD: The turmoil in the stock markets eased a bit, although wild trading, weird gyrations and unchecked program trading became commonplace in another chaotic week. After the 115-point swing of Jan. 23, the Dow Jones industrials settled down, but not before jumping 43.17 points on Tuesday. The Dow hit a record of 2,163.39 before settling back to end the week at 2,158.04, a gain of 56.52.

LEAD: SO far, 2,800 of the 4,800 physicians who practice in Connecticut have joined the first health maintenance organization in the state that will be owned by doctors, according to Timothy Norbeck, executive director of the Connecticut Medical Society.

LEAD: SOME locally rare species of dragonflies, it appears, are partial to trysting on their own north shore, that of Belvedere Lake in Central Park.

LEAD: The engagement of Lynda Jane Johnson and Mark Anthony Miller has been announced by Carol Johnson Bald of Ridgewood, N.J., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley Robert Miller of Quakertown, Pa. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: A military judge dropped two counts of attempted murder against a Fort Rucker flight instructor accused of tampering with 11 Army helicopters, but the instructor, Warrant Officer Louis H. Plunkett Jr., still faces a general court-martial, officials said Friday. Mr. Plunkett has been charged with five counts of damage to government property and one count of violation of Federal law, said Betty Goodson, a spokesman at Fort Rucker.

LEAD: KUDOS to the new Nantucket Cafe in New Canaan for its imaginative use of interior space. In a room that holds just nine tables and seats 22 people, the ambiance of Nantucket has been artfully evoked.

LEAD: Fiction Weeks This Last On Week Week List 1 1 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with a castle, an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 2 1 27 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III.

LEAD: HOW many times have you slowed down your car to stretch your neck for a look at a stranded driver and then continued about your business, shaking your head and muttering to yourself, ''Poor guy''?

LEAD: For a decade, almost from the time they were high school phenomenons, Renaldo Nehemiah and Greg Foster have been rivals running the high hurdles. At their best, when they competed head-to-head, Nehemiah was the world's best hurdler and Foster the second best.

LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators have agreed in Geneva to set up a special working group to discuss what research, development and testing are allowed for defensive systems by the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials say.
LEAD: Iraq said today that it had retaken 15 square miles of territory near Basra, but Iran said it had killed or wounded 3,000 Iraqis in crushing the counteroffensive.
LEAD: 'The rationalization that the ends justify the means seems to be infecting portions of Suffolk's criminal justice system. Unchecked, it may undermine the county's entire justice system. . . .

LEAD: Dr. Marla Joan Fischl and Dr. Peter N. Casadei, who have a joint equine veterinary practice in Old Westbury, L.I., were married last evening at the Regency Hotel in New York. Rabbi Charles Davidson and the Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.
LEAD: If you take a knight and a bishop and plunk them down at random on an empty board, it is not clear which piece is the more useful.
LEAD: EVER since Vaughn Meader sold millions of records imitating John F. Kennedy, Presidents of the United States have been fair game for comic impressionists.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy Gordon of Short Hills, N.J., and Bridgehampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Jean Auchincloss Gordon, to Dwight Earle Vicks 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vicks Jr. of Utica, N.Y.

LEAD: THE allure of stock warrants - basically rights that allow investors to buy common shares for an extended time at a fixed price - tends to rise and fall with speculative fervor. The game offers both big rewards and high risks. Indeed, many holders of warrants have done quite well in the recent Wall Street surge.

LEAD: A WELL-KNOWN Sydney businessman recently stunned his colleagues by suggesting that Australia quadruple its population by allowing more people to immigrate. Jaws fell further when Kerry Packer, one of Australia's most successful media magnates, added that more Asians, already settling here in record numbers, should be encouraged to immigrate.
LEAD: IT starts slowly after Christmas, but the pressure builds quickly as the February school vacation nears. Snow time.
LEAD: The shortage of blood that regularly develops during the Christmas holidays has persisted this year and shows no sign of easing, officials of the New York Blood Center said last week.

LEAD: SOONER or later, an expletive will not be able to be deleted. But in permitting a minicamera-microphone on their 12-Meter yachts, maybe that's what the America's Cup skippers had in mind all along. Maybe they're hoping that an expletive or two will let people realize that they're not rich kids born with a silver spinnaker in their mouths, that they're world-class athletes in a true sense of the word in a true world championship.
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Haberman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Hillary Haberman to Jeffrey Scott Suchman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Suchman of Harrison, N.Y.
LEAD: IN a variation of the Andy Hardy-type scenario in which Mickey Rooney said to Judy Garland, ''Let's put on a show,'' Matthew Parent once said to Jerald Smith-Niles, ''Let's start a theater.''

LEAD: BY the time we left Iroquois country in upstate New York on our holiday trip, a strange sensation had begun, a distant recollection of another time and place. As the Appalachian plateau of Ohio flattened out into the cornfields of Indiana, it became more than a perception; it was real, proving itself again and again.

At the actual concert, Ms. Oliveros introduced her friends and joined them at the end for a three-person improvisation, but offered no compositions of her own.

LEAD: ''HERE IS A MAN WHO would fudge when it suits his purpose.'' So said Australian Justice Philip Powell, with scorn, of the Secretary to Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet, in connection with the trial concerning the attempted suppression of a book about ''the fifth man'' who may have infiltrated Britain's spy service.

LEAD: The Salvadoran Air Force killed seven civilians in bombing and strafing runs near an isolated peasant village last week, according to accounts from local inhabitants and a videotape of the bombed site.

LEAD: GHOSTLY POPULATIONS. By Jack Matthews. (Johns Hopkins University, $14.95.) Children tell two kinds of tales: ghost stories and jokes. As they get older the jokes get dirtier and the ghosts are forgotten. But Jack Matthews gives the impression ''of a man listening to his childhood.'' Like the narrator of his title story, he is a collector of ghost stories, and his characters mutter old riddles as though they're mantras - ''What has four wheels, hemorrhoids, and a dream?

The Rev.

LEAD: John H. Jacobson Jr. has been appointed president of Hope College, school officials said today. Mr. Jacobson is the provost and vice president for academic affairs at Empire State College, which is part of the State University of New York, at Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Mr. Jacobson will become Hope's 10th president in 121 years.

LEAD: With the recent revitalization of some of the world's most ancient baths and the development of new seaside spas, Israel offers a wide range of health- and beauty-oriented vacation spots that also make excellent sites to unwind in after a whirlwind tour. In fact, because of the relaxed atmosphere of most of the establishments and a certain mystique about staying at a spa, many guests leave refreshed without taking any of the formal treatments.

LEAD: A certain unwonted sensation, akin I regret to say to churlishness, creeps over me from time to time these days, traceable directly to an overdose of glasnost. Glasnost, we all know, is a Russian word that has entered the English language and is translatable as ''opening.'' It is used to describe the changes Mr.

LEAD: Isn't Ms. Given equating her students' ''more than half-time'' jobs with their inability to be even half-time students? Isn't she saying that if they didn't hold jobs and, instead, devoted all their time and attention to school, they would be better students?

LEAD: An item in last Sunday's Westchester Guide about Black History Month gave an incorrect location for events in Greenburgh. The story-and-song program at 3 P.M. today will be at the Greenburgh Town Hall; all other events sponsored by the Greenburgh Library will be held at the library, 300 Tarrytown Road in Elmsford.

LEAD: NEAR Route 11 in Salem, beavers have built a dam, 40 feet long and 4 feet high, out of mud and branches. Motorists often stop to admire the dam, which has made a thin, shallow brook into a wide, deep pond.

LEAD: On Monday, 23 million registered voters are scheduled to respond ''yes'' or ''no'' to a question that boils down to this: Is the Philippines better off with a flawed constitution or no constitution at all?
LEAD: AS major snowstorms slammed into Long Island late last month, many Long Islanders were probably asking themselves, ''Why me?'' The answer is not in our stars, but in our geography.

LEAD: A Senate staff report has suggested that Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter engineered the ''improper'' dismissal of a Defense Department aide last April because the official was close to uncovering the sale of American weapons to Iran.
LEAD: Georgetown rallied frequently and frenetically against Syracuse today, forcing the game into overtime and then winning it, 83-81, on a last-second shot.

LEAD: It came as no surprise to me, as a marriage and family therapist, that a teen-ager whose mother married, divorced, remarried , divorced and again remarried would never plan to marry (''One Son, Three Fathers,'' by Steven O'Brien, About Men, Dec. 28).

LEAD: The United States Postal Service released the 1987 Love stamp last Friday in ceremonies that featured singer Tony Bennett. It went on sale yesterday and is just in time for use with Valentine's Day cards. This latest design should be one of the most popular in this strong-selling series.

LEAD: JOSHUA WESSON KNELT last year in a French casino watching the approach of a man armed with a sword, a gnarled stick and a silver goblet. ''I didn't know which way I was going to die - run through, conked or poisoned,'' Mr. Wesson recalls. Instead, in a ceremony attended by Dustin Hoffman and several other Hollywood notables, he was knighted by La Commanderies des Cotes du Rhone, the prestigious wine society.

LEAD: There's little doubt that CBS ''personality'' people are more interested in promoting themselves than the news, and in preaching grade-school admonitions that turn important news items into immature object lessons.

LEAD: In any office there are those who believe that a clean desk betokens a clean mind. They are ruthless in disposing of clutter. Given the proper equipment, they would stay after work and shred the universe. Then there are the rest of us, those whose desks, like our minds, resemble a gigantic In basket.

LEAD: WE all change. I don't run as fast any more, my midsection is sprouting a small spare tire and I am starting a family - all as things should be, I suppose. But there are some changes I have become very conscious of recently. As I am about to enter a brand new stage of life as a family provider I have found that my reading has become more and more focused toward financial materials, to the exclusion of most other types of literature.

LEAD: A VALENTINE'S concert on Feb. 8, Sweet Saturday Night on a Thursday, ''Tonight at 8:30'' at 8 P.M., bluegrass tunes at the symphony - it will be a funny fortnight in Connecticut, but it will all add up to a remarkable and delightful diversity.

LEAD: ELLEN TAAFFE ZWILICH, the only woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for composition (in 1983), is much in the news these days. Friday night at Carnegie Hall her Piano Concerto, jointly commissioned by Carnegie, the Detroit Symphony and the American Symphony, received its New York premiere.

LEAD: Residents in this village were warned today not to use their tap water. Police officials said caustic soda, which is normally added to the water, was not diluted properly, making the water acidic.

LEAD: THE Green Bay Packers have named Tom Braatz as executive vice president of football operations, reducing the responsibilities of Coach Forrest Gregg. The move will mark the first time since Vince Lombardi was hired in 1959 that the Packer head coach has not had complete authority over the football operations.
LEAD: IRON & SILK By Mark Salzman. 211 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

LEAD: Allan V. Cox, dean of earth sciences at Stanford University, died Tuesday of injuries suffered in a bicycle accident near his home in Woodside, Calif. He was 60 years old. Dr. Cox, who became a Stanford professor in 1967 and was appointed dean in 1979, was known for his work in paleomagnatism and plate tectonics.

LEAD: At the First Congregational Church in Canton, Conn., yesterday Beverly Jean Keyes, a daughter of Grace H. Keyes of Canton and the late James R. Keyes, was married to D. Dana Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Donovan Jr. of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Charles Schleich officiated. The bride, a graduate of Middlebury College with an M.B.A.

LEAD: The ''Famous Potatoes'' slogan on Idaho automobile license plates seems to have been around as long as the Sawtooth Mountains or Sun Valley, but one Boisean, Andrew Freese, says it discriminates against other Idaho products, and he is suing the state to have it removed.

LEAD: In the sun-parched griddle of the Arizona desert, Interstate 17 glistens with sleek black puddles. They vaporize as the car approaches. Mirages. Dancing off the rocks, the searing heat plays other tricks. Amid the tumbleweed and cactus, a futuristic space colony materializes on the desert floor, a cluster of vaulting arches and cubic modules and filaments of construction cranes poking into the thin blue sky.
LEAD: A LIFELONG resident of Long Island once said, ''A true New Yorker is someone who doesn't know where Long Island is and hasn't the vaguest idea how to get out there.''

LEAD: THIS COLLECTION OF PHOTOgraphs, from crime magazines and newspapers of the late 1920's and early 30's, will be exhibited, beginning Tuesday, at Manhattan's Pace/MacGill Gallery. The faces of crime were -and remain - grist for tabloid journalism, and they are shown here with the retouching marks and directions of the original editors, who often enhanced their pictures' visual impact.

LEAD: The engagement of Hannah Elisabeth Frost to Ronan Patrick Ryan has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Frost of New York, the father and stepmother of the future bride. Mr. Ryan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ryan of Hazel Park, Mich. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence D. Harvey of New York of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Anne Harvey to Gerald Radburn Taylor 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor Jr. of Easton, Conn.

LEAD: FOR a Presidency that has relied strongly on visual imagery, the ceremonial surroundings of the State of the Union Message last week were a boost. The House of Representatives chamber was crammed with members of both houses, the Cabinet, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Supreme Court and the diplomatic corps.

LEAD: After a $36,000 monument was erected in memory of the seven astronauts who died in the space shuttle disaster, city officials were chagrined to discover that the name of one, Judith A. Resnik, had been misspelled.

Jay Sigel, an amateur golfer from Berwyn, Pa., was named to the 10-man United States Walker Cup team by the United States Golf Association for the sixth time.

LEAD: AS a result of new asbestos regulations promulgated by the New York State Attorney General's office and New York City, almost everyone involved in residential cooperatives will need to take actions not previously deemed necessary. The regulations are designed to protect co-op residents from the health hazards associated with exposure to airborne particles of asbestos.

LEAD: THE union wasn't made in heaven, and it's never been blessed by judge or preacher, but divorce is highly unlikely. This is love, true love, deep, abiding, forever love. It cannot be torn asunder by gossip and wicked innuendo. So what if there's some flaking off at inopportune moments, and occasional willfullness, and little, and even big, tantrums.

We were watching the Giants-Redskins game, which had been much touted; I, casually, mainly reading The New York Times Magazine; he, the football player of the family, intently.

LEAD: THE plight of the most helpless New Yorkers -the babies and children who are orphaned, abandoned, neglected, malnourished, molested, beaten and sometimes killed - was emphasized last week in words and numbers that Nanette Dembitz, a former Family Court judge, called ''heartbreaking.''

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Diefenbach of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ann Diefenbach, to Stuart King Gray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert King Gray of Old Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 27.

LEAD: An article in the Real Estate section Jan. 18 on the effect of the porters' union contract on commercial rents incorrectly stated the frequency of the rent increases and which aspects of the wage increases would have an effect on rents. The increases are calculated annually, not monthly. The base salary for a porter in Class A commercial buildings is $10.237 and the new contract calls for salary increases of 52.5 cents in the first year, 52.5 cents in the second year, and 50 cents in the third year.

LEAD: With a certainty and assurance that hid the effects of a bitter two-week strike, the Long Island Rail Road greeted its riders today with service that passengers, workers and officials said was better than expected.

LEAD: DESPITE growing community opposition, the State Department of Transportation is continuing with its plans to demolish most of the 12 abandoned gas stations along two area parkways, a department official said last week.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Neuberger of New York and Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ellen Neuberger, to Michael Charles Kanterman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Kanterman of Spring Valley, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next month.

LEAD: Fred W. Friendly beamed with satisfaction as he thought of Lesley Stahl, the veteran CBS News correspondent, nervously gnawing her lip in front of a national television audience and trying to figure a way out of the terrible dilemma Mr. Friendly had created for her.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would extend its warranty on the power train of all its domestically made cars and trucks from five years and 50,000 miles to seven years and 70,000 miles. The action by Chrysler, which had been expected, gives the company the longest warranty of any domestic manufacturer.

LEAD: HEMPSTEAD Town and Nassau County officials, under pressure to meet Federal air-quality standards or face a cutoff of funds for road projects, have adopted a tough new environmental stance that could prevent construction, limit the size or increase the cost of major projects planned at Mitchel Field.

LEAD: It is a spectacle of rare proportions. The 20th century's two greatest experiments in government are consumed by inward struggle. Soviet and Chinese leaders have decided that their nations cannot move forward without moving, in some ways, toward the capitalist economies rejected by their revolutions and without embracing some elements of freedom.

LEAD: Despite its comparative youth - 1988 is bicentenary year - Sydney has many fine public and private art galleries and museums, with the added bonuses that most charge no admission and lines are rare. The quality and variety of the collections, including, as they do, major paintings from Europe and other parts of the world, as well as Australia, surprise many visitors to the city.

LEAD: Providence College, which had not beaten St. John's in three seasons and had never been in first place in its seven-year tenure in the Big East Conference, accomplished both feats tonight. LEAD: Two Lebanese brothers imprisoned in West Germany, one of whom is wanted by the United States for hijacking and murder, were recently visited in jail by their parents, officials said today.

Crown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Crown of Chicago, took place last evening at the Pierre Hotel. Rabbi Gerson D. Cohen, chancellor emeritus of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, officiated.

LEAD: Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes team picked its way through shifting winds today to beat Kookaburra III by 1 minute 41 seconds in the opening match of the America's Cup final.

LEAD: WHILE adjustable-rate mortgages are becoming more standardized, there still are substantial variations in pricing and structure that warrant careful scrutiny. The greatest remaining impediment to comparison shopping is that lenders peg their interest-rate adjustments to a variety of esoteric financial indexes.
LEAD: ABOUT 40 students from Stamford High School filed into the city's Superior Court one recent day to witness a divorce trial.

LEAD: THE showdown began came just after sundown. Nine days ago, Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive of the JWT Group, strode out of the board room on the 20th floor of JWT's Lexington Avenue headquarters, took an elevator to the third floor and walked to an office that he himself had once occupied.
LEAD: Since 1973, scores of alcoholic women who were legally entitled to receive care from the state have instead been jailed with criminals, state officials recently acknowledged.
LEAD: MOTHERS OF FEMINISM The Story of Quaker Women in America. By Margaret Hope Bacon. Illustrated. 273 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $16.95.

LEAD: There's a moment of pure happiness in Woody Allen's new ''Radio Days'' in which the narrator's Cousin Ruthie appears with a towel on her head, doing a little dance. Though not the Latin fireball type - Cousin Ruthie ordinarily wears white anklets and spends time gossiping with her mother about the neighbors - she has done what she can with this improvised turban and some junk jewelry.

LEAD: The service that operates New York City's emergency ambulance system said last week that all 43 hospitals in the system would soon be required to maintain fully trained physicians on emergency-room duty around the clock. The announcement followed a series of deaths in recent years that have been blamed on mistakes by poorly supervised interns and residents.

LEAD: Governor Kean will propose a $10.1 billion state budget for the coming fiscal year that calls for higher spending for education, welfare and health care - including a dramatic increase to combat AIDS -but contains little help for cities about to lose Federal revenue-sharing funds.

LEAD: IT'S not much of a street, fewer than 15 houses, and it lost only one tree during Hurricane Gloria. Two of us cleared the blocked driveway together while others came out and looked at the tree, but most were, as usual, invisible.

LEAD: A coalition of President Reagan's most important supporters is demanding the ouster of Representative George W. Crockett Jr., a Michigan Democrat, as head of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, maintaining that he is a ''security risk.''

LEAD: IN just over a month, maple sugaring season will arrive and Leon Anstett is ready.

LEAD: Akabir scored a two-length upset victory over Theatrical in a roughly run Bougainvillea Handicap today at Hialeah Park. After the race, Theatrical was disqualified from second and placed last.

LEAD: Captive Americans may be swapped for munitions in other parts of the world, but Nicaragua continues to give them away. Last week, officials there released Sam Nesley Hall, an American charged with working against Managua, making him the second captured contra - Eugene Hasenfus became the first last year - to be sent home.

LEAD: If Republicans in Congress seemed especially eager to stomp and cheer for President Reagan during his State of the Union Message last week, they had good reason. If Republicans are to salvage power, many of them believe, Mr. Reagan needs to salvage his Presidency.

LEAD: 'Reasonable' Consent Question: In a recent column you wrote that ''the owner of a rent-stabilized co-op may not unreasonably withhold consent to a sublet, and the unit may be subletted for two years out of any four-year period.'' Can you give me an idea of what has been construed to be an unreasonable withholding of consent?
LEAD: Russia has lived long and suffered much, but its art has often fed on such misfortunes - creating in its music, for example, a wide capacity to stretch the imagination and dream deeply.
LEAD: AS the celebration of Black History Month begins today, historical groups, schools and churches across the state will be offering exhibits, lectures and other programs throughout February.

LEAD: The two new one-act plays by Arthur Miller that open at Lincoln Center next Sunday are thematically linked under the title ''Danger: Memory!'', which could be taken as a symbolic warning to the playwright. In 1964, he inaugurated Lincoln Center's first theater season (in its temporary home in a theater near Washington Square) with ''After the Fall,'' a play that fell far short of expectations.

LEAD: The United States awarded $9 billion in military contracts to foreign companies last year, and some lawmakers charge that the deals hurt both the nation's trade deficit and the struggling American companies that could be doing the work.

LEAD: The announcement two weeks ago thatthe R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company's parent corporation, RJR Nabisco Inc., would move its corporate headquarters to Atlanta has saddened this cigarette-producing city.

LEAD: A long-delayed plan to dredge PCB-laden sediment from the Hudson River moved forward this week when Governor Cuomo named an eight-member board to review a proposed site for burial of the sediment.

LEAD: For now, Harold Hamilton and Loretta Praher, husband-and-wife developers, are luxuriating in the 25-room country mansion in Bernardsville, N.J., that was formerly owned by R. Thornton Wilson. Overseeing the house's restoration, the couple, principals of CHP Developers, can stoke one of 12 fireplaces - three of which are in the master bedroom suite - and watch the deer that grace the property.

LEAD: George W. Wyckoff, a former vice president and governor of T. Mellon & Sons, a Pittsburgh investment management concern, died Jan. 23 at the Latrobe Hospital in Latrobe, Pa. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: In a city where housing can be an obsession even for the well-to-do, life for hundreds of thousands of people on welfare is a daily encounter with dilapidated buildings, crowded rooms and a housing allowance out of line with the cost of living in New York.

LEAD: Ratepayers in 28 Massachusetts communities that invested in the Seabrook nuclear power plant are beginning to see the effect of the construction in their electricity bills, even though they still receive no electricity from the idle plant.

LEAD: THE theme was variations Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, when the New York City Ballet offered Jerome Robbins's ''Goldberg Variations'' and George Balanchine's ''Four Temperaments.'' Both of these intricate works are musical and choreographic examples of the theme-and-variations form.

LEAD: Delegates to the annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark today called for a yearlong study of a controversial proposal to recognize and bless nonmarital relationships, including those between homosexual couples.

No, the swap involving Ryan for Jim Fregosi hasn't got any better for the Mets since the last time anyone looked.

''My wife, Judith, looks for my bags whenever she goes shopping in Pathmark,'' he said proudly.

''The dialogue is brilliant,'' Donald Keene said in The Book Review in 1966, and ''the rapid-fire invention of the language makes every page sparkle, thanks to the translation.

LEAD: Most laboratory animals are bred specifically for research. Since their health and genetic history are known, such ''purpose-bred'' animals yield superior data. Still, each year, some 300,000 dogs and cats are bought from animal shelters for laboratory use. Why? They cost less. Congressman Robert Mrazek, Democrat of New York, has introduced legislation to prohibit the National Institutes of Health from funding experiments that use shelter animals.
LEAD: A state environmental agency and a conservation group are at odds over plans to restore the heavily trodden banks of Walden Pond, where Henry David Thoreau was inspired to write ''Walden.''

LEAD: IN their way, New York's two best-known women's clubs are progressive. Men cannot be full members, but they are everywhere.

LEAD: Eleven North Koreans aboard a ship that developed engine trouble and drifted into Japanese waters more than a week ago have created an unusual diplomatic triangle that resists a swift solution.

LEAD: If the United States Football League had played a 1986 fall season as originally planned, its championship game would have been played today. If variety of setting were the sole criterion of a short story's excellence, Laura Kalpakian's first collection would be superior. With substantial facility she delineates locations ranging from a loch in Scotland to Venice to the Santa Monica pier.

LEAD: WHEN United Airlines announced plans to withdraw $960 million in surplus assets from its pension plan, many of the company's retirees protested that most or all of the money was rightfully theirs. Since the money had been set aside to cover retirement benefits, they contended, any amount by which it had appreciated in a bull market should be used to provide cost-of-living increases.

LEAD: President Reagan's chief political adviser has resigned and will return to Indianapolis to become executive vice president of the Hudson Institute, the White House announced today.

LEAD: I WAS APPLYING FOR A PASSPORT FOR MY 18-month-old daughter when I froze at the marital-status question. Give the kid a chance, I thought, she's still in diapers. But the question haunted me for days. I recognized the feeling, which first appeared soon after Annie was born. But it wasn't until that day at the Passport Office that I began to focus on just how radically my outlook has changed simply because my child is a female.

LEAD: The judge in a trial involving a group of rich young men has denied a motion to dismiss a murder charge against the group's leader and has ordered the trial to begin Monday.

LEAD: For years, local residents used to sit around the fireplace at the Memory Inn in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., listening to the proprietor at the piano. But a fire forced the inn to close in 1980, and last year new owners undertook to restore the 19th century structure and convert it into offices.

LEAD: The most moving scene in ''LBJ: The Early Years'' is this: It is 1955, and Lyndon B. Johnson, the Senate majority leader, recovered from a heart attack, has returned to Washington from Texas. As he approaches the Capitol, Senators and their assistants pass the word. ''The leader's coming,'' ''The leader's coming,'' they say, and spontaneously assemble in a corridor.

LEAD: For a long time, Rio de Janeiro has been popping up as the exotic backdrop of movies, wicked novels and midwinter fantasy. But it remained largely in the background rather than figuring prominently in the routes of frequent travelers to the sun. There was good reason. Five thousand miles - from New York to Rio de Janeiro - is a long way to go for fine weather.

LEAD: SUBWAY (Aperture, $29.95) by the photographer Bruce Davidson offers a vivid diary of the people who enter this dimmed, often hostile arena. There are pictures of proud young mothers and children, weary businessmen, despairing bag people, menacing young men, and passionate couples embracing. In most cases the sitters are fully aware of being photographed and yet the confines of the train prevents them from donning the mask one ordinarily sees in posed pictures.

LEAD: CYPRIEN KATSARIS'S evening of piano music at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday was fiercely difficult, but less for its physical demands than for its testings of the mind and heart.
