LEAD: Today, as before, the single most marked characteristic of the Reagan Administration is the mismatch between its words and reality -a gap that is hard to explain except by incompetence or duplicity.
LEAD: The United Steelworkers union ratified a contract with the USX Corporation, the nation's biggest steelmaker, that will further erode their wages, union officials said today.

LEAD: ELLA T. GRASSO'S statue will remain conspicuous for some time - the pristine white of the Carrara marble that it's carved in guaran-tees that. The sculptor himself, Frank C. Gaylord 2d, allows that it will look like a ''newly painted radiator'' until the acids in Hartford's atmosphere have had their way.

LEAD: Cruises to Mexico Question:Are there any cruises from New Orleans that enable you to see the Mayan and Aztec sites in Mexico? - A. B., Fair Lawn, N.J. Answer:To visit the Mayan sites, passengers need to take a cruise that calls at ports in the Yucatan. The cruise lines arrange guided excursions from the ports to the Mayan ruins by bus and sometimes by plane.

LEAD: IT TAKES A HEAP OF livin' not to feel envious when you read about television newspeople making $1.2 million per year. Fortunately, a heap is the precise amount of livin' I have now undergone. As a result, I felt nothing but pity recently upon reading about the bloated paychecks of certain telenews guys and gals.
LEAD: Sean Couch scored a career-high 33 points tonight to lead Columbia past Harvard, 88-81, in an Ivy League game.

LEAD: THE selection of a superintendent in any of the city's community school districts is invariably a sensitive, politically charged task. On Manhattan's Upper West Side, the process has recently taken on a particularly lively air.

LEAD: THE county's halls of learning are frequently our most adventuresome halls of music, a fact well borne out by the concert calendar this week. Let us begin at Manhattanville College in Purchase, where the ''Castle Concerts'' were innaugurated last year.

LEAD: WEIMAR PHOTO ART In the first three decades of this century Germany produced a prodigious quantity and variety of progressive art, including the art of photography. Opening today, and on display through March 29 at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase, is an exhibition called ''Photographers of the Weimar Republic,'' in which 100 works by six early 20th-century German photographers are to be seen.

LEAD: A special advisory panel has given the Board of Regents the names of five candidates to be the next State Education Commissioner, but the board is unhappy with the size of the list and will seek to expand it, according to several Regents.
LEAD: So the L.I.R.R. was struck again -leaving commuters desperately searching for alternate means of transportation.
LEAD: A ''SORT of Breathalyzer test for peanuts'' was announced by the Federal Department of Agriculture early last year to detect what the department calls drunken peanuts.

LEAD: I agree when Naomi Given writes [ Jan. 18 ] that ''the undergraduate college [ is ] a very troubled institution,'' but I cannot understand how a professor has such a poor and wrong knowledge of too many college - or even high school - students' situations.

LEAD: Whether the Super Bowl lived up to its hype is certainly debatable. What is known, however, is that almost 60 percent of Americans had an opinion on the game (''Poll Finds Preference for Giants,'' The New York Times, Jan. 25).
LEAD: To the Editor: As Jan Benzel related in ''Holiday Migrations Old and New'' (Travel, Dec. 21), we too stumbled onto a happy solution to the problem of an expanding family at Christmas.

LEAD: ACROSS the street from a two-acre wasteland in the South Bronx, Gamaliel Santiago painted vibrant cartoon characters on an old storefront last year, then opened a party-supply store. ''I sensed that the area was on its way up,'' he explained a few days ago. ''I see a rosy future.''

LEAD: Black students in a Maryland county school system that began a unusual desegregation program two years ago have posted significant gains on national standardized test scores, school officials say.

LEAD: THE Tarrytown Planning Board agreed by a narrow margin last week to ask its Village Board of Trustees to revoke the permits that had allowed a local builder to make major changes in his historic-district property.

LEAD: FLORIDA'S official state animal, the panther, was reported nearing extinction when the State Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission began tracking the survivors by radio to learn more about how they lived.

LEAD: The soprano Montserrat Caballe will give a recital at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 27th. Tickets, from $30 to $10, will go on sale tomorrow at the box office and through Carnegie Charge, (212) 247-7800.

LEAD: OBTAINING venison no longer requires a hunting expedition. It has become more widely available commercially, and many butchers given a few days' notice can supply it. The meat is extremely lean and relatively low in cholesterol.

LEAD: It is rare for ordinary citizens to create their own legislation, but that is what the 15 members of the Senior Action Committee in Ridgewood, Queens, have done. They want the state's Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption law, known as SCRIE, to be extended to all nonregulated apartments, provided the landlord agrees to participate.

LEAD: THIS winter we are reading and hearing more about New York's homeless, but with spring we will turn to other pursuits. The problems of the poor and the near poor will remain, however, until we recognize that it is in our own best interest to find some means of providing suitable housing for those who cannot provide it for themselves.

LEAD: To the Editor: Attributing increased layoffs of black managers to this administration's policies (''The Ax Falls on Equal Opportunity,'' Jan. 4) completely misses the point. These unfortunate setbacks are not the result of the current Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, but rather a case of the racial engineering of the past undoing itself.

LEAD: Infant and child mortality rates in Angola and Mozambique are now the highest in the world, largely because of the fighting and war-related economic destabilization in southern Africa, according to Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Adler of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Gale Adler, to Dr. Jess David Amchin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Amchin of Farmingdale, L.I.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: The marriage of Janet King How, director of information services for Ernst & Whinney, certified public accountants in New York, to Salvatore Francis Accardo, a senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Investment Corporation, took place yesterday in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church in Manhattan.
LEAD: THE PHILOSOPHICAL DISENFRANCHISEMENT OF ART By Arthur C. Danto. 216 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $25.
LEAD: AS land gets more valuable in Westchester, low-profit uses are disappearing.
LEAD: Twyla Tharp at BAM

LEAD: As a resident of the Southwest and as a sometime-dealer in antiques and artifacts, I read Derek V. Goodwin's article on the illegal trafficking of Indian ceremonial material with considerable interest (''Raiders of the Sacred Sites,'' Dec. 7). There is surely material to be written about looting and desecrating ceremonial property, but the subject cannot be conveniently wrapped up by peppering a scenario with villains and vigilantes.

LEAD: To the Editor: I live next door to the Bentley, featured in ''Escape Route as Design Element'' on Jan. 18, and my apartment looks directly out on that exterior fire escape. One feature of its design not mentioned in your article is that it has exposed fluorescent lights on every floor that glare through neighboring windows.
LEAD: In a highly secret operation, the Central Intelligence Agency has used an abandoned air base here to airlift arms to guerrillas in Angola, diplomatic and business sources say.

LEAD: For most people, raising six children of their own would be a struggle. For Mayor Charles L. Smith of Pittsfield and his wife, Patricia, caring for an additional 70 children as foster parents and guardians has not been enough.
LEAD: The Exquisite Appellation In his new novel, ''Sphinx'' (Viking), D. M. Thomas mocks an editor who poses as a poet.

LEAD: In 1985 the Human Resources Administration's Department of Special Services for Children put together a book, ''Two Hands,'' described in its subtitle as ''a collection of writing and art work created by human beings under the age of 21 who happen to live within the foster care system of the City of New York.

LEAD: Howard Teicher, a member of the National Security Council staff, attended a dinner at the Brookings Institution the other night and the people around the table were asked to state names and hometowns, such as ''Joe Doakes, New York.''

LEAD: ANTONIO ZUMEL, a negotiator for the Communist insurgents in the Philippines, returned to the underground 10 days ago when the already faltering peace talks with the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino broke down. Mr. Zumel said his life had been threatened.
LEAD: Hundreds of Vietnamese gathered joyously yesterday at Public School 124 in Chinatown to celebrate Tet -or the lunar new year - and call for freedom for Vietnam.

LEAD: On the ice last night, Pierre Larouche showed the old grace and some guile, and he showed even more. He barreled his way into the corners. He knocked pucks loose from defensemen, who seemed like great bears next to his 5-foot-11-inch, 175-pound frame.

LEAD: The spinnaker being lowered on Stars & Stripes during America's Cup race Sunday. Despite technical advances, the tasks of sailboat crews have changed little in centuries. Sports of The Times, page C4. (AP)

LEAD: John Elway threw for the game's only touchdown today and Karl Mecklenburg, Elway's teammate from the Denver Broncos, spearheaded a smothering defense to lead the American Conference to a 10-6 victory over the National Conference in the Pro Bowl.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fred Couples, the professional golfer, and George Brett, the professional third baseman and amateur golfer, got a best-ball birdie 3 on the third extra hole to win the pro-am team title of the 47th annual Pebble Beach National Pro-Am today.

LEAD: PHOTO ALBUM The Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center is made up of two handsomely grand galleries on the ground floor of the high-rise with the outsize lobby at 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street (554-1113). The exhibitions at this Whitney, as at other Whitneys, central and branch, are meticulously and tastefully mounted and usually have a theme.

LEAD: Representative Sala Burton, a California Democrat who succeeded her late husband in Congress in 1983 and carried on his liberal policies, died today of complications arising from cancer. She was 61.
LEAD: In the half-dozen city restaurants where the bureaucratic and political elite have breakfast the talk these mornings is of little else but the selection of Mexico's next President.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has once again extended the deadline it set for receiving final bids on its electronic filing and retrieval system, known as Edgar.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Private efforts to ship arms to Iran became known to Pentagon intelligence officials over a year ago, but the officials did not stop the sales, according to documents and participants who informed the Government. Page A1

LEAD: The New York real estate developer Donald J. Trump has exercised an option to buy 2.3 million shares of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, Mr. Trump said that he had paid $47.62 million for the shares. The Bally shares were being held under an agreement with Bear, Stearns & Company, while Mr.
LEAD: ''Platoon,'' an intense film about the Vietnam War, won Golden Globe awards Saturday night for the best dramatic movie of 1986 and the best director.

LEAD: Wendy Ann Sherman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart K. Sherman of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert W. Greitzer, the son of Harry Greitzer of Rye, N.Y., and the late Elinore Greitzer. Rabbi Peter Weintraub officiated at the Waters Edge Restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

LEAD: * Ameritech, Chicago, the parent of five Bell telephone companies in the Middle West, appointed Ormand J. Wade president of Ameritech Bell Group, Robert L. Barnett president of Ameritech Enterprise Group, Frank R. Zimmerman president of Illinois Bell and Louis J. Rutigliano president of Wisconsin Bell.

LEAD: Kyung Wha Chung, who is currently celebrating the 20th anniversary of the Leventritt Prize that boosted her into the big-league concert circuit, returned to Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon for a recital with the pianist Jonathan Feldman, a recital that reached its high point in a beautifully accomplished performance of Bartok's Second Violin Sonata.

LEAD: Manila residents casting their ballots today in a plebiscite on a new constitution. The election has developed into a vote of confidence for President Corazon C. Aquino. Page A3. (Agence France-Presse)
LEAD: QUESTION: If Pete Rose is the player with the most hits ever in baseball and Ty Cobb is second, who's third?

LEAD: THE cute New York Telephone animated advertising that starts today and features the work of Bob Weber, a New Yorker cartoonist, marks a big break for a fledgling Young & Rubicam writer. His name is John Berners, and he is 25 years old. This effort is not only his first television commercials but also his first full campaign.

LEAD: Biederman & Company, after a competition that had involved seven agencies at the start, has held onto the Israel Ministry of Tourism account, which last year billed in the neighborhood of $3 million.

LEAD: The mystery of Terry Waite deepened today as the Archbishop of Canterbury said the Anglican envoy left instructions that no attempt be made to rescue him if he should be taken hostage in Lebanon.
LEAD: A weaker economy is largely reponsible for the flat profits being reported by the nation's leading corporations for the fourth quarter of 1986 and for the full year, according to analysts.
LEAD: ROCK OF AGES: The Rolling Stone History of Rock and Roll. By Ed Ward, Geoffrey Stokes and Ken Tucker. Rolling Stone Press/Summit Books. Illustrated. 649 pages. $14.95.

LEAD: The importance to corporate America of arms exports has declined under the Reagan Administration, even though the White House has made weapon sales an important part of its foreign policy, according to a new study by the Investor Responsibility Research Center.

LEAD: The medical director of the Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island said yesterday that two emergency room physicians had ''grossly mishandled'' the case of a patient who fell seriously ill and died in December after being treated only with a painkiller.
LEAD: California Democrats, a contentious lot within a contentious party, did something unusual at their state convention here this weekend: They tried, hard, not to pick fights.

LEAD: AMERICA'S CUP STARS & STRIPES VS. KOOKABURRA III, at Fremantle, Australia (TV - ESPN, 11 P.M.) BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. BULLETS, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS. SUPERSONICS, at Seattle, 10:30 P.M. (TV - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radion - WNEW 1130, 10:20 P.M.) COLLEGES: Catholic vs.
LEAD: Ted Fagan, a simultaneous translator for 30 years at the United Nations who became the organization's chief interpreter, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: Reebok International, a major shoe company based in Canton, Mass., has decided to take its ad business to Ammirati & Puris in New York rather than to Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulis in Boston. The billings are about $15 million.

LEAD: Salvadoran leftist rebels, apparently in a determined effort to assert their power, have shot several civilians in the last two months, according to diplomatic, military and human rights officials.
LEAD: These excerpts from ''News! From the Naval Observatory'' show Gail S. Cleere's whimsy: GROUNDHOG DAY

LEAD: ''I've understood since I was a child that people like us would always be in conflict with the political system, it's the whole society.'' Serafim Yevsyukov, just released from the Second Moscow Provincial Psychiatric Clinic. [ A6:3. ]

LEAD: HE became basketball's most celebrated player, a relentless workaholic whose mastery of the game sometimes leaves even his peers aghast. But as a young Hoosier in French Lick, Ind., just looking for a game, what Larry Bird relied on most was his finely tuned ears. ''I lived with my grandma, across the street from the old schoolyard,'' the Celtic forward recalled.

LEAD: A DIVIDEND increase by Sears, Roebuck & Company could be announced next Monday or Tuesday at a regular meeting of its directors. While the company is still declining to comment, reports of a small dividend rise, amounting to a possible 2 cents a share quarterly, are making the rounds as part of a new, more positive perception of the world's largest retailer.
LEAD: A name is a name is a name in most places, but not in this blue-collar suburb.

LEAD: Query: If there are 135,000 spaces in licensed day care centers, and about a million children whose parents are out of the house all day, what's the result? Answer: The rotten child care situation in New York City - hundreds of thousands of very young New Yorkers in unlicensed, unregulated facilities or, worse, left to take care of themselves.
LEAD: The 12 member governments of the European Community gave final approval Friday to a four-year agreement assuring American grain exports to Spain, officials said.
LEAD: Dennis Conner steered Stars & Stripes to victory in the second race of the America's Cup final today, leaving little doubt that the trophy he lost is within reach.

LEAD: The Cavani String Quartet -young, fresh and extremely eager -came to Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon, its thermostat turned high. As a result, Mendelssohn's A minor Quartet, Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's String Quartet 1974 and the Debussy G minor alternately thrived and stumbled under this unremitting heat.

LEAD: Patricia Anne Brown, a daughter of Gerald Robert Brown of New York and the late Carole N. Brown, was married yesterday to David Ethan Bronston, the son of Adele S. Bronston of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Jack E. Bronston of New York. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony at the National Arts
LEAD: Sitting in a darkened van with nine television screens and five men might not be most people's idea of the best way to see ''Me and My Girl,'' but for Betty Corwin it's kind of thrilling.

LEAD: A victory in Pasadena, Calif., by a New York team based in New Jersey is doing wonders for a Boston publisher. It is spurring sales of ''Giants Trivia,'' a book whose more than 600 questions about obvious events and obscure facts spanning more than six decades of team history can separate the casual fan from the true fanatic - even, it turns out, among the team's official historians.

LEAD: Health-Tex Inc., manufacturers of children's apparel, plans to shut down its production plants in the Maine communities of Portland, Brunswick and Gardiner, and lay off 900 workers. Another mill, at Petersburg, Va., will also be closed.

LEAD: The ability of many nuclear reactors now in operation to withstand earthquakes is unknown, because the builders analyzed the plants on the basis of their design instead of on how they were actually built, a design consulting company has complained to Federal regulators.

LEAD: According to its players, the Harvard hockey team that is ranked second in the nation has but one star. He is not a forward or a defenseman or a goalie. He is not the head coach. He is Ronn Tomassoni, an assistant coach and chief recruiter.

LEAD: Warren Kremer Advertising, which specializes in travel advertising, has been tapped by BWIA International, the airline of Trinidad and Tobago. The account had been handled by Ketchum Advertising/New York.

LEAD: Some Roman Catholic officials have begun to acknowledge reports from doctors, social workers and others that members of the Catholic clergy, like Americans in other sectors of society, are suffering and dying from AIDS.

LEAD: WALTER DAVIS and his picture-perfect jump shot have appeared in five All-Star Games. A sixth appearance is coming up Sunday at the Kingdome in Seattle. It is likely to be more meaningful than even his first in 1978.

LEAD: MUCH is being made in the publicity for ''The Wide Net'' of the fact that it represents the first television adaptation of a Eudora Welty story. And that does sound like something to look forward to, especially for those of us who have long been complaining about how American television ignores the bulk of fine American literature that might lend itself rewardingly to dramatization.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Ted Bates Worldwide has been assigned the $40 million Dole Food Company account. For a year it was handled by the William Esty Company, a sister agency under the Saatchi & Saatchi umbrella.

LEAD: CENTRAL Park has many users. When its curators drew plans to rebuild the Great Lawn and Belvedere Lake, they accounted for a symphony orchestra, an opera company and dozens of softball teams. Now they have to deal with a diminutive, four-winged constituency that they had not imagined a week ago. On Tuesday, an amateur entomologist, Charles Matson, disclosed that the lake was home to a variety of dragonflies and damselflies - insects of prehistoric appearance, rainbow irridescence and almost unearthly beauty.

LEAD: The Brazilian guitarist Luiz Bonfa slipped into town for his first New York shows in nearly a decade, a four-night engagement through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's. Mr. Bonfa, who composed the score for ''Black Orpheus'' with Antonio Carlos Jobim, is a subtle, masterly guitarist. His first set Thursday was a collection of exquisite miniatures as he carried lightly syncopated melody, harmony and rhythm on the six nylon strings of his classical guitar.
LEAD: Helen Marie Miller, 71 years old, wife of Representative Clarence Miller, Republican of Ohio, died Saturday at Northern Virginia Hospital in Arlington, Va.

LEAD: In response to the scandal over the manipulation of Guinness's stock price, Britain's Takeover Panel has drastically strengthened the rules governing corporate mergers to increase disclosures of share trading during takeover bids.

LEAD: Miriam Shire, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Michael Wien, a partner in the Manhattan law firm Austrian, Lance & Stewart, were married yesterday at Temple Rodeph Sholom in Bridgeport, Conn. Rabbi Israel Stein officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Shire of Bridgeport, and Barbara N.
LEAD: About 50 blacks attended church services without incident this morning here in an all-white county where turbulent civil rights confrontations occurred the previous two weekends.
LEAD: Like an army, an endurance racing car crew travels on its stomach. Given the quality of most race track fare, it's no wonder the crews often bellyache about it.

LEAD: OPEC's resolve in largely sticking to its month-old limit on crude oil production, along with other developments, has significantly increased the group's chances of stabilizing prices in the $18-a-barrel range this year, oil specialists in the United States believe.
LEAD: THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS. By Doris Kearns Goodwin. Illustrated. 932 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.95.
LEAD: Ski Patrol members helping trapped skiers from gondolas on Saturday at Mt. Snow Ski Area in West Dover, Vt.

LEAD: Treasury auctions will dominate the credit markets this week, starting with today's $13.6 billion sale of bills and continuing for three more days of note and bond auctions totaling $29 billion.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 2, 1987: MONDAY Airborne Freight Gannett Co Coastal Corp Standard Brands Paint Data-Design Labs Xerox Corp TUESDAY Adams-Mills General Housewares Bemis Co IE Industries CBI Industries Kansas City Pwr & Lt Coachmen Indus Monarch Mach Tool Federal-Mogul Corp Timken Co WEDNESDAY Carlisle Co Portland Genl Corp Ingersoll-Rand Thomas & Betts Peoples Energy THURSDAY Dover Corp Mercantile Stores Liberty Corp FRIDAY ASA Ltd.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Child-custody experts believe that the judge in the Baby M case will have to rely on New Jersey custody law and its primary tenet - the ''best interests'' of the child - to resolve the bitter tug-of-war over the 10-month-old girl.
LEAD: On the eve of quarterly note and bond sales totaling $29 billion, the Treasury market is stalemated, with interest rates little changed since the previous quarterly financing in early November.

LEAD: Teams of city building inspectors, police officers and even volunteer citizens patrolled the streets yesterday to insure that no demolition or construction occurred in single-room-occupancy hotels over the weekend when city protection of the hotels lapsed.

LEAD: ''Smithsonian World,'' the award-winning television program that has explored subjects ranging from American roadside architecture to the Panama Canal, could lose its financing and be canceled next fall, according to Public Broadcasting Service officials.

LEAD: Security officers in deserted departure lounge at Beirut Airport after Middle East Airlines, Lebanon's national carrier, announced a halt to all flights to the airport until further notice. Announcement said decision was taken because of advice from insurers that all insurance cover of M.E.A. passengers had been withdrawn.

LEAD: In certain parts of this, the nation's fifth largest city, the problem is not urban blight or urban angst. It is urban deer. Whole herds of white-tailed does, fawns and antlered bucks that seem to have bounded right out of ''Bambi.''

LEAD: More than 35,000 people marched silently today behind a huge banner reading ''For Peace and Against Terrorism'' in a protest against violence called by city leaders. On Friday, a car bomb exploded downtown, destroying a military bus, killing one officer and the bus driver, and wounding 28 military personnel and 13 pedestrians.

LEAD: Many Europeans, Israelis and other foreigners see Americans' reaction to the Iran-contra affair as a self-damaging wound, much as they viewed the uproar over Watergate. They shake their heads and wonder about our penchant for regicide.

LEAD: Christian Broda, a former Austrian Justice Minister who fought long and successfully for abolishing the death penalty, died today at his home, apparently after a heart attack, according to relatives. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: As best friends, brothers-in-law and mutual admirers, S. J. Perelman and Nathanael West frequently talked about collaborating on a project. So far as is known, only once did they share authorship over a sustained period. The result was a play called ''Even Stephen,'' a satire on book publishing and mating habits in academia.

LEAD: When President Reagan at the end of 1984 announced his program to protect the domestic steel industry, he said the ''expected result'' was that foreign steel would represent 20.2 percent of domestic consumption. In 1985, the first full year of the program, the foreign share was 25.2 percent, and last year it was 23.1 percent.

LEAD: Tourism a little closer to home is going to benefit LSGE Advertising of Avon, Conn., which has become the ad agency for tourism of the Connecticut Department of Economic Development. The department formerly did its own advertising.

LEAD: Union members will begin returning to work at USX Corporation steel mills, some as early as Monday, as the steelmaker begins the complicated process of resuming production after a six-month work stoppage.

LEAD: THE principal roles in ''Tannhauser'' changed hands Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera. William Johns took the title role and proved himself capable of getting through what may be Wagner's most arduous tenor part with plenty of voice left for the end. Indeed if he had sung the whole role as well as he did the broken-spirited ''Rome Narrative'' in the last act, one would look forward to hearing him again.
LEAD: It sometimes seems that this capitalist enclave is planning to take over China in just 10 years.

LEAD: Israel, reacting to the Senate Intelligence Committee report on the Iran affair, denied again today that it had been involved in diverting money from the Iran arms sales or transferring weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels.
LEAD: * American Can Co. is offering $100 million of Baa-1/BBB-rated 8 5/8 percent debentures due in 2007 at 99.30 to yield 8.70 percent, through Morgan Stanley & Co. They are noncallable for life.
LEAD: The Group of Five leading industrial nations have decided to put off a meeting they were considering to negotiate a solution for the fallen dollar.

LEAD: Visitors to the Statue of Liberty will have to pay $1 beginning today to see the monument. The fee, the first charged in the statue's 100-year history, was authorized by Congress as part of a test program.

LEAD: Benequity Holdings, a California limited partnership concentrating in the real estate business, on Friday called a tender offer for the company inadequate. The Renouf Corporation International, a subsidiary of the Renouf Corporation Australia Ltd., has offered between $28 and $30 a share for 1.5 million shares of

LEAD: The bleating of thousands of Merino sheep, the barking of Kelpie dogs, the swearing of shepherds and the whine of mechanical clippers punctuate shearing time on this sheep station 500 miles northwest of Sydney - the payoff of a year's effort by Malcolm and Nancy Robinson.
LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency is forcing its station chief in Costa Rica to take early retirement, intelligence sources said today.
LEAD: The Giants had hardly won Super Bowl XXI last Sunday before the questions came:

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending December Tuesday Leading Indicators December New-Home Sales December Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Unemployment December
LEAD: A 15-year-old youth was fatally stabbed while walking with two friends down Barnwell Avenue in the Elmhurst section of Queens last night, the police said.

LEAD: High Pentagon intelligence officials learned more than a year ago that private arms dealers were trying illegally to ship 39 American fighter planes and vast amounts of other weapons to Iran, but the officials did not stop the sales, according to confidential documents and participants who informed the

LEAD: Peter Vallone, the New York City Council majority leader, wants to strip the Board of Estimate of its budget-making authority. That could be done by the State Legislature, but if it isn't, the Queens Democrat hints he will seek a citywide referendum in November.

LEAD: Prayers in Troubled County About 50 blacks attended church without incident in Forsyth County, Ga., site of racial confrontations on two previous weekends. Page A14. Politics and Payrolls The trial of a high-ranking Queens Democrat has illustrated how political patronage affects the payroll of the State Legislature.

LEAD: They are not sure when they will fly, or how long it will to take to qualify the redesigned booster rockets for the space shuttle, but today astronauts begin months of intensive training for the first mission since the Challenger disaster.
LEAD: Kathy Postlewait sank a 6-foot putt for par on the first extra hole today to win the $200,000 Mazda Classic in a sudden-death playoff with Betsy King.
LEAD: The 1985 trial of James Diaz, a self-described drifter who was charged with the rape and murder of a Port Jefferson nurse, came under renewed scrutiny here this week.

LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan's repressive South Korean Government doesn't deserve much benefit of doubt. But Mr. Chun has cause now to be more reasonable. He desperately seeks success for the Olympics in his country next year and the legitimacy the games will confer. This gives the democratic opposition real leverage.
LEAD: ''You and I,'' the Wall Street arbitrager said last week to the takeover reporter, ''are out of business.''
LEAD: An American journalist has been detained in Iran, the Swiss Foreign Ministry said today.

LEAD: More than just a bit late, the Performing Arts Annual for 1986 has just been published by the Library of Congress. It is the first of what the library hopes will be yearly publications calling attention to the rich trove of holdings the library has in the performing arts.

LEAD: HE tossed his racquet in mock anger, whacked a tennis ball into the stands so a fan might have a souvenir, signed autographs between games, then playfully crawled under a table near the umpire's chair to hide when the number of autograph- seekers quickly multiplied.

LEAD: David Rivers scored all of his 14 points in the second half, including a field goal and two free throws in the final minute, as Notre Dame upset top-ranked North Carolina, 60-58, today. It was the fifth time in 13 years the Fighting Irish had beaten a No. 1 team at home.

LEAD: The Gates Corporation said Friday that it had completed the acquisition of the General Electric Company's battery business. Terms were not disclosed. Gates said the purchase includes G.E. plants in Gainesville, Fla.; Juarez, Mexico, and Newcastle, England. The agreement calls for G.E. to continue marketing rechargeable batteries for the consumer market under its name.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has sent out a new round of subpoenas that focus more narrowly on the role that the investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert played in several large transactions, according to lawyers and investment bankers with knowledge of the inquiry. The subpoenas are part of the S.E.C.
LEAD: ''I THINK the Fed is coming under immense pressure from the banks, and for some reason it's caving in,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer.
LEAD: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect.
LEAD: The country is preparing for a national election campaign, and the Government of President Suharto, declaring the event a ''festival of democracy,'' is taking no chances.

LEAD: Filipinos voted today on a new constitution that was seen as a test of strength for President Corazon C. Aquino. Officials said the turnout was heavy in what appeared to be the most peaceful nationwide vote in years.

LEAD: The shaken management of the J. Walter Thompson Company, subsidiary of the JWT Group, announced Friday that it had elected eight new directors, enlarging the board. Only two of its 20 seats had been emptied by the discharge of Joseph W. O'Donnell, chairman, and John E. Peters, president.

LEAD: To hear some people tell it, Amsterdam Avenue is blossoming like Columbus Avenue, its glitzier neighbor one block east. Others, however, say the avenue's working-class character and neighborhood feeling is being endangered by the sort of change that has rippled along many other Manhattan streets.
LEAD: One way to compete in a mature industry such as glass containers, says H. Ray Looney, is to put two medium-sized companies together to create one major competitior.

LEAD: In an effort to bring more money to the nation's farming sector, the Federal Government and industry groups are studying a plan that would enable small agricultural banks to sell billions of dollars in farm mortgages to Wall Street investors, according to officials and bankers.
LEAD: Yves Allegret, a prominent French film maker, died Saturday, his family announced in Paris. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: ROBERT F. McDONALD always thought of himself as a resourceful man. But as he waited last summer to find out who would be affected by yet another round of layoffs at the International Paper Company's offices in New York City he found himself paralyzed with fear.
LEAD: Arms dealers trying to sell American weapons to Iran as part of what came to be known as the Demavand project had extensive contacts with major financial institutions in Europe.

LEAD: The Holly Sugar Corporation, a leading producer of beet sugar, said Friday that Shamrock Holding Inc. and Brookehill Equities Inc. had expressed an interest in acquiring the company. Responding to requests for corporate information by Shamrock and Brookehill, Holly said it had hired Allen & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: The New York metropolitan area's three major airports, struggling under the weight of their own rapid growth, will soon begin extensive expansion and renovation intended to unclog roadways, speed crowds through terminals and reduce flight delays.

LEAD: THE program for ''Death of Eagles,'' now at the Neighborhood Group Theater, 420 West 42d Street, contains the following caution from the director: ''In viewing this play, one must not try to apply the rules of logic. The play is a dream . . . a black comedy that circles around and around, creating an absurd parody of America's proud military.

LEAD: Mayor Koch at Kennedy International Airport after returning from a nine-day vacation in Poland and Hungary. His trip included a visit with Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, and visits to two Nazi death camps. Mr. Koch called Poland an ''extraordinary'' country, populated by people of uncommon courage and said that he was persuaded that economic sanctions against Poland should be lifted.

LEAD: A drive to create a Columbia College scholarship in honor of Stuart Garcia, a leading member of the class of 1984 who died of AIDS last year, has won the endorsement of the Columbia University Senate.
LEAD: Florida will probably have to start letting convicts out of their cells unless something is done quickly to relieve overcrowding in the state prison system.
LEAD: An anonymous contributor has paid tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a $50 gift to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: The opening half of one of college hockey's best displays, the Beanpot Tournament, is scheduled for tonight in a sold out and loud Boston Garden. And the pairings are providential: Harvard-Northeastern and Boston College-Boston University.
LEAD: A husband and his wife were found shot to death with their hands taped behind their backs in their apartment in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MY 1986-1987 waterfowl hunting ended with a three-hour vigil in the stinging cold, during which several flocks of Canada geese glanced at our decoys, honked derisively and departed with the alacrity of a teen-aged churl asked by his mother to mow the lawn.

LEAD: Tom Skiffington, who sent out Akabir to an upset victory in the Bougainvillea Handicap here Saturday, came back 24 hours later to saddle Anka Germania and Chaldea to a 1-2 finish in the First Division of the Columbiana Handicap today at Hialeah Park.
LEAD: THERE are guests who like to entertain - and entertain and entertain - at parties.

LEAD: January is supposed to be a quiet month on Capitol Hill. Like two fighters in the opening round of a long match, Congress and the President generally circle each other warily, flicking verbal jabs, testing reactions, feeling out the ring.

LEAD: Skiing Girardelli Takes Combined: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg overcame a shoulder injury yesterday to upset Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland and win the men's combined title at the Alpine world championships at Crans-Montana, Switzerland. Earlier, Maria Walliser gave Switzerland its third gold medal by winning the women's downhill, beating a teammate, Michela Figini.
LEAD: Harold M. Florsheim, former chairman of the Florsheim Shoe Company, died here Friday. He was 87 years old.

LEAD: A tentative settlement has been reached in a dispute over the will of the artist Georgia O'Keeffe, and it calls for distribution of her works to museums and nonprofit institutions, attorneys say.

LEAD: Joe Barry Carroll had season highs of 43 points and 24 rebounds as the Golden State Warriors beat the Nets, 150-147, today in the first four-overtime game in three years in the National Basketball Association.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has its share of squabbles. Now, with the collegiate baseball season just getting under way, the official tournament baseball used in the N.C.A.A. seems to have become a political football.
LEAD: Sanford I. Weill said he has his top management lineup complete at the Commercial Credit Corporation, the company he is trying to lift by its bootstraps.

LEAD: Long before the Government called on the rebels recently to join in a cease-fire, the war in Afghanistan always paused on Friday mornings in the hills outside this village just beyond the Kabul city limits.
LEAD: The shiny new face of the San Francisco Ballet - under Helgi Tomasson's direction - has been shown off to huge success here this weekend.
LEAD: When Mary E. Kelly mentions that her Los Angeles law office is on the Avenue of the Stars, she chuckles.

LEAD: For the most impertinent bid of this decade, or indeed any other, South's action on the diagramed deal must be a strong candidate. Before considering the auction, however, study this question: is there any way to defeat five diamonds?

LEAD: THIS season, the New York City Ballet is once again offering an amiable music-appreciation lesson. On Friday night at the New York State Theater, Jerome Robbins's ''Fanfare'' returned to the repertory for the first time since 1978.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The economy's rate of growth increased sharply in January, according to a monthly report of the nation's purchasing managers.

LEAD: At Temple Sinai in Stamford, Conn., yesterday Joan M. Bloomfield, the director of strategic development for Newsweek Inc. in New York and publisher of Newsweek on Health magazine, was married to Robert S. Klanfer, the chief financial officer of the American Natural Beverage Corporation, manufacturer and marketer of Soho Soda in New York.

LEAD: Unbeaten in their last four games, and apparently content to skate with the defensive caution dictated by their coach, the Islanders finally are receiving some measure of satisfaction from their work. For a team that is rebuilding both its personnel and its confidence, that in itself is a small victory.

LEAD: Governor Kean may have to calm ruffled feelings among some Democratic leaders and convince members of his own Republican Party that he is not spending too freely when he presents his $10.1 billion state budget to the Legislature on Monday.

LEAD: Administrative charges of navigational mistakes that may have contributed to the sinking of a fishing tug on Lake Michigan last summer have been filed by the Coast Guard against the captain of a Yugoslav freighter and her American pilot.
LEAD: International Report

LEAD: IN the America's Cup, the men on the 12-Meters do essentially what men on sailboats have done for centuries. At the wheel, the skipper peers through the salt spray on his bronzed face. Nearby, his tactician and his navigator observe the wind. Other members of the crew handle the sails. And on the deck are the grinders, 20th-century galley slaves who toil together to turn the winches that move the heavy sails.

LEAD: The Pennsylvania Ballet and the Milwaukee Ballet have agreed to merge into one company that would perform in both places, with its first production scheduled for this fall, officials have announced. The merger is subject to approval by the boards of director of both organizations.

LEAD: Robert Edward Waterman, a research chemist associated with the discovery and mass manufacture of synthetic vitamin B1, died Saturday at his winter home in Delray Beach, Fla., following a brief illness. He was 87 years old and a resident of Morristown, N.J.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Population Commission - 10:30

LEAD: In October 1985, when the Reagan Administration was forcing down a jetliner carrying the hijackers of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, it turned in desperation to a part-time consultant to reach Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy by telephone.

LEAD: Robert B. Claytor was to have retired Dec. 31 as chairman and chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation, one of the nation's largest railroads. But circumstances forced him to stay on for a while more, and his last days in command are proving to be busy ones.

LEAD: A few years back, Assemblyman John C. Dearie recalled recently, a Bronx Democratic Party official approached him with a proposition: If he would hire two staff members selected by the party, the money to pay for them would be added to his legislative payroll.
LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road said yesterday that it was ready for a full rush-hour schedule for today, its first weekday of service after an 11-day strike.

LEAD: Donald McGauchie, a third-generation Australian wheat farmer, raced damaging summer rain as he harvested this season's crop on the sun-bleached plains here. But it is not the rain that is the cause of most of his displeasure these days: it is the United States.

LEAD: A car bomb exploded today near the Indian Embassy in Afghanistan, killing four people, the Kabul radio said. The embassy, which was damaged, is near Afghanistan's Interior Ministry and several other Government buildings.
LEAD: Johnny Miller, who said he had thought his winning years on the tour were over, surprised himself and just about everyone else today with his first golf triumph in nearly four years.

LEAD: THE Olympic career of Anita DeFrantz began with an invitation. She was walking across the campus of Connecticut College when ''a large man holding a long, thin boat'' stopped her and said she would be ''perfect'' for the sport of rowing.
LEAD: Each month, the 500 people on the United States Naval Observatory's mailing list get its newsletter, which states the positions of the planets and the stars in ways like this:
LEAD: One afternoon a few years ago a group of black women showed up in the Lafaytte, Ind., living room of Darlene Clark Hine, a professor of Afro-American history at Purdue University.
LEAD: The brother and sister-in-law of the fashion designer Albert Nipon were found shot to death in their oceanfront condominium Saturday morning, the authorities said.
LEAD: The Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant shut down automatically Saturday when one of two pumps that supply water to the plant's steam generators malfunctioned, authorities said.

LEAD: A week after his release from the Second Moscow Provincial Psychiatric Clinic, Serafim Yevsyukov's muscles still ache so badly he cannot put on his overcoat without help. His fingers tremble slightly, he has lost 25 pounds and he walks with evident discomfort.

LEAD: How should Americans view Howard Beach and Forsyth County, two recent reminders that racism remains alive in the land? The Rev. Jesse Jackson thinks these incidents must be seen in the larger context of class, not just racial conflict.

LEAD: Dan Jacoff giving his son, Ben, a push as they went sledding at Riverside Park near 104th Street. Today should be cloudy, with a chance of showers, and warmer, with temperatures reaching into low 40's. (NYT/Dith Pran)
LEAD: Larry Speakes, the departing White House spokesman, offhandedly revealed an illuminating fact in one of his farewell interviews.
LEAD: It's fitting that the final month of the Big East season will begin this evening with St. John's as the host to Georgetown at Madison Square Garden.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: No opera by a native-born American composer had reached the stage before William Henry Fry's ''Leonora'' played Philadelphia's Chestnut Street Theater in 1845. Fry's piece struggled toward New York and was finally heard here in 1858, but little more had come of it until the Bel Canto Opera company's performance Saturday night at the Fashion Institute of Technology Auditorium, 227 West 27th
LEAD: * Donald V. Gill has been appointed executive vice president at SSC&B:Lintas USA.

LEAD: Leaders of four of Pan Am's unions are offering to help the airline solve its financial problems if their members can get more equity in the company and are protected in the event of a merger or acquisition.
LEAD: Larry Speakes, the departing White House spokesman, offhandedly revealed an illuminating fact in one of his farewell interviews.
LEAD: It's fitting that the final month of the Big East season will begin this evening with St. John's as the host to Georgetown at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: The nation's regional telephone holding companies yesterday lauded a proposal by the Department of Justice that would permit them to enter a variety of businesses from which they are now barred.

LEAD: ''It is certainly heartening that reports from all over the country so far indicate the voting has been clean, honest, orderly and exceptionally heavy. This proves the maturity of the Filipino people.'' - President
LEAD: MANY species of mammals are disappearing from North America's national parks solely because the parks -even those covering hundreds of thousands of acres - are too small to support them.
LEAD: Jerry Peters of Lake Grove, L.I., watching a shot at a driving range that was open despite the blanket of snow in Cantiague Park in Hicksville, L.I. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)

LEAD: Gov. William A. O'Neill, carrying out a promise from his re-election campaign last fall, proposed today a sharp increase in state aid to cities and towns to help them hold down local property taxes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A poll of potential voters in the 1988 New Hampshire Democratic Presidential primary, made public yesterday, found former Senator Gary Hart of Colorado ahead and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts running second.

LEAD: Donald S. Lowitz, a Chicago lawyer who was the chief United States delegate to the United Nations Disarmament Conference here, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, American officials said today. He was 57 years old.

LEAD: Two pianists have won the 1987 Young Concert Artists International audition, and will be presented in recital next season at the 92d Street Y. They are Hung-Kuan Chen, 28 years old, a Taiwan-born citizen of the United States; and the Israeli-born Rina Dokshinsky, 20.

LEAD: When he first set foot inside the Dupont Plaza Hotel on New Year's Day, the day after it was ravaged by the most deadly American hotel fire in 40 years, Dan Garner saw only blackened rubble, charred debris and twisted metal, all covered with muddy soot and ashes.

LEAD: Warren E. Burger, the retired Chief Justice, urged members of Congress today not to block the pay raise for judges and other Federal officials that is scheduled to take effect at 12:01 Wednesday morning.

LEAD: A woman from Rye Brook confessed in a call early Sunday to the police that she killed her boyfriend in 1983 - a death initially ruled a heroin overdose, the authorities said yesterday.
LEAD: In the slanting sun off the Indian Ocean, horns of other boats serenaded Stars & Stripes's return to her dock with a 3-0 lead over Kookaburra III in the America's Cup final.

LEAD: Business productivity, a key measure of the nation's competitiveness, rose less than 1 percent in 1986 as efficiency gains by manufacturers since the 1981-82 recession began to fade, the Labor Department said today.

LEAD: Construction spending dipped five-tenths of 1 percent in December, the second consecutive monthly decline, as widespread weakness in private construction offset a sizable gain in governmental spending, the Commerce Department reported today.
LEAD: Edmund Pendleton, organist at the American Church in Paris for 40 years and a composer and choirmaster, died Friday at his Paris home, his family said today. He was 86.

LEAD: A trillion, for those who lose track of zeros, is a thousand billion. Use this amount to scale up the old quip - ''A billion here, a billion there, why pretty soon you're talking about real money'' - and you have a decent guide to today's economic plight.

LEAD: ANY sensible groundhog emerging from its burrow yesterday would have started packing for a warm vacation at a burrowminium someplace south. But which portable computer should it take along? Had the groundhog surveyed the portable computer marketplace last year, the choices would have been rather uninspiring.

LEAD: Dennis Leonard, who did what many thought was impossible when he pitched for the Kansas City Royals last season after a severe knee injury, retired from baseball yesterday. The 35-year-old right-hander, who ended nearly three years of rehabilitation by pitching a three-hit shutout in his first start last April, said his retirement was a mutual decision with the Royals' general manager, John Schuerholz.

LEAD: Damaso Garcia, a two time American League All-Star at second base, and Luis Leal, a right-handed pitcher, have been acquired by the Atlanta Braves from the Toronto Blue Jays in exchange for another right-hander, Craig McMurtry. . . . The Boston Red Sox have signed five players for the the coming season, including their ace relief pitcher, Calvin Schiraldi, and backup catcher, Marc Sullivan, General Manager Lou Gorman announced yesterday.

LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, said yesterday that it had lost $502.5 million in the fourth quarter, giving it a loss of $448 million for the year.
LEAD: A dogsled expedition that sought to repeat Roald Amundsen's historic journey to the South Pole in 1911 has turned back after almost reaching the Polar Plateau surrounding the South Pole.

LEAD: A coalition of Hispanic groups accused the New York City Transit Authority police yesterday of trying to cover up an incident in which the coalition said two women, seeking to ''clarify'' a dispute involving a friend, were beaten and arrested without provocation by transit officers on a subway train.

LEAD: Archaeologists at work at the Pensacola Naval Air Station are digging through what they believe may be the remains of a 17th century Spanish fort, part of the first European settlement in what is now the United States.

LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service is considering two new W-4 tax-withholding forms - one simpler and one more complicated than the existing form, according to Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas and chairman of a Senate Finance subcommittee that oversees the agency.

LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the Unted States dropped by 11 this week, to 826, according to the Hughes Tool Company's rig count released today. Last year at this time the count was 1,594.

LEAD: Diplomatic records of Soviet-American talks are being used by critics of the Reagan Administration's arms policy to challenge its assertion that the Russians only recently insisted on a narrow interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

LEAD: Former President Richard M. Nixon will challenge the legality of publishing many and possibly all of the 1.5 million Watergate documents the National Archives has prepared for release in May, his lawyer said today.

LEAD: Xavier McDaniel scored 20 of his 35 points in the second half and added a game-high 14 rebounds, leaving the Seattle SuperSonics to a 108-100 National Basketball Association victory over the Nets tonight.

LEAD: CERTAIN natives in Papua New Guinea, impressed by the shipment of consumer goods from capitalistic countries, are worshipers in what has been referred to as ''cargo cults.'' In the eyes of these people, the magical delivery of packages by sea and air can be brought about by imitating the rituals and habits of those representing so-called civilization.

LEAD: Iran and Lebanon have become swamps into which outsiders venture at their peril. This was well understood by Terry Waite, the Anglican envoy last seen in Beirut on Jan. 20. Indeed, he left instructions that no attempt be made to rescue him if he was taken captive. And every Western correspondent knows the risks of accepting even an official invitation to Iran, with its hostile regime of feuding clerical rulers.

LEAD: Three state Supreme Court justices today refused a request from the Governor that they step down pending an investigation into charges of judicial misconduct.

LEAD: LONG ISLAND RAIL ROAD workers, back on the job after the two-week strike, kept a careful eye out for any angry signals from rush-hour commuters Monday morning. ''They seem normal,'' said the conductor, Emmett Smith. ''They seem a little bit better than normal.''

LEAD: Q.Does the nightingale sing only at night? A. Contrary to popular belief, the nightingales sing at all hours -but mainly on clear moonlit nights several weeks after it flies north for the summer, according to bird watchers. Of the two species found in Europe, Asia, and northwestern Africa, the thrush nightingale, Luscinia luscinia, is more accomplished in song than the nightingale, Luscinia megarhynchos, which can sometimes lapse into croaks and chuckles.

LEAD: ''ONE TIME, ONE NIGHT,'' the most powerful song on Los Lobos' new album, ''By the Light of the Moon'' (Slash/Warner Brothers), telescopes several harrowing personal dramas into a canvas of American life that is at once tragic and mystically hopeful. Set to rolling, twangy country-rock in the mode of Creedence Clearwater Revival, its verses sketch a series of related vignettes, each presented in the clipped, unsentimental tone of a news item.

LEAD: THE mobile robot installed last month at the Orlando, Fla., semiconductor plant of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is unlikely to remind anyone of ballistic missiles or jet aircraft, its technological forebears. LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said the MIP Equity Fund, based in The Hague, would invest $5 million in the developemnt of Cetus's Western European subsidiary. The unit, EuroCetus B.V., will be based in Amsterdam. MIP Equity, which had played an important role in Cetus's decision to locate the unit in the Netherlands, is making a five-year loan at 6 percent interest in return for warrants to purchase 165,800 shares of Cetus stock at $03 each; the warrants may be exercised after one year.

LEAD: SKIING Zurbriggen Wins Giant Slalom: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland won the men's giant slalom today for his second gold medal at the world Alpine ski championships in Crans-Montana, Switzerland. Zurbriggen got a big break when Joel Gaspoz, who appeared well ahead, fell after hitting the 48th gate of the 50-gate track.

LEAD: THE purpose of better technology, as anyone knows, is to foster laziness and sloth among the populace. That's what's going on with the up-and-coming formats for prerecorded music, the cassette (which now commands considerably more than half the market) and the compact disk. While they've been coming into their own, popular music has encouraged basking rather than rocking out - a tendency that fits right in with the new technology.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH a home or apartment may seem to have plenty of closet space when you move in, all too often you later discover you need more. Enlarging an existing closet is rarely possible, but often there is room to build another. The easiest place to build an extra closet is in the corner of a room. That way you only have to build two walls for the new closet; the other two are already in place.

LEAD: Carl R. Rogers, a popular author and preeminent American psychotherapist whose influence has spanned decades, died Wednesday night of a heart attack after surgery for a broken hip at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif. He was 85 years old. Dr. Rogers, a psychologist, was known for developing the client-centered approach to psychotherapy, in which the therapist maintains an accepting and empathic stance toward the patient and lets the patient take the lead in the focus, pace and direction of therapy.

LEAD: President Reagan's loss of authority since disclosure of his Iran policy has brought renewed talk that our constitutional system is not working. LEAD: Friday BALINESE DANCE Midwinter Manhattan may seem a long way from the island of Bali, but this weekend the magic of this tropical paradise will be more than in the air. With opulent masks and exotic sounds, Islene Pinder's Balinese American Dance Theater will re-create a journey of demons and deities when the company performs ''Eden'' and ''Night Shadow'' at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace.

LEAD: HARD as it is to believe, the brilliant director of ''The Return of Martin Guerre'' has now made an idiotic comedy about a paleontologist, some women and some bones. The bones, being silent, have a definite advantage over the other players.

LEAD: President Andrei A. Gromyko told former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today that the latest nuclear test in Nevada was part of an American effort to sour relations with the Soviet Union, the Tass press agency said.
LEAD: Greater-than-expected demand from speculators and solid buying by foreign investors at the Treasury's 30-year bond auction yesterday caused prices of outstanding issues to rise sharply.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration has been rebuffed in its plan to convene a conference with six major allies to discuss coordinated responses to the continued hostage-taking in Lebanon, White House and State Department officials said today.

LEAD: Until June 1985, Dr. Brent M. Pratley was a part-time team surgeon for the Brigham Young University football program whose warnings against excessive use of prescription drugs had led B.Y.U. to tighten controls in the training room. Now he himself stands accused of prescribing - in some cases, indiscriminately so - excessive addictive medication to
LEAD: Corporations have given almost everything imaginable to nonprofit groups at one time or another. Now an internationally famous research center can be added to the list.
LEAD: Conflicting reports added to the confusion today over Terry Waite, the missing Church of England envoy who has been trying to negotiate the release of foreign hostages.

LEAD: Markets The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,200 in a surge of trading that also lifted broader-based market indicators to new highs. In a day marked by sharp price swings, the Dow added 10.26 points to close at 2,201.49. Volume was 256.7 million shares, the second-busiest session on record.

LEAD: Long Island's top government officials, holding what they called the first-ever ''summit meeting'' between the leaders of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, agreed today to work jointly to solve several regional problems.

LEAD: The Jack Kemp for President Exploratory Committee is backing a 1988 Presidential hopeful who is regarded by many Democrats and even some of his fellow Republicans as so conservative as to exemplify an earlier era in American political life. So when the committee announced the opening of its Arlington, Va., headquarters and the press phone number (247-1936) there, John Buckley, the Kemp press secretary, felt it necessary to add: ''There should be no historical inferences drawn from the final four digits of the press office's phone number.

LEAD: MORE than anything else, the various episodes of Woody Allen's ''Radio Days'' are held together by the music of the late 1930's to mid-1940's - the highly structured songs with sweetly genteel lyrics that not only provide background for the film but also establish its emotional center.

LEAD: George W. Woodruff, a director of the Coca-Cola Company for 49 years and a major contributor to education and medicine in Georgia, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Emory University Hospital. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: A Federal District judge ruled today that city officials in an Atlanta suburb must allow the Ku Klux Klan to stage a march Saturday. The judge, William C. O'Kelley, ruled that College Park, the suburb, must grant the parade permit to the white supremacist group. The town had sought to deny it unless the organization agreed to pay $3,085 for police overtime.

LEAD: Uncle Sam may soon sabotage St. Valentine's Day. The International Trade Commission is considering invoking sweeping penalties and duties on imported flowers, which could possibly double the cost of flowers sold on the streets of American cities. This is a nice example of the inane application of our trade regulations and of the idiotic system that could subjugate the interests of millions of consumers to the benefit of a few hundred farmers.

LEAD: WE still think of electronic music as a brand-new art form, but by now there are composers who have made a life out of it. Richard Teitelbaum, who presented a most appealing concert Wednesday night at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street, has been involved with electronics as a composer and performer for 20 years and counting.

LEAD: IT is an ordinary day in the Netherlands during January 1945, or a day as ordinary as an occupied nation can know. The Steenwijk family, having pulled down its blackout shades and had its paltry dinner, is at the end of a reasonably peaceful evening. Then shots are heard. A well-known and hated collaborator has been assassinated in front of the house next door, and his body has been moved to the Steenwijk's, who will now be held responsible for the crime.

LEAD: Wayne Gretzky scored his 50th goal of 1986-87 Wednesday night, in the 55th game of Edmonton's season. After only eight years in the N.H.L., Gretzky now claims four of the 10 earliest arrivals at the 50-goal plateau in league history. LEAD: The Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 is in peril. Almost alone among arms control agreements, it has helped prevent nuclear war, sharply curtailing the development of a dangerous mix of defensive and offensive forces. Now President Reagan appears ready to launch a double-barreled attack against the treaty.

LEAD: At a hearing Thursday by the House Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands, Representative Peter H. Kostmayer of Pennsylvania congratulated the National Park Service director, William Penn Mott Jr., for deciding not to charge people fees to see Independence Hall or the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia.

LEAD: A 25-year-old woman from Manhattan, Katherine Alexander, daughter of Shana Alexander, the journalist and author, plunged to her death last night, apparently in a suicide. The body was found in a yard behind the apartment building on Park Avenue at 59th Street where she lived with her mother. According to a police spokesman, Officer Peter O'Donnell, Miss Alexander, who had been under psychiatric care, apparently jumped from an upper floor or the roof of the building.

LEAD: Patrick Flatley of the Islanders, who injured his left knee Wednesday night during the team's 4-1 loss in Vancouver, returned to New York yesterday with suspected ligament damage. Flatley, who suffered the injury after being checked by a Canucks player, was examined by Vancouver's team doctors after the game and sent home on their recommendation.

LEAD: Recruits standing in formation during a drill on ''Zero Day,'' last day of a week of orientation lessons before regular training at the Police Academy on East 20th Street. Page B1. (NYT/Neal Boenzi)

LEAD: BALLET RAMBERT looked casual on Wednesday night. Too casual, perhaps. The program - the second in a weeklong engagement at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street - included three works by the British company's artistic director, Richard Alston. Everyone was amiable in Mr. Alston's ''Java.'' Indeed, to employ a slang term, the dancers even seemed laid back in this choreographic suite to old recordings by the Ink Spots.

LEAD: The Texas Eastern Corporation announced that Dennis R. Hendrix, president and chief operating officer, would be named to the additional post of chief executive, effective June 1, 1987. LEAD: ARQUA is a rustic village in northeastern Italy and the home of the 14th-century poet and philosopher Petrarch. It also is the name of an engaging new restaurant housed in a towering former commercial retail space in TriBeCa. Opened five weeks ago, it is quickly gaining a downtown following for its original and lovingly prepared pastas, herb-scented grilled entrees and homemade desserts.
LEAD: Dennis Conner took Stars & Stripes for a sail today.

LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that it was considering reducing its presence in Angola by selling a 9.8 percent interest in Angola's state-controlled oil production operations, in which it has a 49 percent stake.

LEAD: The fog of battle still swirls over the marshes around Basra.
