By the time Bob Bookman, a thoughtful, soft-spoken literary agent at Creative Artists Agency who was to sell the book to the movies, had unwrapped the package from New York, three teams of movie producers already had secret
LEAD: Sometimes the difference between the ordinary and the sublime is created by more than skill. Presence and charisma, intangibles possessed by only a few special athletes, are often more crucial.

LEAD: Feel in the mood for dancing on chairs and mattresses? Curious about a danced history of the American film? Want to know what happens when someone trips the light fantastic in electronically amplified tap shoes? It's going to be a lively week at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. Steve Krieckhaus, a Missouri-born choreographer who now lives in Philadelphia, is offering a program called ''Missouri Driver's License'' on Monday and Tuesday.

LEAD: Fiction Weeks This Last On Week Week List 1 1 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 2 1 2 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King.

LEAD: Venice will always be a city of mystery and intrigue, just as she was in those last desperate days of the Most Serene Republic at the close of the 18th century. One has only to walk her splendid fondamenti (canal walkways) or cross her magic bridges counting the shadows after nightfall to know that much.

LEAD: When summer comes to Bay Ridge Avenue in Brooklyn, people in the neighborhood often abandon backyards for air-conditioned homes to escape the stench from the nearby Owls Head sewerage-treatment plant.

LEAD: The State Department has told Congress that the United States economy and the military remain dependent on South Africa for 10 minerals and other raw materials that were not included in an import ban enacted last October.

LEAD: ACIRCUIT COURT jury in Jacksonville, Fla., has awarded Lindy Infante, the Cleveland Browns' offensive coordinator, $87,500 in a ruling that the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League breached Infante's contract in 1986. After more than two hours of deliberation Friday, the jury of four men and four women awarded

LEAD: One of the three or four most satisfying piano recitals to come this critic's way in the last few seasons was Peter Serkin's at the 92d St. Y, and now the best parts of it are represented on a new recording for New World Records (NW 344). Those are the knotty, intense Passacaglia (1936) of Stefan Wolpe, a work of steadily accumulating power; two clean-lined and inevitable sounding Stravinsky performances, and an engaging new three-part work by Peter Lieberson called ''Bagatelles.
LEAD: If a hotel can be something more than just the sum of all its parts, then the Beau Rivage in Geneva is one such place.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY's Housing Commissioner, Paul A. Crotty, says the city is taking steps to cooperate with private developers to encourage them to build middle-income housing, which he defined as housing for families with annual income between $25,000 and $48,000.

LEAD: TIRED AND DUSTY AFTER A DAY'S driving from the north, three men on a Yangtze River motorcycle pulled into the courtyard of the inn at Guanduping, a village in China's heartland province of Shaanxi. They stowed their helmets in the cycle's sidecar and moved toward a group of villagers seated at tables of hand-hewn slate.

LEAD: HEALTH-CARE costs are of vital concern to us all. As physicians, we recognize the public's desire that waste be eliminated and duplication minimized in the provision of hospital services. Yet we are fearful that the hastily drawn plans to consolidate hospital services in this region have not carefully assessed the facts, allowed sufficient public input or sought the views, guidance and assistance of practicing physicians in accomplishing those goals while maintaining the public interest.
LEAD: There are probably as many ways to experience music as there are pairs of ears to receive it.
LEAD: The Israeli Navy today reported seizing a cargo boat with 50 Palestinians described as guerrillas trying to sail to Lebanon.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: With all the talk of high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels in this country, how in the world can your magazine print such recipes as you did in ''The Homecoming'' (By Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, Food, Jan. 4), which contain the exact foods that the experts recommend against?

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: FACED with a growing shortage of foster homes, the State Department of Children and Youth Services has started sending teams of social workers into communities to recruit foster parents.
LEAD: Municipal and private hospitals in New York City are being forced to spend millions of dollars a year caring for babies who are awaiting placement in foster homes.

LEAD: BEAUTIFUL craftsmanship is a rare commodity these days, given the dearth of trained talent as well as the high cost of labor and materials. But when the occasional project arises in which machine-age techniques cannot possibly equal what is wrought by hand, there thankfully exists a small group of artisans carrying out their trade with the high standards that were considered commonplace generations ago.
LEAD: Tests conducted today on Liberace's tissue samples could not determine whether the flamboyant pianist died of AIDS, although he had been exposed to the AIDS virus, officials said.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Marano of Newark of the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Joy Marano to Edward Patrick Benigno, a son of Marie Cutrafello of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Quido Benigno of Yonkers. Miss Marano, a graduate of Montclair State College, attends the New York Law School.

LEAD: Caribbean Resorts Question: Can you suggest a family resort in the Caribbean with a reasonable price in winter that includes two meals and water sports and on an island with direct flights from New York? - L. K., Larchmont, N.Y. Answer: Many resorts meet these requirements, but the search can be narrrowed somewhat by referring not to direct but to nonstop flights.

LEAD: TEN years ago, nursing home and medical facilities for military veterans on Long Island were woefully inadequate, experts agreed. Studies showed that by 1990 the Island would have 86,000 veterans over the age of 65, the largest concentration in the state.

LEAD: The College of William and Mary, chartered by the King and Queen of England nearly a century before American colonists created the Constitution, staged a glittering ceremony here today for Warren E. Burger, chairman of the Constitution's bicentennial celebration.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Toepfer of Leonia, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Emelia Toepfer to Howard Roy Permut, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack G. Permut of Great Neck, L.I. A July 12 wedding is planned.
LEAD: An off-duty housing police officer was stabbed in the back yesterday during a traffic dispute in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: DAVID G. TRAGER, the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, seemed quietly amused as he thought about the criticism his panel had received following its two days of public hearings into the Suffolk County Police Department and District Attorney's office.

LEAD: WHY is it we hate prunes so much when we are children? Perhaps it is because they show up in such unflattering circumstances: stewed and served on top of cereal, or with custard for dessert. But prunes are transformed when they become adult food. They go wonderfully with rich winter meats such as pork, venison, duck or goose, and even with chicken or veal.

LEAD: THE THREE ALMOST identical-looking morsels of cream-white cheese are laid out side by side on the counter, surrounded by a dazzling display of cheeses from all over the world. ''But how can you say that West Coast stuff has a rounder, nuttier flavor?'' asks Steven Jenkins, the cheese evangelist of New York City's Fairway Fruits and Vegetables, his voice riper than Limburger with scorn and disbelief.

LEAD: PRESENTING his budget to the Connecticut Legislature last week, Governor O'Neill proposed spending $100 million on a financial commitment that could help guarantee ''the deeply rooted and inalienable right'' of every Connecticut resident to safe and affordable housing.

LEAD: FIVE years ago, in a move that was both surprising and tentative, the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company settled on a way to break up the Bell System's decades-old monopoly of the nation's telephone business. Now the Reagan Administration is offering proposals that would create a handful of miniature A.T.& T.

LEAD: New tactics are needed to help dropouts who return to school, including extending the four-year period in which students are expected to complete high school, according to a senior official of the New York City Board of Education.

LEAD: Saying that Labor Secretary Bill Brock's decision to require the states to issue field sanitation standards for farm workers was an abdication of authority based on a faulty view of federalism, a three-judge panel in Washington last week ordered the Labor Department to issue Federal guidelines that farm worker advocates have been petitioning or suing for since 1972.

LEAD: WHAT feels like an army running over your head, a freight train traveling across your neck and a thousand hands tickling your scalp? What disconnects your mind from your body, is stimulating and relaxing and leaves you tingling and refreshed? The answer, say enthusiasts, is the experience of Japanese head massage.
LEAD: A Loss of Confidence The confidence that characterized the Reagan White House in its first six years is fading, some close to the Administration say. Page 36.
LEAD: Nonstop Flight Recalled on Two Continents

LEAD: AWINTER storm, a series of bad decisions and sheer panic could have claimed the lives of two young men from Massachusetts who were climbing New Hampshire's 3,165-foot-high Mount Monadnock during the middle of last month.
LEAD: Long Island has several natural features that give it the unity and homogeneity that Sharon Honig-Bear finds lacking in ''Seeking the Pulse of the Island'' [ Opinion Page, Jan. 11 ] .

LEAD: THE ever-increasing number and variety of first-rate musical events in the county continue to be a boon to music lovers who prefer not to fight the traffic, parking and sundry other problems that go with concert attendance in mid-Manhattan. Events in the Bronx, on the other hand, are usually closer and more convenient.

LEAD: Nonsmokers breathed more freely in 6,800 Federal buildings around the nation last week, and the New York Public Health Council promised them the same relief in workplaces and public areas around the state.

LEAD: Playing piano four hands -that is, four hands at one piano - is part of the growing up of many musicians. In earlier days, before radio, records and television, it was also an integral part of the education of every music-lover. All symphonic and chamber music was published in four-hand versions so that amateur and professional alike could become familiar with the content of the scores, Most four-hand music, aimed at the amateur as it was, did not need a virtuoso technique.
LEAD: Since the Titan Missile Museum opened its doors here last May, more than 19,000 people have donned hard hats to venture into its subterranean world.
LEAD: In many political domains, nomination is tantamount to election; in the Bronx, it is beginning to seem that election is tantamount to investigation.
LEAD: An insect in the middle of Central Park and a proposal for two giant towers at the foot of it won favor in the eyes of city agencies last week.

LEAD: Waking early on a winter morning in Edinburgh, you may see stone pavements glistening under street lamps as cars and red double-deckers rumble along Princes Street, Princes Street's gardens a watery green despite overcoat weather. If it's clear, the moon may hang full in an inky sky, paper white in contrast to the yellow headlights playing on the fronts of buildings.

LEAD: Cryptoclearance, stretching beyond sprint distances for the first time in his career, dug in the way a promising 3-year-old is supposed to while running down Momsfurrari to win the $108,100 Everglades Stakes today at Hialeah Park.
LEAD: SEMPRE VIVOLO opened in Hauppauge in September. It was scarcely a premiere, for the restaurant is owned by an old trouper in the business.
LEAD: Every two decades in this century Tokyo has reshaped itself, and in the late 1980's it is doing so once again, with potentially significant consequences at home and overseas.

LEAD: IN THIS seat of Bergen County, where high-rise apartment houses and Victorian homes are the more-usual landscape, battle lines have been drawn in an unlikely spot: A 14.2-acre tract of virgin woodlands that is a nuisance to some and a garden spot to others.

LEAD: EUPHORIA has overtaken the oil markets in recent weeks, as the OPEC agreement on production limits has demonstrated a surprising staying power. Even the Soviet Union, never a particularly trustworthy partner in these matters, has promised to join the effort to scale back production. And just this week, the four American oil companies that make up Aramco agreed to pay a fixed price of $18 a barrel.
LEAD: In the 60-year history of contract bridge there have been two men, and only two, whose names have become household words.

LEAD: JESSYE NORMAN is gifted with a soprano voice of oceanic magnitude and power; she is also, at her best, a moving interpreter. Therefore, her Thursday evening recital at Carnegie Hall came as a distinct disappointment.

LEAD: As a 1985 graduate of Great Neck North High School, I feel it is appropriate for me to respond to ''No Parking.'' What exactly is the issue addressed? It is certainly not the lack of parking available to Great Neck students.

LEAD: Because of a production error, the Practical Traveler column in some copies of the Travel section today omitted a passage beneath the drawing. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LEAD: ONE of the enduring occupational hazards facing amateur photographers is the dread malady known as red eye. If you've never heard of it, don't worry: it afflicts pictures, not the person taking them.

LEAD: WITH cupids and lace and big chocolate hearts, I ask Long Island to be my valentine forever. LEAD: Five of 27 caribous brought to Maine recently in an effort to reintroduce the animal to the state have died, two on the trip from their native Canada late last year and three within two weeks after their arrival at a compound at the University of Maine in Orono, the project's director said.
LEAD: Communist negotiators announced Saturday that they would not return to peace talks or extend a 60-day cease-fire that expired at noon today.
LEAD: Much has been made of Providence's use of the 3-point shot. But this afternoon, Pitt showed the Friars a thing or two about scoring 3 points the old-fashioned way, with muscle.

LEAD: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, freely admits that he knows ''a lot more about the problems of dairy farmers than wheat, corn and soybean growers or farmers who raise livestock.'' Since Mr. Leahy has just become chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, his selective ignorance has suddenly assumed greater importance.

LEAD: THE football Giants may have been monopolizing sports fans' minds of late, and although the big men of the gridiron have been in the spotlight, a girls' basketball team here has been steadily gathering its own laurels.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Remaking the American C.E.O.'' (Jan. 25) is an unwarranted, unfair and simplistic attack on an entire class of mostly patriotic and hard-working American men and women.

LEAD: DONALD WATTS still shaves his head, and wears a thick headband on the court, making him look like the planet Saturn in sneakers. At the Dunlap Elementary School in Seattle, his name is Mr. Watts, but yesterday, for a few hours, he was Slick Watts again.

LEAD: ANYONE aware of the difficulties of Edgar Allan Poe's life must wish to see his reputation prosper. Yet he alone among the Immortals calls up the sort of smirk otherwise reserved for writers who are not only living but also local. Anyone who confesses an admiration for Poe learns quickly that he is not respectable, because he set out to create powerful responses in his readers by methods already conventional when he used them.

LEAD: WHEN Apple Computer Inc. was developing its Macintosh personal computer, engineers on the project sported T-shirts that boasted: ''Working 90 hours a week and loving it!''

LEAD: The governing Christian Democratic Party held a major demonstration here today, apparently in an effort to regain political momentum after months of sliding popularity.
LEAD: An 8-year-old Brooklyn girl, critically injured in a fire that had claimed three lives Friday, died early yesterday at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, Fire Department officials said.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about portfolio insurance misstated the current affiliations of Hayne Leland and Mark Rubinstein. They are professors of finance at the University of California, Berkeley Business School.

LEAD: As Ronald Reagan enters the final two years of his Presidency, his White House has started to lose the distinctive aura of confidence and control that contributed heavily to the many achievements of his first six years in office, according to White House insiders and Reagan supporters outside the Government.

LEAD: CAN an econometric model predict how resale prices in Manhattan residential real estate will rise or fall? The next few years will tell, because such an model has been established for the first time with data from M. J. Raynes, a large sales organization, and the help of Susan M. Wachter, an economist and associate professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

LEAD: An influx of soldiers to Fort Drum - expected to bring unprecedented growth to one of the state's most depressed areas - has squeezed the supply of housing here so tightly that advocates for the poor contend that rents have risen beyond the reach of many longtime residents.
LEAD: THE New York Power Authority's plan to put part of a 26.6-mile cable under the county to provide Long Island with cheaper electricity may meet stiff opposition from two local communities.

LEAD: Jill Trenary capped a remarkable comeback from a severe leg injury by upsetting the world champion, Debi Thomas, to win the women's title at the United States figure skating championships today.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York yesterday Dorita Hammond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. Clinton Hammond Jr. of Garden City, L.I., was married to James Sheehy Normile, a son of Margaret Sheehy Normile of Hampton Bays, L.I., and Clearwater, Fla., and the late Daniel Francis Normile.

LEAD: With less than two minutes to play in a game between the University of Hartford and Canisius last month, people were still filing into their seats at the Hartford Civic Center. Very late for the game? Yes. But still plenty early for the concert by Smokey Robinson, the singer, that was to follow the game.

LEAD: Should television carry advertisements for condoms? The question is part of a growing debate. In a recent speech in Washington, Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said that a worldwide AIDS epidemic in the next 10 years would be more devastating than the Black Plague. Meanwhile, there are heated discussions over sex education.

LEAD: AMBITIOUS MEN: Their Drives, Dreams, and Delusions. By Srully Blotnick. (Viking, $18.95.) Srully Blotnick, a business consultant and author, writes with his numbers instead of his heart. Mr. Blotnick, whose previous books are ''The Corporate Steeplechase'' and ''Otherwise Engaged: The Private Lives of Successful Career Women,'' here analyzes successful men.

LEAD: ONE of the last differences separating commercial banks and savings institutions in the state could disappear this year, if merger talks starting between the trade associations representing the two business groups are successful.

LEAD: Putting aside the guns and knives that played a sinister role in previous elections, Philippine voters gave President Corazon C. Aquino and her Government a ringing endorsement and new legitimacy last week.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SHE'S SO THIN THAT IF YOU touch her back you can feel the ribs, like ridges on a roll-top desk. He has a paunch. She likes to sit on a stool, her back ramrod straight; he drapes his body across a couch, assuming a languid, informal pose. She moves slowly, gently; talks softly. He moves quickly, his eyes alert to danger or intrigue, his voice booming with good humor, spiked by the energy of a hair-trigger temper.

LEAD: THE town of Greenburgh made an unusual proposal last summer - to switch two-thirds of its commercial zoning on 450 acres at 15 sites to residential use. It would do this in the hope of gaining some moderate-priced housing instead of more offices and hotels.
LEAD: THE Norwalk Symphony, forced two years ago to transfer from its home of 48 years to a building 15 minutes away, contends it has been losing money and subscribers since the move.

LEAD: Under a rule change drafted by the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, state and local officials could no longer prevent the operation of nuclear power plants. Officials in New York and Massachusetts, who have used the existing rule to block the operation of nuclear plants in their states, called the proposal ''outrageous.
LEAD: To the Editor: Steven Prokesch may well have redefined the acronym C.E.O.: Covetousness, Egoism, and Opportunism.
LEAD: WHEN the Ralston Purina Corporation sold its mushroom farm in Franklin four years ago, it said it was getting out of the business because the Northeast market was oversupplied.

LEAD: Police officials here said today that six disheveled children found in Tallahassee, Fla., might be the offspring of members of a little-known cult, but the officials said they had not ruled out the possibility of kidnapping.

LEAD: At The Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan yesterday Margot Courtney O'Mara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mowbray O'Mara of Greenwich, Conn., was married to Timothy Phillips Connors, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Phillips Connors of Englewood, Colo. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: It took four weeks and four free throws, but Fordham finally defeated Fairfield in basketball yesterday. In fact, the Rams won twice, and by the same 74-70 score.
LEAD: MOLECULES OF THE MIND The Brave New Science of Molecular Psychology. By Jon Franklin. 301 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

LEAD: Scores of urban areas in underdeveloped countries are growing at an explosive rate that may create severe economic and social strains, according to experts gathered at the United Nations this week for a population conference.

Another few feet and it would have created an international incident.

LEAD: The father of a 13-year-old boy who committed suicide at home in 1984 has filed suit against school officials here, charging that teachers and administrators should have known the boy was troubled and likely to harm himself.

LEAD: Plans to stage a mock surprise attack on a group of Jewish teen-agers to dramatize the dangers of terrorism were discarded Friday after objections by parents and the Israeli Consulate to surprising the children.
LEAD: Ideologues on both the right and left are using the results of the Senate elections in November to draw considerably different conclusions about which way the nation is heading politically.

LEAD: A new chapter was written last weekend in an ongoing shaggy-paw story concerning the burgeoning value of a rare furniture style. The chronicle - involving Philadelphia furniture made for Gen. John Cadwalader, a colonial patron of the arts and Revolutionary War hero - was advanced at a New York auction when a 200-year-old wing chair with furry looking feet and a frame riddled with nail holes was sold for the highest price ever paid at auction for a piece of furniture - $2.75 million.
LEAD: Illegal aliens who are not eligible for legal status under the new immigration law are migrating from the United States to Canada in substantial numbers.

LEAD: MASSAGE has had a tenuous link with medicine for years. Nurses traditionally administered back massages to soothe the aches of bed-ridden patients, and even today many nurses and physical therapists study massage techniques.

LEAD: LAST year, when the two C.P.A.'s planning to buy B. Altman & Company's retail stores took their first close look at the 121-year-old department store chain, they went into a state of shock. The merchandise mix, the huge numbers of non-sales employees, even the amount of office equipment in use, all seemed more attuned to a company seeking a tax loss than one looking for a profit.

LEAD: I read and reread the article ''No Parking'' [ Long Island Journal, Jan. 11 ] in disbelief. As a student of the school I must set the record straight.

LEAD: VIRTUALLY every economist we have heard from and most of the publications and sources we consult in monitoring and anticipating the progress of the Long Island economy have told us that 1987, like 1986, will be another good year for our region.

LEAD: Thirteen months ago, Mack Trucks, long a mainstay of this city's economy, threatened to move its biggest assembly plant out of Allentown unless the United Automobile Workers agreed to a long list of economic concessions.

LEAD: The article about the problems that Great Neck North High School students have in finding parking spaces for their Mercedeses, Saab turbo convertibles and other sports cars distresses me greatly. Other world problems - hunger, the Middle East conflict, arms control, etc. - are really rendered pale by comparison.

LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN'S proposed $10.18 billion budget for the coming fiscal year contains increased financing for education, prisons, welfare and health services, but pressures for still higher spending continue to grow faster than the state's ability to pay for new programs.

LEAD: WHOEVER said ''take care of the small things and the big things will take care of themselves'' was seriously naive. That doesn't mean, however, that small things shouldn't be taken care of. LEAD: WHEN the building inspector and Zoning Board of Appeals in Groton, Mass., refused to let Thomas Hefele build a house on his property in 1985, he struck back at what he viewed as ''arbitrary authority.''

Baker, the Treasury Secretary, stepped off his plane into the marble-covered royal entrance of the world's biggest airport. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE state's Board of Public Utilities will not challenge a $7.7 million American Telephone and Telegraph Company rate increase that took effect last Sunday on long-distance calls made within New Jersey.

LEAD: I am responding to Shirley Becker's letter to the editor [ ''Let Nature Take Care of Swans,'' Jan. 18 ] regarding the Jan. 4 article ''Controls on Swans Proposed.'' I share her love of swans, but her conclusion to ''let nature take care of overpopulation'' may be a bit naive. Will nature be able to take care of the overpopulation?

LEAD: AT the Gettysburg cemetery, the Abraham Lincoln of Gore Vidal's novel barely gets through his first sentence - about the events in America ''four score and seven years ago'' - when the young Presidential secretary, John Hay, cynically observes that such rhetoric ''will please the radicals.'' Though the national commitment to the noble notion that ''all men are created equal,'' particularly in its Civil War, black-white context, is thereby dismissed, the Gettysburg Ad-dress itself is not.

LEAD: As most major record companies continue to shrink away from even a token commitment to contemporary music, we must rely increasingly on smaller labels to document the sounds of our time. There is Composers Recordings Incorporated, of course - or CRI, as it is customarily abbreviated - at 170 West 74th Street, New York, N.Y.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The venerable saying that there is more than one way to skin a cat has not lost its validity. In audio, for example, different approaches often lead to the same end, as in the case of two currently popular receivers - one by Nakamichi, the other by Yamaha. They have been attracting attention because they confront audiophiles with contrasting design precepts.

LEAD: In Chicago, it used to be routine police practice to sweep up large numbers of young black and Hispanic men on disorderly conduct charges, hold them overnight and release them the next day without prosecution. In 1982, the American Civil Liberties Union challenged the practice in Federal court. In 1983, when Harold Washington took over as Chicago's first black mayor, the city entered into a consent decree to end the sweeps.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce McBratney of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Carroll McBratney to Franklin Bogue Wallin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin W. Wallin Jr. of Asheville, N.C. The wedding is planned for May.

LEAD: SINCE 1983, the Standard & Poor's 500 index has shamed many money managers. For each of the last four years, the majority of them has failed to do better than the popularly followed index. Corporate executives who hire money managers to run their pension funds, said Byron R. Wien, investment strategist at Morgan, Stanley & Company, ''have lost confidence in the profession.
LEAD: Israel's universities, the reputation and achievements of which have been a source of national pride, are facing a severe financial crisis.
LEAD: The absence of war between India and Pakistan does not mean that they are ever at peace.

LEAD: In this age of merger mania and cost-cutting to protect profits, more and more executives are finding themselves adrift prematurely, but few of them have the sense of self that Richard B. Elsberry displays in his article ''Set Free'' (About Men, Jan. 4).

LEAD: To members of a loosely knit group called Lesser Seattle - dedicated in humor to keeping the largest city of the Pacific Northwest tourist-free and underwhelmed - last year was a nightmare. Vancouver's Expo 86, a few hours to the north, and a shower of superlatives from several national travel guides helped to bring a record number of visitors to the far edge of America.

LEAD: A professor at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., embroiled in controversy since he told students in 1983 that Zionism is a form of racism, has been denied tenure by the Chancellor of the State University.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The college game, unlike professional basketball, has never suffered the sort of slump warranting significant rule changes. Moreover, even if such rule changes were necessary in college basketball, the current 3-point rule would still be inappropriate.
LEAD: MARTIN SIMON is not a woman.

LEAD: THOSE who look forward to Valentine's Day not for the flowers, hearts or romance, but for the opportunity to delve into boxes of bonbons can indulge themselves at two chocolate-oriented events this week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The market for what is becoming known as urban archeology - an old Coca Cola sign or a 1930's refrigerator - continues to grow, and downtown galleries specializing in such merchandise help interior designers looking for kitsch or smoke-screened nostalgia.

LEAD: Federal agents seized $17.7 million in counterfeit $100 bills last week in California and Idaho in what the Secret Service called the largest seizure of bogus money in United States history, the authorities said.

LEAD: Workers preparing bags of food to be distributed to those who were standing in line outside Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center. About 10,000 people were to receive cheese, rice, honey, butter, flour and milk. The hospital has distributed more than two million pounds of Government food in the past four years.
LEAD: Joey Mullen scored one power-play goal and assisted on another tonight as the Calgary Flames defeated the Islanders, 4-1. Mullen's goal was the 199th of his National Hockey League career.

LEAD: ALL CONVERSATION CEASED at a sumptuous Paris ball when the Duchess of Windsor made her entrance. It was 1957, and the Duchess was wearing a dazzling necklace, composed of rows of large cabochon emeralds and diamonds, which everyone in the room began loudly admiring. Everyone, that is, except the

LEAD: ''I WAS the first shark watcher,'' said Arnold Minsky of Brookville. But don't look for the 48-year-old Mr. Minsky in the waters off Montauk, chumming for great whites. Look for him - figuratively speaking - on Wall Street, trolling for the sort of sharks inclined to feed on stock as they raid tempting targets in corporate takeovers.

LEAD: FOR decades, as a conservative foothold in the industrial Midwest, Indiana relied on low tax rates and a laissez-faire tradition to lure and keep businesses. But in the recession of the early 1980's, unemployment rose, productivity declined and a series of plants closed, stunning a state that had seemed immune to such troubles.

LEAD: John McEnroe would prefer that the line on the graph charting his progress was always moving upward, toward what he feels is his untapped potential. Invariably, though, there will be plateaus and even a step or two backward to contend with, times when he will wonder whether he has already played his best tennis.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The blizzard makes the Swiss flag outside Ernie Blake's window at Taos Ski Valley snap like a loose jib.
LEAD: IT didn't take long for Garie Jean Mulcahey of Stamford to realize that she had to find a way to channel her young son's energy, which was being manifested in a number of unusual ways.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo yesterday named the members of his Task Force on Bias-Related Violence and instructed it to ''begin the task of developing specific solutions'' to the kind of racial violence that erupted in Queens in December.

LEAD: Take yesterday's disco rhythms, add a slightly flat British singer, and the result can be a pop hit. That's the formula that has made the Human League a regular entry on the pop Top 40, most recently with ''Human,'' a Philadelphia-soul-style ballad about infidelity written by the band's producers, Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis.
LEAD: When two descendants of royalty fought it out recently for the mayoralty of Palm Beach, Fla., the main issue appeared to be which of them had the most common touch.

LEAD: The engagement of Nancy Anne Rachael Haas and Philip Velie Jenks has been announced by Dolores Marie Lyons of Ipswich, Mass., mother of the future bride. Mr. Jenks is a son of Thomas Story Jenks of Chadds Ford, Pa., and the late Damaris Velie Jenks and a great-grandson of the late John Deere, founder of Deere & Company, the farm-equipment manufacturer.

LEAD: A new report has warned that the high-technology area south of here is not prepared for a ''catastrophe'' that could result from a major release of highly toxic gases in an earthquake, fire or traffic accident.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John W. McEnroe of Summit and Stone Harbor, N.J., have announced that their daughter Maureen Patricia McEnroe and Brian Joseph Harkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Harkins of Montvale, N.J., are to be married March 21.

LEAD: By week's end, President Reagan's supporters and his opponents were debating whether the scorecard reflects the White House's political vulnerablity or merely political miscalculation. But there was little disagreement about the bottom line. In the assertive 100th Congress's first month, victory in the battle over control of the national agenda has gone to the legislators.

LEAD: WHO says fashion designers don't have a sense of humor? Take the skirts pictured here. Just kidding. Actually these skirts are exactly what fashion needs, a good-natured poke at the serious functionalism of much of today's women's wear.

LEAD: Nullifying an Amendment Question: About 50 percent of the residents bought their apartments when our building was converted to a co-op last year. As part of his negotiations with the tenants' association, the sponsor agreed not to apply for major-capital-improvement rent increases for repairs he was planning.
LEAD: THE MAKING OF THE ATOMIC BOMB By Richard Rhodes. Illustrated. 886 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.
LEAD: 'I SHOULD have listened to my numerologist. She said, 'Stay out of Westchester County; it adds up to death and decay.' ''

LEAD: In his article ''Science on the Track of God'' (Jan. 4), James Gleick searches for ''the evidence of design that cannot be explained away,'' and seems frustrated because ''science does eventually manage to explain.'' There is some confusion here, and it revolves around the word ''explanation.'' Science is made up of theories.

LEAD: Once more, we are treated to puffery of yet another macho-Democrat - Sam Nunn, whose philosophy amounts to Reaganism without Reagan. Notably missing, by the way, is his sometime espousal of the draft, an electoral disaster at least as potent as any ''tax-and-spend'' tag.

LEAD: It is too short! Players are averaging more points than they should be. Larry Bird and Chris Mullin would have averaged over 40 points a game in college with this line's ridiculous distance from the net. Players do not show that they are capable of playing in the N.B.A. by scoring from this distance.
LEAD: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has asked the members of the Charter Revision Study Commission to give special attention to 11 specific subjects. These are:

LEAD: A PENETRATING, bone-chilling wind was blowing as Mel Goldstein got into his car at 3:45 one recent morning to drive to work over snow-covered roads. Given the hour and the weather, it seemed like a depressing way to start a day.

LEAD: ''IN the early 1980's, we were hurt quite a bit by cutbacks from Federal sources,'' recalled Gregory Iffrig, director of administration for Missouri's division of parks. The cuts came, he noted, not only in direct grants-in-aid, but also in work programs like the Youth Conservation Corps, which Missouri depended on for help in the upkeep of its 103,000 acres of public recreation and wilderness land.

LEAD: This is a Valentine to the Giants and Giants' fans, from one who had the good fortune/misfortune to not only ''own'' the Giants, but love them. After 23 years, I am finally patching up the pieces of a long-broken heart.

LEAD: Aseven-nation omnibus issue arranged by the Intergovernmental Philatelic Corporation of New York leads off what is expected to be a large-scale program to mark the Chagall centennial year. Marc Chagall, the famed artist who spent most of his life in France, was born 100 years ago on July 7 in Vitebsk,
LEAD: THE setting is an Internal Revenue Service office.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Boyd of Weston and Chilmark, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Catherine Boyd to James Wyatt Spink, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William O. Spink of Mount Sunapee, N.H. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: One year ago today, Diane Elsroth, a 23-year-old stenographer from Peekskill, N.Y., who was staying at the Yonkers home of her boyfriend's parents, took an Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule for a headache and went to bed.
LEAD: Westminster, the most prestigious of the more than 1,000 all-breed dog shows held annually in the United States, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow.

LEAD: The engagement of Amy Fraser Zinsser and Robert Ferreira has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Knowlton Zinsser of New York and Old Black Point, Conn. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Anthony Ferreira of Seekonk, Mass., and Jamestown, R.I.

LEAD: An unemployed construction worker hit the road to get a job, standing nearly three hours in the safety zone of one of America's busiest expressways holding a sign that read: ''Family Man Needs Job.'' It worked. ''I'm just a regular guy trying to live the American dream and have a job,'' the man, Art Fosle, said Friday night in a telephone interview from his home in Sauk Village, a

LEAD: FOR THE BLACK ARTISTS, MUSICIANS, POLITICIANS and entrepreneurs who converged on Harlem in the 1920's and created what came to be known as the Harlem Renaissance, it was a time when everything seemed possible - a time, as a former resident recalled, when ''it was truly bliss to be alive.'' Not only did blacks take pride in their African heritage, pride in black folklore, pride in just being black, but it also seemed natural to believe that art could bridge the formidable gap between the black and white worlds, that excellence and merit could produce social change.
LEAD: Freaks MGM Home Video 113 minutes. $59.95.
LEAD: Diane Harris, a doctoral candidate in classical archeology at Princeton University, and William I. Kline, an architect at Hartman-Cox Architects in Washington, plan to be married April 5.
LEAD: ''When will we see a real correction? Only when the perception of the market changes.'' - Monte Gordon, research director, Dreyfus Corporation, on the surging Dow.

LEAD: ''Question Authority,'' the command of an irreverent, red-lettered bumper sticker from other days, is securely stuck to the front wall of the largest classroom at the Antioch Law School here, too high over the gritty, paint-peeled lecture hall to be removed without a ladder.
LEAD: Last month, eight centuries after Maimonides's advice on gentle social discourse, rival politicians had a scuffle in Parliament that left one wearing a sling.

LEAD: Far too much is made out of shreds of circumstantial evidence in Judith Miller's article. Who is to say that the Soviet-made arms used in the terrorist attacks did not come from somewhere else, perhaps even from Israel's enormous stocks of captured Soviet-made weaponry, some of which have reportedly found their way to the

LEAD: We were sitting around the table after a fine stout lunch, a bunch of us - a couple of Marios, four Bobs, Sam, old George of course, Elizabeth, one Howard and a fellow nobody had expected to be there, Dale.
LEAD: The article ''Taking a Different Approach on Reading'' [ Jan. 4 ] contained a statement that unfortunately continues a widely held myth about reading instruction.

LEAD: The case was limited, but Lochner v. New York, the Supreme Court's 1905 decision invalidating a restriction on bakery working hours, remains a symbol of its age. The dissenters in Lochner, and similar cases that followed, eventually prevailed. Excerpts follow.
LEAD: Ten French medical workers in Somalia, who were captured two weeks ago by Ethiopian-backed rebels, were turned over to France here today.

LEAD: KIMBALL WHEELER'S recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night offered decent, professional-level music-making, amplified considerably by glamour and personal charm. Ms. Wheeler possesses a mezzo-soprano voice of moderate size, dark hue and naturally affecting timbre. Unfortunately, on Wednesday night her upper register was not secure, her pitch sense lacked authority, and her interpretations were careful rather than inspired.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mrs. DeWitt Lounsbery Jr. of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Abigail Lounsbery, to William Rushing Hemphill Jr., the son of Mrs. Hemphill of Austin, Tex., and the late Mr. Hemphill. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: In the ever-mounting struggle between a livable city and the real-estate industry's relentless desire to fill every nook and cranny of midtown Manhattan with a skyscraper, even a well-designed building can be a mixed blessing. A handsome object, in other words, is not in and of itself enough to justify more crowding, more shadows, and more pressure in a part of the city that is already bursting at the seams.

LEAD: DINO DAYS The Yale Peabody Museum has given new meaning to ''The Three B's.'' Bach, Beethoven and Brahms will be displaced, at least from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Thursday through next Tuesday, by baroque, bagels and brontosaurus.
LEAD: LOVING LITTLE EGYPT By Thomas McMahon. 273 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

LEAD: ANY lingering doubts that the Metropolitan Opera has become a director's house should be dispelled by the staging of ''Manon'' that made its debut Friday evening. Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, who produced and designed this production, has so encrusted Massenet's pathetic love story with stylistic sequins and painterly images that poor

LEAD: MAUREEN McGOVERN is not exactly foregoing the potential of her four-octave voice or the coloratura effects of which she is capable in her performances at Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street), where she will perform this afternoon and Thursday night through next Sunday afternoon.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your article called the ''Vanishing Supply of Rentals'' on Dec. 28 quotes an executive of a realty management firm complaining about the 6 percent cap on M.C.I. rent increases as a disincentive to landlords contemplating major capital improvements to a building. He felt that way since a 6 percent increase of an average $500 rental would be only $1,800 over the course of the 5-year amortization period that is used (6 percent times $500 times 60 months).

LEAD: Margot Treman Ross and Paul Augustine Kunkel 3d plan to be married in the summer. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Joseph Hill Williams of Tulsa, Okla., and Llewellyn Gerard Ross of New York. Mr. Kunkel is a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Minster Kunkel of Harrisburg, Pa.

LEAD: To the Editor: Frederick Thayer [ Letters, Jan. 18 ] says that when the Environmental Protection Agency and the Surgeon General join hands to argue that environmental tobacco smoke is a danger to non-smokers, the public should suspect a conspiracy. A more normal reaction would be to have increased confidence in the assertion that passive smoking is a major health hazard.

LEAD: THE DUCK AT THE DOOR FROM the outside, Susan Rosenberg's home in Merrick looks like many suburban split-levels. But when you knock on the glass storm door and a quacking black duck waddles toward you in greeting, it's obvious that all is not exactly as it seems.
LEAD: Traffic flowed smoothly but drivers were irritated after a 25-cent toll increase went into effect yesterday on five New York bridges and tunnels.
LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed Martha Elliot's ''On Safari With the Children,'' (Travel, Jan. 4) since my two boys and I had taken a safari through Kenya and Tanzania in July 1985.
LEAD: John Leypoldt, a former place-kicker for the Buffalo Bills, died today of an apparent heart attack. He was 40 years old.
LEAD: Sammy Chevalier is the birdman of Kennedy International Airport.

LEAD: The police said today that a Lebanese-born businessman believed to be an American citizen had been kidnapped by gunmen who might be holding him for ransom. But relatives said that he had been freed and that he was a Lebanese citizen only.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor: Don Mattingly is a great baseball player, clearly the dominant figure in his sport and surely worth $2 million of George Steinbrenner's money. But let's not get carried away.

LEAD: Fourteen years ago, on Feb. 5, 1973, Jack Kleinsinger, then a 36-year-old Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York and an enthusiastic jazz fan, became a jazz impersario. Although he had never presented a concert of any kind before, he booked the tiny theater De Lys on Christopher Street for two nights, one month apart, to put on programs he called ''Highlights in Jazz.

LEAD: Deborah Elise Ziegler, a vice president of mortgage securities trading for Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, and Lawrence Evan Hilibrand, a managing director in the government securities department at Salomon Brothers in New York, plan to be married March 22.

LEAD: Throughout their histories, colleges have offered a 3.0 for every B a student earns, and but a 2.0 for the less-difficult-to-get C. Seems only right that these principles apply to basketball. Keep the 3-point basket. PETER FILICHIA New York
LEAD: After 222 years, archeologists have again entered the Villa of the Papyri at Herculaneum, dreaming that it holds undiscovered treasures.
LEAD: The Coast Guard has called off an air-and-sea search for 10 people missing from a fishing boat that capsized Thursday. The body of one man has been found and the rest are presumed dead.

LEAD: A New Jersey food distribution company is recalling its three-pound canned hams from stores in six states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, after Federal inspectors found that some of the hams had spoiled, the Agriculture Department announced today.

LEAD: United States courts long ago established an official Chilean role in the 1976 murder in Washington of Orlando Letelier, an exiled opponent of President Augusto Pinochet. But the case has never been resolved because Chile has refused to extradite the suspects.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your article titled ''Rebuilding From the Grass Roots Up'' on Dec. 21 mentions that homes on a redeveloped Charlotte Street in the South Bronx will be sold for $100,000. It then states that these are ''low- and moderate-income projects.'' Since when are $100,000 houses classified as low- and moderate-income?

LEAD: Last month, Sylvia Deutsch was sworn in as chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, the agency with broad responsibility for shaping the city's physical environment through zoning and planning. Mrs. Deutsch was a member of the commission from 1972 to 1981, and then became chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, the body that reviews requests from developers and property owners for hardship relief from zoning rules.

LEAD: YEARS ago, when I was attending Northwest Elementary School in Hartford and Valentine's Day rolled around, it seemed to be common knowledge among classmates that I was born on that day. Decades later, I have never rationalized whether cards for me were tied to my birthday or to the day itself.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. G. Estabrook Kindred of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Skytop, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dorothy Estabrook Kindred to David Edward Yewer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Yewer of Chenequa, Wis. The wedding is planned for next month.

LEAD: A group of Chinese and Americans has set up an organization for the defense of Yang Wei, the first United States-educated Chinese student reported arrested in China's recent crackdown on political dissent.

LEAD: FICTION Weeks On List 1 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 2 3 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) In the America of the future, a k a the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned to them.

LEAD: Teen-agers living in poor neighborhoods give birth in significantly higher numbers than those in the rest of New York City, in some cases accounting for more than one-quarter of all births in a neighborhood, a mayoral panel has found.
LEAD: A GROUP whose decisions could influence the course of county government well into the next century has begun a two-year task of revising the County Charter and Administrative Code.

LEAD: THE Administration made a big deal out of eliminating tax loopholes with the Tax Reform Act of 1986, but nonetheless the new law, which it pushed for so hard, left a few loopholes - or tax incentives, as proponents prefer to call them.

LEAD: REPORTS that the United States shipped arms through Zaire to the rebels in Angola have complicated Mobutu Sese Seko's delicate balancing act in southern Africa. With nine countries as neighbors and with an economic dependency on South Africa, Zaire's President tries to give the appearance of being everyone's friend.

LEAD: ON what began as a quiet December morning three years ago, a truck turned into the seafront American Embassy compound here, veered into an administration building and exploded. Another suicide truck-bomber hit the French Embassy, and there were explosions at five other sites in this comfortably wealthy little Gulf emirate, including buildings used by the Raytheon Corporation, which was installing American-made

LEAD: By loosening restrictions on the seven regional telephone companies known as Baby Bells, industry analysts believe that last week's Justice Department proposal would encourage the development of exotic communications technologies, providing customers with a variety of new services.

LEAD: THOUGH there are hundreds of massage schools nationwide, one obstacle to massage's acceptance in medicine -and in mainstream America - has been a lack of accreditation standards. This is slowly changing, but to date only 13 states - including New York, Delaware, Ohio and Hawaii - require a license to practice massage.

LEAD: Situated in a deteriorating neighborhood on northern Manhattan, the Museum of the American Indian attracts few visitors. But even those who venture to its 70-year-old site at 155th and Broadway can only see a fraction of what is considered perhaps the world's finest collection of native American art and artifacts.

LEAD: With regard to the Jan. 4 article ''Controls on Swans Proposed,'' this is to inform you that on Jan. 6 the Connecticut Audubon Society's Environmental Issues Committee endorsed the addling of eggs but not the outright killing of swans at this time. JOEY CORCORAN

LEAD: Phil Gailey says that Sam Nunn ''is so serious, in fact, that when playing Trivial Pursuit with his 20-year-old daughter, Michelle, he has even been known to question the answers on the game cards'' (''Sam Nunn's Rising Star,'' Jan. 4).

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore J. Grieco of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their granddaughter Christine Ann de Mayo to David Edouard Wagner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Wagner of Raleigh, N.C.

LEAD: The Royal Philharmonic, like all the major British orchestras, is supported by private sponsors and government grants. But when it comes to records, the RPO, like the others, has had to fend for itself, dealing with commercial record companies on a commercial basis. Recently, however, the Royal Philharmonic decided it wanted to be able to call the tune, so to speak, on recordings, and formed its own record company, called, of course, RPO Records.

LEAD: Even in a game that evinces as much individualism as chess, there are times when rivalries are put aside for the sake of reciprocal benefit. Suppose you come up with the kernel for an original tactic in a complicated, heavily studied opening position?

LEAD: Alison Katherine Plotsky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Plotsky of Washington, was married there yesterday to David Shelby Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Montgomery Brown Jr. of Baltimore and Hot Springs, Va. The Rev. Dr. Vienna Cobb Anderson, assisted by Rabbi Harold White, performed the ceremony in the Great Choir of the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

LEAD: In 1983, Dennis Conner became the first skipper ever to lose the America's Cup, which he had won in 1980. Last week he regained it, sailing the 12-Meter yacht Stars & Stripes to victory over Australia's Kookaburra III. (AP)
LEAD: Linda Koch Lorimer, associate provost at Yale University, was named today as the first woman to be president of Randolph-Macon Woman's College in Lynchburg, Va.
LEAD: No Perfumed Words for Proust

LEAD: 'I don't want to pay a dollar. I mean, we got it for free, didn't we?' - Elizabeth Matos High School student from Queens, complaining about a $1 fee for admission to the Statue of Liberty, which went into effect last week.
LEAD: CONNECTICUT DOG RACES
LEAD: EVERY year the pursuit of tourist dollars leads to imaginative planning in communities across America.

LEAD: FOLLOWING a season in which his victory total dropped by five games and his loss total increased by 11, Orel Hershiser, the Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher who last year won a record pay raise in salary arbitration, established an opposite kind of record yesterday: He suffered the largest pay cut ever allowed in arbitration.
LEAD: Inmates seized rifles from the armory at the Sinaloa state penitentiary last night and 64 escaped after fighting a gun battle with guards, the authorities said.

LEAD: Thank you for publishing my letter in the Jan. 18 issue of Connecticut Weekly. However, I wish to point out an error in the printed letter. I said ''swans do raise their wings as a warning to be left alone.'' You quoted me as saying ''they do not raise their wings.'' SHIRLEY BECKER Branford

LEAD: The objects that inspired Marianne Moore were startlingly diverse: a picture of an Egyptian desert rat, a Kiwi shoe-polish can, a magazine advertisement for Missouri hogs, a mechanical crow, a swatch of emerald-green brocade.

LEAD: Vice President Bush was told last summer by an Israeli official that ''we are dealing with the most radical elements'' in Iran because dealings with moderates had proved unsuccessful, an aide to Mr. Bush said today.

LEAD: The fight over who gets to keep Baby M took a poignant turn last week when a New Jersey court heard a recording in which Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother, threatened to kill herself and the child.
LEAD: Du Giang-long carefully arranged his pharmaceuticals on a table and began to extol the value of such products as deer antlers, monkey heads and flying lizards.

LEAD: The engagement of Traci Ann Conway to Matthew Adams Clinton has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Conway Jr. of Manhasset and Quogue, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Y. Clinton of Bryn Mawr, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Republican candidates for the United States Senate raised $28 million more than their Democratic opponents in the 1986 election, but those funds were not a determining factor in most races, an analysis of campaign finance reports shows.

LEAD: Mary Queen of Scots, a much-traveled monarch, seems to have spent about half her reign on a horse, and many of the surviving castles she stayed in are being spruced up to mark the anniversary of her death.
LEAD: To hear Clarence Thomas tell it, employers used to laugh when the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission threatened to come down hard on them for job discrimination.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration, under intense pressure from Congress and Western allies, is likely to defer temporarily a decision on whether to adopt a view of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty that would allow extensive testing of some new types of ''Star Wars'' systems, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: NAN, a neighbor, and I love freezing in April on a beach in Maine (getting a so-called tan), shopping for Christmas on Labor Day, and having icicle duels with our respective husbands in deep winter. We marvel that human beings can be so similar. Except for one thing: Nan can't complain about anything, so I do all the complaining for her.

LEAD: CONGRESS is looking for entrepreneurs among the unemployed. Under a new ''bootstrapping'' bill backed by Representative James A. Courter, Republican of the 12th District (Hunterdon County and parts of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Somerset, Sussex and Warren Counties), jobless workers could draw unemployment checks while starting a small business.
LEAD: About 100 members and supporters of the Ku Klux Klan marched through this suburban Atlanta town today, raising their fists and chanting, ''White power.''
LEAD: History, as written by the current leadership of the Soviet Union, is not being kind to Leonid I. Brezhnev, who led the country for 18 years.

LEAD: BUDDY BELL, the third baseman of the Cincinnati Reds, and Lynn Dickey, who recently retired as quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, combined for a nine-under-par 63 and won the American Airlines Golf Classic by a shot.

LEAD: The concept of scientific inquiry as a path toward knowledge of God is intriguing, if not new. Thomas Paine put forth the idea some 200 years ago in concluding his pamphlet ''The Age of Reason.'' Even he may not have been the first to do so. More interesting yet is Mr. Gleick's attention to the issue of elegant mathematics and great musical works - i.e.

LEAD: I believe the new 3-point basket could be the beginning of a new and exciting stratagem in collegiate basketball, which if interpolated, could have a major impact on the game in general and the last five minutes of play in particular.
LEAD: PALAIS-ROYAL By Richard Sennett. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

LEAD: Apparently acting in the belief that good things come in small packages, Sony has consistently shrunk the size of its products, the Walkman being emblematic of these efforts. In video, this attitude culminated in the Handycam - a bantam camera-recorder combination that may be regarded as the video version of the Walkman.

LEAD: Can America afford to acquire more land for national parks or retrain workers displaced by imports? Can it pay for rebuilding the congested air traffic system or protecting South Africa's neighbors from economic collapse? There's a better question: Can a rich nation afford not to make these and other investments in a decent future?

LEAD: Everything about the mansion built in 1915 for Lucy D. Dahlgren at 15 East 96th Street is decorative - from the Beaux Arts-style facade, replete with carved swags and an intricate wrought-iron balcony, to the grand marble staircase and octagonal dining room with two marble fountains.

LEAD: St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Pennington, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Tabell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Tabell of Princeton, N.J., to Steven McKinsey Nocka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Nocka of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. John C. Belmont performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Malcolm Lucas was sworn in Friday as Chief Justice of California's Supreme Court, succeeding Rose Bird and starting a conservative reorientation of the court. LEAD: It was shortly after noon Thursday that the Board of Estimate began its hearing on an ambitious plan to replace the old Coliseum at Columbus Circle with a huge two-tower complex, complete wth indoor atrium and eight movie theaters.

LEAD: STRANGERS IN PARADISE By Lee K. Abbott. 255 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

LEAD: WATCHING TELEVISION A Pantheon Guide to Popular Culture. Edited by Todd Gitlin. 248 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

LEAD: AS the prominence of conservative legal thinkers has grown during the Reagan Administration, so has a split about the fundamental issues of constitutional jurisprudence. The division centers on whether judges should take the activist role of striking down a wide range of economic regulations.
LEAD: The daily sight of the homeless in Grand Central Terminal stirred Jack Taylor of Norwalk, Conn., to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases fund.
LEAD: When the Grammy Awards are handed out Feb. 24, Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' album will be a strong contender.

LEAD: With few options of its own in the Lebanon hostage situation, the United States is quietly pressing India to seek help from Syria and Iran in at least freeing the one captive who is Indian, American and Indian officials say.

LEAD: ALESSANDRO MENDINI, an Italian architect and editor, and Sinya Okayama, a Japanese designer, worked together when they had furniture exhibitions in Milan and Tokyo in 1984 and 1985. They got along well and had similar design ideas, and that led them to a more ambitious intercontinental collaboration: the design of a series of six objects.

LEAD: To the Editor: If Social Security payroll taxes discourage employers from hiring and employees from working (''Put a Permanent Lid on Payroll Taxes,'' Forum Jan. 25), they fairly suffocate something else: Initiative.

LEAD: AMONG the warmer memories many people harbor from childhood are the sights and sounds of their local railroad - waiting on a platform for a special visitor to arrive, the wistful wail of the whistle as an express rumbles through in the night.

LEAD: A WINTER'S day, the stillness, the quiet all down the length of Jericho Turnpike, a feeling of bleakness as the seasons turn - to some, these bring complaints of winter's gloom; to me, they bring winter's gifts. Among these gifts is a sense of a return to another time when vast stretches of Long Island's turnpikes were empty roads leading to land that was still free of concrete, still being turned by the farmer's hand.

LEAD: THE 1958 Heisman Trophy winner, Pete Dawkins, will be the principal speaker at the Jesse Owens Trophy Awards dinner in New York Feb. 24. . . . Vincent dePaul Draddy, the chairman of the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame said that three deceased players had been elected to the hall.

LEAD: FEARFUL SYMMETRY The Search for Beauty in Modern Physics. By A. Zee. Illustrated. 322 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

LEAD: Since it opened on Broadway last August, ''Me and My Girl'' has consistently effervesced at the box office to the tune of more than half a million dollars a week. And the original Broadway cast album (MCA 6196; LP, cassette, compact disk) captures as much of the giddy lilt as a record could reasonably hope to extract from the champagne of nostalgia musicals.

LEAD: Mark Breland said today he he broke his left hand in the first round of the seven-round knockout victory he scored over Harold Volbrecht to win the World Boxing Association welterweight title Friday night.

LEAD: More than 300 demonstrators chanting ''79th Precinct, Undercover Crack-house,'' marched yesterday from a junior high school in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to the 79th Precinct station house to protest what they said was police collusion with drug dealers.

LEAD: Boxing Curry Wins on Disqualification: Donald Curry, the former world welterweight champion, knocked Tony Montgomery down three times yesterday, then captured the United States Boxing Association junior-middleweight title when Montgomery was disqualified in the fifth round for butting at Las Vegas, Nev.

LEAD: Church Revival Feb. 18 - After firefighters spent five hours fighting the blaze last May at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Jersey City, little remained of the Gothic structure built in the 1870's. Faced with a million dollar rebuilding estimate, the church is extending its appeal for funds to Manhattan with an 8 P.M.

LEAD: WHEN Bashkim Pitarka, Albania's new chief delegate to the United Nations, arrived for lunch recently at the French chief delegate's apartment, he seemed upset to see three United States diplomats.

LEAD: After a long trial of 10 employees and officers of three companies on charges including racketeering, fraud and theft, including theft from the Government, a jury has convicted seven employees of obstruction of justice.

LEAD: John Coltrane: The Coltrane Legacy With John Coltrane, Eric Dolphy, McCoy Tyner, Elvin Jones, Miles Davis. Produced and directed by Burrill Crohn. Color/black and white. Video Artists International. 61 Minutes. $39.95.

LEAD: Federal agents and Panamanian police have arrested a man they say conspired with Carlos Lehder Rivas, a Colombian who has been accused of running the world's largest cocaine supply ring, a Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent said today.

LEAD: I am appalled that you printed the article by Carol Cott Gross on Jan. 11 [ ''Rules for the Florida Visit,'' Opinion Page ] . I think she shows lack of compassion and understanding for older (and probably other) people, and what is supposed to be humorous, I find callous and hurtful. I find no redeeming feature in this article.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: OVERALL, the average cost of placing a long-distance call has declined about 30 percent since the breakup of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company in 1984, according to the Federal Communications Commission. But businesses have benefited more from the decline than individual consumers have, though consumers are also paying less for long-distance calls.

LEAD: THE United States Attorney for the Eastern District has joined the Nassau County District Attorney in investigating possible corruption in the Oyster Bay town government, according to law enforcement officials.

LEAD: I am one of the few persons in the United States who has engaged in lengthy discussion with Abu Nidal (''The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre: An Investigation,'' by Judith Miller, Jan. 4). During my visit last December to the Middle East, seeking the release of the hostages held in Lebanon, I met with members of Abu Nidal's Fatah Revolutionary Council.
LEAD: At the AIDS project in Mama Yemo Hospital here, Zairian technicians hunch over computers, tracking the health histories of thousands of local victims of the disease.

LEAD: IT is no wonder that ''They're Playing Our Song'' has become a staple in small theaters. It is a two-character musical, with a disposable chorus of six. It has a sparse score, also disposable, by Marvin Hamlisch (music) and Carole Bayer Sager (lyrics). And the story, which is said to be based upon the once-upon-a-time romantic relationship between the composer and the lyricist, is by Neil Simon.

LEAD: For the future residents of Seaport - a condominium development planned for Toms River, N.J. - returning home won't mean fighting for a parking space, but rather hoisting the centerboard, cleating the bow line and hosing down the deck.

LEAD: Over recent years basketball has evolved into 7-foot behemoths pushing and shoving for territory under the basket for easy dunks, tip-ins or layups. Placing a premium (3 points) on 19-foot or greater shots returns a modicum of skill to the sport. Rebounds and tip-ins should be equivalent to a foul shot (which incidentally many of the ''big men'' cannot seem to conquer).
LEAD: A SMALL monitoring screen attached to an ultrasound device displayed what I thought to be a double image, of a fetus in the fifth month of gestation resting comfortably in my wife's womb.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An employer's offer of half-pay until retirement age not to come to work would sound fantastic to some, even without forced layoff. I suspect that many employees might voluntarily elect that option, were it presented to them.

LEAD: A surge in foreign investment in the United States has curbed protectionist sentiments among members of Congress because constituents are increasingly benefiting from more than 2.5 million jobs created by foreign capital, in the view of several lawmakers.

LEAD: A flurry of personnel shifts, statements and actions by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, including some related to India's latest confrontation with Pakistan, have prompted unusually strong criticism of his performance.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE BRIDGE. By Maggie Hemingway. (Atheneum, $13.95.) The jacket illustration for this imaginative first novel is a detail from a painting by the British impressionist Philip Steer. A slender woman, closely watched by a man, stands on a bridge and gazes at the sunset beyond a little harbor. During the 1880's Steer summered, mostly alone, in a tiny village on the Suffolk coast called Walberswick.

Barbara Black, dean of the law faculty at Columbia University, leads off at 7 P.M. Tuesday with a discussion of ''The Constitution in United States History.

While confessing that they did not know how long it would last, both sides agreed that $18-a-barrel oil was good for consumers and producers.

LEAD: DOZENS of dissidents in Soviet prisons, labor camps, psychiatric hospitals or internal exile have either been released or offered their freedom in the last two weeks. Some Western human rights groups speculate - and hope - that it is the first stage of a widespread release of prisoners.

LEAD: LYNNE JONES was deeply shaken when she learned that Helle Crafts, a neighbor and an acquaintance, had been found murdered near her home in Newtown. Although she had not known Mrs. Crafts well, each had endured the difficulties of raising children while managing a career as a flight attendant.

''Our objective is not to take Basra or Baghdad,'' he told a group of foreign journalists.

LEAD: Prisoners who have been kept in solitary confinement for days and sometimes years have sued the state for violating their civil rights.
LEAD: My compliments on the Jan. 25 article ''Fears on Mental Center Proposal,'' centering on the interaction between the Long Island Developmental Center's program and the surrounding community.

LEAD: IN the space of seven weeks two winters ago, the Toronto Blue Jays solved their glaring bullpen problem. Or so they thought. They staged a successful foray into the Bay Area and snatched Bill Caudill, right-hander, from the Oakland A's and Gary Lavelle, left-hander, from the San Francisco Giants. Envisioning relief security for years to come, they committed themselves to spending a possible $9.8 million in salaries for the two established pitchers in the next five years.
LEAD: Among nuclear regulators, the Shoreham nuclear power plant is a prime example of what they term ''the hostage plant'' problem.

LEAD: AS enrollment in the state's nursing schools has dropped 40 percent; as more and more nurses leave the field to pursue more lucrative careers, and as outpatient clinics multiply around the state, hospitals are acting vigorously to recruit and retain nurses for the growing number of vacancies.

LEAD: THE few Japanese restaurants to open in recent years in Connecticut have been of relatively high quality. One of the oldest, Hatsune in New Haven, is not only going strong, but has also, for the most part, sustained the high level of achievement reached in its early days.
LEAD: A plea for clemency in an 11-year-old murder case has led to a political dispute that is threatening the prestige and future of President Christos Sartzetakis.

LEAD: THREE years ago, the Eastern North Carolina Chamber of Commerce initiated an awareness campaign to persuade tobacco-country landowners to raze and remove the ramshackle sharecropper shacks and flue-curing barns that have been rendered obsolete by new and more efficent methods of curing the leaf.

LEAD: Just a week remains in which to see the exhibition of oils, watercolors and drawings by Oskar Kokoschka (1886-1980) at the Guggenheim Museum. Just before World War I, Kokoschka was one of the most conspicuous young artists in the Vienna that has lately become so fashionable. In Dresden, between 1917 and 1923, he painted landscapes and figure subjects that are among the glories of German art.
LEAD: A Palestinian convicted in the assassination in 1984 of a Palestine Liberation Organization official has been hanged, an Interior Ministry source said today.

LEAD: Gov. Edwin Edwards, who was acquitted last year of Federal mail fraud and racketeering charges, announced Friday that he would seek a fourth term. Mr. Edwards, whose popularity in recent public oponion polls is at a record low, has already drawn at least seven opponents in the Oct. 24 open primary.

LEAD: DON'T say ''masseuse.'' Massage practitioners who are moving their vocation into the mainstream say the term has unfortunate associations with prostitution. They prefer ''massage therapist'' or ''bodywork practitioner.''
LEAD: The Soviet Government has issued a decree ordering the release of dozens of political prisoners, according to evidence provided today by prisoners already set free.

LEAD: FOUR men were honored recently for together donating a total of 45 gallons of blood over several years to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. They received plaques and hospital officials spoke at a ceremony designed to mark the unusually large donations.
LEAD: IN Farmington, community-college courses are held not only in junior and senior high schools, but also even occasionally in the conference room of a nearby hotel.

LEAD: MY FIRST memory was walking down the hill in a daze, my shirt torn and my face sticky with blood. I thought it was odd to be walking, because I had a bike. But I didn't have it now, although I had no idea why not. I blundered down the road, the Central Park cyclists whizzing by me, and came upon a patrol car parked in an access road 50 feet away.
LEAD: Every day the major candidates for Mayor of the nation's third-largest city crisscross this sprawling place seeking votes in the forthcoming primary election.

The Department of Construction and Land Use, invoking a technicality last August, said a demolition permit was needed.

Those were procedurals set in Hong Kong, and were distinguished by a wacky kind of writing in which seriousness was mingled with farce. There have been 11 in that series.

LEAD: I read, with great interest, your article ''Power Cost Is Down but Still an Issue'' [ Jan. 18 ] . Although I agree that with electric rates down in 1986, the push for cheaper power has lost some momentum, I feel that the fight for reduced Con Ed bills must go on. We pay the highest rates in the nation.
