LEAD: The engagement of Joann Elizabeth Sikorski to Kerry Batchelor Watterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Watterson of Bay Village, Ohio, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Sikorski of Northport, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer D. Phillips of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Elizabeth Phillips to Robert Joseph Stonehill Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stonehill of New York and Weston, Conn.

LEAD: JUST before a buyer takes title to a brand-new home, either a condominium or a single-family house, the builder normally arranges for a final inspection of the property to verify that everything is in order. Many buyers are perplexed by this ritual and do not understand what they should be examining and why.

LEAD: The alarm bells are clanging from Muscat in Oman to Cairo and Tel Aviv. The stately pleasure domes of the Saud dynasty seem to stand just a bit less firmly than they did a month ago. The arms market is booming.

LEAD: ONE of the longest-running cabaret hits in New York is ''Forbidden Broadway,'' the award-winning musical spoof of the people and the shows that dominate Broadway news. Now, Theater Three in Port Jefferson has its own standing-room-only cabaret show in ''Hollywood Exposed,'' a clever musical joke at the expense of the film industry.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George Joseph Ames of Rye, N.Y., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Dorothy Christine Ames to John William Cummings, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Cummings of Stamford, Conn., and Indian Rocks Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Navy has proposed closing the 52-year-old Philadelphia Naval Hospital, said two members of Pennsylvania's Congressional delegation, Senator John Heinz and Representative Thomas M. Foglietta. Under a Navy plan, the hospital, which employs 600 enlisted personnel and 230 civilians, would be eliminated over six months.

LEAD: PADDLESPORT EXPO Paddlesport '87, for people who go boating without benefit of sails or propellers, will offer a day of workshops and browsing in Princeton next Sunday. And whether a paddler enjoys canoeing on a placid lake, bouncing through rapids in a white-water kayak or voyaging to a coastal island in a sea kayak, there will be something of interest.

LEAD: At the start, it seemed that this night would be memorable for how Bobby Carpenter was taunted on the occasion of his homecoming. But the Rangers took what might otherwise have been a bleak time and turned it into a gala evening.
LEAD: A state appeals court has ordered the state to lift rules that limit when the homeless are eligible for emergency aid and how long they should be sheltered.

LEAD: The Pilot of a Western Airlines jet with 59 people aboard veered to the left while approaching the international airport here Friday to avoid a small plane that strayed near the airliner, a Federal official said. Lee Fryer, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said a single-engine Cessna 172 and a Western Boeing 737 flying from Las Vegas, Nev., had been given final clearance to land on parallel runways.
LEAD: : Lee Min Woo, right, head of the major South Korean opposition party, and his supporters being confronted by police at a rally to protest the death of a student three weeks ago. Page 3. (AP)

LEAD: THE composer Charles Ives has been abundantly celebrated in recent years; as such, this listener found Continuum's program Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, ''Ives the Visionary,'' somewhat less engaging than the group's usual performances. At this point, Ives does not need Continuum's advocacy as much as do most of the composers the group takes on (recent concerts have been devoted to new music from Israel, the avant-garde in the Soviet Union, the music of Arvo Part, Alfred Schnittke and the man who elevated the player piano into the world of high Modernism, Conlon Nancarrow.)

LEAD: The municipal court system here, plagued by charges of corruption and a growing backlog of cases, is mired in a crisis that could force the city to start releasing inmates from jail next month, court and state officials say.

LEAD: The Hotel Washington, with more than 80 years at the corner of Pennsylvania Avenue and 15th Street N.W., is naturally interested in keeping up the tone of the neighborhood. Fully aware that there will be a new tenant in the White House, just a block away, in less than two years, the hotel is asking all its customers these days: ''Who should be our neighbor in 1988?

LEAD: For almost two months now, this quiet, sparsely populated land has been living under the threatening shadow of what some here call ''demonstration sanctions'' by its looming southern neighbor, South Africa.

LEAD: ''I am not going to close another bookstore in this city,'' Suzanne Zavrian declared recently, with considerable resolve, while she sat among the fine books that crowd the diminutive Pomander Bookshop at 252 West 95th Street. As she spoke, a young customer bought a scholarly anthology of ancient Chinese poetry - on impulse.
LEAD: William E. Chilton 3d, the firebrand publisher of The Charleston Gazette, died of a heart attack Saturday while playing in a squash tournament in Washington, D.C. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: A distraught man with a knife ran into the Holland Tunnel in Lower Manhattan early last night and, threatening to stab himself, forced authorities to close the westbound lanes for 90 minutes until he was captured unharmed.
LEAD: A PLAY about a vampire and a female psychiatrist seems to have the makings of a shaggy Dracula story, but ''Lust and the Unicorn,'' now at La Mama, is more ambitious than that.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve is likely to hold monetary policy unchanged at this week's Open Market Committee meeting, where Fed officials and their advisers meet to assess the economy and plot a course.
LEAD: The interpretation of the word ''free'' has called for the creation of a panel by the National Advertising Review Board, the supreme court of the advertising self-regulation system.
LEAD: EARLIER in the season, one of the easiest ways to get on Jerome Lane's bad side was to call the University of Pittsburgh sophomore forward a great garbage player.

LEAD: President Reagan's reaffirmation, in his State of the Union Message, of the importance of protecting our country was deeply ironic, coming on the heels of his decision to violate the SALT II treaty. This decision marked the first time either superpower has violated the treaty sublimit on missiles and bombers, thereby risking an accelerated nuclear arms race.
LEAD: Herk van Tongeren, a sculptor, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Seattle. He was 43 years old and lived in Hopewell, N.J.

LEAD: Three veteran book publishers who were edged out of top jobs at major houses are returning as the heads of their own small companies. And one of them - Barney Rosset, the founder of Grove Press - is returning with a new work by Samuel Beckett, the Nobel laureate.
LEAD: In Tupelo, Miss., the problem is blackbirds. Mike Barker, the manager of the Tupelo Municipal Airport, employs a cinematic simile to describe the area's blackbird population on the wing.

LEAD: RONALD K. SHERMAN joins Calet, Hirsch & Spector today as president. In doing so, he is once again in the company of Glen W. Fortinberry, chairman and president of Ross Roy Inc., Detroit, the parent company of C.H.&S. The two had worked together in the Detroit office of J. Walter Thompson until 1975, when Mr.

LEAD: In an era when the National Collegiate Athletic Association's enforcement caseload seems to grow by the hour, a number of member schools are turning to outside legal specialists to help them cope with the complex thicket of N.C.A.A. regulations and the intricacies of the infractions process.
LEAD: Sydney Gruson, a former vice chairman and director of The New York Times Company, plans a new career in investment banking. On March 2, he will join Rothschild Inc. as a senior adviser.

LEAD: Two American studios have signed a major television licensing agreement with China's only national television network, an arrangement that will beam such shows as ''Star Trek'' into Chinese households.

LEAD: In a little less than a year, a presidential commission seeking to recover the ''hidden wealth'' of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos has become in effect the nation's largest and most diversified conglomerate.
LEAD: J. Walter Thompson, New York, has won the Philadelphia-based Acme Supermarket account, estimated to be in the range of $8 million to $10 million.

LEAD: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Tuesday, about Volvo and international business, gave an incorrect figure for the Swedish auto maker's 1986 profits. It earned $1.14 billion before taxes.

LEAD: Physical Princeton covers only a few square miles just west of U.S. Route 1. But a kind of metaphysical Princeton, part prestige, part post office box number, has cast its boundaries far and wide.

LEAD: The Cross & Trecker Corporation, a major manufacturer of machine tools, has long been plagued by the industry's continuing troubles: flat orders, weakening prices and intensifying foreign competition. Now, a downturn in automobile production, plus predictions of declining capital investment by industry, spell more distress for the company.
LEAD: A new generation of electronic toys designed to be used by children as they watch specific cartoon shows on television are to be featured this week at the New York Toy Fair.
LEAD: A 60-day cease-fire with the Communist rebels ended today, and although both sides said they were prepared to return to war, there were no immediate reports of military engagements.
LEAD: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said recently that he and his family own three pieces of income-producing property - stores and apartments - in Richmond Hill.
LEAD: Stuart A. Rose started in 1980 with four electronics stores in Dayton, Ohio, and has turned them into a company with 106 stores in 16 states. Now he wants his business to get bigger.
LEAD: Antonio Hernandez Mancha after he became head of a Spanish conservative opposition party. Page A6.

LEAD: A pilot and his passenger were killed Friday night when their twin-engine plane crashed in a remote area southeast of here shortly after the pilot radioed that he was having instrument troubles. They were identified as Kenneth Barton, the pilot, who was chief of the volunteer fire department in Garrison, and Dr.
LEAD: AT Carnegie Hall Saturday night Mstislav Rostropovich continued this month's extended celebration of his 60th birthday with all the expansiveness and exuberance we have come to expect.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Power corrupts, Adlai Stevenson once drily observed, but lack of power corrupts absolutely.

LEAD: Pitching at Yankee Stadium last May 2, Ed Correa allowed just three hits in a 7-0 Texas victory, the only shutout the Yankees would suffer until the last game before the All-Star break. His performance was first rate, but the 20-year-old Ranger wasn't feeling first rate. ''I don't know how I did it,'' he said the other day.
LEAD: ''It is not polible to make any such decision htis year or next year.'' George P. Shultz ''Star Wars'' deployment.

LEAD: Stuart T. Saunders, a railroad merger specialist who was a driving force in the creation of the Penn Central Railroad and who served as its chairman, died Saturday of heart failure at Stuart Circle Hospital in Richmond, Va. He was 77 years old.
LEAD: ''I want to deploy it - I believe that the President wants to deploy just as soon as we can.'' Caspar W. Weinberger. A11:1

LEAD: Everything that John McEnroe needed to know about the eventual outcome of the match became clear at break point in the sixth game of the third set today. He whipped a backhand down the line, an apparent winner that would break Tim Mayotte and send both players back to ''Go'' in the final of the Ebel United States Pro Indoor
LEAD: It took a while for Indiana's Steve Alford to start scoring against Michigan today, but once he did there was no stopping him.

LEAD: For the last two decades, MCA Inc., the giant entertainment company long known as a cautious spender, was, in the words of one media executive, ''a day late and a dollar short'' when it came to acquisitions. But once-staid MCA is starting to shed its tight-fisted image.
LEAD: Robert R. Hagopian, president and chief executive officer of the financially troubled Spendthrift Farm Inc., resigned Saturday, the thoroughbred operation announced.

LEAD: Adrian Moorhouse of Britain set a world best time for 25-meter pools in the 100-meter breast-stroke today, clocking 59.75 seconds. It was the first time a swimmer broke the one-minute barrier for the 100-meter breast-stroke at a 25-meter pool meet.

LEAD: Using a new personal computer, analysts at the State Health Services Department here are trying to sort out who ate what, who became ill and who did not last weekend at a popular West Hartford restaurant where an outbreak of salmonella poisoning infected more than 100 patrons and workers.
LEAD: Kim Man Chul with his two daughters and one of his sons after arrival last night with seven other family members. They had traveled to Japan in a small boat. Page A5. (AP)

LEAD: In the two years since crack first struck New York City's poorest neighborhoods, the powerful form of cocaine has taken an unprecedented toll on women, children and families, according to newly gathered statistics and interviews with drug treatment experts.
LEAD: BASKETBALL COLLEGES: Syracuse vs. Pittsburgh, 7:30 P.M. (TV - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Franklin Pierce at C.W. Post, 6:00 P.M.

LEAD: The two-year-old agency Angotti, Thomas, Hedge has been awarded the more than $5 million KLM Royal Dutch Airlines account. The previous agency, Ogilvy & Mather, had handled the account for the last 25 years.

LEAD: Blunder it assuredly was. The Iran-contra arms crisis involved reckless ransoming of hostages and covertly funding the Nicaraguan rebels. But ignorance and ineptitude, the Reagan Administration's first lines of defense, may not excuse its officials even in the eyes of the special prosecutor, much less the investigating
LEAD: The cost of medical care rose 7.7 percent last year, seven times as fast as the Consumer Price Index for all items, according to new Government data.

LEAD: Four Army soldiers were killed Friday night when their helicopter crashed in a remote, swampy area as they were flying to assist civilians who were injured in a traffic accident, officials said. The identity of one of the victims was withheld pending notification of his family. The others were First Lieut.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Indonesia is caught up in gold fever.

LEAD: Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, has a very simple explanation for his support of the Congressional pay increase that went into effect, at least temporarily, last week. When he was appointed to the Senate in 1968, Mr. Stevens recalled at a dinner with reporters, he exchanged a private salary of about $100,000 a year for a public one of about $30,000.
LEAD: Spain's main conservative opposition party chose a young and little known provincial leader this weekend to overcome the party's internal divisions and lagging fortunes.

LEAD: The Pentagon has decided to review military data-processing contracts awarded to foreign companies with a view toward preventing disclosure of sensitive information to foreign governments, according to a Defense Department official.
LEAD: Gary Hart was the first choice for President among Iowa Democrats, while Senator Robert Dole was the leader among Republicans, according to a poll published today.

LEAD: THE stock price of the International Business Machines Corporation fell 22 percent in 1986, while the Dow Jones industrial average was climbing 22 percent. Last month, after I.B.M. released another lackluster earnings report, its shares sagged to $115.75.

LEAD: The trouble began at William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx when a sophomore boy threw a piece of chalk at a sophomore girl. Ethnic slurs were exchanged, along with threats, and by lunchtime the girl was on the telephone to fellow gang members. In the office of Project Smart, the coordinator, Dorothea Grant, recalls glancing out and seeing ''a big gang of kids outside the school.

LEAD: After months of procrastination, the Nets will name Carl Scheer as their general manager next week. He replaces Lewis Schaffel, who resigned before the start of the season to head a group of investors that is trying to bring a National Basketball Association franchise to Miami.

LEAD: JIM WRIGHT of Texas has begun using his enhanced influence as the new Speaker of the House to bargain on behalf of crippled savings and loan associations, many of which are in his home state. As many as 65 Texas associations, the highest concentration in the nation, are said to currently have a negative net worth.
LEAD: Zola Budd will fly to West Germany this week for treatment for injuries that could end the runner's career, British press reports said today.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, saying he was reflecting President Reagan's thinking, said today that no decision would made be made over the next two years on whether to start deploying elements of a ''Star Wars'' system in the early 1990's.

LEAD: This week's key meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee to establish monetary targets for 1987 will be the last before the panel's annual rotation of regional presidents occurs March 1. The shift assumes additional importance because of two current vacancies on the Federal Reserve Board.

LEAD: U.S. to Review Data Secrecy To keep sensitive information secret, the Pentagon will review data-processing contracts awarded to foreign companies, an official said. Page A13. More Local Tax Power? Cuts in Federal aid have prompted a movement by some state officials to give wider powers of taxation to local governments.

LEAD: THE OPENING one-act play in ''Danger: Memory!,'' Arthur Miller's new double bill at Lincoln Center, is titled ''I Can't Remember Anything,'' but it's Arthur Miller's nature that he can never forget. The horrors that haunt his characters today - the 20th century's police inquisitions, pogroms and wars - are the same specters that hung over ''After the Fall'' and ''Incident at Vichy,'' plays he wrote for the first Lincoln Center theater company, more than two decades ago.

LEAD: Diane Susan VanDerster, a daughter of Mrs. Robert M. Bernstein of Rye Brook, N.Y., and the late George Joseph VanDerster, was married yesterday to Dr. Lloyd Mark Loft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Loft of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Bernhard H. Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N

LEAD: The mood at last Thursday evening's meeting of securities analysts called by the JWT Group Inc. was, according to Vance Brown, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., ''somber at best.''

LEAD: After a decade of relative obscurity as the District Attorney of Queens, John J. Santucci now finds himself in a whirlwind of controversy that has focused attention on his record and judgment as a prosecutor.

LEAD: One of the more radical programs for reform of the United States Senate in recent years has been put forward, to the astonishment of some of his colleagues, under the name of Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the States Rights candidate for President in 1948, a pioneer among Southern Democrats-turning
LEAD: An Illinois mother honored as an adoptive parent has been jailed in Tijuana, Mexico, charged with child stealing.
LEAD: Pressure is growing on American companies to completely sever business ties with South Africa - not just hand over local operations to South Africans.
LEAD: About 18 months ago, when the management of the Quebec Nordiques was approached with the idea of being host to the National Hockey League All-Star Game, Marcel Aubut had an idea of his own.

LEAD: Charles Busch, the author and star of the comedy ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom,'' will appear in a benefit performance on Feb. 16 at 8 P.M. at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street. The evening will feature Mr. Busch in his one-man show ''Alone With a Cast of Thousands.'' Proceeds will benefit the AIDS Resource Center and the Gay Men's Health Crisis.

LEAD: Federal agents and the Panamanian police have arrested a man they say conspired with Carlos Lehder Rivas, a Colombian who has been accused of running the world's largest cocaine supply ring, a Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent said Saturday.
LEAD: There was talk throughout the weekend about a storybook finish, as if the hero of pro basketball's annual playground game was preordained.
LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday pledged his support for Governor Mario Cuomo if the Governor decided to seek the Presidency.

LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov stood in his hallway today and weighed the question: Is there evidence yet of a real shift in the Soviet handling of human rights, or have there been only gestures designed to deceive the West?

LEAD: Nancy Lopez shot a 2-over-par 74 and weathered a challenge from Kathy Baker to win the $200,000 Sarasota Classic by three strokes today, a victory that qualifies her for induction into the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales January Friday Producer Prices January Inventory-Sales Ratio January
LEAD: CHARLES MOULTON combined tap dancing with technology on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. The result was ''Tapnology.''
LEAD: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, as expected, tonight rejected an offer by an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens to acquire the company for about $2 billion in cash, or about $15 a share.
LEAD: Saudi Arabia is walking a tightrope trying to balance its economic interests with its desire for political stability in the Persian Gulf, according to Saudi and diplomatic sources.
LEAD: The media used the occasion of Mr. Reagan's 76th birthday to clobber him.

LEAD: A Missouri highway patrolman was shot and killed here today as he sat in his patrol car, the authorities said. Russell W. Harper, 45 years old, of Springfield, an 18-year veteran, was killed by one of several bullets that pierced his car, said Sgt. Sam Kaunley, a highway patrol spokesman. Sergeant Kaunley said a witness told the police that a white man wearing camouflage trousers, a dark sweatshirt and a blue and white cap got out of a red pickup truck and fired shots at the patrol car.
LEAD: RANJANA HAKSAR WATSON describes her company as ''all-American.''

LEAD: As details increase on how the Reagan Administration solicited money from foreign governments to help the Nicaraguan rebels and other anti-Communist insurgent groups around the world, leading senators remain divided over the propriety and wisdom of the unorthodox policy.

LEAD: A 2 1/2-month-old Canadian girl who underwent surgery to replace her malformed heart was in critical but stable condition today, and doctors were optimistic about her progress. The girl, identified only as Jessica of Calgary, Alberta, received the transplanted heart Saturday at Loma Linda University Medical Center, said a hospital spokesman.

LEAD: THE script was already written for the weekend jamboree: Michael Jordan in the slam-dunk, Larry Bird in the 3-point, the Seattle old-timers in the ''legends'' game and Doctor J would be the most valuable player in the All-Star Game, his last, after all the tributes and the videotapes of his greatest dunks and the standing ovations of the past 48 hours.
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $710 million in January, as the total amount of savings bonds held by the public reached a record $93.11 billion, the Government reported.

LEAD: Although the date of the general election has not been set, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her major opponents are now engaged in a serious struggle to position themselves for a contest that could reshape party politics in Britain.
LEAD: The municipal bond market faces two large financings this week, both intended to take advantage of the steep drop in tax-exempt bond yields.
LEAD: The body of an unidentified man was found lying on the floor of the bathroom in a Hollis, Queens, apartment last night, apparently the victim of a small explosion, the police said.

LEAD: RAS MICHAEL celebrated Bob Marley's birthday on Friday at Sounds of Brazil with reggae at its most devotional, and least pop-directed. Reggae has roots in Rastafarian religion, which includes a sect known as Nyabingi, which has been translated as ''Death to black and white oppressors.'' Nyabingi cult ceremonies include music, which Ras Michael -whose original name was Michael Henry and is also known as Michael
LEAD: John C. Merritt has been named chairman and chief executive of Van Kampen Merritt, the investment banking arm of Xerox Financial Services Inc.
LEAD: Hu Yaobang, who resigned in disgrace as the chief of China's Communist Party three weeks ago, is hospitalized here, according to a Chinese source.
LEAD: Davidson Dunton, a former journalist and retired president of Carleton University, died in a hospital here Saturday. He was 74 years old.

LEAD: Dedicated to New York City's past but anxious about its own future, the Landmarks Preservation Commission may find itself by year's end with many different members and new ways of doing business.

LEAD: The Economy The liability insurance crisis appears to be over after two years of coverage cancellations and sharp increases in premiums. Companies that could not buy coverage at any price are now finding it, and premiums have leveled off. But coverage is more expensive, and less extensive, than before.
LEAD: ''It's absolutely unconscionable, terrifyingly stupid,'' remarked Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.
LEAD: Jack Lucey has been named advertising director of operations for The New York Times, Erich G. Linker Jr., The Times' vice president for advertising, announced last week.
LEAD: Kansas officials say they overstated the number of children who died of abuse or neglect in their state last year. They said there were 12 deaths, not 21 as reported.

LEAD: One evening last week, a successful local businessman who has always preached ''faith in Brazil'' sat glumly in a restaurant and confessed almost apologetically: ''This afternoon, I canceled a major investment.''

LEAD: Spectators on Florida's new Sunshine Skyway Bridge after dedication Saturday. The $230 million, 4.1-mile bridge is seen as a key link in interstate highway system. In 1980, 35 motorists died on the bridge it replaces, seen in background, after it was struck by a freighter. Page A15. (NYT/Patrick Langan)

LEAD: Skiing Upset Victory: Frank Woerndl, a journeyman who was almost dropped from the West German team earlier this year, scored an upset yesterday in the men's slalom at the close of the Alpine Ski World Championships in Crans-Montana, Switzerland. The 27-year-old Woerndl gave West Germany its first gold medal ever in the event and led a medal sweep over the favorites in the final event of the two-week championships.
LEAD: One of the mysteries of Manila's ''hidden wealth'' investigation is the origin of the report that Imelda R. Marcos owned 3,000 pairs of shoes.
LEAD: Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion was released from Hotel Dieu hospital today, less than a day after collapsing at a Hockey Hall of Fame exhibit.

LEAD: THERE seem to be a remarkable number of dancegoers with bronchitis at each performance of ''Moves,'' a ballet by Jerome Robbins that was presented by the New York City Ballet last Wednesday at the New York State Theater. And the ballet's performers always seem to seethe coolly with emotion. The reason seems to lie in the fact that the ballet is performed in silence.
LEAD: After deciding for the clubs in two cases, Raymond Goetz, the arbitrator, awarded Andy Hawkins, a San Diego pitcher, a $535,000 salary yesterday over the Padres' figure of $450,000.
LEAD: In 1927, a man born George Herman Ehrhardt hit 60 home runs to set a major league record. He had a teammate born Ludwig Heinrich Gehrig.
LEAD: Former American officials who met last week with Mikhail S. Gorbachev said yesterday that they believed that his efforts to change Soviet society would have far-reaching effects.

LEAD: It happens in stages - but quickly, before the mother understands what has really taken place, said Janet, an 18-year-old woman now living at a Phoenix House center in upstate New York and separated from her 17-month-old son.

LEAD: Just six weeks after it was passed by the Legislature, a five-year $8.6 billion program to rebuild New York City's mass-transit system has ground to a halt - once again caught up in a conflict between the city and its suburbs over which area will pay increased taxes to finance the plan.

LEAD: As the discussions of a potential takeover of Church's Fried Chicken Inc. progressed last week, it became clear that C. Stephen Lynn, the 39-year-old chairman, president and chief executive of Sonic Industries, was the man to watch. Sonic is an Oklahoma City-based drive-in hamburger chain.

LEAD: OHIO STATE'S Dennis Hopson was stalking the backcourt from the point of the Buckeye's 1-2-2 zone press when the man he was eyeing, Darryl Johnson of Michigan State, lobbed a routine cross-court pass.
LEAD: A high-ranking State Department official has called for ''a more open and legitimate political system'' in South Korea, terming it essential for that nation's long-term stability.
LEAD: THE DINNER PARTY. By Howard Fast. 250 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.
LEAD: Despite two years of rapidly rising premiums, the property and casualty insurance industry is jittery again.
LEAD: Warren Arthur Bahr, a former chief operating officer of the advertising agency Isidore Lefkowitz & Elgort Inc., died at his home in North Salem, N.Y., on Friday. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: Jury selection is scheduled to begin today for the trial of a combined group of civil rights suits brought almost three years ago against The Daily News by four black journalists. Representatives of both sides predict a bitter courtroom battle.

LEAD: Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, which has won the heart of America with its commercials for Bartles & Jaymes wine coolers and Gallo wine, will be turning its creative talents loose on the computer products of PC's Limited of Austin, described by Business Week as ''the hottest little computer maker in Texas.

LEAD: Carl Lewis got his revenge over the world-record holder in the 60-yard dash, Lee McRae, in The Dallas Morning News Indoor Games and signaled he may be ready to become a force again on the USA-Mobil Grand Prix circuit.

LEAD: HE is slightly eccentric, but that seems fashionable among the National Hockey League's goaltenders who, rookies or not, are an uninhibited breed. Ron Hextall, the 22-year-old all-star newcomer who is arguably the most successful goaltender the league has to offer at the moment, is also, and without question, its noisiest.

LEAD: The financially troubled Hawkeye Bancorporation, once one of the country's biggest agricultural lenders, has been charged by the Federal Reserve Board with unsafe banking practices because the holding company refused to save one of its banks from collapse.

LEAD: Two intruders ransacked John Cardinal O'Connor's bedroom, rifled a desk in his private office and rummaged through several other rooms behind St. Patrick's Cathedral last night, the police said.

LEAD: It has been almost two years since Alec Collett, a 65-year-old British journalist working for the United Nations, disappeared in Lebanon, but his American wife says she and their 13-year-old son are ''holding on.''

LEAD: Aides to Vice President Bush asserted today that other senior officials at the White House knew last summer that contacts were under way with radical, not moderate, elements in Iran seeking to free American hostages in Lebanon.

LEAD: Armed with the knowledge that he can complete four rotations in the air and confident that he will make the first quadruple jump in competition, Brian Boitano is ready to take on all challengers for his world championship.

LEAD: In a defensive struggle between teams trying to avoid last place in the Patrick Division, Chris Kontos scored 2 minutes 12 seconds into overtime to give the Penguins a 2-1 triumph over the Devils tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: The Energy Department, which will disclose tomorrow its site-selection process for the $4.4 billion supercollider atom smasher, is said to be interested in using this as bait to induce Texas, Nevada or Washington State to accept a nuclear waste repository.
LEAD: For five days last week, negative upon negative about Mary Beth Whitehead's life was piled into the court record of the Baby M custody case.

LEAD: QUESTION: Has there ever been a team triple-crown winner in the major leagues, one that in the same season had one player win the league's home run title, another player win the runs-batted-in title and a third player win the batting title?
LEAD: On the eve of the meeting to decide the site of the 1988 Democratic National Convention, city leaders in Atlanta were cautiously optimistic that they had taken the lead from Houston.

LEAD: Late last month, the White House submitted to Congress a report entitled ''National Security Strategy of the United States'' over the signature of President Reagan, in an effort to keep the lawmakers up to date on the underlying principles of the nation's foreign policy and their use abroad.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The National Football League is said to be increasingly concerned at not having a single black head coach among its 28 teams, even though more than half the players in the league are black. That concern cannot have been eased by the Atlanta Falcons' announcement this week of their new head coach.
LEAD: The insurance crisis that stalled many everyday activities across the country last year because of coverage cancellations and sharp premium increases is ending as abruptly as it began.
LEAD: Several late-night moviegoers watched while a judge was assaulted and robbed near a downtown newsstand but none of them helped her, the judge said today.
LEAD: Seven years after a tanker rammed the Sunshine Skyway Bridge, killing 35 motorists, a sleek new span across Tampa Bay has been dedicated.

LEAD: Should nuclear power be regulated by the Federal Government or the states? Only Washington has the technical expertise and the duty to weigh the national interest. But states including New York and Massachusetts refuse to cooperate in emergency evacuation plans for the plants at Shoreham and Seabrook, effectively blocking their start-ups.

LEAD: Bridge theorists, like economists, worry about unemployment. In the past decade they have found uses for several unemployed doubles and redoubles.

LEAD: ONE of the highlights of Ballet Rambert's just-ended weeklong season at City Center was ''Soda Lake,'' a solo choreographed by the company's director, Richard Alston. On Saturday afternoon Ben Craft took on the role with notable results.
LEAD: A Unitarian Universalist minister distributed condoms to his congregation during a worship service Sunday, saying the spread of AIDS must stop and condoms would help.

LEAD: Many city and county governments have been so weakened by cuts in Federal aid that state officials around the country, despite a history of bitter relations with their cities and counties, have begun a movement to persuade their legislatures to give the local governments broader taxing powers.

LEAD: IT'S all a matter of style. ''The Last Fling,'' tonight's television movie on ABC at 9, tries hard, and often rather amiably, to be what used to be known as a romantic romp. Billy Wilder, in his ''Some Like It Hot'' period, would probably have pulled it off with great dollops of panache. Television, insistently clumsy, gives us silliness that keeps toppling into stupidity.

LEAD: Poland remains a police state, but once again it tolerates the most freedom in Eastern Europe. Its Government is still widely loathed, but now tries harder to court popular opinion. Polish democrats are still hounded, but now face heavy financial penalties rather than jail.

LEAD: ''Platoon,'' a movie that no studio wanted to make, is the top-grossing movie in the country this month. Over the weekend ended Feb. 1, the Vietnam War picture sold $8.3 million worth of tickets at fewer than 600 theaters, an average of more than $14,000 a theater.
LEAD: Corey Pavin topped a six-stroke comeback with a 20-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole and successfully defended his title today in the Hawaiian Open golf tournament.
LEAD: FOR the first time in several years, I have made an early start at readying my fishing gear for the forthcoming season, at practicing that which I so glibly preach.
LEAD: * Black & Decker Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million of 10-year notes, through First Boston Corp.
LEAD: Several people who had put off giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have finally done so with gifts to the 75th annual appeal.
LEAD: Alfred Lion, who founded the influential Blue Note Records jazz label, died last Monday of heart failure at Pomerado Hospital in the San Diego suburb of Poway. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: SOMETIME soon, the Boston College hockey team will win another game that will not be just another game. It will be the 556th victory for Coach Len Ceglarski, and no other college hockey coach has been on the winning side that many times.

Thirty years after he had his first hit, ''Wonderful, Wonderful,'' Mr.
LEAD: A clandestine group that last month kidnapped three American professors and an Indian academic here today repeated its threat to kill them unless 400 Arabs held in Israeli jails are freed.

LEAD: RALPH LEMON AND COMPANY opened a new series this weekend that will present a New York showcase for experimental work developed over the summers at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass.

LEAD: NEAR the third tee at the Lake Karrinyup Country Club, black swans, pelicans, cranes and ducks could be seen splashing. Off in a eucalyptus tree, a kookaburra laughed, understandably. Three wandering Yanks, turning a lay day into a play day, were about to swing their drivers. With a loopy lunge, one who shall be known as Kindred Spirit pushed his tee shot toward trees and palm bushes.

LEAD: Every morning Mary Louise Skelton rises at 7, prepares breakfast for Lucille Hays and helps her get dressed. Then she drives her to the day-care center a mile away, gives her a peck on the cheek and goes off to work.

LEAD: A fierce lobbying battle has emerged over what to do with about $15 billion that utilities have collected from their customers for tax payments that will no longer be owed. The $15 billion has been accumulated by electric, gas, water and telephone companies on the assumption that their Federal income-tax rate would be 46 percent.

LEAD: The Comptroller of New York City is expected to be a dour, single- minded scrutinizer of municipal financial practices, not an investment adviser, and certainly not a trader of favors. Harrison Goldin, New York's Comptroller for 13 years, knows the rules; indeed, he often extols them.
LEAD: Eleven North Koreans who escaped by boat to Japan arrived in Seoul today to a hero's welcome, marking a rare defection by North Korean civilians to the South.

LEAD: Billboards in Grand Rapids, Mich., damaged by winds from storm that struck yesterday. The storm, accompanied by winds gusting up to 86 miles an hour, left seven inches of snow in some areas, knocked down power lines, forced closing of some roads and destroyed a seawall on Chicago's waterfront. (AP)
LEAD: This suburb of Miami is preparing for the future by dusting off its past, encouraging a civic facelift by promoting the old instead of the new.

LEAD: HUMAN growth hormone, long available in minuscule amounts to help abnormally short children reach normal adult height, is finally being produced in mass quantities by genetic engineering techniques, opening the door to a wealth of potential new medical uses. But experts fear that plentiful supplies may also encourage abuse - that practitioners of ''cosmetic endocrinology'' will use the hormone to increase athletic prowess or to increase the height of children in the belief it will improve their social and economic prospects.

LEAD: Kidnappers holding four Western hostages reiterated that they would kill their captives at midnight tonight unless 400 Arab prisoners were freed by Israel, then, as the deadline passed, announced that it had been extended ''until further notice.''

LEAD: Q. How do bullet-proof vests work? A. Most lightweight bullet-resistant garments are made of Kevlar, a material developed by the Du Pont Company. Kevlar, once described as ''the step beyond nylon,'' is formed of fibers of aromatic polyamide, ultra-strong chains of carbon atoms. The material resists penetration by low-velocity projectiles like shrapnel and pistol bullets.
LEAD: A joint oversight commission of the State Legislature declared today that New York health officials exceeded their legal authority in enacting tough new statewide anti-smoking regulations.

It could reconstitute a relationship between the intelligence community and Congress that was building beautifully until it came apart this winter.

LEAD: ''WHEN I think of the role of the Kitchen,'' said Arto Lindsay, who is now the music curator at New York's avant-garde institution, ''it's been in finding what's happening next and trying to help that happen.'' Mr. Lindsay has been active in New York's new music since the late 1970's, playing compacted noise in the band DNA, quasi-jazz in the Lounge Lizards and fractured Brazilian music with the Ambitious Lovers.

LEAD: NOT long ago, Stella Isaacs, who was born in Russia 84 years ago and now lives on the Upper West Side, received a photocopy of a letter that began: ''Kiss someone when you get this letter and make magic. This paper has been sent to you for good luck. You will receive good luck and a surprise within four days of receiving this letter, providing you send it back out.

LEAD: When President Reagan held his last news conference, on Nov. 19, he was asked about the Iran arms deal and he gave a four-part defense: The United States had shipped only a token number of ''defensive'' antitank missiles to Iran. The Government had not condoned arms shipments by third countries like Israel.

LEAD: A tea bag containing a lethal dose of cyanide was found in a Princeton Township supermarket on Tuesday after an anonymous caller told a store employee that he had also poisoned some store cheese and left the tea bag as proof of his visit, the authorities said today.

LEAD: John M. Snyder, editor of Point Blank, house organ of the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms, has come up with an especially hard-line argument against the latest efforts to control handguns. ''If only one life is lost because a victim did not have a handgun with which to defend himself against a criminal because of a handgun purchase waiting period requirement,'' he maintains, ''the perpetrators of that requirement will have the life of that innocent victim on their consciences for the rest of their lives.

LEAD: THE Gothic style, revived many times and in many countries since it first appeared in the late Middle Ages, is once again being exhibited by museums and pursued seriously by collectors and dealers. The versions most enthusiasts seek today are those from the mid-19th century that echo the architecture of medieval cathedrals, awash with pointed arches, quatrefoils, finials, crockets, rosettes, crenelated moldings and clustered columns.

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran arms case, Lawrence E. Walsh, has widened his investigation by assuming control of at least three Justice Department inquiries into the private American supply network for Nicaraguan rebel groups, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.

LEAD: THE evidence is plain in my mailbox every week: letter writing is a dying art. Some old friends write a note from time to time. At Christmas, others send a printout omnibus letter about their lives since last Christmas. Sometimes these computerized letters have a small personal touch at the end, but even with that, they remain letters to no one in particular.

The device was listed as having an explosive force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT. Six protesters gathered on a road leading to the test site gate, and one demonstrator was arrested for trespassing.

LEAD: DEAR Valentine, how do I love thee? With a tussie-mussie, a tuzzie-muzzie, a nosegay or a posy? An Anglo-Latin dictionary of 1440 gives the three terms as interchangeable for a small fragrant bunch of flowers. Today a posy is defined as a nosegay or bouquet, nice to smell, and a tussie-mussie as a fragrant hand-held cluster or knot of flowers.

LEAD: TNT Ltd., an Australia-based freight company, said that the Airborne Freight Corporation had expressed an interest in a possible joint venture. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, TNT, which holds a 17.6 percent stake in Airborne, said that talks on a joint venture began after Airborne rejected a TNT takeover bid of $172 million, or $29 a share.

LEAD: Orders for semiconductors remained flat during January, an industry trade group said yesterday. But the book-to-bill ratio increased for the fourth month in a row, providing a further sign that the American chip industry is recovering.

LEAD: FOR a couple of years, British acquaintances have been singling out something called ''The Black Stuff'' and its five-part sequel ''Boys From the Black Stuff'' as examples of television in their country at its biting best. Written by Alan Bleasdale, the plays follow the lives and sagging fortunes of a group of Tarmac layers in Liverpool.

LEAD: In the fourth quarter, the nation's biggest commercial banking companies were plagued by continued weakness in lending, a decline in investment-banking income and a disturbingly high level of special items. As a result, the year turned out to be one of the harshest for the banks since deregulation began in the late 1970's.

LEAD: William Shawn's 35-year reign as editor of The New Yorker, a reign as distinguished and as total as any in the annals of modern journalism, is expected to end without fanfare tomorrow when the legendary 79-year-old editor passes the torch to Robert Gottlieb, who is 24 years his junior.

LEAD: Testimony ended yesterday in the manslaughter trial of the police officer charged with shooting an elderly woman in an eviction dispute two years ago.

LEAD: IT took colossal crust - more specifically, it took Sylvester Stallone - to make a film that is largely about arm-wrestling. LEAD: Q. We recently moved into a brownstone and in one room there appears to be a lot of the original wainscoting on the walls. LEAD: Forrest McDonald is a conservative Republican who says he is ill at ease in Washington, even the Washington of Ronald Reagan. But he is not ill at ease talking about the Constitution and the Federal Government that has evolved from it. He is an expert on that subject.

LEAD: The armed forces are confronting a growing problem over the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in arms, ammunition and explosives through theft, breakage, mistakes in record-keeping and other abuses, according to investigators for the Defense Department and Congress.

LEAD: The dollar moved higher yesterday, largely because traders who had sold the currency short earlier began buying out of their positions late in the day. Dealers said the late demand came after a day of lackluster trading in which prices overseas and in New York had moved in extremely narrow ranges.

LEAD: For 20 years, the problems of the Federal-state welfare system have become increasingly apparent. Among them are its incentives for single motherhood and broken families, high and increasing costs, paternalistic and unresponsive bureaucracies, staggering economic obstacles in the way of departing the system for remunerative work, constant intergovernmental friction, a bewildering array of inconsistent regulations and the strong suspicion that the system is perpetuating a dependent welfare class that threatens to persist over generations.

One of the leading traditional Celtic folk ensembles, the Boys of the Lough play highland music that is by turns delicate, buoyant and martial. Formed over a decade ago, the quintet now includes Cathal McConnell (flute, tin whistle, vocals), Aly Bain (fiddle), Dave Richardson (mandolin, tenor banjo, cittern concertina), John Coakley (guitar, piano, fiddle, tin whistle, bodhran) and Christy O'Leary (uillean pipes).

LEAD: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of a Senate judicial screening panel, charged today that the Reagan Administration had a ''shameful'' record on appointing women and members of minorities to the Federal bench and warned that the courts might become ''an enclave of white male exclusivity.''

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds decreased $15.8 million, to $236.01 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $452.6 million, to $65.32 billion. Assets of the 196 general purpose funds were up $156.1 million, to $62.99 billion.

Ruland, who was acquired in a deal last April that sent Moses Malone to the Washington Bullets, has been ordered to rest his left knee completely. Cartilage in the knee has eroded.

LEAD: Nancy Pelosi, who has raised millions of dollars for the Democratic Party, announced her candidacy for the House of Representatives today, a few hours after Mayor Dianne Feinstein said she would not enter the race.

LEAD: The Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has told his 850 priests that groups that condone homosexual activity will no longer be allowed to use churches, hospitals or colleges for meetings or religious services. The ban applies to the two boroughs in the diocese, Brooklyn and Queens.

LEAD: The United States and its four principal economic allies may be edging toward agreement on stabilizing their currencies but they are still a considerable distance from an accord, American and foreign officials said here today.

LEAD: A fugitive wanted in Argentina on charges of kidnapping and making $2.5 million in extortion demands was arrested yesterday on a midtown Manhattan street, the United States Marshals Service in Manhattan said.
LEAD: A Stanford University group issued a report here today that found little evidence to support Reagan Administration charges of Soviet cheating on arms control agreements.

LEAD: In a move that surprised and dismayed many futures traders, board members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange voted late Wednesday to install daily price ranges on its widely used Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures contract.

Mr. Robards will, naturally, play the devilish widower, a considerable change of pace from his last starring role on the Great White Way - his 1985 portrayal of Hickey in ''The Iceman Cometh.

LEAD: In the first year after the drinking age in New York State was raised to 21, alcohol purchases among 16- to 20-year-olds declined by half, according to a five-year study released today by the state.

LEAD: Kidder, Peabody & Company is offering $750 million of collateralized mortgage obligations, in a financing that typifies the willingness of dealers and investors to devise varieties of mortgage-backed securities.

LEAD: The new W-4 withholding form for Federal taxes has infuriated taxpayers and sent the Internal Revenue Service, chastened, back to the drawing board. A new new form or revised instructions, or both, will issue soon. The exercise offers the public and Internal Revenue an important lesson. Reforming the tax process isn't simple.

LEAD: Several Marine guards were reassigned from their postings at the American Embassy here after an internal investigation indicated they had been involved in illegal currency transactions, Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman said today.

LEAD: Even though the oil slump has forced an unfamiliar economic restraint on this country, the building of palaces continues, and one in particular is worth note. It will be the new main home and offices of King Fahd, the seat of a dynasty that started in tents.

LEAD: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 15.2 percent, helped by a strong performance in all its main groups: newspapers, magazines and broadcasting and cable television.

LEAD: Adm. William C. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned here today that the American people would stop supporting the Nicaraguan rebels unless they performed better.

LEAD: Kevin Bass, Houston's right fielder, won his salary arbitration, but Gary Pettis, California's center fielder, lost for the second successive year. Bass, who earned $310,000 last year, gained a 1987 salary of $630,000; the Astros' offer was $560,000. It was the Astros' second loss in three cases. Pettis had a $300,000 salary last year after losing in arbitration and went up to $400,000 with his loss this time.

LEAD: Henry Bohn Hass, a specialist in organic chemistry who is credited with the discovery of gas chromatography, one of chemistry's most powerful analytic tools, died of pnuemonia yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital, Manhasset, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Queens.

LEAD: A West German freighter that picked up distress signals in the night rescued 24 men and a woman from a stricken Turkish merchantman in a battering Atlantic storm early yesterday, but three other seamen were lost when their lifeboat capsized at the brink of deliverance.

LEAD: A year ago, when the Metropolitan Opera introduced its latest version of ''Carmen,'' a lack of singing made opening night hard to bear. LEAD: Jerome Robbins's ''Moves,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday at the New York State Theater, is a beautifully wrought work that communicates strong emotions through stark moves and gestures performed in silence. Coming after ''Moves,'' as it did on Wednesday's program, Mr. Robbins's ''Four Seasons'' looked more madcap than ever.

LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

LEAD: Kidder, Peabody & Company may face a host of lawsuits and financial penalties as a result of insider trading charges against its employees, corporate lawyers say. Indeed, these experts think the Federal Government could force the firm to pay back all illegal profits derived from the trading, plus triple damages.

LEAD: College Basketball Columbia 81, Yale 72: Sean Couch scored 29 points and Matt Shannon added 16 last night to lead Columbia to the Ivy League victory. The loss ended Yale's five-game winning streak and dropped the Elis out of a first-place tie in the Ivy League with Cornell. Yale is 13-8 over all and 6-3 in the league.

LEAD: More than 150 Roman Catholic bishops meeting here have concluded that abstinence and marital fidelity are better weapons to fight AIDS than are condoms, which they believe create a false sense of security, a bishop said Friday. LEAD: The Vermont Senate today rejected a bill calling for the reinstatement of the death penalty. The vote was 21 to 8.
