LEAD: THE former Yankee catcher Rick Cerone called George Steinbrenner and asked for an invitation to the Yankees' spring camp as an unsigned player. Instead, Steinbrenner gave him a $250,000 non-guaranteed contract. Part of that money, though, is guaranteed because just for showing up in spring training, Cerone is assured a 30-day share of that salary.
LEAD: THOUGH the General Assembly will consider making available $100 million in housing aid this year, towns have still not taken full advantage of $35 million of the aid appropriated last year.

LEAD: A bloodhound, a whippet, several setters and a pair of hunting dogs - garden sculptures all - helped make the recent Winter Antiques Show an unqualified success. These zinc, bronze, lead and stone canine figures - life-sized and larger - sparked smiles and lots of laughter throughout the nine-day fair - the first anyone could recall at which there was such a large gathering of dogs.

LEAD: I have never been robbed abroad, save for an incident in Ghana in which two soldiers with machine guns took some cash. That was more like taxation than thievery, however, because the perpetrators were soldiers on duty at a roadblock. So I never have been properly robbed abroad. Yet I do worry a bit when I am overseas about the security of my cash and passport.
LEAD: The sudden relocation of large numbers of refugees under Khmer Rouge control in a closed Thai-Cambodian border camp is worrying relief agencies, a United Nations official said today.
LEAD: Four men entered a Chinese restaurant in Queens early yesterday, blocked the entrance and opened fire on a small group of diners, injuring five, one of them seriously, the police said.

LEAD: To the Editor: When James W. Davis laments the shrinking pool of volunteers for the armed services, I'm forced to recall the complexion of my outfit in Vietnam in 1969-70, when I was an Army draftee in Pleiku Province.

LEAD: To underline the need for the business community to work with teachers in preparing students for future employment, the County Chamber of Commerce in White Plains has compiled and published a job-hunting guide based on a survey of vocational opportunities in Westchester.

LEAD: Strategists for Vice President Bush, acknowledging that they overestimated their candidate's strength, now concede that the Rev. Pat Robertson won nearly as many delegates as the Vice President in the state's precinct voting last August.

LEAD: COMMUNITY School Board 19, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, is composed of people with fairly standard backgrounds for a local New York City school board. Most of them work for, or are related to, or were once themselves politicians. There is a former assemblyman, two staff members of two assemblymen, the former staff member of a congressman, the sister of a New York City councilwoman and the chairwoman of the local planning board.

LEAD: IF speculation about Governor Cuomo's Presidential prospects has given him increased stature, it has done the same for some other players in state government as well. There is a feeling here among Republicans and even Democrats that this is a vulnerable time for Mr. Cuomo and that he can ill afford either an embarrassing legislative defeat or the appearance that he is not in full control of government.

LEAD: To the Editor: Mr. Leifermann certainly did his share to perpetuate the Blowing Rocks State Nature Preserve as ''one of the least known'' beaches in Florida. I read the article while on vacation in Deerfield Beach, Fla., and was intrigued by the idea of visiting this attraction. I consulted the Pompano Beach office of the American Automobile Association for further information on Blowing Rocks and found that none of the travel advisers who were consulted, some of whom were longtime residents of the area, had heard of the preserve.

LEAD: Like his tenure, John F. Lehman Jr.'s departure from the Navy is somewhat bumpy. The announcement last week that the Secretary would leave this spring was made by a Defense Department spokesman; there was no letter of resignation, no word of Mr. Lehman's plans and no mention of a successor - though it was said that Secretary of Defense Caspar W.
LEAD: President Reagan has rejected a proposal to combine warnings about AIDS with his anti-narcotics campaign, the Surgeon General of the United States says.

LEAD: FOUR months after County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke convinced the Westchester County Medical Center that it should apply to the state to become the regional center for the treatment of victims of AIDS, the future of the center remains uncertain.

LEAD: IN recent years, terrorists have systematically kidnapped foreigners as a means of extracting concessions from governments. In reacting, more governments have adopted new laws, ordered tighter defenses, shared information and resources and publicly vowed never to yield to terrorist blackmail.

LEAD: A BIT OF SPRING Just when we need it most, the Bartlett Arboretum has scheduled its annual Open Greenhouse from 1 to 3 P.M. today. A display of bulbs and flowers forced into early bloom may be seen at the arboretum association's headquarters at 151 Brookdale Road in North Stamford.

LEAD: AS the inventors told it, the biggest problem isn't coming up with ideas, or even executing them, but getting creations to market. ''I have more than 200 ideas, I just need the right contacts,'' said Abbas Husain, a New Jersey doctor who received a patent this year for a ''safer nail clipper.'' By the end of the conference, more than a dozen of the inventors were convinced they had found a contact on the speaker's platform, or at least someone who could help them make a connection.

LEAD: St. John's hopes for a late-season rush to first place in the Big East were dashed by Providence last night. The Friars, who defeated St. John's in overtime last month, beat the Redmen, 79-78, at Alumni Hall.
LEAD: A man and a woman were killed and another man was critically wounded in what was believed to be a drug-related shooting in an apartment in the Bronx, the police reported yesterday.

LEAD: CLASSES IN NATURE Children can still be enrolled in Pace University's nature program, scheduled from 1:30 to 3:30 P.M. Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. The popular sessions, which are limited to 15 participants, have been operated by the university's Environmental Center for more than a decade, introducing children 5 to 7 years old to some of the finer points of animal, plant and aquatic life.
LEAD: Anthony J. Alvarado, the former New York City Schools Chancellor, has been rejected by Community Board 3 as a candidate for superintendent of public schools on Manhattan's West Side.

LEAD: THE Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan celebrates its 25th anniversary this year. Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, the academy threw itself a grand party, with a concert featuring the Interlochen Arts Academy Orchestra and the violinist Ida Kavafian (Interlochen '69) in a program that included Beethoven's ''Coriolan'' Overture, Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in E minor, and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No.

LEAD: All the computerized financial records of this Rocky Mountain community have been erased, leaving officials with no idea how much money has been spent this year or how much cash the town has left.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rothberg of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Anne Rothberg to Andrew Samuel Rowen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Rowen of New York. The wedding is planned for May 24. Ms. Rothberg, who graduated from Stanford University, is a candidate for an M.B.A.

LEAD: Motor-Home Trip Question: Would it be possible to rent a trailer in San Diego large enough for two people (both 65) and leave it in Seattle? How can we make arrangements for such a tour? -A. J. G., Ormond, Fla. Answer: Yes, but there is a drop-off charge. Travelers planning to set out on a long tour aboard a recreational vehicle for the first time should study some of the advisory material that is available.

LEAD: DURING a luncheon at a restaurant on the edge of the city last week, John Chaney, the basketball coach at Temple University, stood before 100 guests who had gathered to honor the city's best high school athletes.
LEAD: A leading New York State appeals judge has recommended random audits to deter lawyers from stealing money that has been temporarily entrusted to them by their clients.
LEAD: ''Look what a tax collector in a mountain village just received!'' shouted Francois Pacquere, a young man with a mustache and darting black eyes.
LEAD: Steadily, the Air Force is placing on alert the long-disputed MX nuclear missile in silos buried under the bleak prairie here in southeast Wyoming near Cheyenne.

LEAD: Dean Kartsonas scored 26 points to lead Cornell to an 86-74 victory over Yale tonight to remain atop the Ivy League. The Big Red, 14-8 over all and 8-2 in the league, won its sixth straight game to go a game and a half in front of Penn. Yale fell to 13-9 and 6-4 in the league. Kartsonas hit 10 of 11 shots from the field and 4 and 4 from the free-throw line for Cornell.

LEAD: The state has the right to evict a hermit living in a makeshift wigwam on public land, but it must find him a home where he can be close to nature and preserve his independence, a Housing Court judge has ruled.

LEAD: In a remarkable essay entitled ''A People's Theater'' (1919), W. B. Yeats, the founder of the Abbey Theater, described two seemingly opposed yet integrally related traditions in modern Irish drama. The first was that of the social realists who, by focusing on the problems faced by people in their daily lives, had helped Irishmen to gain a greater understanding of themselves in relation to the life of

LEAD: On the day last month when John Cardinal O'Connor met with Jewish leaders to smooth over differences regarding the Cardinal's trip to the Middle East, another, less publicized, meeting was held - between the Cardinal and the man he calls ''the Prophet of the Holocaust,'' Elie Wiesel.

LEAD: Golf Floyd Gains Tie With Eagle on Last Hole: Ray Floyd's last-hole eagle lifted him into a share of the third-round lead yesterday with J. C. Snead in a day of remarkable shooting at the Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif. Floyd's eagle finished off a 6-under-par 66. He was tied at 199 with Snead, who also shot 66 on the South course at Torrey Pines.

LEAD: COPING with terror is daily fare for oversize people. We peek around corners, anticipating threats to our dignity every time we leave the security of our homes. Stress and anxiety in public places are as familiar to us as tuna and cottage cheese.
LEAD: THE absence of one of the most prized food fish from this area, the Atlantic striped bass, is to be lamented. Levels of PCB's in the fish led to a Government ban. What is the cook to do?

LEAD: Eastern Airlines agreed last week to pay the full $9.5 million fine imposed by the Federal Aviation Administration, 11 months after a comprehensive inspection found more than 78,000 violations of agency rules.

LEAD: When the New York financier Disque D. Deane pledged $20 million to Duke University two months ago, Duke's president, H. Keith H. Brodie, hailed it as a ''landmark gift.'' But now university officials are debating whether to accept the gift because of a condition Mr. Deane attached to it.
LEAD: The contras seemed to be losing the battle in Washington last week.

LEAD: 'The routine promotion of condoms through network advertising has been stopped by networks who are so hypocritically priggish that they refuse to describe disease control as they promote disease transmission. While portraying thousands of sexual encounters each year in programming . . . television is unwilling to give the life-saving information about safe sex and condoms.

LEAD: There's a fresh exhilarating spirit about old Lisbon. The Portuguese seem to have discovered that old is beautiful and brought new life to the fading city center. Some of the main streets have been closed to traffic, creating lively esplanades with open-air cafes and handcraft stands.

LEAD: To kvetch, Leo Rosten wrote in his dictionary-cum-cosmology, ''The Joys of Yiddish,'' is, literally, to squeeze (''Don't kvetch the peaches''); in its verb form it can mean to fuss, to fret, to delay or to shrug, though it has entered the American lexicon as the more generic to complain or gripe.
LEAD: MUCH of American foreign policy is driven by the engine of economic necessity.

LEAD: United States weather forecasters are lagging significantly behind their European counterparts in the international competition to improve global forecasts, according to meteorologists on both sides of the Atlantic.
LEAD: SKI OPERATORS are fond of saying that, ideal as conditions might be, most people have to look out in their backyards and see snow before they ''think skiing.''

LEAD: AS Congress considers legislation aimed at protecting the nation's families, a measure that would guarantee unpaid leave for parents to care for their children is expected to become a hotly debated issue.

LEAD: In a rambling stable near Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx, where hoof picks and poultice jars tumble from lockers and steam puffs from the chimney of an old-fashioned forge, a select group of New York City police officers are taught how to practice their profession on horseback.

LEAD: The engagement of Victoria Anne Oliver to Gordon Geoffrey Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Norman Cohen of New York and Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Lee Oliver of New York and Amagansett, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be.
LEAD: To the Editor: United States citizens are responsible for the frequent abuse of power by their Presidents.

LEAD: Last year there were about 1.6 million apprehensions of would-be illegal immigrants trying to cross the border between Mexico and the United States. Most of these were Mexicans, but by no means all.
LEAD: To homosexual Catholics in the diocese that is composed of Brooklyn and Queens, the news was a surprise.
LEAD: I.R.A.'s are pro-family and pro-America. - Senator William V. Roth, Republican of Maryland

LEAD: Mahler continues to ride serenely along at the crest of his mainstream popularity (at least one trusts it's the crest; with all due respect to his music, it's daunting to imagine it even more popular than it is today). Even with the record companies devoting so much of their energies to compact-disk reissues, new Mahler symphony recordings continue to pour forth, unstoppably.

LEAD: THERE used to be only two 19th-century Giffords to consider - the well-known Sanford Robinson (1823 to 1880) and the comparatively obscure Robert Swain (1840 to 1905). Now there are three, because the work of Charles Henry Gifford (1839 to 1904), uncovered by the historian John I. H. Baur, is having its first major exposure in the show that has just arrived at the Katonah Gallery from the New Bedford Whaling Museum in Massachusetts.

LEAD: When a militant Moslem group today withdrew its offer to exchange three American professors and an Indian scholar for 400 Arab prisoners held by Israel, it did not fix a new date for killing its captives.

LEAD: ELISABETH SOEDERSTROEM played the Marschallin in ''Der Rosenkavalier'' at the Metropolitan Opera Friday night. As the schedule stands, the soprano's three performances in this role - Strauss's classic portrait of an aristocratic woman at the conclusion of a love affair and the threshold of thinking about the passage of time - will conclude her final season at the Met.

LEAD: FICTION 1 1 2 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 2 2 3 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse.
LEAD: ZERO DB And Other Stories. By Madison Smartt Bell. 179 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95.
LEAD: Eamonn Coghlan won the Meadowlands Mile tonight, which surprised no one. Lee McRae, and not Ben Johnson or Carl Lewis, won the 55-meter dash, which surprised many people.

LEAD: A New Orleans police dog, shot in the face Oct.5 after tracking two suspected car thieves to their hiding place under a house, received two medals Friday as the city Police Department honored its officers. In a shootout with police, one suspect was killed and the other wounded. Zeiko, a rottweiler, received the Medal of Merit, the department's second-highest award and the department's Wound Award.

LEAD: AS speculation mounts about Mario M. Cuomo's potential Presidential candidacy, so, too, does the advice he receives - solicited or not -from around the country. Declare now. No, wait until late summer. Carry the banner of the traditional liberal Democrat.
LEAD: Garrison Keillor, the host of the popular public radio show ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' told his audience last night that he would leave the air in June to return to writing.
LEAD: An 11-year-old boy was killed and a 12-year-old girl was critically wounded in unrelated shootings yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn and Queens, the police reported.

LEAD: With a pitching staff headed by Rasmussen and Rhoden, the Yankees would appear to have changed for the better. But wait! How have they changed? They lost Ron Guidry, their most versatile, dependable and successful pitcher for the last 10 seasons. With 15-20 victories gone, the enormous void must be filled by the likes of Hudson, Filson and Tewksbury.

LEAD: Marcia A. Hakim, the corporate secretary and associate general counsel of Trans World Airlines in New York, was married yesterday to Carl H. Hewitt, a vice president and assistant general counsel of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a securities trading firm in New York. Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union in New York, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York.
LEAD: ''A more open and democratic Soviet Union would be a great safeguard to peace.'' - Andrei D. Sakharov. [ 8:1. ]
LEAD: AFTER three outbreaks of salmonella illness in three months, health officials and lawmakers in the state are looking for measures to counter this type of food poisoning.

LEAD: It was in South Africa's black townships that Paul Simon found the harmonies and rhythms for his best-selling ''Graceland'' album, and today he brought that music as close to back home as he could.

LEAD: Texaco lost its appeal to get a $10.53 billion award to Pennzoil overturned, but the Texas appeals court reduced punitive damages to $1 billion, from $3 billion, making the total $8.5 billion, plus about $4 billion in interest. The award had been for ''wrongful interference'' in a Pennzoil deal to acquire Getty in 1984.

LEAD: BECAUSE of the often prohibitive cost of paying for major energy-related and other home repairs, the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development is starting a demonstration program to provide low-interest deferred loans for qualified elderly low- to moderate-income homeowners.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: The engagement of Rebecca Laing Rogers to John Michael Sisto Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sisto of Watchung, N.J., and Hillsboro Beach, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Grant Rogers of Washington and West Palm Beach, Fla., parents of the future bride. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article about American landmarks (Travel, Jan. 18) mentioned the St. Louis railroad station and its conversion into hotels, shops and restaurants. That is an excellent conversion. I remember the station in the 1940's when it was active and contained a very large U.S.O. center for servicemen and women.
LEAD: THOSE WHO FALL By John Muirhead. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

LEAD: UNTIL Henry David Thoreau in the middle of the 19th century, America had no great literature of place and scarcely even the beginnings of such a tradition. Here is an extraordinary cultural phenomenon once we begin to think about it, since it tells us that Americans after 200 years had not yet learned to make significant artistic use of the magnificent lands they called their own.

LEAD: There is something in the air in Sicily that stimulates the foreigner to creativity. The best Sicilian art -the Greek temples, the Byzantine mosaics, the Arab-Norman churches - bears witness to the fullness of expression that foreign cultures attained after they had invaded the island.

LEAD: Paul Whiteman's ''Experiment in Modern Music'' at Aeolian Hall in February 1924 has been remembered until now only because it introduced George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' which Whiteman had commissioned for the occasion. Most of the rest of the program was an attempt by Whiteman to demonstrate the ways in which he was making ''discordant jazz'' palatable.

LEAD: WHILE scores of political prisoners were getting out of Soviet jails and labor camps last week, a Government commission was at work on a sweeping revision of the Soviet criminal code that, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, promised, will make it harder in the future to put people ''behind bars and behind barbed wire.
LEAD: The welfare system was designed 50 years ago for a different America. To conclude that the system isn't working may be the easy part. How to rebuild it is another matter.

LEAD: THERE'S probably not a home in New Jersey - or, for that matter, in any other state -that has not had on its shelves an item made by Johnson & Johnson, the New Brunswick-based health-products manufacturer.
LEAD: Bourgeois Lips

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Zeltner of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Boca Grande, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Zeltner to Lawrence Brian Sorrel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Sorrel of Scarsdale, N.Y. A May 9 wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Mets have definitely changed for the better, at least physically, with the addition of Kevin McReynolds and a full year of Dave Magadan. I question how they've changed emotionally in view of the newsworthy winter some of the Mets experienced.

LEAD: A MALAPROPISM IS a word or phrase that is amusingly off the mark. For example, a recent pamphlet circulated by the Department of Health and Human Services dealt with ''inpatients'' but stated that ''hospital insurance covers impatient hospital care.'' (Inpatient is a retronym based on outpatient; used to be, a person receiving treatment in a hospital was merely a patient, and only the hatchet-faced head nurse was impatient.) The eponymous -ism was formed from ''Mrs.

LEAD: NATIONAL security and newspapers, often portrayed as at odds, may both benefit from technology developed by a Massachusetts company and being marketed with the help of the Princeton-based Gallup Organization.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hudson of Boston and Peru, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jean Hudson, to Roderick David Raabe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raabe of Tokyo and Chathamport, Mass. A July wedding is planned. Miss Hudson and her fiance expect to receive M.B.A.

LEAD: Representative Jack F. Kemp made the customary pilgrimage to the site of 1988's first Presidential primary this week, speaking here and in Hanover on Friday. The New York Republican said he plans to announce his candidacy on April 6. Mr. Kemp allied himself strongly with the Reagan Administration, but said there would be some differences between a Kemp White House and the Reagan White House.
LEAD: BIOTECHNOLOGY The University-Industrial Complex. By Martin Kenney. 306 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $23.95.
LEAD: Surely no national security issue has had such a brief yet bizarre history as the Strategic Defense Initiative.
LEAD: ''On this day, at this hour and at this minute, the heart of Aleksandr Sergeyevich Pushkin ceased to beat,'' the solemn voice intoned through the sound system at Pushkin Square here on Tuesday.

LEAD: To the Editor: How we enjoyed reading ''The Roof of the World by Bus, Car and Foot'' (Travel, Jan. 18)! Last October my husband and I experienced that route from Katmandu to the 18,000-foot pass and under circumstances not much better.

LEAD: I would like to express my gratitude for Elise Bell's compassionate article in which she voiced her surprise that the bill outlawing the use of the cruel steel-jaw trap recently adopted by the Suffolk Legislature is the first such restriction enacted in New York State [ ''The Barbarism of the Steel-Jaw Trap,'' Opinion Page, Jan.

LEAD: The ''storm'' of epilepsy must be endured on many levels: biologically and medically, psychologically and socially. Hiding epilepsy, which even one of Mr. Eichenwald's physicians erroneously advocated, is the outcome of societal stigma. It is perpetuated by a society that is frightened by the loss of control and powerlessness that the disorder represents.
LEAD: To the Editor: May I take the liberty of bringing to your attention errors in ''Austrian Pastry at Teatime'' (Travel, Jan. 25):

LEAD: Mstislav Rostropovich's ongoing 60th birthday party is somewhat larger than life, like his cello playing and his image, embodying the genial, sentimental aspect of the Russian bear. By the end of the New York phase, which began last weekend at Carnegie Hall and will run to March 21, he will have played 15 cello concertos in five programs with three orchestras, conducted four symphonies and the massive War Requiem of his beloved Benjamin Britten and played all six of the Bach cello suites for good measure.

LEAD: Susan Anne FitzPatrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. FitzPatrick of Plattsburgh, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Bruce Leonard Pellerin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Pellerin, also of Plattsburgh. The Rev. Gilbert B. Menard performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.
LEAD: Poor, rural towns in Maine will no longer dump untreated wastes into once-pristine streams and rivers. Tumors will no longer grow on flounder at the bottom of Boston Harbor.

LEAD: AS the nation celebrates George Washington's birthday this week, there is one series of events associated with the Father of the Country that some Dobbs Ferry residents might like to forget - and historians would like to correct.

LEAD: Four top financial executives stood before a Federal judge last week on insider trading charges. But it is becoming more and more evident that it is Wall Street itself, and its role in the corporate takeover boom of recent years, that is facing trial.
LEAD: WOOD warms you twice.

LEAD: To the Editor: Readers of the article on Regensburg may well consider a visit there between May 16 and Aug. 9 of this year, when they can also view a spectacular exhibition devoted to Regensburg manuscript illumination (traced from the eighth century to the Renaissance). The exhibition, held at the Stadtische Galerie Regensburg, will be open daily from 10 A.M.

LEAD: Because of a production error, the Practical Traveler column in some copies of the Travel section last week omitted three lines beneath the drawing. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LEAD: Stiff and wooden acting is sometimes a form of art. In Belgium, the seemingly rigid Toone Marionettes are the smallest, oldest and most dashing of all the inhabitants of Brussels. They dwell in the maze of carless streets next to the Grand-Place that contains some of the city's most-frequented seafood restaurants, whose windows are adorned with centerpieces of crayfish, crabs and lobsters.
LEAD: ''SURVIVAL,'' said President Corazon C. Aquino's executive secretary, Joker Arroyo, with a disdainful flick of his hand.

LEAD: The Little Androscoggin, a slip of a river that winds through Mechanic Falls in the hills outside Auburn, has become the focus of a fight between state environmentalists hoping to protect the river's brook trout and town residents hoping to see an idle paper mill reopen.

LEAD: HAVING safely passed the scrimp-and-save stage of my life, I have earned the right to be extravagant. Sometimes I am even a little wasteful. I am no longer a penny-pincher. I am, however, a penny picker-upper.
LEAD: AFTER trying such themes as ''Love Thy Neighbor,'' the United Way in Burlington, Vt., went in for shock effect in its charity drive last fall - ''reality,'' the group called it.
LEAD: Are the Mets stronger? I think not.
LEAD: ''Every shoe that drops I'm sure is heard in Washington.'' -Daniel J. Good, head of merchant banking, Shearson Lehman, on the crackdown on insider trading.

LEAD: Diana Krumholz, a doctoral candidate in art history and archeology at Columbia University, and Kevin McDonald, a managament consultant at Fletcher & Company in Boston, were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York. The Rev. John Burens of All Souls Unitarian Church performed the ceremony.

LEAD: For North Americans, Panama usually starts with the canal, but it should not end there. There is plenty to do on this isthmus linking South America to Central America, where Indians, the original inhabitants, have blended with later arrivals -- Spanish, Chinese, Africans, French and North Americans.

LEAD: Nancy Susan Weber and N. Lee Sasser, partners in the law firm of Sasser & Weber in Orlando, Fla., were married last evening at the Tavern on the Green in New York by Acting Justice Shirley R. Levittan of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: The truth is quite simple: Robert Ragaini is propagating the worst type of sexism in an effort to justify his own neurotic behavior. Fear of intimacy has not been shown to be genetically linked to the Y chromosome, as far as I know. Continuing the myth that women are naturally more emotional and that men are, as he puts it, ''more goal oriented'' is no different from saying that black people naturally have rhythm.

LEAD: The night ferry from Takeshiba Pier on Tokyo Bay slides away at 10 o'clock from fluorescent-lit buildings, oil refinery flares and the roar of Haneda Airport and heads out into the Pacific Ocean. Seven hours later, as the vessel approaches Oshima, the first of the seven Izu Islands, flying fish lunge from the bow wave and skim on silver wings across a sea tinted pink by sunrise; wild flowers and evergreen shrubs exhale a delicate perfume.

LEAD: WHEN scholars get together to discuss their research, it is usually at the college or graduate-school level. But last Wednesday 175 seniors from six high schools in the county participated in a daylong European History Colloquium at the New Rochelle High School. LEAD: To the Editor: James W. Davis manages to ignore some financial and political realities that need to be considered in discussing the issue of a draft.
LEAD: THE feistiest new fashion in underwear-as-outerwear is the boxer short. Even women don them for dancing and beach cover-ups, or layer them to peek out over trousers.
LEAD: The conservative economic ideas often identified with President Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher have become a key part of the campaign debate in Ireland this year.
LEAD: Almost a year after its opening, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is still plagued by problems, trade show organizers and exhibitors say.

LEAD: WHEN Yehudi Menuhin arrives tomorrow at the Hartt School of Music, his six-day residency in Hartford will include master classes, private coaching and rehearsals for two concerts with the Hartt Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, the first on campus Thursday and the other Saturday in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln
LEAD: EVERYBODY has a weakness.
LEAD: Adults arrested for robbery in the United States, Canada and England face a similar risk of serving jail or prison sentences, a study prepared for the Justice Department said today.

LEAD: Rejecting arguments that the city cannot afford it, St. Louis Aldermen have voted in favor of a bill giving them 48 percent pay increases. The measure, approved Friday 18 to 10, would raise salaries for the part-time positions from $12,500 a year to $18,500. The board must vote one more time next week, but the bill is expected to pass.
LEAD: Saudi Arabia's top Government banker said today that the major industrial countries were ''coming close'' to devising a new way to try to stop the turmoil in the dollar and other currencies.
LEAD: The state's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, called this weekend for increased state aid for New York City, which, he said, has not asked for enough.

LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine today titled ''Sakharov's List'' describes the events that followed Andrei D. Sakharov's delivery of a list to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, citing 14 men confined by Moscow because of their political or religious views. Dr. Sakharov argued that the men should be freed.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a map on Jan. 18 of Istanbul incorrectly showed the locations of two restaurants, and the caption for a photograph incorrectly identified a restaurant. The Ziya and Samdan (there are other restaurants also called Samdan in Istanbul) restaurants are in the modern city, and the restaurant identified in the caption as the Samdan was actually the Hidiv Kasri.

LEAD: THE Koch administration is often accused of not doing enough to house low-income families, and when the vast housing needs of those families are measured against the city's programs, that judgment seems reasonable.
LEAD: To the Editor: John Dornberg's fine sketch of the historical city of Regensburg (Travel, Jan. 18) stirred memories of a delightful incident of a few years ago.
LEAD: ROOSEVELT RACEWAY, once one of the nation's most profitable sports facilities, is today generating large losses and little interest at the box office.

LEAD: In the end, there was the sight of Valery Kamensky, the 20-year-old center and leader of the new generation of hockey talent in the Soviet Union, manufacturing a goal with a brilliant individual effort once considered uncharacteristic of his team's precise, group-oriented style.
LEAD: DEEP BLACK Space Espionage and National Security. By William E. Burrows. Illustrated. 401 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.
LEAD: ESSEX is a town where, in order to be considered a native, a person must have been born in the small village and lived there at least 300 years, said First Selectman John A. Johns.

LEAD: One of the most startling musical events of 1950 was the emergence of a 22-year-old Quechua Indian from the Peruvian Andes with a five-octave voice who sang contralto, mezzo soprano, soprano and coloratura, using growls, chirps and a variety of wordless effects when words would not suffice. Her first album, ''Voice of Xtabay,'' hit the top of the pop best-seller list at the end of 1950.

LEAD: BASKETBALL may not have the same brawling tradition as professional hockey, but a Continental Basketball Association game between the Charleston Gunners of West Virginia and the Cincinnati Slammers at the Charleston Civic Center Friday night had all the makings of a National Hockey League free-for-all.

LEAD: Mark Thatcher, the son of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, married a Texas millionaire's daughter today in a private Valentine's Day wedding. The 33-year-old bridegroom is a Dallas auto executive. The bride, Diane Burgdorf, 26, is a bank employee.

LEAD: A Federal judge today issued a preliminary injunction requiring Medicaid in Virginia to pay for the liver transplant of a 4-year-old girl who was denied aid because of the state's criteria on liver diseases.

LEAD: Nicole Debrunner Anderes, a municipal bond analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in New York, and John Wilson Walter 2d, an assistant vice president of Titus & Donnelly Inc., muncipal bond brokers in New York, plan to be married in September.

LEAD: JOE YOUNG, a 38-year-old driver from Richmond was killed Friday, and Dr. Duell Sturgill suffered two broken legs in a wild six-car pileup during a 200-mile race for four-cylinder subcompacts at the Daytona International Speedway. Young, who was killed instantly, was the 16th driver to die at Daytona since the 2.5-mile track was opened in 1959.

LEAD: SIXTEEN weeks after they completed a runaway season by winning the World Series with an unforgettable comeback, the Mets head into spring training this week as the team that had to improve the least and probably improved the most.

LEAD: THE SACRED COW AND THE ABOMINABLE PIG: Riddles of Food and Culture, by Marvin Harris. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $6.95.) Hindus won't eat beef, while Jews and Moslems avoid pork and Americans quake at the idea of consuming cockroaches, thought a delicacy in some cultures. Marvin Harris examines the reasons people eat what they do in this book, originally titled ''Good to Eat.

LEAD: Joyce Carol Oates has been successsful in a wide range of literary genres, but she has failed to carry off her latest try at something different: a two-word fiction, the pseudonym Rosamond Smith. The author's longtime agent and her editor at E.P. Dutton were flabbergasted last week to learn that Miss Oates had signed with Simon & Schuster to publish ''Lives of the Twins'' under the false name.

LEAD: WALL Street's unprecedented surge has made a lot on investors very happy - and very nervous. Those not content merely to take their gains and run are often forced to ride out the storms of a highly volatile market, hoping that the latest trough is not the start of a prolonged slump. Some brokers argue that such investors can have their cake and eat it too, by hedging their portfolios with put options.

LEAD: South Korea called on North Korea today to reopen suspended talks between the two Governments and rejected a proposal from Pyongyang for a new high-level political and military meeting, officials said.

LEAD: A woman barred from serving on a jury because she is deaf has sued the Blair County judge who dismissed her, alleging she was a victim of discrimination.

LEAD: AN interesting and perhaps important debut recital took place at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Gustavo Romero's choice of music was predictable, and it was cast in a predictably Romantic style. But this young New York pianist has qualities that elevate him a little above the faceless musicality we have come to expect from such events.

LEAD: Lafayette Street, which runs southward from Astor Place just to the east of lively lower Broadway, has been undergoing its own renaissance in recent years with residential development, stylish new restaurants such as Indochine and the continued allure of the Public Theater.

LEAD: The real-estate association that represents New York City's biggest landlords and developers is urging the city to offer special incentives in two districts on the west side of lower Manhattan to prevent corporations from putting their computer operations in the suburbs.

LEAD: Declaring that New York's early laws ''set the pattern for the national Constitution,'' Governor Cuomo this week marked the beginning of a three-year state celebration of the United States Constitution with a display of rare state documents in Albany.

LEAD: For ordinary success in music, almost everyone would agree, irreducible amounts of talent and training are important. But for extraordinary, flabbergasting success, nothing can take the place of a high E.Q., or Exploitability Quotient. Some musicians come by a high E.Q. naturally, some acquire it through diligent study and yet others have it thrust upon them by canny managers.

LEAD: MUSIC SPECTRUM, a chamber-music series presented for the last three seasons by the Russian-Israeli pianist Boris Berman in cooperation with the Yale School of Music, offered an excellent if rather overflowing concert of Czechoslovak music Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall.

LEAD: The engagement of Patricia Lynne Hambrick to Scott Alden Rossborough has been announced by Doris Dana Hambrick of Pleasanton, Calif., and Kenneth Edward Hambrick of Walnut Creek, Calif., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Rossborough of Spruce Head, Me.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, read in Time last week that the magazine had received 46,000 letters on various topics last year. He had a staff member check his own constituent mail and discovered that Time was not even in the race. He received 537,886 letters on all sorts of topics.
LEAD: On Feb. 17, 1947, perhaps as few as 200 -maybe as many as 10,000 - Soviet citizens tuned in, using short-wave radios to listen to the Voice of America's first Russian-language broadcast.

LEAD: St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Kinston, N.C., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Melanie Wilson Hardy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Noel Hardy Jr. of Kinston, to Paul Russell Hardin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Hardin 3d of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Claude Phillip Craig performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Administration is deeply divided over a White House proposal that would give states broad new authority to waive Federal laws defining eligibility for benefits under health, education, welfare, housing and veterans' programs.

LEAD: Buying arms from the West, waging a protracted war against Iraq, taking hostages - Iran is and has been very much in the news. But Peter J. Chelkowski, professor of Near Eastern studies at New York University, has been interested in Iran for quite another reason. He has been studying its stamps, and he's not a philatelist.

LEAD: IT WAS difficult to keep track of the movement of legislative leaders and five urban Mayors around the State House last Tuesday, as well as the shape of the various urban-aid packages they were discussing. However, when the day ended at about 8 P.M. the Mayors, at least, thought they had achieved success.

LEAD: MY mother told me the grim details in our Sunday night long-distance call. Her neighbors were at home when it happened. Louise was gardening, Jim was painting and the older kids were outside. Jim went up to check on Bobby and there he was, in his usual posture, standing in his crib looking out the window.

LEAD: A crowd of 52,745, the largest regular-season turnout in National Basketball Association history, was on hand tonight as the Detroit Pistons scored a 125-107 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

LEAD: Ronald Steel's article contains an error which an astute Wagnerite would pick up. His reference to Mr. Shultz as an ''improbably stolid Siegfried'' is improbable mostly because it is Siegfried's father, Siegmund, who drew the sword from the tree.

LEAD: Imagine 88,000 acres of rolling hills, forests and lakes set aside as a natural habitat for white-tailed deer, beaver, the odd wolf and other wildlife. Imagine it covered by a northern winter's accumulation of snow and frosted with a night's deposit of fluffy new powder. Then imagine it overlaid with 125 miles of groomed cross-country ski trails - all on the doorstep of Canada's capital.

LEAD: ALEJANDRO PENA, the Los Angeles pitcher who came back slowly last season from 1985 shoulder surgery, yesterday became the fourth player whose salary was reduced in arbitration this year and the fifth over all. Don Sears, the arbitrator who heard the case Friday, chose the Dodgers' figure of $280,000 over Pena's $367,500.

LEAD: Nick Ghiz is a sculptor who has a way with abandoned and ephemeral materials. For some time he worked with wood. In the last few years he has been building with paper and glue around a wire scaffolding. He does not want his work to be in any way heavy. He does want it to be magical.
LEAD: VEILED SENTIMENTS Honor and Poetry in a Bedouin Society. By Lila Abu-Lughod. Illustrated. 317 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $35.

LEAD: THE SOUND IS ALWAYS with me - an insistent, rhythmic series of short happy chirps. Like a loyal, friendly cricket, it follows me wherever I go. I hear it at the opera when I rest my head in my hand. It perches beside my bed, singing as I go to sleep, as I wake up. It is my link to the world, my conscience, a reaffirmation of order and integrity in the face of hideous gaping chaos.

LEAD: The Mets will not win their division by 21 1/2 games this year, not because they have weakened, but rather because the Phillies, the Cardinals and Pirates will not all collapse at once.

LEAD: As cross-country skiers step onto their skinny skis in woodlands, meadows and national parks this winter, a major topic of conversation is skating. Pushing outward with each ski alternately, a technique known as the V-skate, is filtering down from racing to the recreational level. Some recreational ski tourers are switching to skating from the slower, traditional stride.

LEAD: THE current stampede to automatic-focusing cameras among single-lens-reflex users brings into bold relief one of photography's less-than-well-kept secrets: for as long as conventional single-lens-reflex cameras have been built and sold, their owners have found them darned difficult to focus.

LEAD: ''A pension established in 1971 and Social Security do not leave a great deal to be shared with others,'' said Donald Bartlett of Chazy, N.Y., with a gift of $20 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I do this for the first time and feel better already.''

LEAD: Dunk: Michael Jordan of the Bulls scoring against the Knicks at the Garden. Bulls won, 112-108. Page 4.

LEAD: Hizma, Israeli-occupied West Bank Just outside this tiny Arab hamlet in the Judean hills, a hand-painted sign reading ''Dreamers Commune'' points the way to the newest Israeli settlement in occupied territory. Perched on a hardscrabble hillside 10 miles north of Jerusalem, this stockade-like settlement, with a watchtower at its center, looks to be more out of the Wild West than the West Bank.
LEAD: THE radio and television had threatened us with possibly 10 inches of snow. I knew my duty and dressed quickly for the siege on the supermarket. Where else does one head when disaster looms?

LEAD: After more than half a century in Nashville, the headquarters of the United States Business and Industrial Council, an outspoken organization of 1,500 conservative business people around the country, is moving to Washington. The main reason, it says, is to lobby more effectively on trade issues.

LEAD: WHO WOULD HAVE THOUGHT THAT VIDEO GAMES - the sport of cola-swigging adolescents - would find a place in the ascetic, achievement-oriented world of beauty and fitness? With their promise of motivating, entertaining and amusing body-conscious exercisers, the new electronic fitness equipment is nudging jump ropes and stationary bicycles to the back of the gym.

LEAD: A top official of a Federal laboratory for the design of nuclear weapons said today that no computer simulations, however advanced or powerful, could ever replace the need for the explosive testing of nuclear arms beneath the earth.

LEAD: Ralph Nader's public interest lobby and legal agency, Public Citizen, is pondering legal action to try to block the pay increases that recently took effect for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior Government officials. But its lawyers are in a quandary over how to do it. One of the problems is that any lawsuit would almost inevitably be decided by a judge whose own raise could well depend on his own ruling.

LEAD: Because of editing errors, the recipe for Chiu Chow braised duck in the Jan. 25 Food column is wrong in part. LEAD: WHEN you walk through the door of Tre Amici in Babylon, you forget you're on Long Island. The brass railings, fresh flowers on the bar, the antique breakfront and the espresso machine all say Italy.

LEAD: I can't describe what strong emotions Kurt Eichenwald's article ''Braving Epilepsy's Storm'' (Jan. 11) evoked in me. I am a physician, and I, too, have epilepsy. Shortly after I graduated from medical school, in 1985, I experienced three seizures.

LEAD: It's poking up everywhere like daffodils through the melting snows of the Reagan revolution. Six months ago, it was still the L-word, the political philosophy that dared not speak its name. Careful believers called themselves ''progressives.'' Even brave ones dared no more than ''neo-liberal.'' Old liberalism - social-program liberalism - was discredited.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lawrence Montgomery of Irving, Tex., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jane Montgomery, to Tyler Hans Hofinga, a son of Shirley Philippine Dixon of Riverside, Calif., and Peter Hans Hofinga of Irvine, Calif. Miss Montgomery is the director of media development and a product manager for Amscan Inc., a party goods company in Harrison, N.Y.

LEAD: The female figure in the Italian Renaissance was not only idealized as a Neoplatonic manifestation of ''heaven on earth,'' but seen as the embodiment of intellectual refinement. And with this elevation of the flesh came a new cultural phenomenon - that of the ''honest courtesan.'' These highbrow mistresses, companions to princes, painters, ambassadors and merchants, writes Lynne Lawner in LIVES OF THE COURTESANS: Portraits of the Renaissance (Rizzoli, $35), were at once financially autonomous and perpetually enslaved.

LEAD: It is by a conspicuous coincidence that a show devoted to Jasper Johns's paintings of ''The Seasons'' should be on view through March 7 at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, while simultaneously there can be seen in the new Lila Acheson Wallace wing at the Metropolitan Museum what may well be the single largest work of contemporary art ever to be mounted in a great American museum.

LEAD: I THINK of those old fellows -commercial pioneers, really -with the onset of the Lincoln-Washington birthday sales. I mean those ubiquitous gentlemen of yesteryear, ''the dollar-down, dollar-a-week'' men.
LEAD: Tobacco Ads: Legal Debate A plan that would prohibit the advertising of tobacco products has started a lively debate at the American Bar Association's convention. Page 26.

LEAD: Vietnamese immigrants who have settled in Philadelphia over the last decade have often been silent victims of assault, robbery and extortion by a small gang of Vietnamese youths. LEAD: If you want to see how incomplete was Pizarro's conquest of the Incas, go to Cuzco. Step inside the cathedral on the Plaza de Armas, walk past the altar of beaten silver with its monstrance of solid gold, and pause before a 17th-century painting of the Last Supper. Here Jesus and his disciples sit down to a meal not of bread and wine, but of cuy and chicha - guinea pig and corn beer.

LEAD: DWIGHT GOODEN is on probation for three years after having pleaded no contest to two felony charges: violently resisting arrest and battery on a Tampa police officer. His former fiancee, Carlene Pearson, was arrested two weeks ago for carrying a loaded two-shot derringer at La Guardia Airport, where she was to meet the Mets' right-hander for a reported reconciliation.

LEAD: ONE second I was standing square on my feet, shoveling a light covering of snow. The next I was sprawled on my behind, sliding down the driveway. I did what a lot of other people have done in the last few weeks. I fell down.

LEAD: To the Editor: In his Feb. 7 letter, Judge Bruce McM. Wright cites as historical fact the story of Thomas Jefferson's slave mistress, Sally Hemmings. It is simply ridiculous that this patent lie should still be seen in print. Its origin is almost as old as our Republic.

LEAD: The Soviet authorities gave Andrei D. Sakharov an official forum to speak his mind here today, and he used the unusual occasion to appeal for more civil liberties and an easing of emigration curbs.

LEAD: Following last week's economic reports, the White House issued its customary response. ''Virtually all of the economy's vital signs point to a healthy 1987,'' Marlin Fitzwater, President Reagan's spokesman, said, forecasting ''continued prosperity under the Reagan expansion.'' On the question of expansion, there was little disagreement from private analysts.
LEAD: As a male, I frankly have grown tired of reading about men who are unable to commit to relationships (''The Truth Is Not Simple,'' by Robert Ragaini, About Men, Jan. 11). It's old news.

LEAD: OF THE REVIVAL STYLES THAT burgeoned during the 19th century, Gothic Revival is perhaps best remembered in this country for the so-called Carpenter Gothic, or gingerbread, houses built in the mid-19th century. Characterized by steeply pitched roofs adorned with decorative details, both the architecture and interior design were inspired by medieval English sources.

LEAD: With its sixth season recently completed, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival - the most publicized and popular American showcase for the new performing arts - is making plans that include more emphasis on European dance companies and increased roles for theater and opera. Very visibly at the peak of its success, the festival - it was called a series in 1981 and 1982, rechristened a festival in 1983 - appears to be at a turning point.

LEAD: On Jan. 18 an article appeared in the Long Island section titled ''Nassau's Water Needs Protection'' [ Opinion Page ] . The piece asserted that Suffolk County officials are ''shrewdly'' pursuing Environmental Quality Bond Act money with which to purchase environmentally sensitive acreage while Nassau County and its municipalities are not.

LEAD: Bayport $180,000 60 Oakwood Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 110-year-old colonial; fireplace, basement, wraparound porch, barn, 1 acre; taxes $3,700. Commack $228,000 4 Town Line Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; eat-in kitchen, dining room, den, fireplace, skylights, loft; taxes $5,100.

LEAD: A review Feb. 8 of ''Watching Television: A Pantheon Guide to Popular Culture,'' edited by Todd Gitlin and published by Pantheon Books, contained incomplete price information. The book is available in hard cover at $19.95 and in paperback at $9.95.

LEAD: SURROGATE motherhood presents such troublesome ethical and legal dilemmas that most state legislatures have declined to confront the issue. Those that have tried have been discouraged in their attempts to regulate the practice. Most bills have died in committee, while those that have survived have gone on to defeat.

LEAD: A former Augustinian academy that later became a retreat house -a sprawling Spanish-style structure in the Grymes Hill section of Staten Island - once epitomized tranquility. But it is now caught in a fierce tug-of-war between two developers, both fighting to acquire the 19-acre site to create a vast colony of condominiums.
LEAD: ''Why do you write?'' I was asked by an officer of the secret police in Warsaw. ''An intelligent man does not write. An intelligent man does not leave any traces.''
LEAD: WHEN Leslie Elion of Mount Kisco wanted to send flowers to a hospitalized friend in Chicago recently, she called the Westchester County Office for the Disabled.

LEAD: The Knicks have grown used to waiting. It has almost become a pastime for several players, those who are hoping to be playing for another team before pro basketball's trade deadline arrives at midnight tonight. So the feeling wasn't new to them, even though the reason was.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Those who believe that the Guggenheim Museum should have no addition whatsoever - that to tamper with Frank Lloyd Wright's masterpiece in any fashion would be akin to adding a few square inches to one of the Picassos or Braques that repose within it - will not be satisfied with the museum's latest plan, announced last week.
LEAD: AT the expo held across the street from the conference last weekend, the emphasis shifted to the inventions themselves and the inventors were as proud as students at a school science fair.

LEAD: The marriage of Jennifer Mead, a daughter of Donald Edwin Mead of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and the late Sonia Richon Mead, to John Sullivan took place yesterday at the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House in New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Healy Sullivan of Cuernavaca, Mexico.

LEAD: A FEW DAYS AFTER Andrei D. Sakharov was released from internal exile in Gorky last December, the 65-year-old theoretical physicist and human-rights activist sat in his Moscow apartment, bundled in an American warm-up jacket, and proposed a modest litmus test of the liberalization ostensibly taking place in Soviet society.
LEAD: Arlie G. Skelton Jr. of Boonville, Ind., is no longer speaking to his neighbor.
LEAD: Guide to Central Florida Rand McNally Video Trips. Annette Funicello, host. Lightning Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: STARTING WITH SICHUAN, moving on to Mexican and flourishing in the riffs of New Orleans, American tastes in food have been moving steadily south and becoming significantly spicy. Consequently, food watchers and eaters have not been surprised that among the new eats in town is Caribbean cuisine.

LEAD: Many composers have written spirited memoirs - one thinks immediately of Hector Berlioz, Richard Wagner and, in our time, Aaron Copland, Virgil Thomson and Otto Luening. Next month the composer Robert Starer month the composer Robert Starer thors, with the Random House publication of ''Continuo: A Life in Music.
LEAD: An ancient Roman city is quickly emerging here from a high-speed archeological dig in which the hated bulldozer is peeling back time alongside the painstaking pick-and-brush workers.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. R.Thomas Dalbey of Denver of the engagement of their daughter Marie Overton Dalbey to Marc Tabah, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tabah of Demarest, N.J., and Cabris, France. The wedding is to be June 13.

LEAD: The caption with a photo of Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and Gustav Heningburg that appeared on the Opinion Page of Feb. 1, to illustrate an article by Howard Quirk did not credit the photographer. The photo was taken by Suzanne Poor.
LEAD: THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS By Doris Kearns Goodwin. Illustrated. 932 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

LEAD: EASTERN Connecticut's regional police helicopter program, the first time that several communities in the state have shared a rescue and patrol copter, is working well for participating towns and is attracting the attention of other communities.

LEAD: More than 1,000 people have been killed and 40,000 imprisoned during a campaign of ''forced Bulgarianization'' of ethnic Turks in Bulgaria, a former member of the Bulgarian Parliament said last week.

LEAD: To the Editor: Almost as an article of faith, James W. Davis, in his call for renewal of the draft (''Bring Back the Draft,'' Op-Ed, Feb. 5) asserts ''the armed forces, however, cannot go out and recruit the middle-aged.''

LEAD: WITH Tomas Sandstrom out at least six weeks because of a broken ankle, the Rangers have recalled the right wing, Chris Jensen, from New Haven. Jensen, who was sent to the American Hockey League team two weeks ago, has appeared in 31 N.H.L. games this season with 5 goals and 7 assists. . . . After spending six years as an assistant for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Howard Tippett has been named defensive coordinator at the University of Illinois.

LEAD: Finally there is something to say about Mona Lisa's smile. A current theory holds that ''La Gioconda'' is a self-portrait - Leonardo without his beard - and that the smile is, in fact, a trickster's derisive glimmer, a transvestite joke: five centuries of pulling the wool over everyone's eyes.
LEAD: Wednesday's shooting on a busy Greenwich Village street of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial set off reverberations of fear in the New York underworld.
LEAD: WHILE the state of the new play is imperiled on Broadway, it appears to be flourishing in Connecticut's theaters.
LEAD: THERE are many people who, from time to time, blame a biased and partisan press for unwanted election results. And for a few high-intensity races, that is conceivably true.
LEAD: COLD and windy feels worse than cold and calm.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH it is still not certain whether a Southerner will be running for President, there is little doubt that the South looms large in the politics of 1988. Democrats decided last week to hold their national convention in Atlanta; the Republicans voted last month to take theirs to New Orleans.

LEAD: THE United States Coast Guard will hold a public hearing at 7 P.M. Wednesday at the New Rochelle City Hall on a proposal to develop Davids Island, an 80-acre piece of land 3,500 feet offshore, by building 2,000 condominiums and a marina for 850 boats.

LEAD: ALL my life I've had this little problem. I seem to be invisible. When I look in the mirror, a wide-eyed woman stares back at me, but in groups I'm unnoticed. No, it's worse than that; I'd say unpresent.

LEAD: Indian health officials said Friday that at least 71 cases of AIDS had been recorded in this nation, and scientists said they were worried by the high number of women who are prostitutes among the total.

LEAD: February brought a Brooklyn woman daffodil leaves standing up a couple of inches in her garden -since frozen - a pair of black and white ladderbacked downy woodpeckers and, best of all, a rooster gorgeously appointed with red cockscomb, full rufous ruff, red feathers shading into iridescent greens toward the tail.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
