LEAD: In his article on David Salle, Paul Taylor appears to be confusing a media event with an original artistic interpretation of that event. The assassination of Lee Harvey Oswald may, indeed, be public property, as Mr. Salle claims, but Cockrill/Judge Hughes's line drawing of the event is not public property.

LEAD: THE cold wind whipped off the ocean, sending frigid sea spray in the direction of the few who ventured out on the Long Beach boardwalk. A few hundred feet away, on the second floor balcony of a small garden apartment, Susan Montana proudly surveyed her ocean view.
LEAD: A WALKER IN JERUSALEM by Samuel Heilman. Summit Books. 366 pages. $18.95.
LEAD: American labor unions, weakened in the early 1980's by rapidly declining membership and concessions on wages and benefits, held their ground in some key areas in 1986.

LEAD: With each new charge of insider trading, pressure is mounting in Washington to legislate a policing structure to compensate for what some on Capitol Hill are calling ''a real breakdown in the self-regulatory mechanisms on Wall Street.'' Last week's events, which stunned even the traders who had been talking for months about shoes dropping, are only expected to heighten the sense of urgency.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Riot police subduing an anti-Government demonstrator yesterday in Dhaka. The protest was called to mourn the deaths of two students who died earlier in the day in the southern port city of Chittagong. They were killed, and scores were injured, when five gasoline bombs were thrown at Moslem demonstrators.

LEAD: A MAN, taking notes, hovers near the bar at Biscayne Babies, a popular haunt for young revelers in the Coconut Grove section of Miami. In Miami's Casablanca-like climate of international intrigue, he could be mistaken for a spy as he strains to hear exchanges between the bartenders and waitresses above the background din of rock music.

LEAD: THE arrests last week of three prominent traders on Wall Street renewed concern about the takeover frenzy and the temptations of its huge profits. Much of the debate centers on how best to slow the torrid pace of hostile bids. But there is also a continuing argument about the extent to which the voice of the shareholder is heard in the board room.
LEAD: Beginning on May 7, smoking will be banned in most public indoor areas in New York State and restricted on the job and in most restaurants.
LEAD: W-o-r-c-e-s-t-e-r: No Free Rides
LEAD: For the last three months Japan has been mesmerized, appalled and frustrated by an overseas hostage situation of its own: the abduction of a trading-company executive in the Philippines.
LEAD: BALTIMORE GLASS DISPLAY

LEAD: CROSS COUNTRY SKI INNS OF THE EASTERN U.S. AND CANADA By Marge Lamy, with photographs by George W. Gardner. 124 pages. The Stephen Greene Press, distributed by Viking Penguin. Paperback. $12.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The engagement of Lynn Brandi to Alvin Woodrow Bunis Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bunis of Cincinnati, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. E. Bruce Brandi of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: BESIDES keeping heads warm, hats are providing a note of needed cheer these dreary winter days. On second thought, perhaps cheer doesn't quite cover the gamut of what hats are now providing, so let's add some words, like drama, adventure, flair and hoot - as in, ''That hat's a hoot.''

LEAD: Early in Paul Schrader's new film, ''Light of Day,'' the director jumps from a sequence of a rock-and-roll band performing in a Cleveland bar to short shots of the musicians at their day jobs. Two of them work in a metal-pressing plant, and just before the camera leaves the scene it shows the factory's current product, commemorative trays of Prince Charles and Lady Diana.

LEAD: IN Norwich, keeping properties spruced up is now the law. A new city ordinance specifies that all buildings in the city ''shall reflect a level of maintenance in keeping with the standards of the community and not constitute a blighting factor for adjoining property owners.''

LEAD: The conviction of a Mount Vernon man in a child-abuse case, after 18 children testified, came despite a national climate that experts say has developed against basing such convictions on the testimony of children.

LEAD: It was the second attempt, and it took the intervention of Governor Cuomo to bring it about, but last week a dozen white teen-agers were indicted in the attack on three black men in Howard Beach that shocked the nation and heightened racial tensions in New York.

LEAD: Judith D. Altschuler Is Wed Judith Debra Altschuler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Altschuler of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Bruce Jeffrey Zalbe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Zalbe of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Mark Diamond officiated at the Greenbelt (Md.) Hilton. The bride, a graduate of Rider College, is a physician's assistant in Washington.
LEAD: A 6-month-old baby girl was found dead yesterday afternoon in a two-wheeled cart behind a building in Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: BOB HAWKE is a casual, down-to-earth kind of Australian, a former union leader who in 1954 set a world beer-drinking record by guzzling two and a half pints in 12 seconds. Soon, he will try to set another record by becoming the first Prime Minister from the Labor Party to win a third term.

LEAD: Lawyers for John Gotti and his six co-defendants have taken the offensive in recent weeks at their Federal racketeering trial, asserting that the prosecutors had gone to extreme and unfair lengths to win convictions.

LEAD: BRUISED FRUIT. By Amy Ephron. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Perhaps to differentiate herself from the bittersweet comic writing practiced by her sisters Nora and Delia, Amy Ephron has gone in another direction - toward bittersweet tragic writing. Her second novel, ''Bruised Fruit,'' is composed of the sort of affectless prose associated with stories about disengaged women by writers like Jean Rhys.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Danny Manning scored 26 points and Cedric Hunter hit a key free throw in the final seconds today as Kansas took sole possession of first place in the Big Eight with an 86-84 victory over Oklahoma.

LEAD: Work can be oversold as a fix for welfare and a cure for poverty. Just ask the three million Americans who work full time and still can't escape poverty. Nevertheless, self-sufficiency through work properly remains the fulcrum of welfare reform. The challenge is to be realistic about just how much can be achieved through work, both for society and for individual welfare recipients.

LEAD: THE dispatches of those who returned from exotic mountain ranges used to sound pretty much the same, waxing expansive on the fellowship and courage exhibited during some bold gamble in which everyone behaved marvelously. Even a saga as exciting as ''Annapurna,'' the story of the 1950 French ascent of that treacherous 26,504-foot-high Himalayan peak, celebrated selflessness, as when the veteran mountaineer Lionel Terray yielded>ju his chance at the summit to the author, Maurice
LEAD: SOMEBODY ELSE'S LIFE By Morris Philipson. 298 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

LEAD: THE six jazz musicians who make up the group called the Leaders -because, in theory, they normally lead groups of their own - have not entirely separated themselves from the privileges of leadership in their performances at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, between Grove and Bleeker Streets, where they are appearing through today.

LEAD: What a curious piece on George Shultz. The nation cries for integrity in its public officials. When Professor Steel finds it, he calls it vanity. When an offhand answer is given to a fuzzy question, professorial pique erupts.

LEAD: KATIE MORAG AND THE TWO GRANDMOTHERS Written and illustrated by Mairi Hedderwick. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 8) KATIE MORAG AND THE TIRESOME TED Written and illustrated by Mairi Hedderwick. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 8)

LEAD: HIDDEN SYMPTOMS. By Deirdre Madden. (Atlantic Monthly, $14.95.) Although Deirdre Madden's first novel is set in Belfast in 1969, it is more about familial love than Ireland's political struggles. In her view, however, the two are united: the loyalties between parents and children can easily be perverted into the sectarian hatreds that divide the country.

LEAD: To The Editor: What was to have been a perfect family vacation in Ixtapa, Mexico, suddenly turned into a nightmare due to the onset of a life-threatening virual infection that attacked my daughter. The infection, incidently, was of a homegrown U.S.A. variety.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Ruth Rothschild Mayleas of New York of the engagement of her daughter, Alexandra Rothschild Mayleas, to Peter Lindsay Heth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Heth of San Diego. The wedding is planned for April 11. Ms. Mayleas is a daughter also of William M. Mayleas of Laguna Niguel, Calif.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration's clandestine dealings with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels grew out of a well-concealed program established in the White House at least four years ago to conduct covert foreign policy initiatives, according to many present and former Government officials.

LEAD: NOBODY had built a better mousetrap, but there were plenty of other ideas among the inventors who gathered last weekend in Arlington, Va., for the Seventh Annual National Inventors Conference. Under the aegis of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, more than 50 inventors from around the country displayed their newly patented creations - ranging from a fortune-cookie folding machine to a shoe that allows its wearer to virtually walk on water - in hopes of attracting some commercial interest.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Kurjan of Woodmere, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Roberta Lee Kurjan to Ethan H. Schwartz, a son of Rabbi Dr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Schwartz of Evanston, Ill. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: ON A RECENT Saturday night, quite a few of the regulars of the ''21'' Club saw fit to knot their funeral ties and come over to the midtown restaurant to pay their respects. At the end of the evening, the restaurant would close its doors, only temporarily, to be sure - it will reopen in early April -for restoration, not renovation, as the new management is careful to claim.

LEAD: There was an air of anticipation as Dr. Gregg Hesseltine gently removed the bandages from his patient's severely mangled leg. There was only a chance in a hundred that the operation was successful.
LEAD: ORCHESTRA NEW ENGLAND, known in Connecticut for its innovative ''Colonial Concerts'' and summertime ''Stars and Stripes'' series, has filed for reorganization under bankruptcy laws.
LEAD: THE setting is an Internal Revenue Service office.

LEAD: One member of the United Klans of America had been sentenced to death, and another to life in prison, for the 1981 murder of a black teen-ager whose battered body was left hanging from a tree. Last week the Klan itself was held to account.
LEAD: New charges have been filed against a youth who was accused last month of attacking several people with a golf club.
LEAD: ''I THINK it was the rapport between labor and management at the North Tarrytown plant that finally decided them,'' said Vincent Tese, the state Director of Economic Development.

LEAD: THE Morris County Board of Chosen Freeholders has unofficially approved a $1.183 million package that would maintain services for the elderly, ranging from Meals on Wheels for the homebound to minor home repairs for those too frail to do their own.

LEAD: In a clockwork assault that authorities said bore the handwriting of terror organizations, a postal van was robbed in a residential neighborhood here today, and three police guards were slain by assailants who made off with $900,000.
LEAD: An Iranian opposition group said Friday that its guerrillas had wounded the brother of Iran's President in an attack with hand grenades and machine guns in a northeastern Iranian city.
LEAD: ONE key to avoiding sprawl and gridlock along the Route 1 corridor region may be adopting ''centers'' as the basic building blocks of regional planning and zoning.

LEAD: No American commercial television production has ever come remotely close to the sustained quality of British miniseries like ''Brideshead Revisited,'' ''I, Claudius'' or ''Ascent of Man.'' What networks do give us is elephants like ''Amerika.'' This 14 1/2-hour political melodrama, costing at least $40 million, begins tonight and tells a good deal about how ABC Entertainment regards the average viewer's intelligence.

LEAD: The 14 1/2-hour production of ''Amerika,'' beginning a weeklong run tonight at 9, has been a costly exercise for the ABC Network division of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. In dollars, the mini-series, set in a Soviet-occupied United States in 1997, has added up to at least $40 million, or somewhere around $2.8 million per 49-minute (before commercials) hour.
LEAD: IN 1985, The Trenton Times dropped the ''Trenton'' and became, simply, The Times, a move intended to show that the paper was not for Trenton only.

LEAD: IF you were naming a restaurant, you might have qualms about calling it Rigoletto's, after the ill-starred and vindictive jester of the tragic Verdi opera. Perhaps the proprietor of Rigoletto's, a new Italian eatery in New Canaan, recalls the opera differently, for the menu states that ''the character of Rigoletto .
LEAD: MY husband and I sit here in our den surrounded by files, pads of paper, pencils and two calculators, preparing for our favorite annual event. The preparation of our taxes.
LEAD: AFTER several false starts, an effort to revive an idled 650,000-square-foot Playskool plant on this city's economically scarred Northwest side is finally taking shape.

LEAD: COME AS YOU ARE: The Peace Corps Story. By Coates Redmon. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) Anyone who has known Peace Corps volunteers in the field cannot help but be impressed by their dedication and diligence. But readers curious about the first generation of Americans to take on third world deprivation hand-to-hand won't find much of an account in ''Come as You Are.
LEAD: The suicide of a scientist at the National Institutes of Health was related to an investigation into possible fraud in a manuscript on genetics research, his widow said Friday.

LEAD: I read with increasing distress Ronald Steel's attack on Secretary of State George Pratt Shultz (''Shultz's Way,'' Jan. 11). It is one thing to differ with a man's policies; it seems quite another to question his integrity because he differs from you on political issues.
LEAD: Boris Godunov By Mussorgsky. The Bolshoi Opera with Yevgeni Nesterenko as Boris. From a 1978 live performance. Kultur. 181 minutes (2 cassettes). $69.95.
LEAD: As AIDS continues its spread, mounting fear over the epidemic has been matched by persistent confusion over how the virus that causes the disease is transmitted.

LEAD: TWO EUROPEAN 'VISITS' Andre de la Varre Jr., a tour guide and filmmaker, will show his travelogue ''Switzerland and the Alps'' Friday evening at Snug Harbor on Staten Island. On Saturday afternoon, at the Williams Carlos Center for the Arts in Rutherford, he will present his film-lecture ''Vienna - Memories and Reality.

LEAD: Were special honors to be awarded for dubious achievements, the new compact-disk changers would rank among the leading contenders. Spinning stacks of CD's for hours on end, they stretch out the music beyond anyone's attention span and make it all seem vapid. Hailed for their nearly interminable running time, these longwinded changers are the culmination of a trend that - up to a point - made sense.
LEAD: A $150 million plan was under consideration in Florida last year to make a river crooked again after the Federal Government had spent $21 million to make it straight.

LEAD: Nancy Ellen Margolis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney H. Margolis of Houston, was married at Temple Beth Israel there last night to Robert Edward Risman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Risman of Birmingham, Ala. Rabbi Samuel Karff, assisted by Rabbi Dr. Hyman Judah Schachtel and Rabbi Dr. Henry Bamberger, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The position of Senator Norman J. Levy, Republican of Merrick, on a gasoline tax to improve Long Island's roads was misstated in last Sunday's Long Island Weekly section. A spokesman for Mr. Levy, James V. Moriarty, said the Senator was opposed to such a tax.

LEAD: The pressures of population growth and economic expansion are starting to exceed the ability of the earth's natural systems to sustain such activity, a new report by the Worldwatch Institute warned today.

LEAD: SHOPPING centers age fast, especially in Southern California, and updating old ones often costs more than they are worth. But in the Crenshaw area of this city, a local developer and the city hope to confound that problem at a cost of $100 million by reviving and expanding the state's first regional shopping mall.

LEAD: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has been fighting with the Pentagon for years, seeking to loosen United States export controls that he blames for billions of dollars of business lost to Europe and Japan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A sudden souring of Brazil's economic situation has seriously eroded political and popular support for President Jose Sarney, tumbling the country into its worst crisis since civilian rule returned two years ago.

LEAD: Iraq said its warplanes bombed the Iranian capital, Teheran, and nine other cities today. Iran disputed the report of a bombing of Teheran but confirmed Iraqi raids on eight other cities and reported civilians were killed or wounded in them.

LEAD: THE problem with a CD-ROM-stored data base, as I mentioned last week, is that while it is fine for someone delving into history, it will not do for up-to-the-minute information like stock quotations or just-breaking news stories. For that kind of timely data, one's computer needs access by modem to an on-line data base.

LEAD: To the Editor: We at the Nature Conservancy are grateful that Mr. Leifermann found the Blowing Rocks Preserve special enough to mention, but several statements about the preserve were misleading. Blowing Rocks is not a ''State Nature Preserve.'' The Blowing Rocks Preserve is owned and managed by the Nature

LEAD: Demonstrators with signs referring to Mayor Emory Folmar of Montgomery at a rally outside the State Capitol after a march yesterday. The demonstration was called to protest what black leaders regard as racist committee assignments in the Legislature. (AP)
LEAD: ELDERLY people who suffer from arthritis are being urged to take to the computer keyboard to learn strategies to fight their disease.

LEAD: Forty-five cases of arson and cross-burnings have occurred after minority families have moved into mostly white neighborhoods around the country in the last two years, a national legal and educational group said in a recent report.

LEAD: THE newest attraction at the Rockefeller State Park Preserve in North Tarrytown is a giant jagged chunk of rock at least 600 million years old. This mass of free-standing gneiss, almost 20 feet high and 65 feet in circumference, is probably the largest ''glacial erratic'' to be found anywhere in the county.

LEAD: Deep into the grimy city's bowels stride the subway riders. Purses jammed under arms, tokens jammed in hands. Jaws set. Eyes straight ahead.

LEAD: Fifty-five pounds of heroin was seized by agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration and the United States Customs Service on Friday, leading to the arrest of two Taiwanese men in a Brooklyn apartment.

LEAD: Eighteen people were found guilty here last week of parading in and obstructing the rotunda of the Capitol, in a case stemming from the arrest of 112 demonstrators who last August protested United States aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents.
LEAD: DEAR GEORGE:

LEAD: Donald L. Fowler of South Carolina, a veteran Democratic leader and rules expert, has been chosen as the chief executive officer of the party's national convention to be held in Atlanta in mid-July next year. Mr. Fowler, selected for the job by the national chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., will be in charge of all planning and organization for the convention for the next 17 months.

LEAD: Neighborhood youngsters looking at the wreckage of the Helping Hand Rescue Mission yesterday in Huntington Station. The building was destroyed by an explosion and fire late Saturday night. The mission, which distributed food and clothing to needy people, was unoccupied at the time of the blast and there were no injuries.
LEAD: Donald Royal hit two free throws with 24 seconds left in overtime to break a 66-all tie and Scott Paddock made two more foul shots as Notre Dame edged Duke, 70-66, today.

LEAD: Amid questions about its Christian mission and its role in the neighborhood, Union Theological Seminary is cautiously exploring whether to raise money by allowing a developer to build a luxury condominium tower on its Collegiate Gothic campus just north of Columbia University.

LEAD: Late in the second act of ''Dazy,'' a musical set in midtown Manhattan, a homeless man assures the audience, ''You've got to be a romantic to live out on the street.'' The pronouncement, which flies in the face of evidence that most New Yorkers encounter every day, exemplifies the colossal wrongheadedness of a show that portrays street people as muddled bohemian eccentrics down on their luck.

LEAD: A fairly familiar story these days is the one about well-meaning children taking their elderly parents away from traditional surroundings and placing them, perhaps at considerable cost, in a presumably safer, more comfortable environment. Far too often, the transplanted old folk end up unhappy and decidedly unappreciative.

LEAD: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday last week reported an erroneous finding by a committee of baseball researchers. The committee, which said it had turned up evidence that Babe Ruth was born with the surname Ehrhardt, now acknowledges that this belief, which apparently first surfaced in the 1920's, has since been authoritatively discounted.
LEAD: BASEBALL'S Uncertain Spring starts Friday.

LEAD: Alvin W. Trivelpiece, Assistant Secretary of Energy for energy research, has been named Executive Officer of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the association announced today.

LEAD: Andrea Kanon Frey, a product manager for the American Home Products Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Howard Bass, the television production cost analyst for DFS-Dorland Worldwide, an advertising agency in New York. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Water Club restaurant in New

LEAD: ALEXANDER VON ZEMLINSKY had the misfortune of being born sane in an extravagant age. Eminent composer of his day, conductor, teacher of Schoenberg, colleague of Mahler, Zemlinsky did everything with enormous technique and thoughtful care; yet he has sunk into musical history, pulled down by the inertia of forgetfulness and neglect.
LEAD: Pushing Back Retirement New laws barring age discrimination are likely to encourage older workers to stay on the job, earning incomes and paying taxes. Page 43.

LEAD: Corporate profits showed modest improvement in the fourth quarter, a result of the weaker dollar and continued low oil prices and interest rates. Still, economists said the earnings remained below expectations and indicated continuing sluggishness in the economy.

LEAD: In New York, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's observation took on a new meaning this weekend when arctic winds swept across the region, and plummeting temperatures divided the city into two camps: those who view the cold as exhilarating, and those for whom the cold is a brutal - and sometimes lethal - hardship.
LEAD: Lawyers are at odds as the American Bar Association prepares to take up proposals for improving the system of recovering damages for personal injuries.

LEAD: A prep school student upset because he had been caught drinking went on a shooting rampage on campus, wounding an administrator and a teacher before being shot to death by the police, according to police and school officials.

LEAD: Marian Johnston, a 71-year-old word-processing secretary at Bradley Hospital in Riverside, R.I., is happy about the new Federal law that bans mandatory retirement because of age. ''I don't know what I would have done if they hadn't hired me last August,'' she said.

LEAD: Blessed with open space, stunning scenery and a benign climate, the biggest problem facing people in this part of Northern California, it would seem, is protecting the region from urban growth. LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Bill Elliott won his second Daytona 500 as Geoff Bodine, losing a gamble, ran out of gas three laps from the end today at Daytona International Speedway.

LEAD: The Briefing column on the Washington Talk page Tuesday incorrectly described the function at which the Canadian Embassy played host to visiting officials from the South Pacific nation of Vanuatu. The event was a prayer meeting for representatives of countries in the Oceania region, not a diplomatic reception.
LEAD: Iosif Z. Begun, the Jewish dissident whose continued imprisonment set off violent demonstrations in downtown Moscow last week, has been freed, a senior Soviet official said today.

LEAD: For a school that's getting a brand-new $8.5 million gym next season, Williams College is making an awful lot of fuss about the old one. All former Williams basketball players have been invited back to bid farewell to the old gym when the Ephmen play their final game there Feb. 28, and many are expected to show up this Saturday for the game against the college's chief rival,

LEAD: Officials of the National Archives and their counterparts in the Soviet Union may begin exchanging copies of the two countries' official records for the first time under an international agreement to be signed this week. The agreement, between the American Council of Learned Societies and the Main Archival Administration of the Soviet Council of Ministers, would create a Commission on Archival

LEAD: ''The question is not whether the Federal courts should be changed but rather whether that change, through inaction, will take the form of continuing deterioration, or of some structural alteration that will preserve the essence of a valuable institution. I hope the bar will have the foresight to give thoughtful consideration to this.

LEAD: Already struggling to contain the highest inflation rate in the country's history, the Brazilian Government is now bracing itself for a new foreign debt crisis brought on by a dramatic slump in its hard currency reserves, according to Government officials.

LEAD: Theodore M. Weis, a trumpet player with several classical ensembles in New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital on Saturday. He was 66 years old and lived in Englewood.

LEAD: On Friday, Jan. 17 of last year, when Ronald Reagan or his autopen signed the ''finding'' submitted by Admiral Poindexter sending arms to Iran without notifying Congress, the two officials who ordinarily handled secret arms transfers had not yet returned from a trip to China.

LEAD: On a typical day in Judge Renee White's courtroom, a procession of defendants passed before the bench - accused crack users and crack dealers, young men charged with washing motorists' windows without permission, Senegalese accused of peddling without a license.

LEAD: Bill Cartwright had already spoken to a real estate agent about selling his house. Trent Tucker was trying various tennis racquets for a possible change of venue to a warmer climate. Pat Cummings wondered what would become of his Manhattan apartment. And Jawann Oldham was envisioning himself as some team's starting center.

LEAD: QUESTION: In major league baseball, which has occurred more frequently, a no-hitter or a batter hitting for the cycle? Although both are scarce, over the years, it has been slightly easier for a starting pitcher to keep an opposing team hitless for nine innings than it has been for a batter to rap opposing pitchers for a single, double, triple and home run in one game.

LEAD: It was a few beers past midnight at the Quarter Deck Inn. Outside, the wind-chill factor pushed 10 degrees, and the weather forecast called for light snow. Inside, the bar was elbow-to-elbow with smartly sweatered out-of-towners, and the band was earnestly bopping its way through a current hit, ''It's Hip to be Square.

LEAD: Tropical rain turned a sunny afternoon of formful racing at Hialeah Park into a dark and humid twilight zone of strange results, capped by the defeat of Conquistarose, the 1-to-5 favorite, in the Citation Stakes.

LEAD: Mimi Williams, 32 years old, always longed to be ordained into the clergy. But because she was a Roman Catholic and the Catholic Church still refuses to ordain women, ''I knew there was no hope,'' she said.

LEAD: One of the mysteries of this country, to an American, is the Australian fondness for a black yeast spread called Vegemite. It sometimes seems virtually the national food, spread on toast, mixed with hot water to make a drink or added to stews.
LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Presidents' Day. Government offices, most banks and many businesses are also closed.
LEAD: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg won his second United States Indoor tennis championship in the past three years today when a knee injury forced second-seeded Jimmy Connors to retire in the second set.

LEAD: When John Zigarlick Jr. arrived at this remote spot 65 miles below the Arctic Circle recently, he dined on beef stroganoff and strawberries in the mine cafeteria before heading off to the racquetball court for an evening game.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: About 4,000 Philippine police officers swore allegiance to the new Constitution during ceremony yesterday. Similar ceremonies are planned today for soldiers at garrisons nationwide. (AP)
LEAD: Mario Biaggi sits in a rocker in his office here, his silvery hair framed by the Capitol dome that rises beyond the window.

LEAD: With tensions over semiconductor trade increasing, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry called in the heads of Japan's six semiconductor companies on Friday and asked them to honor an American-Japanese semiconductor agreement.

LEAD: Fidel Bassa of Colombia won the World Boxing Association flyweight title with a unanimous 15-round decision over the champion, Hilario Zapata, of Panama Friday night. There were no knockdowns. Bassa, 24 years old, fighting in only his 17th bout, is the sixth Colombian to win a world boxing title.
LEAD: For the moment, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds two of the most demanding jobs on Capitol Hill - chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee and 1988 Presidential candidate.

LEAD: Fred Perry, a former junior-college coach who's the baseball director at the new 135-acre Boardwalk and Baseball amusement complex in Orlando, Fla., is determined to make the game a year-round thing. That might seem an ambitious undertaking in itself, but Perry, who has visions of turning the park's six diamonds into a baseball mecca, attracting college teams 12 months a year, is even more ambitious than that.

LEAD: Compared with say, football, which produces thousands of serious injuries a year, cheerleading is a safe pursuit. When it turns unsafe, though, the accidents can be extreme. Now two well-publicized incidents last fall - the death of a cheerleader at North Dakota State and the paralysis of another at

LEAD: The latest garments for sale at a marketplace in Kinshasa are displayed by a saleswoman brandishing a sharp knife. She cuts open a 100-pound bale and, as customers eagerly surge forward, out spill pastel polo shirts, khaki short-sleeve shirts and cotton pants - all secondhand.

LEAD: The penalty killers for the Rangers were vastly responsible last night at Madison Square Garden in helping Bob Froese continue his remarkable record as a goaltender against the Pittsburgh Penguins.
LEAD: This city is famous for many things but only the tiny and esoteric Alligator Records has been able to successfully mine one of the city's most precious treasures - the blues.

LEAD: In a scientific advance with potentially valuable commercial application, researchers at the University of Houston and the University of Alabama in Huntsville have produced a superconductive compound that loses all resistance to electricity when cooled to the temperature of liquid nitrogen, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday.

LEAD: After suspending its basketball head coach and assistant coach over the weekend for possible violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules and regulations, Adelphi University announced yesterday that one of its players, Charles Webb, was being held out of yesterday's game with Mount St.
LEAD: He is known as El Cojo - the crippled one - and the image of him shown repeatedly on national television and in the nation's newspapers in recent days has been both sad and brutal.

LEAD: THOSE who enjoy hunting when guns are not coughing incessantly in the surrounding hills, when it is possible to spend a day in the woods without encountering anyone, save, perhaps, a snowshoer or a cross-country skier, should remember that this is such a time of year. And in some states there are two major species of small game - the ruffed grouse and the snowshoe rabbit - that still may be pursued.

LEAD: The hardest-working bridge theorist in North America, most experts would agree, is Marty Bergen of White Plains. His creative ideas have been shown to work in his partnership with Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., and have been set out in two books entitled ''Better Bidding With Bergen.''
LEAD: A security guard at a Manhattan welfare hotel was killed yesterday with a shotgun blast to the face when he tried to break up a couple's dispute.
LEAD: Richard Kendrick, a retired actor, died at the Bellevue Hospital Center last Tuesday after suffering a stroke. He was in his early 80's and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: The utopian world of the kibbutz movement moved into the shadows of a full moon and critical indebtedness this weekend, heading resolutely into another cycle of planting and reaping.

LEAD: Jose Napoleon Duarte was lauded at a major political demonstration a week ago, as thousands of Government workers, peasants from state-run co-operatives and others dependent on Government patronage were trucked into El Salvador's capital for a show of his ruling Christian Democratic Party's political machine at work.
LEAD: * Amherst Group, Cambridge, Mass., named Charles W. Shields executive vice president and chief operating officer.
LEAD: An infant was killed in his crib in a fire that started in his bedroom in a ninth-floor apartment in a city-owned housing project in Brooklyn, authorities said.

LEAD: In a move intended to deny international legal protection to terrorists and anti-Western guerrillas, President Reagan has decided against ratification of part of a major revision of the 1949 Geneva Conventions on treatment of combatants and war victims, according to Administration documents.

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he agreed fully with the action taken by Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn in banning a group of homosexual Roman Catholics from holding masses or meetings on property of the Brooklyn Diocese.
LEAD: Pope John Paul II today condemned a shooting and robbery here early Saturday in which two policemen were killed and a third was seriously wounded. A terrorist group has claimed responsibility.

LEAD: It was not until his last two years of college that Roger W. Stone decided to join his family's business, the Stone Container Corporation. If the company's commitment to the paper industry was ever in doubt in those early days some 20 years ago, those doubts now have been put to rest.

LEAD: EVER since 1978, when the Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act first required the Federal Reserve to present semiannual reports of its monetary policy goals to Congress, the Fed's chairman has had a near-monopoly on members' attention. But this time around, things will be different, much to the annoyance of Paul A.
LEAD: ''I am not a horse trader,'' Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's Executive Commission, insisted recently. ''I don't ask for 10, expecting to get 5.''

LEAD: Speaking of animals, ''The Little Foxes'' is a sturdy mount that, with some whipping, has made it into the winner's circle in seasons past. But after almost a half century, it needs more of the whip than is applied at the Equity Library Theater. Under the restrained direction of Thomas Edward West, it starts a bit slow, shows its stuff around the Act

LEAD: At Temple Beth Shalom in Miami Beach yesterday, Julie Lowell Russin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David J. Russin of Miami Beach, was married to Jeffrey Bercow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Bercow of Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Gary Glickstein performed the ceremony.

LEAD: While Don Mattingly and the Yankees negotiated unsuccessfully before their salary arbitration hearing today, Dwight Gooden and the Mets canceled their Friday arbitration date by reaching agreement yesterday on a new contract.

LEAD: DAVE JOHNSON says he will warn them. Frank Cashen says he will lecture them. Gary Carter says he will watch them. Keith Hernandez says he will monitor them. And, if necessary, he will give them the message: ''Put it behind you.''

LEAD: Associate Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court said today that the Federal judiciary was being transformed from an ''elite'' into a vast bureaucracy by a flood of routine cases, and called for a major overhaul.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Up to 13 of the 300 Soviet children born since the reactor accident at Chernobyl to women who lived nearby are expected to suffer mental retardation because of exposure to hazardous levels of radiation, an American physician who recently returned from the contaminated area said here today. But none of the children have been observed to have any physical defects, he said.

LEAD: The corporate restructuring announced last week by the Lafarge Corporation should help cut costs and improve market position, according to Bertrand C. Collomb, the company's new vice chairman and chief executive officer. But in a sluggish industry, it may be some time before the improvements begin to show for the Dallas-based cement producer.

LEAD: The West German freighter Colombo sailing toward the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge yesterday. Aboard were 24 Turkish seamen and a woman who were rescued by the Colombo after their merchant ship sank in a storm in the Atlantic on Friday. Three members of the crew were lost in the sinking. LEAD: Students at Mexico's largest university voted today to end an 18-day strike after the university administration agreed to reconsider plans for sweeping changes in policies.

LEAD: In its short existence, the Black Rock Coalition has created showcases for little-known black musicians and has raised the right questions about the stereotypes that black performers still face. It also insists that the music business, in its shortsightedness, is missing out on the commercial prospects of black rock - and to prove the point, it put on a showcase of eight bands Wednesday and Thursday at CBGB.

LEAD: WHEN it comes to couples' social lives, a kind of Noah's ark syndrome has long held sway: everything has happened two-by-two - theater tickets, dinner invitations, even friendships. ''Both members of the couple have had to go together,'' said Karen Shanor, a clinical psychologist in Washington. ''Otherwise, neither person was considered a valid presence.

LEAD: Northeastern state officials want to create stronger markets for recycled products in an effort to deal with the growing problem of garbage disposal.
LEAD: Esprit, the San Francisco-based sportswear company, has named Corrado Federico president and chief operating officer, a new post.

LEAD: The prospects for major banking legislation this year appear to have improved sharply with a decision by the American Bankers Association to support Senator Proxmire's version of what should be done.

LEAD: The evangelist Oral Roberts may have drawn widespread criticism when he told his television audience he would die if he could not raise $4.5 million by April. But there are few signs of any storms raging on the futuristic $500 million campus he has created here.

LEAD: For a farewell salute to Julius Erving at their home game against Philadelphia on April 6, the Knicks have chosen as their theme ''Is There a Doctor in the House?'' LEAD: Earvin (Magic) Johnson scored 39 points and led Los Angeles back from a 17-point third-quarter deficit to a 106-103 victory over the Boston Celtics, giving the Lakers the best record in the National Basketball Association.
LEAD: Restrictions on foreign trade cost Americans $50 billion a year, according to Daniel Oliver, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

LEAD: Hundreds of Bronx religious leaders at a rally yesterday called on Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch to replace Borough President Stanley Simon with an ''interim administrator'' while Mr. Simon fights criminal allegations against him.
LEAD: Many public-school dropouts are ranked in the top quarter of their class and some are less than 14 years old, according to a study of the nation's fourth-largest district.

LEAD: The Mendelssohn String Quartet concentrated on music of its namesake at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening, and played as though determined to defend the composer against the impression that he was oversupplied with delicacy, elegance and grace, and a little short on true grit. This listener found himself wishing the performers had embraced the former qualities more fully.

LEAD: ''We are only sorry this gift is so late and so little when one considers the immense need of destitute people,'' said the family of Jennifer and David Saltman of Hillsdale, N.Y., with a $50 contribution to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: The Vienna Philharmonic is to play the complete Beethoven symphonies and piano concertos in a six-concert series at Carnegie Hall next month, under the direction of Claudio Abbado and with Maurizio Pollini as soloist. The performances would be the orchestra's first in New York since 1976.

LEAD: FROM Miami to Mesa, baseball returns to the national scene this week when 18 spring training camps open in Florida and eight others in Arizona. And, until the season starts on April 6, they will be the oases for tourists, travelers and other souls who have been wandering since Jesse Orosco of the Mets struck out Marty Barrett of the Boston Red Sox to end the World

LEAD: Donald Byrd has tackled racism, the pain of rejection as an artist and the loss of innocence in his dances. In ''The Rehearsal,'' a new work performed by Donald Byrd/The Group on Friday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, Mr. Byrd has created a flawed but often evocative fable, to music by Carman Moore, about a choreographer and his dancers.

LEAD: The marriage of Sandra Irwin, an elementary school teacher at the E. M. Baker School in Great Neck, L.I., to Bradley A. Kaufman, a real-estate associate at the New York law firm of Bachner, Tally, Polevoy, Misher & Brinberg, took place yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Economy Japan's six chip makers were asked to honor an agreement with the U.S. The request by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry follows charges by U.S. trade officials that Japanese companies are continuing to ''dump'' computer chips - selling them below the cost of production - despite the agreement reached last July 31.

LEAD: A Washington dispatch Feb. 7 on a letter from Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, to President Reagan about the consequences of a failure to consult with Congress on the Antiballistic Missile Treaty incorrectly quoted from the letter. Mr. Nunn wrote that a failure to consult would lead to a ''constitutional confrontation of profound dimensions.

LEAD: Nancy Ann Zarett, an associate at the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, was married yesterday to Dr. George William Niedt, a fellow in the division of dermatopathology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Judge Seymour Schwartz of the Civil Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

LEAD: AS the hockey season follows its logical progress toward the frenetic stretch drive that portends April's playoffs and payoffs, the rookie coach is continually reminded that he didn't expect this job to be fun.

LEAD: ''Oracle'' by Donald Howell and Albert Tavares - an hourlong piece for voices and electronic keyboards presented Saturday at Mr. Tavares's studio on Eighth Avenue - is based on phonetic syllables derived from ancient chants and on ''text material . . . generated using psychosynthesis, a new psychology developed by Roberto Assagioli as a method of integrating various aspects of the personality through the use of symbolic images created in a meditative state,'' according to the program.

LEAD: IT was still winter outside his New Jersey home, and the only thing on Lou Piniella's mind was escaping to the warm breezes of Florida and his second spring as the Yankees' manager. LEAD: ''Out of the Blue: Six Startling Views,'' an imaginative program of dances presented on Saturday by the Dance Center of the Emanu-El Midtown Y, lived up to its title for much of the evening. This was dance with an eye firmly fixed on the world around it. These were dances that were notably provocative and polished.

LEAD: New York State environmental officials have charged that the Metro-North Commuter Railroad is illegally using a lagoon near the Hudson River to store more than a million gallons of water containing toxic wastes.
LEAD: The devil is getting a face lift in this small northern Michigan community of 2,000 people.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo canceled a meeting today with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and an appearance at a dinner sponsored by black and Hispanic legislators so that he could depart a day early on the second of his national trips, to New Orleans.
LEAD: The presidents of all the major Central American countries except Nicaragua met here today and invited the Nicaraguan Government to join them in a new regional peace conference within 90 days.

LEAD: Marla Bazar Is Married Marla Anne Bazar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Bazar of Franklin Square, L.I., was married yesterday to Philip Howard Edelstein, the son of Alfred Edelstein of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Anita Edelstein of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Alan Lavin officiated at Temple Sholom in Brooklyn.

LEAD: THE SOCIETY OF MIND. By Marvin Minsky. Illustrated. 339 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95. What on earth is a ''society of mind''? By choosing this phrase for the title of his new book on how people think and feel, Marvin Minsky, the artificial-intelligence expert, is trying to convey his belief that each mind is made of many smaller processes, which he calls ''agents.
LEAD: The United States has begun a vigorous campaign to nudge South Korea's rival political parties toward a compromise that would lead to a more democratic government.

LEAD: Asserting that it is not enough to have sermons, songs and nice poems about farmers, a group of nearly 100 Christians and Jews has just concluded a two-day conference here on the social impact of the continuing farm depression.

LEAD: Karolos Koun, a Greek theater director whose lively staging of ancient Greek plays won him acclaim in Europe, died last Saturday after suffering a heart attack, according to friends in Athens. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: A malfunction of the starting gate resulted in cancellation of Aqueduct's ninth and final race yesterday and necessitated a refund of $923,507 in triple, exacta and straight bets.
LEAD: Some ballets look better the second season around and Jerome Robbins's ''Piccolo Balletto'' for the New York City Ballet is certainly a case in point.

LEAD: On Soviet movie screens, punk rockers spray-paint hostile graffiti on building walls. In one Soviet journal, a drug addict's diary describes watching a fellow addict slit his wrists and die, and in another a sociologist drily chronicles greed and disaffection among Soviet youth.

LEAD: A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction Saturday requiring Medicaid in Virginia to pay for the liver transplant of a 4-year-old girl who was denied aid because of the state's criteria on liver diseases.
LEAD: Four years ago this month, after having been turned down by Jacqueline Onassis and Beverly Sills, Mayor Koch named Bess Myerson commissioner of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs.

LEAD: Yes, Dick Baldwin, the basketball coach at Broome Community College in Binghamton, N.Y., swept past the legendary Adolph Rupp of Kentucky in career coaching victories over the weekend.

Lungren, Republican of California, believes the American people ''are not really upset with us over the rate of pay we receive but with the perceived failure to perform after we get paid.

LEAD: The Rev. Herbert Daughtry, a Brooklyn minister active in civil rights cases, called yesterday for a special prosecutor and an independent autopsy in the death of a Queens burglary suspect who collapsed last Thursday in a police holding cell shortly after a violent struggle with eight police officers.

LEAD: OUT from decades of gloom and neglect, a powerful and palatial stretch of the Avenue of the Americas - where New York's great department stores once nestled shoulder to sumptuous shoulder - is returning to life.
LEAD: A computerized telephone service that will let Michigan taxpayers learn the status of their refunds was introduced Friday by the state Treasurer, Robert Bowman.
LEAD: George Burns won $240,000 in the Andy Williams Open golf tournament today. Craig Stadler lost $37,333.

LEAD: President Reagan was poorly prepared for the summit meeting in Iceland last October and the two-day meeting ended with ''an astonishing degree of confusion'' about potential nuclear arms control agreements, the House Armed Services Committee said today.

LEAD: The trucks stretch for miles across the Mexican border, farther than the eye can see, creeping forward by the inch with their cargoes of auto parts, video cassettes, fresh tomatoes and toys to cross the bridge and clear United States Customs. And as the lines grow longer each day on the Mexican side, tempers grow shorter on the American side.

LEAD: Imagine the day it will cost just pennies more to phone across the country than across the street. It's no fantasy; cost-cutting technology could make it a commonplace in a few years. But getting there will require public forbearance.
LEAD: All Navy and Marine Corps CH-53E Super Stallion helicopters were grounded Saturday for inspection of a gear box problem that was found after a forced landing Oct. 21, a marine spokesman said.

LEAD: Practically every conceivable element of the Chun Violin Duo's concert at Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon conspired against its success. First, the nerve-jangling acoustics of this renovated space gave the sound of two violins playing in their upper registers a badly distortive glare.

LEAD: Angry state legislators have demanded that Gov. George Deukmejian dismiss his appointees to California's Bicentennial Commission for approving for sale a history textbook that includes an essay on slavery that refers to black children as ''pickaninnies'' and says that the ''constant fear of slave rebellion'' made life for Southern whites ''a nightmare.

LEAD: * Remember Bob Wieland, the legless Vietnam veteran who took more than 99 excruciating hours to complete the New York City Marathon last November? He's still on the go. Wieland, a weight lifter who propels himself by using his arms to lift and drag his 123-pound body, is now entered in the Los Angeles Marathon, and this time he hopes to win.

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser who has been embroiled in the arms-to-Iran investigation, apparently made a very successful start as a public speaker after he left the White House. Industry sources say Mr. McFarlane earned more than $250,000 in 1986 making speeches on foreign affairs around the country and was similarly booked this year when he was hospitalized a week ago for an overdose of Valium in what the police reported as a suicide attempt.

LEAD: N.H.L. Blackhawks 6, Nordiques 4: In Chicago, Denis Savard scored his 25th goal of the season and Bob Sauve turned away 34 shots and earned an assist yesterday. Chicago wrapped up the victory in the opening 5 minutes of the final period as Curt Fraser collected his 19th goal and Troy Murray his 22d.

LEAD: Outside a cafe in Cadaques, Spain, the artist Marcel Duchamp is playing chess. As a camera closes in, he describes the game as part of his passion for play: ''If you play with life, you are just as alive as people who believe in religion or art.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Four separate gunbattles raged in Beirut today in one of the worst days of violence in the Lebanese capital in months.

LEAD: Mourning the loss of three comrades but glad to be alive, 24 Turkish seamen and a woman from a ship abandoned in a howling Atlantic storm sailed into New York yesterday aboard a West German freighter.
LEAD: Two homeless men were stabbed, one fatally, yesterday as they slept on a loading dock on Manhattan's West Side, the police said.

LEAD: Ib Andersen took over the leading male role in Paul Mejia's ''Sinfonia Mistica'' at the New York City Ballet's performance Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. It was a role originally intended for him, but an injury prevented him from dancing it at the premiere, on Feb. 5.
LEAD: Most A.F.L.-C.I.O. members became eligible today for low-cost legal services ranging from free consultations and document reviews to discounts on lawyers' fees.
LEAD: Corruption investigations in Queens and the Bronx illuminate the dimmer financial dealings of party organizations and the need to subject party ''housekeeping'' accounts to closer scrutiny.
LEAD: In 1986, a year that saw the closing of two major retail chains, Gimbels and Ohrbach's, retail sales in New York and the surrounding suburbs were the strongest in three years.

LEAD: In 1972, America's farm workers asked the Federal Government to insure them the basic dignities to which virtually all other American workers are entitled. They wanted drinking water in the workplace, which in their case is the fields. Fewer than half are provided with it. They wanted to be able to wash pesticide residue off their hands.

LEAD: WRITERS WHO READ This is the fourth season for the series of short-story readings called ''Writer Nights.'' There will be three programs in all and the first is tonight at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Each night four writers read their own stories.
LEAD: Federal attorneys have objected to a motion by the industrialist Victor Posner to move his retrial on income tax evasion charges to New York.

LEAD: UNDERSTANDING TOSCANINI. By Joseph Horowitz. 492 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $30. JOSEPH HOROWITZ, a former music writer for The New York Times who is now the program annotator for the 92d Street Y, has written a laudably serious book about the most famous of all conductors, Arturo Toscanini.

LEAD: In pro football, only one instant-replay official can reverse a ruling. One too many, some people feel. And once the next play begins, no reversal is possible. LEAD: Despite a stunning decline in state revenues caused by falling oil prices, Alaskans seem determined to resist any cuts in their state's impressive list of gifts to them.

LEAD: Treasury auctions this week are limited to the weekly sale of new three-month and six-month bills. The bill auctions were delayed until today because of the Presidents' Day holiday yesterday.

LEAD: Despite higher prices and a more stable market, the United States is almost inevitably headed toward new oil shortages that could be as disruptive as those of the 1970's, according to increasingly urgent warnings by Government policy makers and other analysts.

LEAD: Robert Wagner Jr., president of New York City's Board of Education, thinks community school boards are so steeped in politics and patronage as to stifle education reform. His views are echoed in a Bronx grand jury investigation of local boards. Mr. Wagner proposes appointed rather than elected boards, stripped of authority to hire and dismiss principals and other administrators.

LEAD: Animal studies suggest that newborns may be particularly vulnerable to inner ear damage from loud noises, and that the damage could result in loss of some brain cells linked to the ear, a researcher says.

LEAD: Charlie Lea, the one-time ace of the Montreal pitching staff, has signed a minor-league contract with the Expos' Class AAA team in Indianapolis. The move circumvented an arbitrator's ruling last week that prohibited clubs from dealing with their own unsigned free agents until May 1. The 31-year-old Lea, who missed the last two seasons with a rotator cuff injury, will now be able to attend Montreal's major-league training camp beginning in West Palm Beach, Fla., next week as an invitee.

LEAD: MAREDA GAITHER-GRAVES'S recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall was consistent in its satisfactions and limitations. The former stem from a wide-ranging and heartfelt sympathy for the songs she chose. What the soprano seems to lack is the ability to produce a free-flowing, attractive sound at dynamic levels above the softest.

LEAD: President Reagan has faced more important but probably no tougher decisions than whether to seek ratification of revisions to the 1949 Geneva Conventions. If he said yes, that would improve protection for prisoners of war and civilians in wartime, but at the price of new legal protection for guerrillas and possible terrorists.

LEAD: * Bertelsmann Inc. named Juergen Kraemer executive vice president and managing director. He will serve as the company's chief financial officer. Manfred Kuehn was named vice president and general counsel.

LEAD: An unusual alignment of the Earth, the moon and the core of the Milky Way galaxy is giving astronomers a rare opportunity to study that core, a mysterious region hidden from sight where processes not found elsewhere in the galaxy are at work.

LEAD: On 340 square miles of what was a barren desert only a decade ago, Saudi Arabia has built the world's biggest new industrial city. Jubail is an odorless, litterless, smog-free community with hotels, an airport, highways, schools, mosques, shopping centers, a hospital, baseball diamonds and more than 100,000 imported trees that are irrigated with water reclaimed from the sewers.
LEAD: At least the winter wasn't a total loss for Dwight Gooden.

LEAD: THERE I was, at 11 P.M., trying to access the Dow Jones News/Retrieval Service with a software package I was reviewing, but something was distinctly suspicious. The word ''dialing'' flashed on the monitor screen before me, but no sound emanated from the PC's Limited 286 computer except the rather excessively loud whir of the fan.

I cannot recall ever hearing such a spirited, affirmative, beautifully conceived performance of this wonderful work before.

LEAD: MARKETS Stock prices soared to further records as Wall Street chose to ignore the latest insider-trading scandal and concentrated instead on positive economic signals. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,237.49, after rising 54.14 points, its largest one-day climb ever. Trading was a brisk 187.8 million shares, as the market got a push when word spread throughout Wall Street that Robert Prechter was predicting that the Dow would advance to the 2,300 level before any correction.

LEAD: Jimmy Connors, whose right knee was injured in the final of the United States Indoor championships in Memphis last Sunday, will be sidelined for only a short period of time, according to his attorney. ''Jimmy had the knee examined and X-rayed by doctors in St. Louis Monday, and there appears to be no ligament or cartilage damage,'' Irving Blumberg, the attorney, said in a statement released by ProServ, the company managing Connors's business affairs.

LEAD: DAWNINE SAMPLE DYER and Bill Dyer drink the American equivalent of Champagne throughout dinner at least twice a week in their Napa Valley home. ''You can't beat it as an everyday house white,'' Mrs. Dyer said.

LEAD: Baker International Inc. said it had agreed to sell the domestic operations of its electrical submersible pump division to Trico Industries for an undisclosed amount. LEAD: A man arrested Monday and charged with the burglary of a hotel room in Greenwich Village was wanted for 22 bank holdups in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, the police reported last night.

LEAD: The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, said yesterday that a bribery and corruption investigaton into the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, may eventually lead to as many as 20 indictments.

LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would travel around the nation in the weeks and months ahead to promote a legislative program aimed at making America more competitive in the world marketplace.
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced a high-powered portable computer yesterday that is smaller and lighter than the company's earlier models.

LEAD: The director of the Kennedy Space Center said today that by the end of 1987 the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its contractors would have refilled all 2,000 center jobs lost as a result of the space shuttle Challenger's explosion.
LEAD: When President Reagan proposed a new health insurance program for catastrophic illness, it was widely seen as a victory for Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
LEAD: The America's Cup, recaptured from the Australians earlier this month, went on display here today at City Hall.

LEAD: Ronnie DeSillers waving to classmates yesterday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., as he was put aboard an air ambulance for flight to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. The 7-year-old boy's plight attracted national attention, including a telephone call and a donation from President Reagan, after money collected for his medical bills was stolen.

LEAD: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday as market participants focused on changes in the dollar and overnight interest rates while waiting for tomorrow's Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker.

LEAD: The Ubu Repertory Theater, a company founded in 1982 to acquaint Americans with new French theater works in English translation, opens its festival of new plays from French-speaking Africa today with ''The Daughter of the Gods,'' a tale written by the Senegalese playwright Abdou Anta Ka and based on an African folk legend.
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the St. John's-Fairleigh Dickinson basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden on Monday omitted the result of the first game.

LEAD: Labor Secretary Bill Brock, left, talking with Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., at session of the organization's winter meeting in Bal Harbour, Fla. Speaking before the 35-member council, Mr. Brock indicated that the Reagan Administration might try to revive a below-minimum wage for teen-agers if Democrats and labor unions persist in efforts to raise the current minimum wage of $3.35 an hour.

LEAD: The first preview for ''Starlight Express,'' the new musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Richard Stilgoe, has again been postponed, from this Thursday until Tuesday, Feb. 24, according to a spokesman for the show, Bill Evans.

LEAD: This time of year, as April 15 draws closer, is when the motivation to find ways to trim income tax bills is greatest, though the options available for legally outwitting the tax collector are the smallest.

LEAD: A 20-year-old college student from Brooklyn finally stepped forward yesterday, shyly and almost fearfully, to become a millionaire.
LEAD: Par is a simple concept for golfers but a complex one for bridge players.

LEAD: When some small-town politicians get elected to the United States Senate, they feel compelled to try to move up to a new social echelon and dress accordingly. But not Warren B. LEAD: Armed with new technology and eager to shorten supply lines, some American manufacturers have started to bring overseas operations home or switch from foreign to domestic suppliers. LEAD: A state health department investigation found that a Brooklyn emergency room failed to administer oxygen to an 18-year-old Brooklyn youth who was rushed there by ambulance while suffering an acute asthma attack on Dec. 8, City Council president Andrew M. Stein said yesterday.

LEAD: The chairman of the National Governors' Association said today that President Reagan's plan for revising the welfare system was inadequate. He said the nation should instead look to a plan being formulated by the governors that would immediately require a large number of those on the welfare to go to work.

LEAD: Jack Trudeau, the starting quarterback for the Indianapolis Colts, is to go on trial April 2 on charges of disorderly conduct and battery on a police officer arising from a fight outside an Indianapolis bar. Trudeau, 24, and a friend, Joseph C. Venkus, 25, were arrested early last Friday. After they pleaded not guilty, Trudeau was released on his recognizance, and Venkus, a law student, was freed on $500 bond.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz clashed today with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel over whether an international conference, possibly including the Soviet Union as a participant, should even be considered as a vehicle for starting peace negotiations in the Middle East.

LEAD: IN the sparse months of winter, cooks must often make do with vegetables that are limited in variety and quality. Winter tomatoes, for example, which are shipped unripened thousands of miles, are usually too pallid to add to green salads. Cucumbers may not be at their peak of flavor in February, but to my taste they are preferable.
LEAD: A state of anarchy is developing in Pakistan. Its consequences should be cause for alarm to Congress and to the American people.
LEAD: American negotiators have been telling Soviet officials in Geneva that Washington's new, broader interpretation of the 1972 ABM treaty is justified, officials said today.

LEAD: About 500 black students stayed home today to protest the school board's failure to name a black as assistant school superintendent, boycott leaders said. The 1,650-student school system is 34 percent black, and protest leaders said 95 percent of the black students stayed home. The Rev. Michael Cathey, a spokesman for a group of black parents, said the school board had ''renegged'' on a promise to appoint a black as assistant superintendent.

LEAD: In an effort to demonstrate broad-based support that has yet to appear in the public opinion polls, Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York today announced the formation of a Presidential steering committee. It is composed of 800 prominent Republican elected officials, state party workers, conservative activists, sports figures and executives of major corporations.

LEAD: FEW people have much idea what happens to their sewage, but Houstonians know all too well. LEAD: ''KVETCH,'' as in the title of Steven Berkoff's new comedy, is a complaint, which, if allowed to fester, can become an anxiety attack. As the play begins (at the Westside Arts Theater), we hear Mr. Berkoff's voice offstage, intoning an introduction to his tale of comic woe. As an actor, the playwright specializes in villainy, and his doom-filled narration starts the evening on a properly prophetic note.

LEAD: As New York winters go, this one has been undistinguished, showing no direction and not much will. The tipoff came in early December when forsythia bushes wishfully started to flower, either with laggard yellow blooms from last spring or impatient blooms for next. Later in the month some obligatory snow came, and then quickly went, leading some snowdrops to pop up prematurely and then be stiffened by a cold spell.

Boyd earned $375,000 in 1986 in helping Boston win its first pennant since 1975.

LEAD: IN Beethoven's later years, the metronome was becoming recognized as a valuable tool for a composer to indicate preferred tempos. LEAD: HANDSOME and functional highchairs are sometimes hard to find. The most useful are made of materials that are easy to clean and will not absorb the food that a baby inevitably spills. A search of stores turned up five highchairs that vary in style from a simple molded plastic bucket seat to an elaborate turn-of-the-century wicker version.
