LEAD: TALK ABOUT MUSICALS

LEAD: THE movies are looking for a few good men, to change the face of American foreign policy and out-Rambo Rambo in the process. The latest of these hopefuls is Gunnery Sgt. Jack Burns, who in ''Death Before Dishonor'' is a marine with a mission. Stationed in the fictitious Middle Eastern country of Jemal, Burns (Fred Dryer) must stand by helplessly while his commanding officer (Brian Keith) is kidnapped by Arab terrorists.

LEAD: Did Kansas attempt to recruit the well-traveled Lloyd Daniels after his recent arrest? According to sources at Nevada-Las Vegas, Kansas contacted the Brooklyn-born Daniels within days of his arrest on drug charges in Las Vegas. In an interview yesterday, Larry Brown, the Kansas coach, said that contact had indeed been made, but that the purpose of the call was not to recruit

LEAD: The composer-keyboardist Amina Claudine Myers will present her chamber opera ''When the Berries Fell'' tonight at 8 o'clock at the Triplex at Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street (618-1980). It is scored for keyboards, percussion and Ms. Myers's Voice Choir. Tickets are $8; $6 for students

LEAD: This tax filing season is likely to prove a bit more agonizing than usual for investors who unloaded billions of dollars' worth of stocks, mutual funds and other assets last year before capital gains rates went up.
LEAD: The recent surge in stock prices has encouraged more offerings of convertible debt issues, including two yesterday totaling $200 million.
LEAD: Ron Darling won his bid for $1.05 million in salary arbitration yesterday and immediately noticed a bizarre pattern.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: After deliberating for six hours yesterday on two competing takeover offers, the board of Piedmont Aviation Inc. opened the bidding to all interested parties.

LEAD: A year before the first votes of the 1988 Republican Presidential competition, it is too early for rivals of Vice President Bush to criticize him openly. That might look like an attack on President Reagan. But it is always possible to open fire on a secondary target close to Mr. Bush, on the theory that the Vice

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, told a Presidential review board in his hospital room today that he had taken part in an effort by White House aides to hide President Reagan's key role in the initiation of the Iran arms sales, according to a source familiar with the board's investigation.

LEAD: For Alfred Rodriguez, having a phone could mean getting a job. For Miriam Maldanado, it is the difference between fear and a sense of security. And for the Victoria Insurance Agency, it is vital for business.

LEAD: SINCE invitations to advance screenings are reserved for the special few, the rest of us can be very grateful to the Museum of Modern Art for its ''Perspectives on French Cinema'' series, which offers previews of a batch of movies fresh off the plane from Paris. This year's edition, which opens today, offers a dozen features, 11 of which will be shown twice through March 3 at the museum's Roy and Niuta Titus

LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had arranged an innovative bailout of the troubled BancTexas Group of Dallas that would transfer management control of the holding company and its 11 banks to a little-known merchant banking concern called Hallwood Group Inc.

LEAD: The Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District is offering $100 million of tax-exempt bonds with yields ranging from 4.90 percent for those maturing in 1993 to 5.50 percent in 1997 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
LEAD: Four Brooklyn landlords were arrested yesterday on charges of violating a little-known law by ignoring orders to correct hundreds of unsafe building code violations.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve expects the economy to grow by 2 1/2 percent to 3 percent this year, slightly faster than in 1986, while unemployment drifts down a bit from current levels, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, told Congress today.

LEAD: During the first timeout of tonight's game, with the Nets ahead by 13-11, George Karl, the Golden State Warriors' coach, tried to bolster his struggling club. He described the Nets as a ''depressed team.''

LEAD: THE ornately tiled vaulted ceiling supported by stout columns and ceramic covered walls is reminiscent of a New York subway station before spray paint was invented - which, in fact, it was at the turn of the century. This fanciful room later became a rathskeller in the Vanderbilt Hotel, 4 Park Avenue, at 33d Street.
LEAD: A fireworks expert who worked at last year's Statue of Liberty celebration is being sought in the bombings of several New York City abortion clinics, Federal officials announced yesterday.

LEAD: The Transit Authority plans to make subway trips speedier, but increase waits for some buses in what officials are calling the most comprehensive series of schedule changes since the service cuts of the 1970's.

LEAD: YOUR response to ''Ira, You'll Get Into Trouble'' is likely to be related to your feelings about the student commotions of the late 1960's. Stephen A. Sbarge's cinema verite documentary, completed in 1970 and now at the Thalia, follows an attractive group of New York City high schoolers who try to organize against what they view as a repressive establishment.
LEAD: James A. Payne, an assistant corporation counsel, was named the city's probation commissioner yesterday by Mayor Koch.

LEAD: Tennis Lloyd Upset in Florida: Chris Evert Lloyd's comeback to tournament play ended quickly as Kate Gompert upset the world's second-ranked player, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, last night in the third round of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida, at Boca Raton. In the other late match, second-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany needed only 34 minutes to beat Sara Gomer of England, 6-0, 6-0, allowing 19 points in the 12 games.
LEAD: A potentially crucial clue to the cause of Alzheimer's disease was reported yesterday by scientists studying the mysterious brain disorder.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that experiments would be conducted this year in what he called democratic elections in Communist Party cells, local government bodies and and factory managements.

LEAD: Once a year some of New York's less experienced tournament players have the opportunity to play with experts. The event is the Greater New York Bridge Association's Pro-Am event, scheduled for 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Penta Hotel, 33d Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan. Reservations are needed.

LEAD: The Orlando String Quartet will play Beethoven's String Quartet in F (Op. 59, No. 1, ''Razumovsky'') and Dvorak's Piano Quintet in A (Op. 81), with the pianist Lilian Kallir, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. Admission is $12; information: 570-3949.

LEAD: MEL BOCHNER, who started his career as one of the premier Conceptual artists of the late 1960's and early 70's, has evolved over the past decade into a maker of abstract paintings. His path has not always been easy to follow, and this makes the artist's current exhibition at Sonnabend Gallery (420 West Broadway, at Spring Street) a particularly welcome and useful one.

LEAD: The New York Public Library's periodicals collection has received a gift in excess of $1 million to endow the position of chief librarian for periodicals and journals. The endowment is also to provide for an annual award for ''excellence in journalism,'' with details to be announced.

LEAD: Richard M. Nixon, who does not issue book endorsements every day, wrote: ''Not since George Orwell, to my knowledge, has there been a broad political satire to match 'My Dear Alex.' This book not only affords reading pleasure; it illuminates and provokes. It should command a wide audience and serious critical attention.

LEAD: IT is six years since the drawings department of the Museum of Modern Art last mounted a show of new acquisitions. During the period in question, 554 drawings by 217 artists were acquired. Seventy-two of the drawings in question - roughly one-eighth of the total intake - are in the current show of recently acquired drawings acquisitions at the museum.

LEAD: WHERE American economists commonly believe that the way to eliminate this nation's huge trade deficit is to lower the value of the dollar, Japanese economists maintain that the basic answer to America's trade problem lies in more vigorous industrial growth and better-balanced regional development.

LEAD: Warner Communcations Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire 50 percent of Gulf and Western's domestic movie theater operations. While the companies refused to disclose the amount of the investment, analysts estimated that Warner would spend about $145 million. Gulf and Western owns Mann

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased by $168.4 million, to $236.18 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $516.1 million, to $65.83 billion. Assets of the 198 general purpose funds were down $241.9 million, to $62.75 billion.

LEAD: Charles J. Haughey's incomplete victory - three seats short of a parliamentary majority - in the national election Tuesday has brought him to the crossroads of the most dramatic career in modern Irish politics.
LEAD: Arturo Cruz, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, today dropped a threat to resign and pledged he would fight to give the guerrilla movement a ''democratic political dimension which it lacks.''

LEAD: Representatives of organizations opposed to United States policies on Central America asserted before a House panel today that they were victims of political burglaries in which files were searched but valuables were left untouched.

LEAD: An emotional 11-page plea for understanding signed with Mary Beth Whitehead's name and sent last May to the judge in the Baby M case was not written by Mrs. Whitehead, but by a close friend, testimony revealed today.

LEAD: Both the JWT Group and Grey Advertising released their fourth-quarter earnings yesterday. The most interest, of course, was in JWT because agency watchers, already warned to expect the worst, wanted to know just how bad it was.

LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies yesterday offered $100 million of 8 1/8 percent senior notes due in 1997 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 8.15 percent, or 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

LEAD: Three skiers who died in an avalanche near Breckenridge Wednesday were taking additional risks by skiing outside the boundaries of downhill ski slopes, an increasingly common practice that has made this one of the deadliest years for skiing in recent Colorado history.

LEAD: BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES LAKERS VS. BULLS, at Chicago (TV - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) COLLEGES: C.U.N.Y. Tournament final at Hunter College Sportsplex, 68th St. and Lexington Ave., 8 P.M. Columbia at Penn (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 7 P.M.) GOLF P.G.A. TOUR: Los Angeles Open, Riviera Country Club, Pacific Palisades, Calif.
LEAD: A bucket overflowing with cigarette butts hangs outside the office of United-Guardian Inc. here.
LEAD: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the number of games the New York Rangers have played since their founding. The game last night was their 3,944th.
LEAD: A Danish connection to the Iran-contra affair has become clearer in the last week, largely as a result of a court case here.
LEAD: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons is offering $200 million of 8 3/8 percent debentures due in 2007 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 8.41 percent. Goldman, Sachs & Company heads the underwriters.

LEAD: PUBLIC television's ''Great Performances'' is on an impressive drama roll these days, thanks to a number of wonderful performances. Last Friday, Sir Alec Guinness and Leo McKern brought countless touches of grace to Graham Greene's ''Monsignor Quixote,'' a story set in Spain about a simple village priest and the local Communist politician.

LEAD: It's been 18 months since the philanthropist Leonard Stern offered a $1 million challenge grant to push Help I, a shelter for families now living in welfare hotels. From that day, Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, has put his energy and resourceful leadership into the effort. Yet only now is the project starting to move at last, and it will take an additional year before the first occupants arrive at their new transitional home.

LEAD: The last Flamingo. Like such titles as ''The Last Picture Show'' or ''The Last Convertible,'' the phrase suggests the end of an era and an institution. Pessimists are applying it to the Flamingto Stakes here Feb. 28, the first of the year's seven Grade I prep races for the Kentucky Derby and possibly its last edition as racing fans know it.
LEAD: Catharine Wellington Hoppin, an educator and former head of the Professional Children's School in New York, died Feb. 7 at her home in Stonington, Conn. She was 89 years old.
LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on the Soviet Union today to relax restrictions on emigration.

LEAD: All night they came at him, infringing on the area that he believed was rightfully his, and they hemmed him in. So he pushed at the opposition and he railed at the officials and finally, with one angry motion, Bob Froese let his temper go. The Ranger goalkeeper threw his glove at the referee.
LEAD: A court in Milan today convicted a Lebanese of smuggling explosives into Italy and sentenced him to 13 years in prison.

LEAD: The main point of the television series ''Amerika'' so far is to reconfirm that propaganda is its own nemesis, by dint of boredom. The idea of the United States falling under Soviet occupation, without resistance, sounded provocative. But now one wonders why all the controversy. The film simply falls flat.
LEAD: A former associate of a white supremacist group has pleaded guilty to bombing and murder charges and agreed to tell the authorities about his colleagues.

LEAD: New York State's highest court ruled unanimously today that Albany officials must give the public ''maximum access'' to an estimated 900,000 pages of records from the administration of Erastus Corning 2d, who served as Mayor here from 1942 until his death in 1983.

LEAD: Sherman Douglas scored 8 of Syracuse's final 10 points and finished with 26 to help hold off Providence, 90-81, in a Big East Conference game tonight.

LEAD: The dollar closed narrowly mixed yesterday in hectic trading as currency markets in Europe and New York reacted to the news that the finance ministers of seven leading industrial nations would meet this weekend in Paris.
LEAD: Roused by the termination of special property tax breaks 15 months ago, Manhattan developers rushed nearly 12,000 new apartments onto the high-priced end of the residential market.
LEAD: The mountainous waves of a brimming Lake Michigan that pounded this city's lakefront in recent weeks could serve as an apt symbol of Chicago's current political season.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Bank of Japan is expected to announce a cut in its basic interest rate Friday.

LEAD: President Reagan filled two vacancies at the White House today. He named Frank J. Donatelli, a Washington lawyer, as political director and selected John O. Koehler, a former executive with the Associated Press, a news agency, as communications director.

LEAD: A growing number of Americans are calling for a revival of military conscription, partly on the grounds that the present volunteer Army is not drawing enough applicants qualified to handle today's sophisticated weaponry.
LEAD: The stock market rose modestly yesterday to its third record in a row, as speculation grew over the direction of interest rates and the dollar's value.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration encountered unexpectedly sharp criticism of its trade policies from a Senate committee today, signaling the harsh treatment the White House can expect for the 1,600-page trade bill it has just sent to Congress.

LEAD: ''BARRAVENTO'' (''The Turning Wind''), opening today at the Public Theater, is the first feature by the highly regarded Brazilian director Glauber Rocha, who died at the age of 42 in 1981. The film, made in 1961, is about the efforts of Firmino, part revolutionary, part devil, to free the fishermen in his native

LEAD: New York City's Department of Investigation is examining the role that City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin played in a 1985 corporate takeover battle that benefited both the city's pension funds and Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.
LEAD: Considering that we are a litigious society, it is hardly surprising that the debate over the future of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty has turned into a legal wrangle.
LEAD: BASEBALL
LEAD: More than 20 men armed with machine guns, mortars and grenades attacked the presidential palace in the black homeland of Ciskei early today but were repulsed by guards, the authorities said.

LEAD: Both the New York stations of the CBS and NBC television networks announced yesterday that effective immediately they would accept condom advertising as long as it was related to combating AIDS.

LEAD: They filed in slowly but surely this morning, first Rick Rhoden and then the others: Al Holland, Charles Hudson, Rod Scurry, Joel Skinner, Rick Cerone, Mike Armstrong. It was the day for pitchers and catchers to report, and also the day for the Yankee manager, who is beginning his second season, to offer a state of the spring message in his most encouraging terms.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Six-year-old Douglas Masterson, who has cerebral palsy, used to watch while his younger brother Joey played with toys that flashed, made interesting noises and moved across the floor of their home in Levittown, L.I.
LEAD: The mounting drive to limit public smoking is complicating many personal relationships and creating some serious tensions in the nation's workplace.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration announced details today on a sweeping drug-detecting program that will require about a million Federal workers to submit urine samples under strict controls to prevent cheating, including direct observation of urination in some cases.
LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson challenged the next generation of American military leaders tonight to assess the nation's security in domestic as well as international terms.
LEAD: Many estimable people have protested the ABC television network's political soap opera ''Amerika,'' trying to keep the series off the air. I think they have missed the point.

LEAD: Coach Bob Hill, who had been relying on the younger Knicks to carry the team toward its uncertain future, turned to some forgotten veteran players last night, and the result was the end of a four-game losing streak.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE DOLPHIN, 227 Lexington Avenue, near 33d Street (689-3010) - ** (April 12, 1985) Exceptionally fresh and well-prepared seafood is presented at this trim, neat Murray Hill restaurant with brick along one wall and blond wood paneling on another.

LEAD: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company based in Oakland, Calif., said that it had received preliminary approval from the California Department of Food and Agriculture to conduct field experiments on Frostban, genetically altered bacteria that protect fruit and nut crops from frost damage.
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. Inc. said separately yesterday that they planned to market disposable color cameras.

LEAD: IN ''Duet for One'' Julie Andrews plays Stephanie Anderson, a virtuoso concert violinist whose brilliant career and seemingly successful marriage are both cut off when she contracts multiple sclerosis. The role is a milestone in Ms. Andrews's career for many reasons - it is one of the most emotionally demanding and dramatic parts she has played and it exposed her to the suffering of a group of people she came to respect and admire.

LEAD: While several prominent and talented free agents remain unsigned, the Players Association is about to intensify its conspiracy case against the owners. The association will file a second grievance today, charging that the clubs violated the labor agreement by acting in concert with each other on free agents.
LEAD: ''ROBERT CARMEL is here,''

LEAD: Rescue workers using a sled to transport body of a victim of avalanche Wednesday near the Breckenridge Ski Area. Three bodies have been recovered, including that of Martin Donnelan of Peekskill, N.Y. A fourth victim is being sought. Page A14. (AP)

LEAD: Dr. Edward H. Rynearson, a retired Mayo Clinic physician who argued against prolonging the lives of those with incurable diseases, died here Tuesday in an automobile accident. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: ''THE GOOD WIFE,'' set in the long-ago 1930's, is Marge Hills (Rachel Ward), an earnest, reliable friend to anyone in need in the rural New South Wales town where she lives with her husband, Sonny (Bryan Brown), a hard-working logger. When a baby's expected in the community, Marge becomes the unpaid midwife.

LEAD: PROBABLY more than any other area of popular music, cabaret venerates show-business traditions and the accumulated wisdom of life as expressed in popular song. Or, to quote the title of a Peter Allen-Carole Bayer Sager song, in cabaret ''Everything old is new again.'' ''New'' can mean many things, from a personal vision that has mellowed and deepened over several decades to an artist like the 30-year-old singer-pianist Michael
LEAD: A defense summation in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial yesterday ridiculed two Mafia informers, portraying one as a fearful liar and the other as a professional killer.

LEAD: Two leading proponents of exploration of Mars urged Congressional committees today to reject plans of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to delay an unmanned mission to the planet.

LEAD: The Giants, who were not given a ticker-tape parade at city expense, nevertheless got a salute from New York yesterday. In a ceremony at City Hall attended by a few players and club officials, Mayor Koch, who once called the Giants a ''foreign team,'' said: ''These champions are so mighty that they can plant one foot west of the Hudson and the other east of the Hudson.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 White House aides sought to hide President Reagan's key role in the initiation of Iran arms sales, according to a source quoting Robert C. McFarlane, a former national security adviser. Page A1 A Danish tie in the Iran-contra affair is clearer because of a Copenhagen court case.

LEAD: As demonstrators chanted behind police barricades, Natan Sharansky, the Soviet dissident now living in Israel, stood with his family and friends yesterday in a ''prison cage'' near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL The Group of Seven industrial nations will meet in Paris this weekend, and they are likely to adopt a new method to calm volatility in currencies, officials and economists said. But they said the United States would not commit itself to propping up the dollar. The finance leaders will discuss the concept of reference zones, which would set guidelines for how much a currency should rise or fall in relation to other currencies.

LEAD: The Rev. Bruce Ritter being congratulated by President Reagan at the White House. Father Ritter received the Stone Foundation ''Endow a Dream'' Award for his work with Covenant House, the Times Square shelter he founded for runaway teen-agers. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)
LEAD: * Harrison & Star is a new health-care ad agency at 70 West 36th Street.

LEAD: A bill requiring employers to give time off to parents of newborn or newly adopted children received its first Senate hearing today. Supporters and opponents differed over the need for a national policy on leaves for child care, as well as over whether the 18-week, unpaid leave provided by the bill would place an undue burden on small business.
LEAD: The new immigration control law appears to be having a marked and growing effect in deterring Mexicans and other foreigners from entering the United States illegally.
LEAD: When he knocked out Slobodan Kacar last September and won the International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight title, Bobby Czyz was back in the boxing limelight.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Japan ranked third in direct investment in the United States during a 12-year period beginning in 1974, a trade organization said in a report released today. The Japan External Trade Organization said Japan made 1,154 direct investments, or 14.2 percent of the total, in the United States from 1974 through 1985.

LEAD: Pierce Turner, the Old Town Bar, 45 East 18th Street, and Kenny's Castaways, 157 Bleecker Street. An Irish folk vaudevillian, Pierce Turner writes Celtic-flavored folk-rock songs suffused with affection for his hometown of Wexford. Recently he recorded a delightful solo album of his tunes, ''It's Only a Long Way Across'' (co-produced by Philip Glass and Kurt Munkacsi), that evocatively mixes his barroom reveries with snappy electronics.

LEAD: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as traders were encouraged by statements from Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the central bank had not tightened monetary policy.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo's announcement last night that he would not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination caught many Democratic and Republican leaders throughout New York State by surprise.

LEAD: TWO months ago, Martin Richards, one of the producers of ''Roza,'' said there was no talk of moving it to Broadway and no interest in doing so. Mr. Richards is still saying part of the same thing but not quite all. Now there's talk, sort of, and interest in, certainly, but absolutely no commitment to the Great White Way - until and unless everything works out well at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles.
LEAD: Senior United States officials have begun expressing new concern that Pakistan is moving toward the development of a nuclear bomb, in spite of pledges that it has no such intentions.

LEAD: Milder than normal weather over the North Central states helped Americans save $300 million on heating costs in January, the Government said today. January temperatures ranged from 1 degree to 6 degrees Fahrenheit above normal in the upper Midwest and northern Plains region. That helped cut the average heating bill in the region by between $13 and $22, according to the Climate Assessment and Information Services Center, a Federal agency.
LEAD: Britain's troubled state-owned Leyland Trucks, once a takeover target of the General Motors Corporation, will be combined with the Dutch company DAF under a joint venture announced today.

LEAD: A year-old program intended to streamline justice in New York City by assigning all stages of a case to one judge has speeded the pace of criminal cases through the courts, administrators said yesterday. But they said it has also left a growing number of more difficult cases clogging court calendars.

LEAD: A BALD and very fat man, supposedly an extraterrestrial named Murray, stomps through ''Eat and Run'' devouring every Italian he meets, after which he belches loudly and spits out a button or two. ''Eat and Run'' doesn't get any funnier, and not much of it even measures up to that comic pinnacle. As co-written and directed by Christopher Hart, this comedy specializes in schoolboy humor at its most mirthlessly stupid.

LEAD: BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S ''Albert Herring'' is a farce with serious undertones and the Juilliard American Opera Center, in staging it on Wednesday evening, properly bore down on the broad comedy but did not overlook subtler aspects of this 40-year-old chamber opera. First staged at Glyndebourne in 1947 and given its American premiere at Tanglewood two years later, it was Britten's first attempt at comic opera and a surprisingly mature attempt at that.

LEAD: Potsdam (N.Y.) State, the Division III basketball titan, gained its 54th consecutive victory Tuesday night and is closing in on San Francisco's streak of 60 straight (1955-57), the second-longest run in N.C.A.A. history. (U.C.L.A. won 88 in a row from 1971 to 1974.) Just as impressive, Potsdam is aiming to become an unbeaten N.C.A.A.

LEAD: Carlene Pearson, the former fiancee of Dwight Gooden, pleaded guilty yesterday to attempted criminal possession of a weapon. She will be given five years' probation when she is sentenced April 3. Three weeks ago she was arrested at La Guardia Airport when the police said they found a loaded, stolen two-shot derringer pistol in her handbag.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, in a surprise announcement, said last night that he would not be a candidate for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination.
LEAD: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Peter W. Rodino Jr., today compared the Iran arms affair to the Watergate scandals and warned against White House efforts to ''cover up.''

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Ford Motor earnings misstated the Chrysler Corporation's performance for the fourth quarter. Its earnings rose $108.6 million above the fourth quarter of 1985.

LEAD: RACISM is easy to spot when it is dressed in a white robe and pointy hat. But the racism that keeps one suburb lily-white, while a neighboring suburb quietly grows more and more black, is a trickier, more elusive racism.

LEAD: Janice Elaine Stultz, director of development at Barnard College, was married yesterday to Thomas Peale Roddenbery, plant manager of the Jacobus Pharmaceutical Company in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Howard MacFarland Fish, chaplain at the Lawrenceville School and a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

LEAD: Jimmy Arias, Aaron Krickstein, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso have been named to the United States Davis Cup squad that will face Paraguay next March in Asuncion in the opening round of competition. . . . The Jets said a contract would not be offered to Charles Jackson, a starting linebacker last season.

LEAD: For a man who has been pressing St. Louis to build him a 70,000-seat domed football stadium, Bill Bidwill, the Cardinals' owner, has come up with a curious demand. He wants the city fathers to ban beer there, an idea akin to banning speeches in Washington.
LEAD: The vibraphonist Jay Hoggard will lead a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Visiones, 125 Macdougal Street (673-5576). Sets are at 9 P.M., 12:30 and 2 A.M.; there is a $6 minimum.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo's decision not to run for President has drastically altered the shape of the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, political experts said last night, and has left Gary Hart as the party's one candidate with truly national backing.

LEAD: Jack Gilford, Downstairs Theater Bar at the West Bank, 407 West 42d Street (695-6909). On this weekend 48 years ago, Jack Gilford was part of the opening show at the legendary Greenwich Village nightclub Cafe Society, along with Billie Holiday, the blues singer Joe Turner, the boogie-woogie pianists Albert Ammons, Meade Lux Lewis and Pete Johnson, and a band led by the trumpeter Frankie Newton.

LEAD: When Vice President Bush said last week that ''there might be a little bit of friction'' in the future between some of his policies and those of the Reagan Administration, some who take an interest in such political affairs saw it as the equivalent of fleeing the Alamo just as the bullets started flying.

LEAD: President Reagan lifted economic sanctions against Poland today, calling the action a reward for the release of political prisoners and other moves toward reconciliation with supporters of the banned Solidarity movement and the Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Nearly half of the employees at the International Business Machines Corporation's distribution center in Greencastle have chosen to retire early rather than transfer when the plant closes next month. Dale K. Bennett, a spokeswoman for I.B.M., said that about 400 employees planned to take early retirement and that 500 had decided to take jobs at other I.B.M.
LEAD: SECURITY COUNCIL
LEAD: No matter what happens in Nicaragua, the fellow who seems to speak for the State Department is General Micawber: Something hopeful is always about to turn up.

LEAD: The Brazilian Government, facing an acute shortage of hard-currency reserves, has decided to reduce interest payments on its foreign debt, Government officials said today. They said the reduction would be made while Brazil negotiates long-term arrangements with commercial creditors.

LEAD: Seven of the biggest industrial democracies are to meet this weekend in Paris, where they are likely to adopt a new method to calm volatility in their currencies, official sources and economists said today.

LEAD: To acquaint young Americans with Brazil and its renowned soccer talents, Pele is organizing a program to send 80 youth soccer teams from the United States to play in Brazil this summer. Pele and Julio Mazzei, his friend and adviser, said the players would be between the ages of 12 and 18, with eight teams going to Brazil every week from June 19 until the end of August, and each guaranteed eight games there.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it plans to develop with the Microsoft Corporation a new version of its Unix computer operating system for the 80386 microprocessor built by the Intel Corporation. Unix is an advanced software system that enables users to manage a variety of data through its multi-tasking and multi-user functions.

LEAD: The timing of the latest wave of arrests in the still-unraveling Wall Street insider trading imbroglio could not have been more painfully poignant for students in the nation's leading business schools.

LEAD: Roman Catholic officials, yielding to complaints from broadcasters and some church leaders, today dropped a plan to auction television rights for coverage of the visit of Pope John Paul II in September.

LEAD: Announcing a Presidential candidacy these days has become a major production, particularly for lesser-known hopefuls eager to become better-known. On Monday, for example, a chartered DC-9 will carry 20 members of Congress and assorted reporters from Washington to St. Louis for the noon announcement of Representative Richard A.

LEAD: MANY mutual funds with ''aggressive growth'' as their investment objective are pouring money into the stock market these days. But the Strong Opportunity Fund - a big winner last year with a total return of 59.9 percent in this venturesome category - has switched lately to a more conservative tack.
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it earned $116 million, or 45 cents a share, in its first quarter, up 6.4 percent from $109 million, or 43 cents a share, a year ago.

LEAD: Tucker Wayne & Company, Atlanta, won the account of Management Science America, an independent supplier of computer software, last week. Today its first ad, on three consecutive pages, is scheduled to appear in The Wall Street Journal and a number of trade publications.

LEAD: The defense lawyer in Israel's trial of a war crimes suspect from a Nazi camp questioned today whether ''wishful thinking'' might have motivated the accusations of survivors of the Treblinka death camp.

LEAD: The organist David Shuler will play a program of 20th-century music, including the premieres of works by Charles Wuorinen and Gunther Schuller, at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission is $3. St. Bartholemew's is at the corner of Park Avenue and 51st Street. Information: 751-1616, extension 226.

LEAD: A Geneva dispatch on Feb. 13 about a United Nations report on executions in Iran characterized the Bahai International Community incorrectly. It is not an opposition group but a religious group whose members have been persecuted in Iran.

LEAD: When Dennis B. Levine telephoned one of his secret insider-trading confederates soon after being arrested last May 12, the confederate was less than eager to talk. But Mr. Levine, who had used his considerable charm to recruit a handful of Wall Street professionals into his scheme, assured the other person that his call was safe.

LEAD: AS anyone who took square dancing at summer camp knows, ''home'' is the position from which all steps originate and the spot to which a dancer returns after do-si-do-ing. This is the signally simple metaphor that hangs over ''Square Dance'' like a heart-shaped, helium-filled balloon with a slow leak.

LEAD: The sharks, sensing bad blood, were out in force at the New York Yacht Club yesterday as Dennis Conner, the skipper who lost the America's Cup to Australia in 1983, paid his first visit to the trophy's former home on West 44th Street since reclaiming the cup earlier this month -for the San Diego Yacht

LEAD: Dr. Henry Blumenthal, a historian of Franco-American relations at Rutgers University for many years, died Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

LEAD: SOMETIMES I get the feeling that New Yorkers could survive quite adequately without restaurant critics. This disquieting thought came to mind several weeks ago during an exploration on the East Side in which I ''discovered'' Primola, a seven-month-old Italian restaurant that, as it turned out, had already been uncovered long before by legions of amateur restaurant scouts.

LEAD: The parrot by the bar imitated the whistle of incoming shellfire; Fat Tommy, the huge, surly cat, slept wedged between the Reuters and the Associated Press news tickers in the lobby, and the telephones and telexes usually worked.

LEAD: A Bronx woman was arrested yesterday and charged with restraining her 6-year-old daughter while three men raped the girl on separate occasions and then gave the mother money or drugs, the police said.

LEAD: ''THE glitterati were as thick as porterhouse steaks,'' says Rena deButts, a contemporary hostess with the mostest, on the morning after throwing a party for all the rising young novelists, artists and photographers in Manhattan. According to ''The Maderati,'' Richard Greenberg's new comedy about Rena (Mary Joy) and her soigne crowd, the glitterati are actually thicker than porterhouse steaks and a great deal tougher besides.

LEAD: The William Esty Company, which last year lost Salem cigarettes, the mentholated brand it had introduced for R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, has now been assigned Kool, an even better-known menthol from Brown & Williamson, as well as Kim, a new cigarette product in this country.

LEAD: The soprano Roberta Peters will sing works by Scarlatti, Schubert, Meyerbeer, Faure and Noel Coward at the 92d Street Y tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock, accompanied by the pianist Jakov Kreizberg and the flutist Paul Dunkel. Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50. The 92d Street Y is at 1395 Lexington Avenue.

LEAD: The director John Landis testified today that he did not tell the parents of two children who were killed in the filming of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' how large the special effects explosions would be on the movie set or how close the children would be to those explosions.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury is investigating whether the E. F. Hutton Group violated reporting requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission at its Providence, R.I., office between 1981 and 1984, the company disclosed yesterday. It made the disclosure in an S.E.C. filing.
LEAD: POISON. An 87th Precinct Novel. By Ed McBain. 264 pages. Arbor House. $16.95. CHILD'S PLAY. A Dalziel-Pascoe Murder

LEAD: Hudson Guild Theater, 441 West 26th Street. ''The Last Passion Play,'' a drama by Kenshaka Ali. Today, 7:30 P.M. Admission free on a first- come, first-served basis. Informa tion: 760-9810. Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights, Brooklyn.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Crossland Savings Bank of Brooklyn said it has agreed in principle to take over the Western Savings and Loan Association, a troubled savings institution based in Salt Lake City. In return for control over Western's $400 million in assets and 13 branches in four states, Crossland agreed to inject Western with $50 million in fresh capital.

LEAD: Staley Continental Inc. filed a $200 million suit against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday, charging that the investment banking firm tried to ''extort'' the company into a leveraged buyout.

LEAD: The City Attorney today released copies of a report on the arrest of Dwight Gooden and four companions who fought with Tampa police officers last December after his car was stopped by the police.

LEAD: Vida Blue retired yesterday, less than a month after signing as a free agent with the Oakland A's. A team spokesman, Jay Alves, said the decision was a surprise. The 37-year-old left-hander helped the A's to world championships in 1972, 1973 and 1974 and had a career record of 209-161. ''My physical condition is good, so while I am still in good health I have decided to retire,'' Blue said.

LEAD: In this age of the silicon-veined microchip, the unfriendly takeover and the arbitrager rampant, what could be more tempting than to dismiss as a wallow in Victorian sentiment the three-part ''Wonderworks'' presentation of ''A Little Princess,'' scheduled to begin tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 21?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Old Croton Aqueduct no longer carries New York City's water supply from a river in northern Westchester County to a reservoir on 42d Street, 41 miles south. Instead, hikers, joggers and cross-country skiers travel on top of this 19th-century engineering marvel, part of which is a linear park.

LEAD: The Dayton Hudson Corporation plans to start a live, one-hour television show this spring offering viewers a chance to buy just about everything sold in its Dayton's stores except furniture and appliances. Dayton Hudson thus joins a growing list of major reatilers getting into the televised shop-from-home business.

LEAD: WITH all the attention paid to Neo-Expressionist painting, relatively little notice has been taken of the number of younger artists whose approach is rooted in German Expressionist drawing and graphic art. The ink drawings of Peter Drake (at the Curt Marcus Gallery, 578 Broadway, at Prince Street, through March 4), as well as the work of artists like Sue Coe and Paul Marcus, offer a purer, less self-conscious form of expressionism than any branch of Neo-Expressionist painting.
LEAD: There was more heavy fighting in West Beirut today as regular Syrian and Lebanese soldiers took up positions at main intersections to try to enforce a cease-fire.

LEAD: The tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp will lead a quintet - with the trombonist Grachan Moncur 3d, the pianist Dave Burrell, the bassist Cameron Brown and the drummer Beaver Harris - tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M.
LEAD: Henry-Russell Hitchcock, one of the country's most distinguished architectural historians and teachers, died of cancer yesterday in New York. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: The continuing brutality of the conflict between the English and the Irish is captured with empathetic awareness in Shirley Gee's ''Never in My Lifetime.'' The play, winner of the 1984 Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, is having its American premiere here by the Hartman Theater Company. As expected, there are no villains or martyrs in this war-torn stretch of Northern Ireland.
LEAD: Faster Subway Rides

LEAD: The dissident psychiatrist Anatoly Koryagin, pale and emaciated from six years in prison and labor camp, was reunited today with his wife on a street in Kharkov, friends told a Dutch rights group.

LEAD: To most people, Palm Beach conjures images of dowagers and diamonds, of parties and mansions, of heiresses and scandalous liaisons. Some of that is still true, but it is no longer the whole story.
LEAD: A team of oceanographers has piloted a small submarine into the eye of an underwater volcano near Hawaii and reports finding a strange new world.

LEAD: IF music were ever reinstated as an Olympic event, Mstislav Rostropovich might walk away with all the gold medals. As a way of celebrating his 60th birthday, the ebullient cellist, conductor and pianist is in the midst of a strenuous two-month series of concerts in New York, Boston and Washington that should qualify him to be known as music's marathon man.
LEAD: Financial analysts with Wall Street investment concerns have contributed $28,956.50 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the Yankee clubhouse on the first day of spring training, there were handshakes all around - the casual reunion handshakes of old friends and the firm introductory handshakes of new teammates.

LEAD: HOLLAND & CALLAWAY, an ad agency that has evolved into a media promotion specialty shop, has resigned The Daily News account to work on the promotion of New York Newsday. Jim Callaway, the president, said his new client should be billing as much as the old, and that was around $5 million.

LEAD: The violinist Mark Peskanov will play works by Mozart, Richard Strauss and Aaron Copland at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night at 8 o'clock, accompanied by the pianist Rita Sloan. Tickets are $10; information: 362-1911.

LEAD: Andrei Sakharov, Yelena Bonner, Natan Sharansky. Americans know these names: they are heroes fighting the evil Soviet system. Their Chinese counterparts, also courageously fighting repression, are nameless and unknown. That's partly because Americans pay so much attention to the Soviet Union. It's also because Americans think of the Chinese as the good-guy Communists.
LEAD: Friday BOOKS, BOOKS, BOOKS

LEAD: Mexico has paid off a $1.1 billion bridge loan from central banks of 16 countries and the United States Treasury Department, the Government said today. The credit, approved last August, provided funds while Mexico negotiated a new long-term loan agreement with foreign commercial banks. Nearly half the bridge loan was provided by the United States, with the Treasury Department contributing $272 million and the Federal Reserve Bank, $273 million.

LEAD: WHAT does it mean when a pair of 17th-century gilded silver salvers, a French commode, a 19th-century rosewood cabinet, a Regency vase and a Victorian partners' desk are all sold for prices far in excess of the auction houses' estimates? Have the professionals goofed, is the current buoyancy of the art market responsible, are low presale estimates a ploy to attract potential buyers or was it a bidding war between two collectors?

LEAD: A picture on Monday with a television review of ''Marcel Duchamp: In His Own Words'' was published in error because of an incorrect caption supplied by WNET. It showed the artist Hans Richter, not Duchamp.

LEAD: AS winter moves into its final month this weekend, New Yorkers may already be dreaming of spring. Nevertheless, many cold-weather pleasures still await the intrepid outdoor explorer. The crowds are gone from the area's parks and gardens, and if tranquillity is ever to be found in the city, this is the time to look for it.
LEAD: Iran's human rights record last year was marked by ''serious abuses,'' including political killings, torture and violent repression of religious minorities, the State Department said today.

LEAD: The investor Irwin L. Jacobs, renewing his four-month-old bid for the Borg-Warner Corporation, said today that he intends to begin a tender offer for no less than $44 a share in cash, if a friendly merger cannot be arranged soon.
LEAD: A bipartisan coalition of key legislators, joined by nearly 200 organizations, announced today that two major civil rights measures would be their top priorities for the 100th Congress.

LEAD: WHEN the outside world began to penetrate Janet Fish's still lifes in the late 1970's, it was as a mere bit player. Her oversized glass objects were still the center of interest. Plates by the stack, legions of tumblers, bowls and other containers, they reposed on their tables coruscating in bright daylight - no dishwashing problems here, but then no food or drink to cause them, unless it was the fruit and vegetables that materialized about the same time as the inserts of urban and rural landscape.

LEAD: LIKE its title, Fredi M. Murer's ''Alpine Fire'' is ultimately a lot more corny (and a lot less meaningful) than one wants to believe while watching it. The Swiss film is the first fiction feature to be made by Mr. Murer, who, until now, has specialized in documentaries, and who clearly knows how to photograph scenery and weather under difficult conditions.
LEAD: An expanded New York City Health Department program to promote the use of condoms was announced yesterday by the Health Commissioner, Steven C. Joseph.

LEAD: Coach Tim Baab of John Carroll University, bemoaning the length of the basketball season: ''I love the game, but I love my mother-in-law too, and I wouldn't think of living with her for six months.''
LEAD: A highly critical assessment of Soviet sociology that was recently published in Pravda is remarkable for its candor even in this era of openness under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: JACK GALVIN, the title character's father in the family drama ''Billy Galvin,'' likes to watch the Muppets on television. He calls people ''Yardbird,'' and can't stand it when his wife forgets to close the kitchen cabinet door. These details, in John Gray's simple, big-hearted and essentially familiar film, are meant to say a good deal more about Jack's character than they actually do.
LEAD: The economy grew at a slower rate in the fourth quarter than previously thought, the Government reported yesterday. But some analysts saw a hint of a silver lining in the news.
LEAD: For the first time since Jesse Orosco struck out Marty Barrett and wiped out the Boston Red Sox 115 days ago, there were Mets on a baseball field in uniform today.

LEAD: At a breakfast Thursday with Yitzhak Shamir, the Israeli Prime Minister, a reporter asked what Israel's current policy was with respect to selling arms to terrorist nations. ''Israel is the only country fighting terrorism,'' he replied. ''We are successful.'' As for the arms shipments to Iran in which Israel assisted, he added: ''The Iran affair was an exception.

LEAD: The sign above the door of an old factory building here says ''Shion Shalom Prayer Hall'' in Hebrew and English. Inside, worshipers in prayer shawls and yarmulkes read from the Torah at Saturday Sabbath services.

LEAD: A bomb exploded outside the office of an Afghan guerrilla group today, killing 10 people and wounding 62, the authorities said. Angry Pakistanis later attacked Afghan refugees, and up to four people were reported killed.

LEAD: The Surprising Soprano was as surprised as anyone, he insists, when his career in operatic parody opened up in 1969. ''It was not my idea. I didn't know I could do these things,'' said Michael Aspinall shortly after his arrival from Rome last week. The blame, he alleges, lies with ''a friend of mine who wanted to do it, and wanted me to try to sing duets with him.

LEAD: Ever since round and gray Riverfront Stadium opened in 1970, Cincinnatians have missed the quaint atmosphere of the Reds' previous home, Crosley Field. So when the suburban town of Blue Ash developed a 12-diamond amateur baseball complex that included two professional-sized fields, City Manager Marvin Thompson asked, ''Why not make one like Riverfront and one like Crosley?

LEAD: Lawyers for Patricia Lara, the Colombian journalist detained and then expelled from the United States in October, filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday seeking to obtain Government documents pertaining to her case.

LEAD: Defense lawyers yesterday attacked the credibility of the government's key witness in the fraud trial of the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, telling jurors that the witness was desperately trying to stay out of jail and at one time said he wanted to ''blow up'' a credit union to hide his criminal transactions.
LEAD: The Government has long made liberal use of its authority to classify information as ''secret.'' But a question has arisen over whether it recently went a few steps too far.

LEAD: Following is an excerpt from a transcript of Governor Cuomo's question-and-answer session last night on a statewide radio broadcast: Q. We have about four minutes left Governor. If we can get back to what I asked you at the beginning of the broadcast and you said maybe we'd talk about it later; it's almost later.
LEAD: Fighting continues in Beirut: Once, the words made the heart sink. Now, they have echoed for a dozen years; too long.
LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 66.1 percent, largely because of a hefty gain from the initial public offering of stock in its bottling operations.
LEAD: Yesterday was by far the easiest day the College of Staten Island's basketball team has had in a while. The only thing the Dolphins had to worry about was basketball.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Control of American arms sales is so weak that convicted felons can obtain export licenses and officials do not track billions of dollars in weapons sold overseas, a Senate panel was told today.

LEAD: Harry Caray, the veteran Chicago Cubs baseball announcer, was resting comfortably in fair condition in a Palm Springs, Calif., hospital after suffering a mild stroke on Tuesday. ''He seems to be a little better,'' said Bill Wills, a spokesman for the Tribune Company, which owns the Cubs, The Chicago Tribune, WGN Radio and WGN-TV.

LEAD: President Reagan ''was not aware'' of any ''cover-up'' of his role in the Iran arms affair, his chief spokesman said today, and the President said he was not worried about what a commission investigating the operation would say when its report comes out next week.

LEAD: The Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun was freed and reunited with his family today after more than three years in prison and a week of conflicting reports about his fate, relatives in Moscow reported.

LEAD: A Manhattan judge yesterday denied a New York City police union's request to block a departmental ban on hogtying prisoners.

LEAD: Buoyed by strong sales of its ST personal computer and a resurgence in the video game market, the Atari Corporation today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $23 million, or 87 cents a share, up 54.4 percent from $14.9 million, or 64 cents a share, a year ago. Fourth-quarter 1986 results include an extraordinary credit of $11 million.

LEAD: Charles C. Wei, a shipping executive and a leading figure in contract bridge, died in New York Hospital yesterday from complications resulting from diabetes. He was 72 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Houston.
LEAD: A defense lawyer told the jury yesterday in the ''pizza connection'' trial that the main defendant was driven out of the Mafia in a brutal war because he was opposed to drug trafficking.

LEAD: Shola Lynch, the Hunter College High School senior who is one of the top schoolgirl middle-distance runners in the country, was barred from the Public Schools Athletic League championships at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn today and will not be allowed to compete in the state championships at Cornell on

LEAD: Some women got together at Alice's Restaurant the other morning, as they do every day in this central Wisconsin town. They talked about the warm spell, the upcoming Alice in Dairyland contest and, between sips of coffee, the ABC mini-series ''Amerika.''

LEAD: THE JAGUAR SMILE. A Nicaraguan Journey. By Salman Rushdie. 171 pages. Viking. $12.95.

LEAD: A chart in some copies of Business Day yesterday, with an article about international financial meetings this weekend in Paris, incorrectly described one proposed way of keeping currencies within trading ranges against other currencies. If the dollar strengthened beyond the top limit of a proposed range against the yen, for instance, the countries involved might try to bring the dollar back down by selling dollars or buying yen; if the dollar weakened too much, the countries might buy dollars and sell yen.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: N.B.A. Lakers 110, Bulls 100: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, becoming the first National Basketball Association player to score 36,000 career points, connected on a skyhook and hit two key free throws in the final 2 minutes 32 seconds last night for the Lakers in Chicago. The Lakers insured the outcome on two baskets in the final 54 seconds by Magic Johnson, who added 28 points.

LEAD: A top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that the bureau was ''not involved in any capacity'' in break-ins against churches and organizations opposed to the Government's activities in Central America.

LEAD: Israeli hospital workers returned to their jobs today after a five-day walkout that President Chaim Herzog denounced as an ''abuse of the right to strike.'' The 9,000 clerks and maintenance workers at the hospitals of Histadrut, the nation's main labor federation, promised to halt their protest while a committee examines their demand for a 14-percent pay increase.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: This week has brought a flood of memories, Billie Jean King said, recollections of her youth spent playing tennis on public courts in southern California, of the unquenchable thirst she had for learning all she could about the history of the game.

LEAD: It is hard to come by good dance that is also informed by wit, intelligence and terse but glowing humanity. But that was what shone through a program by Susan Rose and her pleasantly casual Danceworks company on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where the Boston-based dancers will perform again tonight and

LEAD: Two founders of a securities firm whose collapse touched off a financial crisis in Ohio have been sentenced to jail by a judge who expressed contempt for the plea bargains the prosecutors had reached.

LEAD: Ted Fiore is a throwback to a time in basketball when aspiring coaches paid dues at the junior high school level, learned more about the craft in high school, served another apprenticeship as a college assistant and finally took a head coaching job.

LEAD: Civilian complaints against Transit Authority police officers rose 33 percent in 1986, compared with the year before, the Acting Transit Police Chief, Vincent Del Castillo, announced yesterday.

LEAD: A big change has come over Washington in the last few weeks. People are beginning to talk about the Reagan Administration in the past tense. The reporters are still running around like blind dogs in a meat house, but almost everybody else seems willing to leave the recent White House scandals to the investigators, the historians and the psychological novelists.

LEAD: Kendra Stearns O'Donnell, an official of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, has been named principal of the Phillips Exeter Academy, the New Hampshire preparatory school announced yesterday, adding that she would be the first woman to head one a major independent secondary school in New England. Dr. O'Donnell, who has taught at Princeton University, will succeed Stephen G.

LEAD: ''H arlem Renaissance,'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem, at 145 West 125th Street, is a serious and substantial historical exhibition, well researched and well installed. Eloquent throughout its length on the subject of what has rightly been called ''the dignity of the undefeated,'' it is by turns vivacious and poignant, elegiac and a great deal of fun.

LEAD: French Canals Question: Where can we obtain information about arranging a canal or river trip by boat or barge - without crew - in France? LEAD: Even listeners on a tight budget now have the option of buying a separate tuner and amplifier in place of the customary receiver. In the past, low-cost receivers were pretty much the standard down in the bargain basement, and so-called separates (i.e., separate tuners and amplifiers) were confined mainly to the upper brackets.

LEAD: Cars in the parking lot at the Sugarbush Ski Resort have added baby seats. The slopes are dotted with pint-sized skiers. At the resort's day-care center, 40 children -from 3-month-old Spike to 5 1/2-year-old Justin - are turning graham crackers into graham cracker crumbs while their parents are skiing.

LEAD: THEY didn't make it to California for the Super Bowl, but a couple of members of the Chicago Bears will be jetting to the West Coast today in quest of a consolation prize of sorts. Willie Gault and Richard Dent are going to Los Angeles in hopes of picking up a Grammy Award Tuesday night. They were among the Bears featured in ''The Super Bowl Shuffle,'' which became a rap hit after the Bears won the 1986 Super Bowl and is one of five Grammy finalists for the best song by a rhythm and blues group.

LEAD: EVERYBODY I know who once spent every summer at the same ''summer place'' remembers one summer as the End of an Era. And of course that's not necessarily so. Memories lie, and they are full of murk. But such ''eras'' have a way of floating up through the murk of one's memory in winter, the year's murkiest season.
LEAD: About 4,000 Syrian troops dismantled their camp near Beirut today and, according to unconfirmed radio reports, scouts from the force were in a suburb of the capital.

LEAD: The Soviet press has for the first time publicly identified eight Jews who are not allowed to emigrate because they were once employed in secret Government work.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: On March 11, the pianist Konrad Wolff will play Mozart's Adagio in B minor (K. 540) and Sonata in B-flat (K. 570), Schubert's Sonata in B-flat (D. 960), Liszt's ''Valse Oubliee No. 3'' and Ravel's ''Valses Nobles et Sentimentales'' at Merkin Concert Hall. While this is an attractive but not especially unusual program for a debut recital, the circumstances surrounding this particular concert are extraordinary.

LEAD: Syd Thrift, attempting to rebuild a losing team with young talent, said today that the Pittsburgh Pirates would show enough improvement this season to justify his rehiring as general manager.

LEAD: IN 1965, three men, all in their early 20's, were working in vastly different parts of the world. Ernie Turner, a member of the Peace Corps, was teaching in Borneo. Lars Cederholm, as manager of Sweden's largest tour-operating company, was overseas most of the year, negotiating business in Europe, North Africa, South America and the Middle East.

LEAD: THE debate over tobacco advertising is shifting from doctors to lawyers. Last week, the American Bar Association took up and rejected a resolution supporting efforts to ban all advertising of tobacco products. A few days later, Representative Michael L. Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, reintroduced a bill in Congress that calls for such a ban.

LEAD: RUNNING two miles through the rugged foothills of the Santa Cruz mountains, the Stanford Linear Accelerator has been described as the world's longest shed. But during its 10 years of operation, this architecturally unimposing structure has been responsible for some of the most important breakthroughs in particle physics.

LEAD: Getting people to think in terms of what could be, rather than what is, lies at the heart of restoration, according to James Boorstein, a restoration expert. ''To some, it may seem like an old, crumbling staircase,'' he said, ''whereas it should really be seen as a structure with wonderful winders and detailed balusters, one that has the potential to be beautiful, given some work.

LEAD: I'M NOT KNOWN TO make many mistakes,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen modestly, in extricating himself from a fund-raising furor, ''but when I do, it's a doozie.''

LEAD: GREG had waited for this day for a long time. He had witnessed his older brother, Chris, losing several baby teeth, followed by the inevitable visit from the Tooth Fairy. Finally, one of his own teeth had fallen out, and at last he could look forward to the reward being under his pillow.

LEAD: At Symphony Hall in Newark Thursday, a nonprofit group that promotes entertainment for the disadvantaged, Special Audiences of New Jersey, along with the Newark Board of Education, is sponsoring the city's first rap contest, with a top prize of $50 for each member of the winning team and $500 to be awarded in all.

LEAD: Piedmont's board is seeking any and all suitors. USAir started the bidding war by offering $68 a share in cash and stock. Then Norfolk Southern offered $65 in cash, and USAir came back with an offer of $71 in cash for half of Piedmont and $73 a share in cash and stock for the rest. Norfolk said it would not match that offer, but Piedmont said it would entertain other offers.
LEAD: THE United States will start to run out of gas, many analysts agree, in as little as three decades.

LEAD: BRIAN AND KATHLEEN SCHWAB looked out the window of their Pomfret home, past their two acres of land, and pointed to the cornfields beyond. ''That's why we work from home,'' said Mr. Schwab, who, with his wife, publishes Connecticut Parent, a free monthly, statewide magazine with a 50,000 circulation.

LEAD: An expert advisory panel created by Congress will soon recommend a standardized national fee schedule for payment of physicians who treat the 31 million elderly and disabled people under Medicare, the Federal health insurance program.

LEAD: My own private dream has always been to speak graceful and fluent French; I have also always wanted to rent a house in Provence. Last summer, having made arrangements for the latter, I attempted the former; I signed up for the total immersion course at Berlitz. In my preliminary interview I rated myself somewhere between ''fairly good command'' and ''speaks with proficiency.

LEAD: LIKE so many Northerners, I longed to retire to an island in the sun, hoping, perhaps, that those promised older, golder years would actually come into being with the help of a hot tropical sun. At any rate, I pursued my goal more assiduously than most, and now I own seaside property in the Bahamas.

LEAD: Philip Lawrence, an actor and director noted for his work in Shakespearean and other classical stage productions, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan of complications resulting from diabetes. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: After reading William Safire's article ''Locust Valley Lockjaw'' (On Language, Jan. 18), I tried to enunciate, pressing ''the tips of the lower incisors firmly against the inside of the upper incisors,'' but it did not work. Perhaps one needs to be a member of the Larchmont Yacht Club to get the right drawl.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was happy to read Marcia Seligson's article (Travel, Jan. 4) exclaiming the virtues of Laguna Beach, Calif. I, too, am captivated by all that it has to offer. So much so that we have a time share for three weeks a year there.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Christian churches scattered in the hills of this remote corner of India summon their worshipers with a resonant brass gong. Hymns are sung slowly to the beat of old tribal drums.

LEAD: THE Pittsburgh Dance Alloy is a company of dancers whose way of moving is appealingly direct, keen-edged and quietly lyrical. Founded 10 years ago, the group is dedicated to presenting work by a wide variety of contemporary modern choreographers. But the company was sold short by the five dances it presented Wednesday in a New York debut program at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

LEAD: When Californians voted during the early 1970's to impose America's most stringent coastal zoning regulations in an effort to preserve their shoreline from overdevelopment, many of them may have been thinking about a lonely 60-mile stretch of coast near Half Moon Bay.

LEAD: For me, spring training means that maybe, just maybe, the world will stop talking about the 1986 World Series. As recently as Feb. 16 The Times rean an article about the Mets' victory in game 6, complete with a photo of the famous ball-between-the-legs play. Poor me. Poor Red Sox fans everywhere.

LEAD: AFTER two quiet weeks, Connecticut orchestras are springing back into action, with more than a dozen concerts scheduled over the next fortnight, along with a touring visit from the Boston Symphony.

LEAD: The Esthetic Movement in America in the decade from the 1870's to the 1880's has been neglected until recently by scholars of the decorative arts. LEAD: An advisory committee has recommended that the Food and Drug Administration approve a new drug to help lower cholesterol levels in the blood.

LEAD: Two weekends ago, an English conductor named Roger Norrington presented three days of lectures, discussions and demonstrations in London's Queen Elizabeth Hall that culminated in a full-dress, large-scale, original-instruments performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. In recent years, others have performed and recorded earlier Beethoven symphonies on original instruments.
LEAD: The commander of United States forces in Latin America, Gen. John R. Galvin, says he plans to expand the American military presence in his region next year.

LEAD: IN the days when Martin A. Siegel was riding high as one of the country's top takeover specialists, junior associates at Kidder, Peabody & Company admiringly called him the barracuda. ''He was pretty, he was smooth and he was fast,'' one of them explained.
LEAD: CONNECTICUT'S voting patterns and political-party development of the last 25 years have led this state close to the one-party rule we see in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to our north.

LEAD: When politicians decide not to run for President, it's news. Whether the reasons they give -especially the family reasons cited by Mario M. Cuomo Thursday, or by Edward M. Kennedy in 1982 - seem to explain it all or not, there is something that seems unusual in proclaimed self-denial by a politician prominent enough to be thought of a serious candidate to begin with.

LEAD: For thousands of Ethiopian Jews who fled their famine-stricken country and were airlifted from Sudanese refugee camps in 1984, their rescue and arrival in Israel were the fulfillment of a dream.

LEAD: ORDINARILY, my wife never speaks before her second cup of coffee. And when she does, it's usually to the coffee pot. But this morning began quickly with her plaintive lament: ''Oh, no. Oh, no. Oh, no.''

LEAD: With the same kind of methodical argument that helped build his reputation in Congress, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia has decided to remove himself from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination and devote himself full time to his duties in the Senate.

LEAD: Republican members of the House are planning to hold a historical conference all their own next month in observance of the opening of the current 100th Congress.
LEAD: Spring training is to life what going on the road was to Willy Loman. It gives us hope. NORMAN KLINE Larchmont, N.Y.
LEAD: The message in ''Amerika'' is this: We had it coming. It wasn't the Soviet Union; it was us.

LEAD: GOING LIVE. By Muriel Dobbin. (Dutton, $17.95.) To judge by Muriel Dobbin's entertaining new novel, the television news industry is the glamorous career of choice for ambitious women today. At 37, the veteran television correspondent Martha Vogel is young enough to dream of being her network's national news anchor, but mature enough to realize that her superiors favor female broadcasters with younger, less wrinkled faces.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Egbert Laird Mortimer 3d of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Virginia Mortimer, to Richard Lawrence Grubman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grubman of Englewood, N.J. The wedding is to be June 27.

LEAD: MORE gaunt men with prison haircuts went home last week from Soviet penal colonies. The Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun was freed and Anatoly Koryagin, a psychiatrist locked up for exposing the abuse of Soviet mental hospitals, was reunited with his wife. By the end of the week, Soviet authorities said the number of prisoners pardoned by Government decree had passed 150.

LEAD: The article ''Youth Cases Put Strain on Mental Aid'' [ Feb. 1 ] includes statements by Dr. Carolina Hedlund of the Northern Westchester Guidance Clinic that may leave the reader with an erroneous impression - namely, that all private practitioners in psychotherapy charge fees beyond the reach of low-income families.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Where History's Sweep Conquers the Visitor'' by Frederic Raphael (Travel, Jan. 18) was really a delight (Turkish). It warmed the cockles of our hearts. My wife and I have been vacationing in Turkey for about six years. Wherever we traveled, always by public bus, we were befriended by the warmest, most caring people we have met in our travels.

LEAD: A large cache of Soviet-made arms sitting unclaimed and unsalable in a warehouse in Honduras has become one of the latest mysteries emerging from the Federal and Congressional investigations of the private network to arm the Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: In the imperfect world of physical phenomena, superconductivity seems almost too good to be true. When certain substances are cooled to near absolute zero, they lose their resistance to electricity. Thus current can be conducted through them without energy loss, allowing the development of more efficient power lines and magnets powerful enough to propel trains.

Lynch, Republican of the 17th District (parts of Middlesex and Union Counties), the Senate majority leader and also Mayor of New Brunswick, has asked the state's Capital Budget and Planning Commission to review his proposal for a cultural capital-improvement fund, a $90 million bond issue that would provide grants for art centers and historic buildings operated by the state.

LEAD: Getting James Baldwin's ''Go Tell It on the Mountain'' to television took a great deal of time and dedication on the part of its producers, Robert Geller and Cal Skaggs, but the effort was worth it as can be seen once again on American Playhouse, Monday at 9 P.M. on channels 13 and 49. It is a lovely film, rich in detail and emotional reverberations.

LEAD: Somewhere on a 50-acre plot outside Lafayette, La., a man sits on an old Ford tractor. He is alone in his solitude and his thoughts. No one is nearby. Cars that pass by the area are as far away as a drive to the distant land of left-center field at Yankee Stadium. The man on the tractor knows that spot and that stadium well.

LEAD: Prospects for major changes in economic policies that might stabilize the dollar appeared dim tonight, as leading finance ministers and central bank officials rushed about Paris in quest of agreements to calm the world's financial markets.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo may not be entering any races for now, but he certainly appeared to be keeping in training. LEAD: History is written by survivors. In jazz, living musicians deliver final judgments on their predecessors; they decide, consciously and intuitively, what styles and ideas will stay current, and it doesn't hurt if the inventors of those styles are still alive and blowing. At the moment, as jazz's younger generation rediscovers the 1950's and 1960's, the contributions of such vital, active musicians as Sonny Rollins, Wayne Shorter and Ornette Coleman are justly celebrated.
