LEAD: SANFORD N. McDONNELL, the 64-year-old chairman of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, often describes the aerospace industry as a ''Las Vegas-type'' business in which companies gamble billions of dollars every time they decide to develop a new plane.

LEAD: ACROSS the nation, state governments are grappling with how to respond to the just-passed Federal Tax Reform Act of 1986. Unfortunately, much of what has been said and written - about ''revenue windfalls'' and ''back-door tax increases'' - misses the point.

LEAD: The engagement of Judith Eldon Rose to Ivan L. Epstein has been announced by her parents, Sally R. Adolph of Tucson, Ariz., and William R. Rose 2d of Scarsdale and Lake Placid, N.Y. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton J. Epstein of Atlanta. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Miller of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ivy Michelle Miller to Dr. Andrew Marc Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schneider of Tamarac, Fla. Miss Miller, editor in chief of Modern Screen and Movie Mirror magazines in New York, and her fiance, a third-year resident at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, plan to be married in June.
LEAD: DURING the intermission of a performance by the New Jersey Symphony Chamber Orchestra at the Strand Theater here last month, a leak in the ceiling set off a fire alarm.

LEAD: Olga Espinola, a computer programmer for Honeywell Inc. in Wellesley, Mass., has just finished writing a program that uses diagrams, colors and highlighted characters to teach the use of a calculator.

LEAD: MANDELA'S CHILDREN. By Ora Mendels. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Part thriller, part psychological portrait, part history, ''Mandela's Children'' (the title refers to political offspring) tells the story of Ruth Harris, a white woman brought up in Johannesburg. An ardent student activist there in the 60's, she is now a United States citizen, divorced, with a grown son.

LEAD: Irish voters last week gave a veteran politician, former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey, another turn at trying to pull the country out of its economic slough. Mr. Haughey, also known as ''Boss,'' thrashed the Fine Gael party of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, who called for the elections last month after his coalition

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. O'Brien of Atlanta and Branchport, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claire F. O'Brien, to Timothy J. Brosnan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin J. Brosnan of New York. Ms. O'Brien, an associate at Davidson, Dawson & Clark in New York, and her fiance, an associate at Hawkins, Delafield & Wood in New York, both graduated from the Fordham University School of Law.

LEAD: The Gateway Arch still towers above the city, the Mississippi River still winds along its eastern boundary, and baseball is still the favorite pastime. But in the last five years, St. Louis has undergone a fundamental transformation.
LEAD: YASIR Arafat never wins.

LEAD: To the Editor: My husband and I, having spent a week on the Anatolian coast of Turkey last October, certainly share Mr. Raphael's enthusiasm for Turkey. We only regret that more was not said about the coastal resort town of Bodrum and the beauty of the Anatolian landscape. We rented a car in Izmir in order to go south to Bodrum for a few days, and the drive through the mountains and the broad, cotton-growing valleys was marvellous, going past great herds of black goats and the occasional camel.
LEAD: THE EYES OF THE DRAGON By Stephen King. Illustrated by David Palladini. 326 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.
LEAD: For a man with an important new job in Minneapolis, Garland Wright is spending an unusual amount of time in Manhattan these days.

LEAD: IN A Jan. 11 Opinion Page article, ''Speed Is Needed on Tax Reform,'' my distinguished Democratic colleague, State Senator John A. Lynch of the 17th District (parts of Middlesex and Union Counties), raised some very salient points regarding New Jersey's system of property taxation and the need for reform.

LEAD: After tugging in different directions for months, the United States and its chief economic allies tried again this weekend to pull together to stabilize their currencies and reduce trade imbalances.

LEAD: Bobby Lloyd's Rutgers jersey was retired during halftime of today's game with Penn State and by the time the game ended after two overtimes, Lloyd's school scoring record was nearly retired as well.

LEAD: A major ballet company is measured by its overall standard of dancing and by the artistic value of its repertory. These are the two prerequisites upon which Helgi Tomasson has set his sights since becoming director of the San Francisco Ballet in July 1985. The winter season, which has just closed, revealed a strikingly impressive new improvement in the company's classical dancing.
LEAD: THE booming construction industry is making it harder for towns to find help in their planning, zoning and building offices, as higher salaries lure workers out of government.

LEAD: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that it had filed suit against four lawyers who used to work for the organization, seeking to recover more than $2 million in legal fees.

LEAD: A PAIR of beautiful concerto performances formed the highlight of the Orchestra of St. Luke's program Tuesday at Carnegie Hall - and not entirely because of the soloists, fine as they were. It is altogether unusual to hear an orchestra's opening tutti in a Classical concerto shaped with such care, played with such interest, as they were here in Mozart's Third Violin Concerto and Haydn's familiar Piano Concerto in D under Trevor
LEAD: Public and private colleges and universities in New Jersey will receive $22.8 million for 17 projects under a bill signed Friday by Governor Kean.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. E. McIntosh Cover of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne McIntosh Cover to Townsend Gilbert Rawlins, a son of Joyce W. Rawlins of Greenwich, Conn., and M. Morgan Rawlins of New York, New Hope, Pa., and Bridgehampton, L.I. A late summer wedding is planned.
LEAD: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut rank among the top five states in establishing and enforcing programs to protect the environment, according to a private report issued today.

LEAD: TO a sensitive or squeamish observer, the contents of Christopher Durang's wild and wicked autobiographically based ''The Marriage of Bette and Boo'' are no laughing matter. Count among them stillborn children (whose bodies are hurled onto the floor by the delivering doctors), wretched families and miserable marriages.

LEAD: THE United States has had enormous success in creating new jobs - nearly 13 million during the current recovery. Even though our unemployment rate is still quite high, a larger proportion of our population is working today than ever before. But some of our factories have closed down. And more and more jobs are in services.
LEAD: BRENT NANCE is an insurance broker. As such, the thought of writing policies for people who are at high risk of developing AIDS makes him shudder.
LEAD: The more bizarre, the more disorganized, the more unplanned an attack looks, the better are its chances to go undetected.

LEAD: OUR FRIEND MANSO. By Benito Perez Galdos. Translated by Robert Russell. (Columbia University, $25.) Perez Galdos is one of the treasures of 19th-century Spanish fiction. ''Our Friend Manso'' (1882), here translated into English for the first time, reflects his prodigious, inexhaustible curiosity about the human condition and the limits of the novelist's art.

LEAD: FLIPPING FOR IT. By Daniel Asa Rose. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) This first novel feels like a detective story, though it's about the pains of divorce. The dialogue is matter-of-fact; the action, over a four-week period, moves episodically; the secondary characters are colorful and talk cynically, with dark humor.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Ennis of New York and Sharon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Betsy Louise Ennis to Edward Isaac Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Adler of New York.
LEAD: LITTLE WILSON AND BIG GOD By Anthony Burgess. 460 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.
LEAD: Two months ago on a rainy Tuesday night, a robbery was unfolding at the Tita Candy Store in the North Bronx.

LEAD: Martha Graham Party Feb. 23 - The Martha Graham Dance Company is 60 years old, and next on the list of projects for that legend of modern dance is the Martha Graham Dance School in Florence. A ''Diamond for Martha'' benefit auction at Christie's will celebrate the dual occasion, starting with cocktails and a buffet at the auction house at 6:30 P.M.

LEAD: La Salle kept St. Peter's scoreless for almost four minutes toward the end of the game tonight to post a 68-61 victory that enabled it to tie the Peacocks for first place in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.
LEAD: Navy offset a 38-point performance by Kevin Houston of Army and came from behind in the second half to defeat the Cadets today, 58-52, in the annual game between the two service academies.

LEAD: If Andrew Tobias's idea of tax heaven is just a smaller bite, he has found it in Florida. LEAD: EIGHTEEN AMERICAN WARPLANES SET out from Lakenheath Air Base in England last April 14 to begin a 14-hour, 5,400-mile round-trip flight to Tripoli, Libya. It is now clear that nine of those Air Force F-111's had an unprecedented peacetime mission. Their targets: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family.
LEAD: A mayoral commission has grossly underestimated the long-term tax windfall to New York City resulting from changes in the Federal tax code, the State Comptroller contends.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. Marie A. Hanache of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter Suzanne M. DeVries to Gerard B. Sullivan, a son of Lillian G. Sullivan of Warwick, R.I., and the late Daniel J. Sullivan. The wedding is to be in September.

LEAD: If you want toys or bicycles in Half Moon Bay, a coastal farming community about 30 miles south of San Francisco, you go to the small blue house on Main Street just across the Main Street Bridge. This is The Toy Pedaler, a five-room cottage stocked to the rafters with kites, kaleidoscopes, hand-cranked carousels, trail bikes, thingamabobs and gadgets.

LEAD: TO preserve the dwindling supply of open land for ecological and recreational purposes, Connecticut should acquire another 100,000 acres -about 3 percent of the state's land area - by the year 2000, a state panel recommended last week.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has indicated that the Soviet Union will announce the next nuclear test in advance, breaking with a longstanding policy of keeping silent about its testing program.

LEAD: After two nights of sporadic violence by youths, calm prevailed today in a mostly black Tampa neighborhood as community leaders went door to door urging parents to keep teen-agers off the streets.

LEAD: A state plan to close six developmental centers for the mentally handicapped, including two in New York City, would swell the ranks of homeless and destitute people, opponents of the plan say.

LEAD: A contest for the most popular author in Westchester is going on in county libraries and bookstores, where readers can vote until March 15 for their favorites among 21 local writers whose books have been published in the last two years.
LEAD: The Nets have held the edge in the metropolitan area's hotly contested race toward basketball oblivion practically since the start of the regular season. But all of a sudden, it's a race again.

Deane of Kings Point, L.I. A June 6 wedding is planned. LEAD: I HAVE upstairs shoes and downstairs shoes. My downstairs array of footgear has more character, or perhaps it is just more endearing.

LEAD: To the Editor: Harold Poling proposes that Japan limit automobile shipments to the United States to two million units annually, and that it use more American parts in vehicles built in Japan (''Counting Cars From 'Immigrant' Plants,'' Forum, Feb. 1). I hope not. In 1979 I bought a '78 Lincoln Town Car with 12,000 miles on it, which had been regularly serviced by the Lincoln dealer.

LEAD: Joe Franco and James Robinson scored 14 points each, and Fordham took the lead for good with an early first-half surge at Byrne Meadowlands Arena to defeat Texas, 60-48, today.

LEAD: The Suffolk County Legislature's proposed legal fund to protect citizens from the harassment and expense of frivolous lawsuits is well intentioned but doomed to failure [ ''Dispute on Suffolk Legal Fund,'' Jan. 18 ] . This concept, which merely attempts to equalize the legal battle by providing some public funding to citizens who are unjustly sued, is basically flawed.
LEAD: Andy Brickley scored twice in the first period, and the Devils held on to end a three-game losing streak with a 6-5 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

LEAD: The engagement of Tracy Gill to Andrew Charles Ferguson has been announced by Jill Gill and Ardian C. Gill, both of New York and Saltaire, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Noel Ferguson of Detroit and St. Clair Shores, Mich. A May 3 wedding is planned.

LEAD: Antonin Scalia is turning out to be a talkative Supreme Court Justice, on the bench and wherever else he goes. Last week at the American Bar Association convention he asserted that Federal judges were becoming ''case processors'' and later joined a friendly public argument about the Constitution and the press.

LEAD: BRAZIL'S decision to suspend payments on its $108 billion foreign debt last week marked the reappearance of an explosive element that had been kept safely locked away for two decades by the country's military rulers. Politics, all that business of wanting to be popular and having to get elected, has returned with a vengeance.

LEAD: North of the Caribbean and east of Florida is a 1,000-square-mile area in the Atlantic dubbed bajamar, or shallow sea, by Spanish explorers nearly 500 years ago. And almost lost in the midst of bajamar's opaline waters, tucked in among 600 or so outcroppings of land, which comprise the Bahamian archipelago, is an island whose dimensions are so meager that it could easily be overlooked by more adventurous travelers.

LEAD: Cathryn A. Shaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Shaw Jr. of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Kurt Nicholas Holm, a son of Edna May Holm of Omaha and E.Richard Holm of Fremont, Neb. The Rev. Charles Temple performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

LEAD: ''Students are expressing diminished confidence in their ability to shoulder the responsibilities of adulthood. More and more I hear students say: It's the administration's responsibility to take care of us. Ten years ago most students would have laughed at that notion.'' - Edgar F. Beckham, dean of the college at Wesleyan University.

LEAD: THE sixth graders in Hilary Cooper's class are learning to write research papers. The topic is invertebrates and they can focus on any animal they wish, Ms. Cooper said. For the past month, she has been patiently showing them how to take notes, compile a bibliography, and produce an outline. It is slow going, but worth it, she said.
LEAD: Even Jerome Lane lost track of how many rebounds he pulled down today as he led Pittsburgh to a 76-66 Big East victory over Connecticut.

LEAD: More than 100 artifacts from the Monitor, the Civil War ironclad warship, will be placed in the Mariners' Museum here and will give Virginia a national reputation in its maritime history, according to the the museum executive director.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Elliot M. Sanger Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sanger, to Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton P. Trachtenberg of Massapequa Park, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: UNFLINCHING, according to book reviewers, is what novelists and short-story writers ought to be. Serious fiction flinches from nothing - neither death, decay, ingratitude or the failure of friendship, hope or love.
LEAD: Workers who reveal waste, fraud and abuse can expect retaliation, financial loss and high emotional and physical stress, according to a survey by two Maryland researchers.
LEAD: Not everyone applauded when Fidelity Investments announced a program that would allow investors to sell mutual funds short.

LEAD: THE six singers in the Deller Consort gathered around a table at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday night, as if preparing for a panel meeting. Instead, they sang songs by William Byrd and Michael East, Italian madrigals by Giovanni Gastoldi, Carlo Gesualdo, Claudio Monteverdi and others, and a selection of 20th-century French chansons.
LEAD: Joseph Cardinal Parecattil, retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of Ernakulam in southern India, died Friday in Cochin, the United News of India reported today. He was 74 years old.

LEAD: To the Editor: Richard Reeves' article ''A taste of Istanbul'' (Travel, Jan. 18) was extremely interesting. To his elegant list of eating places I would like to add another, one of my favorites, Beyti in Yesilyurt, a small suburban village only 10 minutes from Istanbul airport in Yesilkoy. This is strictly a meat restaurant, offering a variety of delicious grills, mostly of lamb.

LEAD: POINTING THE WAY The final week of Black History Month will be observed at Westchester Community College with a symposium that addresses the unusual issues facing black children in suburban schools and communities. A panel of four educators will discuss the issues at 11 A.M. Wednesday in Room 102 of the Science Building.

LEAD: The marriage of Cathy Felicia Franklin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Franklin of New York, to Madison Kent Karlock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Karlock of Bourbonnais, Ill., took place last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony.

LEAD: JOHN HARLIN is not averse to exploring the woods behind his home in Greenwich on cross-country skis after a new snowfall, but Eastern ski resorts hold little appeal for him. What he enjoys is the challenge of the sport known as extreme skiing.

LEAD: WHEN Kenneth Conboy accepted his new assignment as Commissioner of Investigation a year ago, soon after the start of New York City's corruption scandals, he made the city's contracting procedures a high priority. He expected to find them, he said, ''suffused with the grossest kind of political influence and profiteering.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY is hot this year in a cold sport: iceboating. Both the new world champion and the runner-up in iceboating's dominant DN class are from Point Pleasant.

LEAD: There are at least two reasons why I read Alan Cowell's beautifully written article ''A Farewell to South Africa'' (Jan. 25) with a special personal interest. The first is that it reminded me of my own torn feelings in 1962, when the South African Government expelled me and closed down the Time bureau in Johannesburg for what was to be 14 years.

LEAD: Maximizing a site is often a euphemism for squeezing every possible square foot out of a lot. But at 15 Gold Street in the financial district, where the market for vacant office space is soft, maximizing the 4,500-square-foot plot had more to do with concept than space.

LEAD: The engagement of Joan Morgan McGivern to Andrew Lyle Rossner has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Owen McGivern of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Elaine Rossner of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Vernon C. Rossner.
LEAD: An article on Nov. 16 incorrectly reported that Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. of Las Vegas had announced plans to build a casino in Atlantic City. The company has no such plans.

LEAD: Italians eat according to the seasons of the year. Although they import many out-of-season fruits and a few vegetables from Africa, South America and Israel, a truly good Italian cook - and the country is full of them - prizes home-grown produce in a way that many Americans do not. And what is grown locally is more precious than what comes from even 100 miles away.

LEAD: The International Silver Company, formed in 1898 and once one of the world's largest silver-goods manufacturers, began to falter in the 1950's with foreign competition and the emergence of stainless steel. The company diversified, changed its name to Insilco Corporation in 1969 and finally sold off International Silver, then a subsidiary, in 1983.
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission has given the flock of 1988 Presidential aspirants a financial target to aim for as they line up their campaigns: $26.7 million.

LEAD: A fire did an estimated $300,000 damage to four residential buildings in South Boston Friday night, displaced eight people and slightly injured a firefighter and a woman. Fire Capt. Matthew Corbett said the fire started in a building undergoing renovation and spread to three others. He said the renovated building was destroyed.
LEAD: Ross Bleckner is a 37-year-old painter who lives in New York and works in two distinct styles.

LEAD: I read your Jan. 25 front-page article, ''Mondello's Dual Role: Voter Reaction Feared,'' with great interest. There is not one line of proof in your article concerning possible voter reaction.

LEAD: SAVORIES RESTAURANT in Port Jefferson is a restaurant that is bucking the trends. A few years ago, before American restaurants were the rage, Savories featured American food. About a year ago, the restaurant changed ownership, and Savories now serves the currently out-of-fashion Continental cuisine.
LEAD: THIS REALLY HAPPENED. I'm not kidding.

LEAD: EVERYONE SEEMS INTERESTED in what goes on at the Paris couture these days. Granted, the interest may not be quite as intense as it was in the 1930's, 40's, 50's, even into the 60's, before European ready-to-wear took over. In those olden, golden days, the Paris couture was the be-all and end-all of creativity.

LEAD: Only in New York State are policy-makers still intent on building a system of institutional care for people with mental retardation. In other states, most institutions have been replaced by family-scale accommodations that foster personal development and promote social integration.

LEAD: A FEW YEARS AGO, FRESH OUT OF COLLEGE and in need of money, I took a job as a secretary in a large Boston bank. I had been trying to support myself as a freelance writer and was determined to keep writing, but I'd come to realize the good sense in my late grandfather's admonition upon hearing that I'd decided to become a writer: ''Get a real job.

LEAD: Looking for a good buy in blank video tape is like looking for a bargain in soap. Pricing depends chiefly on the local store, competing products seem similar, and you can't tell much from the package. The only guidance usually comes from advertisements. This is not without value, for some ads can be quite informative.

LEAD: The Phantom of the Opera was at least there, at the opera house. Last week a report by the State Comptroller disclosed that attendance figures compiled by New York City cultural institutions had included thousands of phantoms who weren't there at all.

LEAD: Sixty-five Ku Klux Klan members and their supporters rallied on the courthouse steps in this northeast Georgia town today, protesting the killing of a white school principal in which a black teen-ager was charged.

LEAD: Merry Gines, founder and president of First New York Equity Inc., an investment advisory and financial planning concern in New York, and J.Stephen Sheils, a partner in the New York law firm Moore, Bersen, Lifflander & Mewhinney, plan to be married April 25.

LEAD: A debate has developed over whether the space weapon envisioned by the Reagan Administration for the first phase of its plan for a defense against missiles could strike offensively at targets in orbit and on earth.
LEAD: The president of Yale University, in the first of a series of lectures by experts on the United States Constitution, has assailed the views of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as too rigid.

LEAD: American and Israeli officials did their best last week to ease strains prompted by the Iran-contra affair. President Reagan met with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and praised ''the close and special relations'' with Israel, ''a major non-NATO ally.''
LEAD: John Y. Brown Jr. has entered the Democratic race for his old job, ending months of speculation about whether the former Governor would attempt a political comeback.

LEAD: THE traditional sparkle and bustle of downtown New Haven streets on a recent frosty evening recalled days gone by as hordes of people wandered through boutiques and craft shops, scurried in and out of steamy restaurants and coffee shops and waited on lines for tickets to the Shubert, the Palace or the Yale Repertory Theater.

LEAD: THE LARGE OAK refectory table is worn with the rich patina of age, as well it might be after more than 300 years of use. The fireplace is a gaping maw where whole boars and lambs rotate easily on the spit. The light filtering through the lead-paned windows and lapping at the tapestry-covered walls is gentle, like the docile, comforting landscape at Clapham House, the beautiful 18th-century East Sussex manor of Sabine and Patrick Brassart.

LEAD: BECAUSE an appraisal is pivotal to the approval or denial of a mortgage loan, an equity loan or a request for refinancing, the professional real-estate appraiser is frequently held in awe by buyers and homeowners.
LEAD: The Voice of America is planning to celebrate its 45th birthday tomorrow with an international festival of food, drink and music.

LEAD: The marriage of Suzanne Lesley Appel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Appel of Alexandria, Va., to Murray James McGill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis McGill of Calingiri and Perth, Australia, took place yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: On a bright day in winter the ruins of Casas Grandes are deserted except for a caretaker hoeing weeds around one of the unexcavated mounds. He comes to collect the admission charge of 120 pesos (about 13 cents) from the foreign visitors, expresses regret that the government in Mexico City has not yet sent brochures to replenish his stock, and goes back to work, leaving us with the ancient plazas, the ceremonial mounds and the adobe maze all to ourselves.

LEAD: SOME friends who returned from Spain recently brought me a large packet of saffron as a present. I was extremely pleased, not just because it is the world's most expensive spice, but because I love it so much in rice dishes and with seafood.
LEAD: Wilmington Club Rejects Women
LEAD: STEPHEN SPROUSE, the 33-year-old designer who rode a wave of publicity into business oblivion, is back.

LEAD: JOHN GIBBONS presented a first-class program of harpsichord music by Rameau, Bach, Domenico Scarlatti and Antoine Forqueray at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night. Mr. Gibbons, currently a professor at the New England Conservatory and a member of the Boston Museum Trio, plays with a charged dynamism that does not preclude subtlety.
LEAD: RECENT discussions of high technology on Long Island have obscured some crucial facts that will have to be addressed if the local economy is not to suffer serious decline in the future.

LEAD: The engagement of Claire Laporte to Neil Michael Kulick has been announced by James W. Craven and Adele P. Laporte of Ann Arbor, Mich., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kulick of Short Hills, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: An article in the Arts and Leisure section today, ''Lonette McKee on Becoming Lady Day,'' discusses the actress's role as Billie Holiday in ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill'' at the Westside Arts Theater. After the section went to press, Miss McKee's agent announced that she had withdrawn because of throat problems.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo's decision not to run for President may make him the most powerful broker in the 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign and a major influence on the party's direction that a candidacy could not have guaranteed, Democrats around the country said yesterday.
LEAD: Young American men from 15 to 24 years old are killing themselves at a rate 50 percent higher than at the beginning of the previous decade, according to a new Federal study.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: NORTH DAKOTA, which bans most Sunday shopping and has no state lottery, moved cautiously to expand its charity gambling in 1981 by authorizing blackjack. For the first three years the take from the card game climbed steadily. Then it dropped sharply.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rosenbach of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Judith Rosenbach to Rabbi Ronald Z. Schwartz, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Maurice Schwartz of Towson, Md. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: HERNANDO DE SOTO HAS NEVER TAKEN MUCH for granted.
LEAD: Ancient Art, Modern Sites On West Coast
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua was now willing to consider a regional peace plan proposed last month by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica.

LEAD: Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons At Pontiac, Mich., 7 P.M. Television MSG, 7 P.M. Radio WPAT 930 AM, 7 P.M. Philadelphia 76ers vs. L.A. Lakers At Philadelphia, noon Television Channel 2, noon. College Georgia Tech at DePaul Television Channel 4, 1 P.M. Georgetown at Syracuse Television Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Jurgensen of Long Beach, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter Elaine Marie Jurgensen to Christopher Mahon Beermann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Edward Beermann of Douglaston, Queens.

LEAD: Visitors to Cambridge, Mass., can sample Harvard, tasting a bit of the undergraduate extracurricular experience for the price of a dinner. At the Hasty Pudding Club, one of Harvard's original secret societies, a restaurant called Upstairs at the Pudding is open to the public.

LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India conferred at dinner this evening and expressed satisfaction at the way they had defused a crisis over troop buildups on their border last month.
LEAD: THE SEVEN AGES By Eva Figes. 186 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95.

LEAD: A NEW generation has come to life since Adolf Eichmann, the dour technocrat of the Nazi death camps, was tried and hanged 25 years ago, his ashes cast downwind from Israel upon the Mediterranean. Last Monday, the nation began only the second trial of an alleged Nazi war criminal in its history. This time the defendant was a retired auto worker extradited from Cleveland, John Demjanjuk (pronounced Dem-YAN-yuk), who seemed to startle the national audience in offering a bluff smile and a plea of innocence of ever having been a sadistic functionary in the

LEAD: EVERY night before Dorothy Noce goes to bed, she flicks on her television and goes jewelry shopping. ''I've bought three gold chains for my girls, five for myself, and one for my daughter's boyfriend,'' said Mrs. Noce, a resident of Ridley Park, Pa., one of the areas reached by the Home Shopping Network's satellite.

LEAD: NOT long ago, more than 14,000 jewelry buyers descended on midtown Manhattan to survey a dazzling array of jewels and gems at the industry's largest international jewelry show. The record turnout was just one of many signs of the sparkling health of an industry that just five years ago was floundering under the weight of a national recession.

LEAD: To the Editor: Barry Bluestone and Bennett Harrison greatly overdramatize the significance of the shift toward low-wage jobs over the period 1979 to 1985 (''The Grim Truth About the Job 'Miracle' ,'' Forum, Feb. 1). They couch their statistical results in terms of the distribution of the net change in jobs by wage level and by part-time/full-time employment, without showing the corresponding changes in the distribution of all jobs.

LEAD: To the Editor: Anyone going to Rio de Janeiro who remembers Carmen Miranda, the ''Brazilian Bombshell,'' in those wonderful 1940's movie musicals might want to visit the little-known Carmen Miranda Museum. We found it in the public park along Flamingo Beach about a 10-minute taxi ride from our hotel on Copacabana

LEAD: 'What we want to do is turn what is now primarily a payments system with a minor work component into a system that is first and foremost a jobs program, supported by an income assistance component. Our proposal focuses on education, training and employment for the families now dependent on the welfare system, along with a decent living standard with which these families can support their children while they strive for self-sufficiency.

LEAD: AMONG the first children's books to take on the threat of nuclear war was Dr. Seuss' ''Butter Battle Book'' (Random House, 1984). There had been many books set in a post-holocaust future, and a few in the past at Hiroshima, like Eleanor Coerr's gentle ''Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes'' (Putnam, 1977) and Toshi Maruki's ''Hiroshima No Pika''
LEAD: NOT long ago a Chicago alderman confided to a friend that he had given up jogging. It was boring, he said: You couldn't knock anyone down.

LEAD: The Defense Department is seeking an agreement with Zaire that would allow the United States to use an air base to support a wide range of activities in central and southern Africa, a Pentagon official said today.

LEAD: To the Editor: One part of your Jan. 25 article, ''New York's Programs at Work at 'Allerton Coops' '' - the transfer of city-owned land to builders for agreements to produce debt-free units -was of special interest to me because it discussed a matter of concern to me and my community.
LEAD: The victory of Charles J. Haughey in the Irish elections has cast doubt over the future of the British-Irish agreement on Northern Ireland.

LEAD: If dealing with sudden wealth is one of the things you are supposed to learn in business school, Melanie Richards, a 20-year-old business major in her third year at Baruch College, must have been listening in class. She bought a Lotto ticket before the Nov. 8 drawing, watched carefully as her numbers were posted on television, hid her $12 million winning ticket in a safe in her Brooklyn home, told no one outside her family, sought legal and financial advice and finally - after coming down with chicken pox and recovering from it - turned in the ticket last week.

LEAD: A Syrian soldier standing guard in West Beirut yesterday. Four thousand reinforcements camped outside the capital dismantled their tents and gave indications that they were preparing to move into the area to quell fighting among Moslems. Page 6. (Reuters)

LEAD: THE New York Racing Association has been forced to delay and possibly withdraw the promotion, announced Thursday, that would have added a bonus to certain Pick Six payoffs. Gerard J. McKeon, president of the N.Y.R.A., announced Friday that, because of an objection to the planned promotion lodged by the Offtrack Betting Corporation with the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, the board would review the matter and announce a decision some time this week.

LEAD: DRIVING within sight of the river's edge from the George Washington Bridge south to the marsh grass and reeds of Caven Point in Jersey City, it is possible, in less than an hour, to get a good measure of the rapid development under way along the New Jersey side of the Hudson River.

LEAD: President Reagan has instructed American arms officials in Geneva not to negotiate or even discuss limits on defensive systems that would be more restrictive than the Administration's new interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The Yamashita treasure, a hoard of stolen gold and jewelry said to have been hidden in the Philippines by a Japanese general during World War II, has the reputation of laying a curse on anyone possessing it. That did not stop John K. Singlaub, the retired American Army general, from requesting permission to hunt the hoard in 209 locations.

LEAD: WITH the Giants' Super Bowl victory as a backdrop and the image of a major league baseball stadium as a coming attraction, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority hopes to get voters to agree to assume its $365 million debt.

LEAD: CHAMBER music in the modern concert setting is a contradiction in terms. The irony is especially strong with popular groups such as Tashi, who manage to attract - and who deserve - the kind of large following that showed up at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.

LEAD: A change of tactics proved the cure for Theatrical's habit of finishing second when the Irish horse led at every call under Pat Day to win the $200,000 Hialeah Turf Cup by a neck over Long Mick today at Hialeah Park.

LEAD: Johnny Bumphus will do more than beat the odds if he becomes world welterweight boxing champion Sunday by beating the only man to halt Donald Curry. He also will spoil Lloyd Honeyghan's Christmas party.

LEAD: Workers at the Campbell Soup Company's northwestern Ohio plant are responsible for more than 50 incidents of sabotaged machinery, but no foreign objects have reached food, a company spokesman said Friday.
LEAD: ''I beg you, let me put the pieces of my life together again.'' - Dennis B. Levine, at his sentencing for insider trading.

LEAD: A pipeline company that has acknowledged dumping a toxic substance, PCB's, along its right of way is unlikely to face criminal charges filed by the Environmental Protection Agency, officials of the agency said today.

LEAD: Since at least some Alzheimer's cases are hereditary, scientists have been seeking a cause among the 23 pairs of chromosomes that form the human genome, the repository of the body's genetic information.

LEAD: If Edgar Allan Poe were to return to check out the season's movie marquees and television schedules, he would no doubt be gratified to discover that the mystery tale is prominently available in both the forms with which his name must be forever connected.

LEAD: THEY KNOW DAVID Kuo well in the mathematics department of the Bronx High School of Science. They have known him since the first day of his first year, when he told the chairman that he understood everything in freshman geometry. They gave him a test and discovered he was right; he answered all the questions correctly.

LEAD: From February through late April friendly, giant gray whales -they're about 45 feet long and weigh between 17 and 35 tons - pass the California coast on their 6,000-mile migration from Mexico's Baja peninsula to their summer home off Alaska. Grays are one of the environmental movement's success stories.
LEAD: When Lonette McKee first picked up the script of ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill,'' she ''got scared of it.''

LEAD: WHEN Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn told his priests earlier this month that they could no longer hold special masses for Dignity, a Catholic homosexual group, he seemed to be stepping uncharacteristically out in front of John Cardinal O'Connor of New York. After all, although Cardinal O'Connor said last Sunday that he agreed with the Bishop's decision, a church in the
LEAD: ON THE ROAD

LEAD: Many players have won more than one world team championship, but very few indeed own more than one world pair title. Only one of them, Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles, has done so with different partners. She captured the Mixed Pairs in Amsterdam in 1966, with Ivan Erdos, and the Women's Pairs with Marilyn Johnson four years later in

LEAD: THIS is the winter of my discontent, and like failing eyesight, forgetfulness, and cellulite, it is very much a byproduct of middle age. I used to love winter. The brisk weather, the beautiful snow, and the opportunity to ski were welcome, but too brief, changes in the cycle of the year. I don't love winter now.
LEAD: The men's clubs of New York came one step closer to a reckoning last week when the Court of Appeals in Albany upheld by a vote of 7 to 0 a city law that would force some of them to admit women.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Eugene Morris Cheston Jr. of Darien, Conn., and William Hamilton Gregory 3d of Glen Cove, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lovering Gregory to John Stephen Wehrle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lackey Wehrle of Ladue, Mo. The wedding is to be April 25.

LEAD: Tina Marie Gallagher and Mark Paul Messing were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James Joseph Gallagher, in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Frank Van Brunt, a Methodist minister, officiated.

LEAD: Former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., right, with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts as the National Governors' Association began its winter meeting. Leaders urged that able welfare recipients be required to find jobs. Page 30. (NYT/Ken Heinen)

LEAD: Twelve days before Charles A. Lindbergh flew nonstop to Paris from New York, two French war heroes tried to fly to New York from Paris, taking off from Le Bourget airfield amid so many elegantly clad well-wishers that troops with bayonets had to hold the crowd back.
LEAD: This Week:
LEAD: Many South Koreans are losing hope that their country can avert a political crisis in its search for a new way to select its national leader.

LEAD: STEVE ELSON and the Borneo Horns, a trio of saxophonists, make their livings in recording studios and funk bands, supplying soul-style riffs and terse, bluesy solos. But on his own, Mr. Elson also composes pieces that combine his studio skills - precise articulation and machine-tooled ensemble riffing - with forays into extended harmony, shifty rhythms and wry humor.

LEAD: ''WHEN THE BERRIES FELL,'' a new two-hour (with one intermission), nine-number score by the jazz- and gospel-based composer and keyboard player Amina Claudine Myers, was described in the program Friday night at the Triplex Theater I as a ''chamber opera'' receiving its ''premiere performance.'' The event was a co-presentation of the Composers' Forum and Manhattan Community College, which houses the Triplex Theater complex at 199 Chambers Street.

LEAD: For New Yorkers, spring training is the hope that Lou Piniella can survive a year of George Steinbrenner, and that Billy Martin stays in the booth. For the Mets, it is the hope that if a player is handcuffed it will mean he took a pitch, and that if he is caught stealing, his penalty will be an out.
LEAD: Her son was attentive, she told the jury, sending her Valentine's Day cards, roses, notes and gifts. Had he been alive this Valentine's Day, he would have certainly called her, she testified.
LEAD: WHETHER your fancy runs to gabled Gothics, glassy new skyscrapers, or even the little cottage you designed yourself, the Connecticut Society of Architects wants to hear from you.
LEAD: Excerpts from an address by Allan E. Gotlieb, the Canadian Ambassador, to a business symposium in Los Angeles Feb. 4:

LEAD: THE growing insider trading scandal passed a milestone last week when Dennis B. Levine was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $362,000. Mr. Levine, the first to be caught in the sweeping inquiry into Wall Street abuses, was charged with illegally earning $12.6 million in five years by trading on inside information.
LEAD: THE HOUSEBOAT DEBATE

LEAD: ''WHEN THE BERRIES FELL,'' a new two-hour (with one intermission), nine-number score by the jazz- and gospel-based composer and keyboard player Amina Claudine Myers, was described in the program Friday night at the Triplex Theater I as a ''chamber opera'' receiving its ''premiere performance.'' The event was a co-presentation of the Composers' Forum and Manhattan Community College, which houses the Triplex Theater complex at 199 Chambers Street.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gavin Reid Jr. of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cathy Elizabeth Reid to James Edward Stranberg Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stranberg of Boston. The wedding is to be in May. The future bride, a graduate of the American School in London and Ithaca College, is a candidate for a nursing degree at Boston University.

LEAD: THROUGHOUT Bowie Kuhn's years as baseball commissioner, Lee MacPhail was one of his staunchest supporters. They even had a common critic, George Steinbrenner. Ironically, though, it was MacPhail who played a role detrimental to Kuhn in two significant episodes in his 16-season tenure: the resignation he submitted over an expansion dispute in 1976 and his ouster as commissioner in 1983.

LEAD: As finance ministers from seven major industrial nations hold talks here this weekend on improving their economic performance and stabilizing currency values, economic growth in Europe and Japan is showing new weakness, largely as a result of the dollar's recent fall, economic figures show.
LEAD: THE HOUSEBOAT DEBATE

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Scaling Back Hikes in Social Security'' (Forum, Jan. 25) begins to lay the groundwork for the next Social Security issues that will face policy makers: long-term financial stability and tax equity for Social Security.

LEAD: After a steady rise in the 1980's, the number of brutality complaints filed against New York City police officers decreased slightly last year, according to the department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.
LEAD: You know how it is, good help is hard to come by. So if you have a real job to do, you have to do it yourself, right?
LEAD: How would I feel about being a billionaire? It can't happen soon enough! VICKI GREENWALD Riverdale, N.Y.

LEAD: Inside Spain's governing Socialist Party, Jose Maria Maravall is known as the Oxford-educated theoretician who, as Minister of Education for the last four years, has held the party's feet to the fire on social ideals.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with regret the articles on Turkey (Travel, Jan. 18). I am disappointed because all those places were stolen from the Greeks. You mention that Turkey is one of the few countries in the world that feed their own people without outside help. This is correct, but I wish you had also mentioned that the land on which Turkey produces its surplus is the same land the Greeks created and fertilized before the Turks invaded it.
LEAD: LANGUAGE is never slow to catch up with practice. The real-estate world now has the phrase ''the sold buildings'' with which to discuss property-assessment practices in New York City.

LEAD: Golf Homecoming a Happy One: Cindy Rarick, who attended the University of Hawaii for two years, won her first L.P.G.A. tournament yesterday by shooting a five-under-par 67 to take the 54-hole Tsumura Hawaiian Ladies Open. Rarick, who earned $45,000, ended the tournament at nine-under 207, two strokes ahead of Jane Geddes.

LEAD: THE sidewalks where Sutter Avenue and Berriman Street cross in the East New York section of Brooklyn are fringed with wastepaper and carpeted with shattered glass. Unwanted tires and junked appliances are piled high in undeveloped lots, and the gouged windows of abandoned walk-ups gaze emptily from above.

LEAD: WOMEN WRITING ABOUT MEN. By Jane Miller. (Pantheon, Paper, $8.95.) Women have long written about men as fathers, brothers, lovers, sons, heroes and, as Adrienne Rich said, ''the phantom of the man-who-would-understand'' - the double. But because female writers have needed, according to Jane Miller, ''to be extremely circumspect'' in these portrayals, many critics have assumed that women write only of themselves.
LEAD: The leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels kept up the fight last week -with each other.

LEAD: It is not unusual for developers to import special building materials from abroad to lend cachet to a project. But Lynn and Jad Barghout of Mount Kisco, N.Y., principals of Ramleh Enterprises, decided to import everything.

LEAD: Sally Jayne Quist, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Quist of Punta Gorda, Fla., was married yesterday to James Franklin Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Miller of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. Kurt Von Roeschlaub officiated at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Port Washington. The bride, a stylist for photographers, attended Ohio Wesleyan University.

LEAD: A 69-year-old American held by East Germany for protesting atop the Berlin Wall has been expelled and sent to the West, a United States spokesman said Friday. The American, John Runnings of Seattle, had been held in East Germany for three months.

LEAD: LAST spring Kenneth Jankowski, a telecommunications specialist with a Chicago bank, received an appealing job offer from TRW in Cleveland. But his wife, Robin, a financial analyst, was unhappy about moving, fearing she might not find an equally attractive job in a strange city.

LEAD: On one side, dignified but furious, stands the League of Women Voters, ''governess of the nation,'' as the columnist Mary McGrory once called it. For the last three Presidential elections, it has sponsored televised debates. On the other side, in rare unity, stand the Republican and Democratic parties.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. John Martin Gibbons Jr. of Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter Fredericka Maureen Gibbons to George Hunt Witter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Orin Witter of West Hartford, Conn. A fall wedding is planned.

LEAD: He hasn't fought in 10 years and at 38 he may seem a bit old to be staging a comeback, but not according to the California Athletic Commission. It approved a license for George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, who plans a March 3 bout in Sacramento against an opponent to be selected. . . .

LEAD: Patricia M. Wiley, director of new product development at the National Distillers Products Company in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Suhr, president of Southeastern Dairies in Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Neil Sessions performed the ceremony at the Hustborne Baptist Church in Louisville.

LEAD: To go beyond their Iceland summit meeting, Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev have to retreat to where they were before that fateful meeting. Reykjavik now blocks the way to useful arms limitations with grand illusions about space-based defenses and a world without nuclear weapons. Reagan officials and critics share that view: a summit that turned into a nadir.

LEAD: More than four years after Mexico raised the curtain on the Latin American debt drama, Brazil's decision Friday to suspend most payments on its huge foreign debt has focused attention anew on the region's failure to recover any degree of financial stability.

LEAD: An ongoing medical and educational program administered by the County Health Department with funds from the state is credited with making strides in the detection and treatment of high blood pressure.

LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino talking to residents of Namulandayan, 90 miles from Manila. Witnesses say Government soldiers killed 12 civilians there on Feb. 10. Mrs. Aquino, who a villager said was ''crying inside,'' asked victims' relatives their version of the shooting. ''Help me,'' she asked. ''Tell me what you know.

LEAD: THE theme of this essay is of more than academic interest to me. One of the first poems of my youth, a tortuous elegy written in my 23d year, opened with the apostrophe, ''O ruined father dead,'' and concluded with the lines, ''Let sons learn from their lipless fathers how / Man enters hell without a golden bough.
LEAD: ON Court Street in Brooklyn a block south of Borough Hall, Louis V. Greco Jr. is breaking through walls to create a modern office complex out of five decrepit buildings.
LEAD: New Hampshire farmers plow fields next to the studios of weavers, ceramists and basket makers.

LEAD: Nine-year-old kid is being questioned by a judge during a custody hearing. Judge says, ''Kid, do you want to live with your father?'' Kid says, ''No, my dad beats me.'' Judge says, ''Well, then, do you want to live with your mother?'' Kid says, ''No, my mother beats me, too.'' Judge says, ''Well, who do you want to live with?

LEAD: FOR the past 15 years, Charles L. Wrye has kept on his desk a sign that says, politely, ''Thank You for Not Smoking.'' An avid antismoker, he long ago decided that even though he has no right to force others to stop smoking, he does have the right to make his own work space smoke-free.
LEAD: HERE we go again. Another (hotel) opening, another (gustatory) show. This time, it is the new Hyatt Regency Hotel in Greenwich, latest of the large chain hotels to open in Fairfield County.

LEAD: President Reagan's former national security adviser told a commission investigating the Iran-contra affair again today that Mr. Reagan had approved the first shipment of American arms to Iran in August 1985, sources familiar with the commission's work said.

LEAD: The Rangers had been looking ahead in grand terms. Some players had even talked about challenging the Flyers for the top of the Patrick Division. That's what six victories in seven games and a second place standing can do to a team's self-image. But a small backslide has humbled the Rangers.

LEAD: Amy Evans Porterfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Porterfield of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, was married in New Canaan yesterday to John Kelly Burke, a son of Betty Burke of Rolling Meadows, Ill., and Francis W. Burke of Carpentersville, Ill. The Rev. Charles Smith performed the Congregational ceremony at the Waveny

LEAD: Right at the beginning of A PROJECT NAMED DESIRE by John William Corrington and Joyce H. Corrington (Viking, $14.95), the tough New Orleans homicide police captain makes his position clear: ''Peetie had been careful. He knew all he had to do was cough hard and I'd be staring down his throat - with a .357 Magnum for a tongue depressor.

LEAD: THE salary arbitration season ended yesterday with Dick Schofield, the California Angels' shortstop, winning a $475,000 salary. Don Sears, the arbitrator who heard the case Friday, awarded Schofield the salary he wanted over the Angels' $305,000. Schofield earned $210,000 last year. The final totals for arbitration this year had clubs winning 16 cases and players 10.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List FICTION 1 4 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 2 5 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) In the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned them.

LEAD: FOR more than half an hour, Tom Seaver sounded like a businessman trying to cut a deal with himself, talking about how he ''really hadn't made a decision yet'' on whether he had retired from baseball.

LEAD: IN 1965, when John R. Miller 3d of Asharoken was working as a sales and marketing executive for Procter & Gamble in the Midwest, he hired and trained the company's first black salesman. ''I remember being thrown out of stores,'' Mr. Miller said. ''People were calling him names.''

LEAD: There is no doubt that writing for an orchestra is a risky proposition for a composer. Because of the tremendous cost of orchestra rehearsal time, and a certain timidity on the part of trustees and subscribers, there is a good chance that a young or unknown composer will never hear a new symphonic work performed.
LEAD: Concern about osteoporosis, a crippling bone disorder that afflicts mainly elderly women, has spawned a cynical campaign by the dairy industry aimed at teen-age girls.
LEAD: Those who call for full-time professional football officials fail to understand the difference between observing a practice and officiating a game.

LEAD: It is true, as Warren Sloat pointed out in his article ''Snakeskin'' (About Men, Jan. 25), that young rattlesnakes are more dangerous, but not because they are quicker. Older snakes develop sphincter control and save some venom for the next bite; young ones give you the whole shot right off - more venom.

LEAD: I never actually heard Brahms play the piano. LEAD: There was no reason for Robert Bevan (1865-1925) to be anything more than an amiable but predestined second rater. LEAD: The Air Force has three kinds of strategic bombers - one in the hand, one in the bush and one in the wild blue yonder. There are B-52's, the newest frames of which were built in 1962. And there is the Stealth or Advanced Technology Bomber, due in the 1990's, whose only certain feature is its daunting cost.

Lou, the husband, wants to go on to Boston, but Sam, the wife, is at the controls, and she is determined to find a hole in the fog and bring the ship down.

LEAD: The New York Public Library has acquired the papers of William Schuman, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer and former president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. LEAD: Dr. Brent M. Pratley, the former part-time Brigham Young University football surgeon who faced the possibility of losing his medical license when accused of having prescribed excessive addictive medication to players, reached a settlement with Utah licensing authorities last week. Under the agreement, Pratley admitted failure to maintain records indicating reasons for the prescriptions, and his penalty is that for the next year he will be allowed to prescribe narcotics only in hospitals and will also perform some community service.

LEAD: Whenever the Government updates one of its price gauges, such as the Consumer Price Index, the typical assumption of economists is that the revised figures will show less inflation than under the old method of calculation. LEAD: The Nets lost again tonight, and Chuck Daly, the coach of the Detroit Pistons coach, explained why.
LEAD: Surgeons were transplanting a liver tonight into 7-year-old Ronnie DeSillers of Florida, who received an outpouring of support from Americans after money for his transplant was stolen.
LEAD: The Uffizi Gallery has unveiled two newly restored 15th-century masterpieces by Botticelli - his ''Annunciation'' and ''The Birth of Venus.''
LEAD: Residents of the city's crime-ridden South Central area are being given a chance to vote on whether to raise property taxes in the district to pay for more police protection.
LEAD: With the 1988 New Hampshire primary just a year away, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has enlisted a prominent resident of the state in his undeclared Presidential campaign.
LEAD: A Houston-based gas pipeline company today released the names of 51 sites in 12 states where it has acknowledged burying toxic PCB's. The largest number, 17, are in southern Pennsylvania.

LEAD: THE most tender cuts of beef come from the long, roughly cylindrical tenderloin, and right in the center of that strip is what is known as the chateaubriand -the most prized cut of all. This piece of beef, which usually weighs about two pounds and can feed three to four diners, is traditionally cooked on a hot pan with just a little oil.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Across the harbor's choppy, cobalt waters, the old United States Immigration Station at Ellis Island is beginning to gleam again, beginning to glisten.

LEAD: Most television biographies of famous people have turned out to be unabashed glorifications of their subjects. ''The Betty Ford Story,'' which is to be shown Monday on ABC with Gena Rowlands starring as Mrs. Ford, is something of an exception. While it is clearly sympathetic to the former First Lady, the main focus of the two-hour television drama is her alcoholism and drug dependency during the years after Gerald Ford lost the Presidential election of 1976.

LEAD: Taylor Mattingly was getting anxious to leave. He tugged gently at his father's ear, shifted from one lap to the other, then finally won his freedom and was placed on the clubhouse floor amid a crowd of reporters. But he did not stray far.

LEAD: New York City's Department for the Aging exercised ''poor oversight'' of $32 million in contracts for services provided for the elderly in 1983-84, according to a State Comptroller's audit released yesterday.
LEAD: Weekend of Wine

LEAD: ONLY 15 years ago, Louis M. Martini, a Napa Valley winery, marketed California's first post-Prohibition bottle of wine labeled ''merlot.'' Today, 174 American wineries make merlot. At least 110 are in California. Success of this nature and on this scale shows how a kind of second-class wine can move into the first class under the guidance of an artful wine maker.

LEAD: In their quest for a new antibiotic, researchers at the Squibb Institute for Medical Research sifted through soil samples taken from around the world. They tested millions of bacteria, looking for just the right one to combat serious hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and septicemia, caused by gram-negative organisms.

LEAD: IN the United States, it seems, people are infatuated with nuts - all kinds of them: almonds, peanuts, cashews, walnuts, hazelnuts, macadamia nuts, pine nuts and more. According to Richard Sullivan, a spokesman for the Association of Food Industries, a trade organization, Americans consume more than 500 million pounds of nuts each year.

LEAD: A city that started the week with one afternoon newspaper had three today. As a result, it found itself witnessing an old-fashioned circulation war complete with fireworks along the Thames, dancing publishers and exchanges of insults that were wickedly inventive even by British standards.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 The President was briefed regularly on the Administration's Iran arms dealings as they took place, the special Presidential commission examining the Iran-contra affair has concluded, sources say. Page A1 Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North filed suit against the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, challenging the constitutionality of the law under which the prosecutor was appointed.

LEAD: ''THE GAY DIVORCE,'' in 1932, was Fred Astaire's last Broadway show. Retitled ''The Gay Divorcee,'' it was the first film to co-star Astaire and Ginger Rogers as romantic partners. Our memories of the Cole Porter musical derive primarily from the movie, despite the fact that Hollywood excised all but one of the Porter songs.

LEAD: In his first full day as the manager of the Kansas City Royals, during a time of the baseball year that usually seems carefree, Billy Gardner said he would be happy to see his predecessor, Dick Howser, return to the job he left on Monday.

LEAD: WHAT spicy chicken wings are to Buffalo, toasted ravioli is to St. Louis. While Buffalo wings quickly became a national fad, the St. Louis culinary creation has - so far - remained a local passion.

LEAD: Chief Judge Sol Wachtler being applauded yesterday before he delivered his ''State of the Judiciary'' message before the Legislature in Albany. At left is Chief Administrative Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa and at rear are Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, left, and Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader.
LEAD: In life, S. M. Otieno was a classically successful modern African.
LEAD: American and Soviet officials confirmed yesterday that the Soviet Union had bought 39.3 million bushels of corn, its first purchase of American grain since last summer.

LEAD: ABOUT half-a-dozen men stand around anxiously eyeing their watches as three enormous sets of stamping dies slide out of the press line and another group of dies advances on a conveyor to take their place. As a problem with automated transfer arms causes the minutes to tick on, brows knit in frustration.

LEAD: Top public health officials and civil liberties advocates voiced unanimity today on the need for strong legislation to protect those who take the AIDS test from discrimination and from unauthorized release of their names.

LEAD: THE Mesabi iron range of northeast Minnesota has its fair share of fast-food restaurants and streamlined supermarkets, but it also has a mother lode of ethnic-food traditions from at least 40 countries. At Mary's Cafe in Hibbing, a luncheonette with oilcloth on the tables and an old-fashioned counter, the Irish cook makes chicken soup with German dumplings, Yugoslav sarma (stuffed cabbage) and Cornish pasties.

LEAD: A man wanted in the bombings of several New York City abortion clinics surrendered quietly to Federal agents in lower Manhattan yesterday, less than 24 hours after John Cardinal O'Connor delivered a televised plea for him to turn himself in.
LEAD: The tournament bridge players of New York City mourned doubly this week, for one of their most senior and one of their most junior.

LEAD: A San Juan lawyer told investigators that he funneled more than $4,000 a month in bribes to the wife of Representative Robert Garcia on behalf of a South Bronx military contractor whose former executives have pleaded guilty to corruption. Page B1. (NYT)

LEAD: The growth in the number of homeless families in New York City could be limited if state and Federal policies were changed to encourage single adults and families to share apartments, a mayoral commission said yesterday.
LEAD: A mental-health expert retained by Baby M's legal guardian changed his mind and recommended today ending the legal parental rights of Mary Beth Whitehead, a key issue in the custody hearing.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North filed suit today against the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, challenging the constitutionality of the Federal law permitting appointment of a special prosecutor.
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz accused a member of Congress today of undermining the Reagan Administration's policy in Central America by trying to run his ''own foreign policy.''

LEAD: The announcements last week of next year's seasons at the Metropolitan and New York City Operas reflect not only the delicate attempts of each company to balance finite resources against artistic responsibility, but also a renewed cooperation that in another field might raise the eyebrows of a finicky antitrust lawyer.

LEAD: WITHOUT an atmosphere of communication and trust and without the delegation of enough authority to get the job done, an advertiser company intent on setting up its own network TV buying operation might as well forget the whole thing.

LEAD: AIDED by computer simulations that give a better understanding of what happens when a ski pounds against the snow, engineers are making significant improvements in the design of ski equipment. The advances can be found in virtually every piece of gear from boots and bindings to poles and gloves.

Each meeting between the intrastate rivals, it seems, has been for a share of first or second place in the Big East Conference. Syracuse has won four of the last seven meetings, and the average score of those seven games has been 76-73, with three decisions determined in overtime.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that a crucial ''Star Wars'' test, scheduled in 1988, could lead to deployment of a space-based defense against ballistic missiles as early as 1994.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that Government officials and bankers were ''suffering from battle fatigue'' in dealing with persistent third world debt problems and that the negotiation process needed to be reinvigorated.

LEAD: When Don Mattingly had the nerve to win his arbitration case against the Yankees, George Steinbrenner, The True Sportsman, fumed and snorted.

LEAD: WHEN Jonathan Waxman, the celebrated young California chef, came to New York in 1983 to open what is now Jams restaurant, the first person he went to see for advice on staffing was a rubicund and genial former butcher named Marc Sarrazin. When Daniel Boulud and Patrice Boely, who are today the chefs at Le Cirque and the Polo, respectively, arrived in Manhattan four years ago, their first business lunch was with Marc Sarrazin.

LEAD: Although Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, announced last Friday that he had resigned the Ansell Americas account for Lifestyles condoms, he said yesterday that he actually delivered the letter of resignation last Wednesday. And he offered a copy of his letter dated ''18 February'' to prove it.

LEAD: Astronomers reported yesterday that the gigantic explosion of a massive star has occurred much closer to the Earth than any observed since 1604. Because such nearby supernovas are so rare, this event is likely to have a dramatic effect on scientific understanding of how stars, galaxies and the entire universe have evolved through the ages.

LEAD: A consensus appeared to be emerging today against widespread mandatory testing for infection with the AIDS virus as public health officials began an extraordinary two-day meeting to discuss ways to curb the spread of the deadly viral disease.
LEAD: A senior West German official says the United States is now putting little pressure on Bonn to extradite a suspect in the hijacking of an American airliner to Beirut in 1985.
LEAD: Beginning tomorrow, baby-boomers can use their favorite audio gadget - the compact-disk player -for their favorite music, the Beatles.

LEAD: The Canadian novelist Robertson Davies has been chosen the recipient of the 1987 Medal of Honor for Literature. The National Arts Club presented the medal to Mr. Davies yesterday at a dinner at its headquarters, 15 Gramercy Park South.

LEAD: Defense Department officials said today that General Bernard W. Rogers would retire in June as Supreme Allied Commander of NATO forces in Europe and would be replaced by General John R. Galvin, now commander of United States forces in Latin America.

LEAD: ''MR. ED'' is back on television, indicating that, as most middle-of-the-road antiques shops suggest, Americans cannot discriminate between things worth saving and things that simply exist. These are charming works, full of good tunes and expert part writing. Mr.
LEAD: In the competitive market yesterday, Tennessee offered a $113 million tax-exempt issue of general obligation bonds through Salomon Brothers.
LEAD: The Dr. Jack Ramsay coaching cure-all that produced 785 victories in Philadelphia, Buffalo and Portland, appears to be putting the Indiana Pacers back on the road to respectability.

LEAD: The Treasury Department has proposed new rules requiring all entities that deal solely in Government securities to register with the Government and meet minimum capital standards. The proposed rules would restrict dealers in their handling of customers' securities and set new record-keeping and reporting requirements.

LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that police officers who searched the wrong man's apartment in a multiunit dwelling had not violated the Constitution because their mistake was reasonable.
LEAD: For three quarters last night in Madison Square Garden, the Portland Trail Blazers paraded freely down the Knicks' lane.

LEAD: Greg Louganis, holder of 41 United States diving titles and a double gold medalist at the 1984 Olympic Games, was named yesterday as the winner of the Jesse Owens International Trophy, then said he had begun an educational crusade against alcoholism, an addiction that he began to fight in himself 3 1/2 years ago.

LEAD: A retired Long Island taxidermist and his son who had been found in possession of 293 stuffed birds, including a bald eagle and a peregrine falcon, were sentenced yesterday to prison for violating a Federal statute intended to protect migratory birds.

LEAD: In voting by the Boxing Writers Association of America, Mike Tyson, the undefeated World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, has been named winner of the Edward J. Neil Memorial award as the 1986 fighter of the year. . . . Vinny Pazienza, undefeated in 18 pro bouts, will meet the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, Greg Haugen, at the Providence Civic Center in May, according to Lou Duva, Pazienza's manager.

LEAD: Some China watchers based in Hong Kong have concluded that Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, has been severely weakened in the recent political turmoil in Beijing and may no longer exercise real power.

LEAD: ONE recent evening a neighbor arrived in my kitchen after I had finished the advance preparation for cooking a chateaubriand, which was on my work counter uncooked. A puzzled look crossed my friend's face and he asked, ''What cut of beef is that?'' It occurred to me at that moment that probably not one person in a hundred would be able to identify a chateaubriand, perhaps the most coveted piece of beef of all.
LEAD: A computer system monitoring flights in the Houston area failed today, causing scores of delays for almost three hours in southern Texas and New Orleans, the authorities said.

LEAD: AS it turned out, after all the delays, the meeting of the Group of Five to Seven in Paris -it turned out to be a Group of Six because Italy walked out - was well timed. For, without the Paris agreement, the decision of Brazil last Friday to suspend interest payments on medium- and long-term foreign debt could have caused the dollar to go into a free fall.

LEAD: In a break with publishing tradition, Farrar, Straus & Giroux will pay authors a royalty on copies of their books that are remaindered - that is, sold at a fraction of their original price after their regular sales life is exhausted.

LEAD: Ike Vern, a freelance magazine photographer and documentary film maker, died Monday after heart surgery at the Texas Heart Institute of St. Luke's Hospital in Houston. He was 70 years old and lived in Orlando, Fla. He was a former resident of Manhattan.

LEAD: Saying it cannot keep pace with the growing cost of maintaining Division I athletic programs, Utica College in upstate New York will drop all of its National Collegiate Athletic Association programs to Division III in 1988, President Lansing Baker said yesterday. Utica will be unclassified during the 1987-1988 academic year.

LEAD: In a move that virtually assures a full-fledged Presidential drive by Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican plans to announce next week the formation of an ''exploratory committee'' for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988.

LEAD: If you're looking for work this spring, forget the Mets. They are so set that only one position has even the semblance of any competition, and that is third base, the traditional revolving door through which 80 men have come and gone.

LEAD: A South Queens coalition of blacks and whites, formed after the Howard Beach attack in December, asked Mayor Koch last night for his personal support and for city financing for its proposed programs to ease racial tensions.

LEAD: Always eager to bestow some international glitter on his race, Fred Lebow, director of the New York City Marathon, traveled abroad a few weeks back and, at the very least, came up with his fair share of brass. While taking in the Manila Marathon, Lebow was approached by Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, the Chief of Staff of the Philippine armed forces.
LEAD: THE OLD DEVILS. By Kingsley Amis. 294 pages. Summit Books. $16.95.

LEAD: Detectives investigating a series of confrontations between white and black youths in Bayside, Queens, early Sunday were told by two new witnesses that one of the blacks had fired a gun during one of the incidents, a police spokesman said yesterday.

LEAD: MARTTI TALVELA first appeared in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's ''Boris Godunov'' 13 years ago and immediately established himself as the Boris of his generation. The tall and hulking Finnish basso returned to the role of the demented Czar Monday night in the opera's first performance of the season, giving no sign of wanting to abdicate his title.

LEAD: In its second deal in two days, Litton Industries said it had agreed to acquire the Lamb Technicon Corporation for more than $100 million in stock. Lamb, which is based in Warren, Mich is a leading supplier of manufacturing systems for the domestic and international automotive industry.
LEAD: For years, many individuals have looked to the tax code for help in subsidizing some of their more costly personal possessions, such as luxury cars and home computers.

LEAD: The 25 assists posted Monday night by Nate McMillan in the SuperSonics' victory over the Clippers tied an N.B.A. rookie record set 13 years back by Ernie DiGregorio. LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, fresh from an international meeting in Paris on currency exchange, appeared on Capitol Hill Tuesday sporting a vivid emerald green necktie. He told reporters he had adopted the fashion note because ''it's the color of the dollar.'' Economic analysts interpreted this as evidence that the Secretary, accused in the past of ''talking down the dollar,'' had committed himself to strengthening its position on world markets.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo of New York led a parade of governors, senators and representatives today in a blunt attack on a proposal that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission ease emergency evacuation standards at commercial power reactors.

LEAD: New York City Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones plans to cancel a $300,000 dropout-prevention program contract with Touro College in the Bronx because few students received help, central school board officials said yesterday.
LEAD: Scarred by scandal and barely functioning a year ago, the Parking Violations Bureau lay at the heart of New York City's biggest corruption inquiry in a generation.

LEAD: Sales of new domestically assembled cars fell 25.8 percent in the middle 10 days of February despite rebates, subsidized financing and other incentives, the nation's eight major manufacturers reported today.

LEAD: TO THE LIVING SECTION In her column on adoption and surrogacy, Anna Quindlen seems to understand the pain of childlessness.
LEAD: The old-fashioned definition of military discipline holds that when the commander says to jump, the soldier jumps -and asks how high on the way up.

LEAD: Chu Kao-cheng, right, a member of the opposition Democratic Progress Party, being restrained after he and Chou Su-fu of the ruling Kuomintang, left, engaged in a fist fight on the floor of the legislature. On Monday, about 30 members of the legislative assembly took part in a brawl during a swearing-in ceremony.
LEAD: William T. Fairbourn, who retired from the Marines with the rank of major general and then spoke out against the nuclear arms race, died Saturday. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: While the Baby M trial in New Jersey has focused attention on the practice of surrogate motherhood, across the country cases are emerging in which surrogate arrangements have been improvised between friends and relatives, or by homosexual couples and single people, with no supervision by doctors or lawyers.

LEAD: Key finance ministers met in the opulent chambers of the Louvre last weekend and agreed to the minimum. They pledged to juice up the West German and Japanese economies and cut the American budget deficit. On the diving dollar, which prompted the meeting, they concluded that it has dropped enough for now, and that it's time for a breather.

LEAD: Paul Simon's controversial ''Graceland'' was named album of the year at the Grammy Awards ceremony here tonight. ''That's What Friends Are For,'' the upbeat ballad that raised $750,000 for AIDS research, won three Grammys, and Steve Winwood won record of the year.
