Yves Saint Laurent, the fashion house, said earlier this week that it might sell some of the businesses of Charles of the Ritz, including that company's cosmetics line.

LEAD: Lieut. Gov. Jo Ann Zimmerman last year on her family's farm. She and her husband, Tom, are slated to have their home in Waukee sold at auction next week to satify a mortgage. They also face foreclosure on 292 acres about 25 miles away on which they raise cattle. She won election last year by appealing to distressed farmers.

LEAD: A New York City landlord testified yesterday that he agreed to pay Jay L. Turoff, the former head of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, a percentage of his shares in an electronic taxi meter company in exchange for Mr. Turoff mandating the use of such meters by all taxis in the city.

LEAD: The House of Representatives unanimously approved a resolution today that would force the Enivronmental Protection Agency to stick to a rigid timetable for distributing funds to schools to clean up asbestos.

LEAD: Eleanor B. Stevenson, who, with her husband, Willaim E. Stevenson, received the Bronze Star for their work with the American Red Cross in World War II in Europe, died Sunday at her home in Shell Point Village in Fort Myers, Fla. She was 84 years old Mrs. Stevenson went with her husband when he volunteered to established wartime Red cross units in European theaters of war.

LEAD: Howard Johnson taking batting practice yesterday at the Mets training camp in St. Petersburg, Fla. He is Manager Davey Johnson's choice to play third base, but the rookie Dave Magadan has other ideas. Page A21. (AP)

LEAD: Edwin McArthur, a conductor, accompanist, singing coach, composer and biographer of Kirsten Flagstad, died yesterday at his studio in Manhattan, immediately after giving a lesson. He was 79 years old and lived in Hackensack, N.J.

LEAD: JAN WALLMAN'S Restaurant-Cabaret, which left Cornelia Street more than a year ago, reopened last week at 49 West 44th Street, with a pair of performers who frequently appeared in the downtown room - Judy Kreston and David Lahm. Although the new club is normally to offer a different performer every night of the week, Miss Kreston and Mr.

LEAD: The Tower Commission has concluded that President Reagan, far from being remote from the Administration's Iran arms dealings, was briefed on them regularly as they took place, according to officials familiar with the commission's report.
LEAD: Bernie Federko set up two goals to lift the St. Louis Blues to their third consecutive victory, a 3-2 decision tonight over the Islanders.
LEAD: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

LEAD: The Flamingo Stakes here Saturday begins the countdown to the Kentucky Derby nine weeks later, which means that the syrupy sentiment surrounding that race will begin to flow: Owners will remember the night the old mare delivered the little foal who has grown into a Derby dream, and trainers will recall that magical morning workout when their colt first flashed the glimmer of brilliance that could win him the coveted roses at Churchill

LEAD: A battle over political interference in French journalism intensified Monday when a business group dominated by a rightist press baron was awarded a television franchise that France's conservative Government took back from its original owners, accusing them of being Socialist sympathizers.

LEAD: Roy Face, the former Pittsburgh reliever, when asked to explain the difference between the forkball he threw two decades ago and the split-finger fastball Mike Scott throws today: ''The money.''

LEAD: Do not delude yourself, Reagan fans, that even a President deeply wounded by the scandal of the arms sales to Iran is ''finished'' or ''paralyzed,'' much less ''powerless.'' Mr. Reagan is still President, even if napping on the Oval Office couch.

LEAD: Departing from its more usual role of critic, the Parks Council, a civic watchdog organization, has been developing ideas of its own for New York City's waterfront, and yesterday it unveiled an unusual one: floating a recreation center, complete with 10-lane swimming pool and open-air cafe, on a barge somewhere along the water's edge.

LEAD: The Tigers' first baseman and designated hitter, Darrell Evans, who became a free agent when he was not tendered an offer by the Tigers by Dec. 20, signed a one-year contract with Detroit yesterday. Evans, 39, earned $760,000 last season in the final year of a three-year contract. He batted .241 with a team-high 29 home runs and 85 runs batted in 151 games.
LEAD: ''I'd like to ask one question of everybody. Everybody who can remember what they were doing on Aug. 8, 1985, raise your hand.'' - President Reagan [ A1:6. ]

LEAD: Anthony J. Gumbiner, the 42-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Hallwood Group Inc., has spent 13 years working to reverse the sliding fortunes of distressed companies. His company is now focusing on financial institutions.

LEAD: Seventeen junior high school students were injured today when a science experiment went awry, the authorities in this southern Illinois community said. A police dispatcher said a reaction between water and sodium was believed to have caused an explosion. Five students were admitted to nearby hospitals, most with face burns and eye problems and 12 were treated and released, according to hospital spokesmen.

LEAD: Denis Potvin, who injured his left knee in a collision with a Montreal player Saturday at Nassau Coliseum, has sprained ligaments in the knee and will be unable to skate for at least three weeks. He will probably be lost to the club for the remainder of the regular season.
LEAD: The 1988 Presidential bandwagons are rolling along into the future without taking time to fill in the potholes or examine the ''wrong way'' signs of the past.

LEAD: The Government moved against its opponents on two fronts today, announcing the arrests of 13 purported campus revolutionaries and later seeking to block an indoor rally by the mainstream opposition.

LEAD: Jesse Orosco's magical flying glove, the one that seemingly defied gravity and never came down after the Met reliever flung it into the air in triumph at the conclusion of both the league playoffs and the World Series last year, is enchanted after all.
LEAD: Mayor Harold Washington, this city's first black Mayor, became the first mayoral incumbent Tuesday to win renomination in Chicago in the last decade.

LEAD: Retail prices in the 12 countries of the European Community rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, twice the rate of the previous three months, community officials said today. The inflation rate for the year ended Jan. 31 was 2.7 percent, the community said. It said that the highest inflation rates for January were recorded in Portugal, at 1.2 percent, and Greece, at 1.1 percent.

LEAD: THE Atlanta Ballet has been a welcome resident company of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College for three years. But the program the company presented on Saturday night was a disturbing one. The dearth of interesting new ballet choreographers is by now a commonplace, so the program's bland tone wasn't so terribly unusual.

LEAD: A NASA technician examining the underside of the Space Shuttle Discovery yesterday in Cape Canaveral, Fla. The Discovery is being prepared for a scheduled launching next February in what will be the first shuttle flight since the Challenger exploded in January 1986, killing all seven crew members.
LEAD: With drug stocks providing a pocket of strength in an otherwise sloppy market, Wall Street was able to move ahead slightly yesterday although trading volume was much lighter.
LEAD: A listing of Westminster Kennel Club dog show results in Sports Pages on Feb. 11 misidentified the winner for the Rhodesian Ridegeback breed. The winning dog was Ch. Mshindaji's Special K.

LEAD: MILLIONS of American women who are trying to prevent osteoporosis by increasing their calcium intake may be ignoring the most important cause of the disease: the decline of estrogens after menopause.

LEAD: The space agency and the builder of the booster rocket whose failure destroyed the space shuttle Challenger have reached an agreement under which the builder will reduce its fees by $10 million and take no profit from $409 million in work needed to fix future rockets, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

LEAD: The people of this single-belfry village, about a 90-minute drive from Paris, say that from time to time they saw Nathalie Menigon doing her shopping in town. But as the local butcher put it, nobody could have been expected to recognize her.

LEAD: Libya sought to acquire the ability to produce nuclear weapons in 1981 negotiations with Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, and other arms dealers, according to a report made public today.

LEAD: Japan's economy is likely to stay sluggish in coming months as the high value of the yen dampens business, according to Government figures issued today. The leading economic indicator for December was 50, up from 41.7 in November. Above 50 implies a pickup; below 50 implies a slowdown.

LEAD: Klaus Barbie, the Gestapo chief of Nazi-occupied Lyons, will go on trial May 11 on charges of crimes against humanity, court officials said today. Mr. Barbie, 73 years old, is accused of having deported hundreds of Jews and Resistance members to death camps.

LEAD: A San Juan lawyer has told investigators that he funneled more than $4,000 a month in bribes to the wife of Representative Robert Garcia on behalf of a South Bronx military contractor, according to officials familiar with the inquiry.
LEAD: A painting by the 19th-century French artist Jacques Louis David was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's for a record price for the artist. Both the seller and the buyer were anonymous.
LEAD: A firefighter hosing down flames yesterday at the Great Gee furniture warehouse in Bayonne, N.J.

LEAD: A man from Mercer County became sick and was briefly hospitalized Monday after drinking half-and-half tainted with cyanide, the State Health Department announced today. He had bought the cartonat a local supermarket.
LEAD: The Federal Government ran a $2.17 billion budget deficit in January, the smallest monthly deficit total since June, the Treasury Department said today.

LEAD: It's been understood for some time that college baseball's power has gone South: The last 20 N.C.A.A. championships have all been won by Sun Belt teams from Florida to California, compared with eight titles by Northern teams the previous 20 years.

LEAD: With unexpected alacrity, New York taxpayers prepaid state taxes for which they had not been billed, apparenty hoping to maximize Federal deductions before the new tax law takes effect. LEAD: Two men with handguns fired at a teacher today, hitting her with one shot, just after she had brought her 4-year-old daughter to nursery school, the police said. The authorities said they had no motive or witnesses. The teacher, Leonette Taylor-Coleman, 38 years old, of New Rochelle, was admitted to New Rochelle Hospital with a bullet wound to the buttocks and was in stable condition, said a spokesman for the hospital, Frank Hall.

LEAD: As chairman of the Budget Committee, Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, could be assured lots of big campaign contributions if he would seek them. LEAD: Democratic Presidential candidates, faced with a quandary over how to unify the party's urban white and black supporters, today took the course of party loyalty and endorsed Mr. Washington for re-election.

LEAD: EVEN by Stuart Sherman's own minimalist standards, his ''Evening of One-Act Plays'' at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art is miniature theater. Seven short plays, some as brief as blackouts, are sandwiched between two mini-movies. But those who have followed the peregrinations of this artist from his solo performances to his fragmented, environmental trilogy about Chekhov, Strindberg and Brecht should find that the current evening of short Sherman helps to fill in the blanks.

LEAD: Long before our species had an identity, let alone a telescope, there was a dark space in the Greater Magellanic Cloud as it might have been seen from Earth. On Tuesday, shortly before dawn, a light went on in that dark space and by chance, a Chilean observer with a telescope noticed it. What he saw, he realized after studying a routine photograph, was an event that had taken place about 163,000 years before.

Meanwhile, she eyes him as a mischievous older brother, someone she has to keep under control.

LEAD: WHEN Franz Kafka was readying ''The Metamorphosis'' for publication, he implored his editor not to allow pictures of Gregor Samsa's transformation into a cockroach. ''Not that, please not that!'' the author wrote. ''The insect cannot be depicted. It cannot even be shown from a distance.'' The publisher complied, illustrating ''The Metamorphosis'' instead with a door opening into darkness - an image at once more abstract and yet more terrifying.

LEAD: With Wall Street ignoring the troubles in the Reagan Administration and its own scandals, stock prices managed to gain slightly yesterday, although investors seemed distracted and trading volume was reduced.

LEAD: For writing an article in this week's issue of The Hockey News in which he criticized officiating in the National Hockey League, Bryan Trottier of the Islanders has been fined $1,000 by the league, the maximum allowed under N.H.L. bylaws. In the article, Trottier wrote, ''Some nights I think the refereeing in the N.H.L.

LEAD: The Challenge Grant Program of the National Endowment for the Arts has broadened its criteria for eligibility, the agency has announced. Arts groups may now apply for a challenge grant for projects in a variety of areas, not only for fund-raising campaigns to increase their endowment or to erase their debts, as in previous years.

LEAD: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament said today that he was pleased that the Tower Commission had confirmed his revelations on the arms-to-Iran deal, but he said the commission's report had not explained the Reagan Administration's mistakes.

LEAD: Sixteen soloists and companies from New York's dance and music communities are to perform in ''The Spinal Series'' at 8 P.M. on Wednesday at Town Hall and March 12 at Alice Tully Hall. The performances, produced by Manhattan Performing Ensemble in cooperation with the American Paralysis Association, will raise money for the association's Project Target, a research program, as well as the New York Regional Spinal Cord Injury System and Shake-a-Leg, a therapeutic summer rehabilitation program.

LEAD: Howard H. Baker Jr. said today that he was on the verge of deciding to run for the Presidency when President Reagan asked him to take charge of the beleaguered White House staff. Putting aside his own White House ambitions, he agreed to take the job.
LEAD: A City Council committee approved yesterday a measure that could place as many as 1,800 new medallion cabs on New York City's streets and that clears the way for a fare increase.
LEAD: Jess Larson, the first Administrator of the General Services Administration and former chairman and president of the Air Force Association, died Wednesday. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: The boys from the yeshiva come to Shmiel Shnitzer's store after a long day of delving into the sacred writings with the sort of keenness American boys devote to memorizing batting averages.
LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: Billy Martin, who said he was preparing to assume a broader role in the Yankee front office this season, arrived in camp today and indicated that his days as a manager might be over. He did not appear disturbed as he considered the possibility. ''I can handle it,'' he said. The former Yankee manager, who spent last season in a limited role in the television broadcast booth, said he would likely decide this season whether he would turn his attention to other projects and give up any thought of a return to the dugout.

LEAD: A French prosecutor, rejecting a plea for severity by a lawyer representing the United States, today asked the court trying a terrorism suspect to hand down a ''moderate'' sentence, saying France could be held hostage if it made him a ''martyr.''

LEAD: A former firefighter and a friend who is a snake dealer were charged yesterday with using three timber rattlesnakes in an attempt to kill a woman from Wallington last fall.
LEAD: The Chemlawn Corporation, which has received an unsolicited tender offer from Waste Management Inc., told shareholders today that they should hold onto their shares.

LEAD: Israel today described as ''totally groundless'' an assertion in a White House memorandum made public by the Tower Commission that Israel once offered military instructors to assist the Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: The ITT Corporation appears to have solved production problems that had plagued a new generation of jam-proof radios and as a result, contract payments for the equipment may soon resume, the Army said. New data from a series of tests conducted early this month on the so-called Sincgars equipment indicates the radios would meet the Army's standard for reliability, an Army statement said.

LEAD: A police undercover operation against crack dealers ended late today with one suspect dead, two police officers wounded in police crossfire, and four other officers injured when the suspect ran them down with his car, officials said.

LEAD: The United States accused some European countries and industrial concerns today of seeking to delay effective measures to protect the earth's ozone layer from destructive industrial chemicals, as a conference on the ozone threat ended without substantial movement toward an agreement.

LEAD: President Reagan moved dramatically today to revive his troubled Presidency by replacing Donald T. Regan with former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. as the White House chief of staff.

LEAD: An 18th-century violin worth more than $60,000, taken from a Manhattan musician in a holdup last week, was recovered yesterday after a Bronx pawnbroker called the police and turned it in. The violin had been pawned for $50. The pawnbroker, who asked the police not to release his name, ''knew it was a nice instrument when he first saw it,'' said Sgt.

LEAD: Residents of the Riverside Rest Home in Dover, N.H., lobbying Thursday in Concord. The group is backing a bill to increase the monthly spending allowance to $40 for Medicare residents of rest and nursing homes in the state. The current amount is $25 for those in rest homes and $30 for those in nursing homes, if they also receive Medicaid.

Heinz & Company, was responsible for directing the disbursal of more than $300 million in grants to Pittsburgh and Pennsylvania organizations.

LEAD: HE was so large and so strong and his feats were so outlandish that he wouldn't be nicknamed for anything so mundane as a mere world, or planet, or star. He was named for an entire constellation. He was the Big Dipper.

LEAD: An emphasis to buy everything new stirs gardeners to neglect the old-fashioned favorites. This is especially true with perennials. I like to think of a child's song that contains some good advice: ''Make new friends, but keep the old. One is silver and the other is gold.''
LEAD: IT is going to be a busy couple of weeks on the symphonic scene, and county residents can take pride in the remarkable depth and variety of the orchestral offerings.
LEAD: SOMETIMES the question is not so much what's in a name as it is what's in a place?

LEAD: FLYING solo or in collaboration with other New Vaudevillians like Michael Moschen (in ''Foolsfire'' and ''The Alchemedians''), Bob Berky has proven himself to be an inspired clown. As a performance artist, he evidently has a desire to expand his range into writing and directing. One result of this ambition is ''Traveling,'' an evening of sketches at the Actors Outlet Theater.
LEAD: Jose W. Diokno, a former Senator who headed the Government's peace negotiating panel until his illness forced him to step down, died of cancer Friday, one day after his 65th birthday.

Easton, Conn. $399,500 95 Deerfield Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 baths, 13-year-old colonial; landscaping, intercom system, circular drive, 3 acres, taxes $3,542.

LEAD: KAZUKO HILLYER says jokingly that when she was growing up in Kyoto, Japan, she was the black sheep of the family because she was always doing the unexpected. ''A Kyoto girl was supposed to be very traditional, and I'm the total opposite,'' she said.

LEAD: Athletes aren't supposed to be looking ahead, but it seemed that some were thinking ''world'' and not ''American'' in the unusual USA/ Mobil indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden Friday.

LEAD: The Feld Ballet will be presenting its first ballet by George Balanchine - the high-spirited ''Tarantella'' - during the company's two-week spring season, which begins Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. And there will be a new work by Carolyn Carlson, the former Alwin Nikolais dancer who currently directs her own dance company in Paris.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Several pounds of plaster molding dropped from a ceiling in Gov. William Donald Schaefer's office today, landing squarely on the chair where the Governor often works. Mr. Schaefer was in another office in the State House at the time. Mr. Schaefer's aides said the Governor could have been seriously injured if he had been at the desk.
LEAD: ONE of Long Island's most barren but conspicuous commercial properties could be transformed soon into a corporate landmark.

LEAD: Survival chic has replaced radical chic in fashionable Paris. No longer a fantasy of camouflage fabric and army surplus clothes, today's chic is a basic designer's suit that allows the wearer to be frisked with ease. When such searches were conducted at the spring ready-to-wear shows in October, they sometimes resembled a Luis Bunuel film or a French comedy.
LEAD: FOR $161 a month, Ralph J. Calise has an apartment at 448 Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan as big as a $2,400-a-month storefront four floors below.

LEAD: THE Soviet Union ended an 18-month unilateral freeze on nuclear testing last week, prompting disagreement over what the resumption of explosive tests bodes for the future of Soviet weaponry. The Pentagon said that it means little and that the Russians already had surged ahead in nuclear arms development despite the moratorium.
LEAD: An aging textile mill, once the scene of a bloody strike that historians say helped frustrate labor organizing in the South, is again the target of a union campaign.
LEAD: AFTER suing the Soviet Union for libel and winning, Raphael Gregorian, a businessman in Palo Alto, Calif., set out to try to collect the $450,000 awarded for damages.

LEAD: The marriage of Rosalind Alice Alpert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Alpert of Lewiston, N.Y., to Toby Salter Myerson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Myerson of Santa Barbara, Calif., took place last evening in Manhattan. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Pierre.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Bacardi rum on Feb. 15 misstated Edwin Nielsen's relationship to Lucia Schueg. Mr. Nielsen, chairman of Bacardi Imports, was Mrs. Schueg's son.

LEAD: REPORTS that the Administration and the Congressional leadership are prepared to abandon the $108 billion budget-deficit ceiling should be unwelcome news to anyone concerned with closing our trade deficit. Despite all the talk today of flagging American competitiveness, no measure - be it protectionism or fair trade, devaluation, foreign expansion or competitiveness - will eliminate the trade imbalance unless we manage to reduce our fiscal deficit by about $150 billion.
LEAD: MARCH is a month of literary events in the state, many of them taking place at Seton Hall University in South Orange.
LEAD: The Administration today welcomed the Soviet decison to seek a separate agreement on medium-range forces and expressed hope that the two sides could move quickly to conclude an arms accord.

LEAD: NOT every new piece of photography hardware can make waves by incorporating the latest technology in user-friendly form. LEAD: SPORTS fans know that corporate names have been popping up in peculiar places - we now have the Nabisco Masters in tennis, football's Sunkist Fiesta Bowl and the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic in golf. For all we know, XXII may be played next January as the Campbell's Souper Bowl. So why should we be shocked to learn that corporations have been horning in on baseball, inventing new awards and naming them after themselves?
LEAD: In a verdict predicted with bitterness by the supporters of Eleanor Bumpurs, the police officer who shot her was acquitted last week of all charges connected with her death.
LEAD: The Pirate Starring Judy Garland, Gene Kelly, Gladys Cooper, Walter Slezak. Produced by Arthur Freed. Directed by Vincente Minnelli. 1948. MGM/UA Home Video. 105 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: Because of erroneous information provided by the British Tourist Authority, the Travel Advisory column of Feb. 22 gave an incorrect telephone number for information on vacations offered by the Youth Hostel Association of Great Britain. The number is 212-581-4700.
LEAD: For many of Stacyville's 550 residents, the view of Mount Katahdin at daybreak is taken for granted but never ignored.

LEAD: GOVERNOR Cuomo took on a formidable task when he called recently for an end to letting New York's State Legislators dispense funds almost at will to institutions and groups in their home districts. These ''member items,'' which got their start during the Rockefeller era, have quadrupled in cost in the last four years to $168 million for 2,744 projects in the current fiscal year.

LEAD: Susan Hunter Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Brown Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Goodall Bailey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodall Bailey of Nashville. The Rev. T.Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

LEAD: North Carolina Democrats held a fund-raiser at a Capitol Hill landmark, the Eastern Market, featuring what one of them called ''the three chief staples of North Carolina life,'' barbecue, blue grass music and basketball.

LEAD: Larry Key helping to salvage possessions from the wreckage of his brother's trailer in Goodwill, La., after a tornado hit there and, above, a family in Glade, Miss., waiting for an ambulance after a tornado struck that community.

LEAD: THE classic 11-acre village green laid out in Guilford in the mid-1600's -crisscrossed with footpaths and surrounded by churches and old buildings housing art galleries, the Town Hall, banks and shops - makes for a blend of old New England charm and contemporary chic that has attracted 500 new residents a year over the last three decades to this historic community.
LEAD: Juan Griles scored a game-high 21 points tonight as C. W. Post rallied for a 66-63 victory over Queens to win its fifth consecutive Big Apple Conference championship at Conolly Gymnasium.

LEAD: Telephone service that was knocked out by a fire 11 days ago has been restored to 28,000 customers in the Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn, the New York Telephone Company said yesterday.
LEAD: CAN housing for lower-income people be saved by a law that forbids alterations or demolitions in the privately owned buildings they occupy?

LEAD: EVERY SO OFTEN, IT IS MEET and proper to once again examine a peculiar subgenre of the English language - and of the American language as well -that has flowered wildly in recent years, like some pulpy jungle plant. It's called winespeak.
